HEADLINE: Sports of the Times;
Newt Should Put Baseball on His List

BYLINE: By GEORGE VECSEY 

 BODY:
THANK goodness the hockey lockout is over. Now we can turn our full attention to something truly atrocious, the baseball strike. At least when the hockey owners took a hostage, it was their own commissioner. Gary Bettman was forced to fend off the union and a band of rogue owners at the same time.
At least the hockey owners had the ultimate sanity to preserve their heritage even if they did not achieve this panacea called the salary cap. As Neil Smith, the greatly relieved general manager of the Rangers, put it: "I kept seeing 'No Decision' on the Stanley Cup for 1995. We could have lost some franchises. Players could have formed their own leagues. It would never have been the same." 
 Everybody in hockey stopped just short of that disaster. I'm not sure the baseball owners and players love their game that much. They were willing to collaborate on a strike that killed the World Series for the first time since 1904. Wonder how the baseball owners feel now that the hockey owners decided they could live without this wonderful salary cap?
The baseball owners are holding their own hostage -- the antitrust laws of the United States of America. They've had that one stuffed in the trunk of their car for decades. This is a case for Newt Gingrich. While examining many other practices of government, the new Speaker of the House is hereby urged to reverse baseball's antitrust exemption, granted in a moment of sentimental folly by the Supreme Court all the way back in 1922.
Because they can operate like a single unit instead of competing companies, the baseball owners can threaten to bring in replacement players to spring training. John Harrington of the Boston Red Sox and other owners must be laughing at baseball fans, as if they cannot tell the difference between a major league player and a scab.
George Steinbrenner must be laughing at Yankee fans, too. Just the other day I saw an advertisement for something called The Fifth Annual Fan Festival, run by the New York Yankees Foundation Inc., to be held at a time and place I will not disclose out of disgust.
Fans are expected to pay $35 to see Babe Ruth memorabilia, get autographs from former Yankees and attend "daily instructional clinics by the manager," who happens to be heartsick over the prospect of managing abject nonentities the owner will drag out of unemployment lines. The advertisement says some proceeds will go to charity. Not good enough. Baseball should just hide in disgrace until it has real players again.
Instead, these shameless moochers have gone to Washington to chat up Congressional leaders. The baseball owners saw the hockey owners lose bargaining power because most of the seven Canadian teams play in provinces with enlightened laws against replacement workers. The baseball owners know how much they rely on their long exemption from antitrust laws.
From what I read, the Gingrichites are not thrilled about government subsidies, starting with the arts and public television and radio. I say they've got the wrong priorities. The night Aaron Copland died in 1990, we were able to follow musical tributes to him as we drove north through the swamps of Georgia and South Carolina because of the interlocking FM stations of National Public Radio. How civilized.
Also, I keep hearing the new Republican majority plans to cut subsidies for rail travel. It should probably be doing the opposite -- making it easier to travel major corridors like Boston-Washington, Milwaukee-Chicago, San Francisco-Los Angeles rather than forcing us into horror shows like O'Hare Airport or Interstate-95 around Washington at rush hour.
My personal philosophy is that the best governments have always supported arts and public services -- the works of Mozart and Goya and the delightfully functional rail stations of Europe are all a result of government subsidy.
If the Newtites really want to find predators willfully slurping from the government trough, they should take a look at baseball owners. These freeloaders exist on tax breaks and public stadiums and civic improvements, like the ones Steinbrenner is trying to squeeze out of New York. The most blatant scam is the antitrust exemption. Sometimes symbols are important. Take that away, and you might have real baseball next spring, not scab ball. Talk about a "contract with America."

GRAPHIC: Photo: The fate of baseball's antitrust exemption may be in the hands of Speaker Newt Gingrich and other Congressional leaders. (David Scull/The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Sports of The Times;
Settlement Didn't Put Players in Penalty Box

BYLINE: By HARVEY ARATON 

DATELINE: WEST ORANGE, N.J.

 BODY:
THE forecast was for snow, and Bob Carpenter cringed at the thought of being marooned. He didn't want to be late reporting to work for the National Hockey League team owned by John McMullen, who locked him out more than three months and was apparently ready, at one point last weekend, to close him down.
It was Tuesday up on Lake Winnipesaukee, N.H., where Carpenter lives, where he spent most of the lockout with his wife, Julie, and their 6-month old daughter, Alexandra. Carpenter did some fishing in the fall. He occasionally drove south to work out with some Boston Bruins. Mostly, he waited for the season to begin. 
 "I never really thought it wouldn't," he said. Why? He said, of the owners: "They'd have risked losing their league."
Carpenter was sitting inside the locker room at the Devils' practice site, a charming little venue called South Mountain Arena. In Manhattan, the league and the union were announcing player ratification of the new collective bargaining agreement. Carpenter was explaining how, upon hearing the forecast Tuesday afternoon, he packed up his family and headed south, to make sure he wouldn't miss the dropping of the first practice puck.
This would be his 14th season, and no matter how many times he repeats the experience, the start is always thrilling. This season, a 48-game sprint, would be no different, and no owner, not even the hawkish McMullen, could scratch that from the deal.
"I don't think you should ever feel like you are playing for him," Carpenter said. "The bottom line is that you are here to make a living playing the game you love."
Make a living. Interesting concept. From most of the settlement reports, you would think the players will now pay tuition, room and board to play in the N.H.L. You got the idea that Gary Bettman had taken a hatchet to Bob Goodenow, and union blood was everywhere.
Sports critics, you should understand, prefer decisive endings, heroes and goats clearly defined, with the future foreseen like five-day weather. No unrestricted free agency until 32! A disgrace, the critics roared, ignoring the fact that unrestricted free agency has been as prevalent in the N.H.L. as fight-free hockey.
Yes, there were serious concessions, like the rookie cap, but let's not kid ourselves. The overwhelming majority of hockey players are not exactly burning up the gossip columns. Sport of the Nineties? Not yet. Not until you, the average sports fan, can name one Ottawa Senator. One Winnipeg Jet. One Quebec Nordique. One Mighty Duck.
There's got to be some context here. Given the record of American unions over the last 15 years, the conservative political climate, baseball's current agenda, it could have been worse. There are a few newspaper unions it has been much worse for lately. Hockey has no salary cap, or payroll tax. There is nothing to prevent the Rangers, for one, from devising inflationary offers to discourage poorer teams from matching on restricted free agents. There is nothing to keep them from spending $9 million more than the Devils, as McMullen has charged, for one more goal.
The truth is, these collective bargaining deals are so complex, each piece interwoven, the full effect can't possibly be determined now. And if it was so one-sided, such a player blood bath, why would the majority of owners have needed their shirts pulled over their heads by Bettman before they agreed to it?
An economic expert from M.I.T. advised the union that it must avoid the cap, or tax, that it could live with the concessions it made. Who should the union believe, Carpenter wanted to know, professionals or sportswriters?
"Let's be honest, if any of us really understood all this, we'd have been business majors, not hockey players," he said.
He is 31 years old, a hockey eternity from the goal-scoring prodigy who burst into Washington back in 1981. He has never drunk from the Stanley Cup. He mourned the summer of 1990, when the favored Bruins lost in the finals to Edmonton. Carpenter made the Devils on a tryout last season, took a ride all the way to Game 7 of the Stanley Cup semifinals, where the Devils came up a goal short.
"The Rangers had the best players," Carpenter said. "I think we had the better team."
That team, he said, must now stay together. Every player, whatever his personal stake, must put the owner out of his mind, must unite behind Coach Jacques Lemaire.
"The years we lost in Boston, we knew that was it, that the team would change," he said. "Here, we've stayed the same. We're together a year under the system. We'll be better, good enough to win.
Carpenter began to undress, unlacing a pair of red Chuck Taylor Converse high tops.
"Cool sneakers," he was told.
He smiled. "Still prefer the skates," he said. "It's winter, time to play hockey."
Time to forget the forecasts that call for the players to be buried alive. Sometimes, even in New Hampshire, they predict a blizzard and get snow that doesn't even stick.

HEADLINE: PASSING THE BUCK;
Global Congress? Not in Congress.

BYLINE: By ELAINE SCIOLINO 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
CALL it a sign of the times.
Years ago, the Senate Foreign Relations Committee was the most prestigious panel on Capitol Hill; Presidents courted its chairmen and senators with presidential aspirations maneuvered for years, even decades, to get a seat. 
 But after last November's election, the rush was away from the committee; the Senate Majority Leader, Bob Dole himself, had to step in and twist the arms of four Republican freshmen to fill vacant seats.
The decline of the committee as a forum for airing deep thoughts and challenging White House policy began some years ago, but it has accelerated since the Republicans captured Congress in November.
For one thing, few senators from the Republican majority want to tangle (or even serve) with the new chairman, Senator Jesse Helms, the North Carolinian with an exceedingly conservative agenda of his own.
But a more fundamental reason is that foreign policy in the new Republican Congress is being shaped more by financial pressures at home and a scarcity of money for projects abroad than by lofty notions of statecraft and geopolitics.
Mitch McConnell, the new chairman of the powerful Senate subcommittee responsible for foreign aid, abandoned the Foreign Relations Committee for the Appropriations Committee two years ago. "The difference between us and them is we're shooting with real bullets," he explained. "We spend the real money."
More to the point, they decide what projects not to fund.
The Kentucky senator has already introduced a sweeping foreign aid bill that would slash foreign aid by 20 percent and abolish three cold war creations -- the agencies that administer foreign aid, monitor arms control developments and disseminate information about the United States to the rest of the globe.
In other words, the real action in Congress these days is not in crafting a larger global vision to rival that of the White House. So many of the Republicans who are taking the legislative reins seem to be saying: Why bother?
This approach dovetails with a traditional Republican view: that members of Congress should not challenge the President's constitutional power to make foreign policy. But with this President, it goes further: They seem to feel they don't have to.
As the maiden witness before the newly named House International Relations Committee last week, James A. Baker 3d, President Bush's Secretary of State, advised his audience to resist the temptation "to give as good as we got" when the Republicans controlled the White House and the Democrats controlled the Congress. Instead, he laid out a sweeping strategy for avoiding policy debates while exerting control over the bureaucracy:
 
Back the President
 "The United States of America has an obligation to lead internationally, and we can only lead internationally, effectively, if we understand that the President has the primary responsibility for the conduct of the nation's foreign policy. Attempts at Congressional micromanagement of foreign policy were a bad idea when the Democrats were in control, and they remain a bad idea today." Republicans, he said, should work with the Democratic Administration, overhaul the foreign policy bureaucracy and use their own legislative authority better. What he did not need to say is that such a strategy would leave the Presidency's authority over foreign policy intact should a Republican -- perhaps even Mr. Baker himself -- win the White House in 1996.
Another reason for the Republican lack of interest in policy debates these days is the painful memory of George Bush's misguided strategy in the 1992 campaign: his foreign policy successes simply did not resonate the way Bill Clinton's focus on the domestic economy did. Finally, argues Jeremy Rossner, the author of a forthcoming study of Congress and foreign policy, "the Republicans as a party have done no better than the Democrats at making order out of the confusion of the post-Cold War era."
Take the House Republicans' "Contract with America." Although it offers a thorough housecleaning of the budget and welfare, foreign policy gets only a light dusting -- commitments to protect American soldiers from being put under United Nations command and to rebuild America's defense establishment.
That makes it easier for individual Republicans to take their own positions on issues if they want.
The foreign policy agenda announced by the Senate Majority leader, Bob Dole, on the Senate floor two weeks ago amounted to two unrelated items of particular interest to him: giving the President more authority to make war but limiting his ability to deploy peacekeepers, and lifting the international arms embargo on Bosnia.
And, without a party line, Republicans have the freedom to change their minds. Senator Frank Murkowski of Alaska, for example, criticized the nuclear accord with North Korea as giving away too much to an untrustworthy Communist regime -- until he took a trip there and came back arguing that it may not be such a bad deal for the United States after all.
"It's the flip side of where we were in 1980, when almost every major Republican leader was in lockstep with the Democrats and agreed with what Jimmy Carter was doing," said Michael Beschloss, a historian who has written on the Presidency. "But in 1995 you have a lot of people engaged in individual issues for almost quirky reasons, and no overall pattern that united them into a consistent critique of the Clinton foreign policy."
 
Cold War Redux
 That doesn't mean that there is no glue to hold much of the Republican Congress together on foreign policy. If you put the small snapshots together, an uneven landscape does emerge, with remarkable similarity to the kind of thinking that dominated the cold war. Republicans seem to want to maintain or increase defense spending, boost American leadership and emphasize traditional security interests.
That vision can be found in the House Republicans' resolution, released last week, which advocates inviting the Czech Republic, Poland, Hungary and Slovakia into NATO within five years as one way to revitalize national security. It can also be found in the "Contract with America's" proposals for defense spending, which would revive Ronald Reagan's vision of a Star Wars missile defense.
What isn't found are calls to spend more -- or even the same amount -- on what is sometimes called the global agenda: peacekeeping, population control, international environmental programs and refugee relief. If the experience of the last several years is any guide, financing such efforts might do as much to counter the real long-range threats to American security as would high-tech defense spending designed to shield America from Russia's waning military might -- or to fight two wars at the same time.

CORRECTION-DATE: January 16, 1995, Monday

 CORRECTION:
An article in the Week in Review yesterday about foreign policy and the Republicans in Congress omitted several words in a statement by the historian Michael Beschloss, altering its meaning. Mr. Beschloss said that in 1980, almost every major Republican leader agreed with "the critique of what Jimmy Carter was doing." He did not say that the Republicans agreed with President Carter's foreign policy.

HEADLINE: What's Up -- and What's Going Up

BYLINE: By TRACIE ROZHON 

 BODY:
A YEAR ago, Costas Kondylis, one of the city's most employed, most pragmatic apartment tower architects, had 13 people working for him.
Today, he has 31.
A year ago, Edward Malloy, president of the Building and Construction Trades Council of Greater New York, was "sitting around with my feet up on the desk looking out the window -- there was nothing going on." Nowadays, he said, he spends his time "a lot more optimistically; I talk a lot on the phone and I go to a lot more meetings with developers." 
 "It's really happening, isn't it?" said Musa Train Klebnikov, project development director for the Battery Park City Authority, which last month commissioned four developers to begin planning buildings for four vacant sites in the huge downtown Manhattan complex. "New York's really coming back."
In the razzmatazz ego-speak of the development community, a sudden burst of optimism doesn't always translate into steel and substance. But there are a number of residential projects that are just being completed -- and a spate of new ones back on the drawing boards of architects like Mr. Kondylis and Peter Claman, another of the city's prolific designers -- that lend credence to Ms. Klebnikov's observation.
Two weeks ago tenants began moving into the 19-story south building of the Brodsky Organization's two-building rental complex on the west side of West End Avenue between 61st and 64th Streets; shortly after, the last piece of chimney flue was set into place on top of the two 38-story towers of the north building.
Once called Manhattan West, but now newly named West End Towers, the 1,000-unit rental complex, 200 apartments of which will be reserved for tenants with limited incomes, is the first of two major Brodsky projects scheduled for completion in the next two years. The other is a 45-story retail and rental development between 58th and 59th Streets on the west side of Ninth Avenue, on a site formerly owned by St. Luke's-Roosevelt Hospital.
A little more than a week ago, another Upper West Side development team, Millennium Partners, celebrated the "topping off" -- bringing the concrete and steel to the roof -- of their second new building in the Lincoln Square area. Philip E. Aarons, one of the partners, said the 30-story building, bounded by Broadway and Columbus Avenue and 66th and 67th Streets, would open its sales office in April and be finished by the summer.
Called Lincoln Triangle, the second Millennium apartment building is to contain 143 unsubsidized, market-rate rental units; the first project, Lincoln Square, one block north, is still receiving its finishing touches. The 46-story Lincoln Square building, which includes a Sony Theaters multiplex, is almost fully occupied and is waiting for several retail tenants to move in. Mr. Aarons said that at least 60 of the building's 83 condominiums had been sold and that all of the 110 rental units had been spoken for.
Demolition on a third Millennium site nearby, at 1965 Broadway, is scheduled to start within the next 45 days. All five of the Upper West Side buildings have been designed by Mr. Claman's firm, Schuman Lichtenstein Claman Efron.
On the Upper East Side, at 92d Street and York Avenue, the Brittany, another new rental tower, still has construction elevators running up and down two sides of its glassy facades, with bare concrete still on the base, awaiting its limestone veneer. Designed by Mr. Kondylis, the 36-story building is expected to get its first tenants this spring.
All over Manhattan, modifications to previously approved permits and environmental-impact statements are being filed. Community groups are being sounded out. Money is being lined up -- typically not from the traditional source, the big banks, but from pension funds and other lenders. Applications for tax abatements available for partially subsidized rental buildings like West End Towers have been filed and developers are waiting to hear.
Developers spend much of their time waiting to hear -- from city and state agencies, lenders and community groups -- and major developments sometimes change dramatically, or vanish entirely. As Mr. Aarons of Millennium puts it: "There's a lot of pitfalls in any development: you can run into site problems, political problems, community problems, financing problems. Any one of them can slow down or stop a project -- and they're not always predictable."
Still, plans for already assembled sites that have been sitting fallow for years are being dusted off, either because the owners have decided that the economic situation is ripe or because new developers have bought or leased or somehow gained control of a site for a fraction of the previous asking price.
Brad Zackson, 34, chairman of the Dynamic Group, a new face among Manhattan developers, bought one property on Astor Place in Manhattan at a bankruptcy auction for $ 6.3 million. He bought another in Brooklyn for less than 10 percent of the once-outstanding bank loans, said Carolyn Schlam, an associate of Mr. Zackson.
Mr. Zackson's Brooklyn site, Kings Bay Landing, near Bensonhurst, a few miles south of the Verrazano-Narrows Bridge, had been taken over by the Chase Manhattan Bank in 1989, Ms. Schlam said.
At that time, she said, more than $ 20 million in loans were outstanding on the waterfront condominium development, for which 60 apartments had been readied in two new buildings. "The brochures were ready to go out," Ms. Schlam said, "but the original developer hit the bad market."
By the time Dynamic became interested, the bank was asking $ 4 million, Ms. Schlam said. "We purchased it this year for under $ 2 million," she said, adding that Dynamic wanted to fix up and upgrade the buildings already built, complete the pool and boat slips and start marketing this spring. Once those units are sold, the developer plans to build a third apartment building, 40 new town houses and a health club.
The saga of the Brooklyn site is typical of the kind of aggressive negotiating now going on. But it is unusual because of its location -- Brooklyn -- and its condominium configuration. Most of the new residential development is in rental apartments, and it is happening primarily in Manhattan, where the rents are considered high enough to justify the high cost of building.
To many real-estate professionals, a high demand for rental units is the force behind the resurgence of construction planning. Steven Spinola, president of the Real Estate Board of New York, said there was now only a 1 percent rental vacancy rate in Manhattan for regulated and unregulated apartments.
But it is not only the demand. Other factors include the existence of already assembled parcels and the availability of government-guaranteed construction bonds, as well as a handsome 20-year city property-tax abatement available to developers willing to devote 20 percent of their total project to subsidized tenants, in what the trade calls "80-20" housing. These, linked with what until recently were among the lowest interest rates in years, added up to the "go" signal for developers who have the resources and the credit to come back into the market.
In addition, many developers and investors said they were more optimistic about the fates of their projects as they move through the city bureaucracy because of Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani's perceived "pro-development" stance.
While recently rising interest rates are obviously a dispiriting factor, some developers and those following the development scene say higher rates will halt the trend only if they keep going up. "It's my guess that unless interest rates go sky high, the building -- especially of rental units -- will continue," said Paul D. Selver, one of the best-known zoning lawyers within the development community.
Jules Demchick, a partner in J. D. Carlisle Development Company, said: "The interest rates aren't as much of a problem as people think. You can pay down the interest rate; you can get a lower interest rate by putting in more of your own money. There are ways to get around it."
Some developers might be able to do that, and others won't. The sins of the late 1980's, when prominent developers were forced to give properties back to the banks, and the banks were stung into their recent lending paralysis, are tough to live down. "For some people, the banks want 50 percent down," said Daniel Brodsky, "and that makes it very, very difficult." As a consequence, most developers say, there is almost no development money coming from the banks.
But there is money from other sources. Donald Trump, who formed a joint venture with the General Electric Pension Trust and the Galbreath Company for a $ 250 million renovation of the former Gulf & Western Building on Columbus Circle, said last week that he had the choice of using G.E.'s huge credit subsidiary for financing or going to another "private institution." He said the joint venture would decide in the next two weeks how to finance what will become Trump International Tower and Hotel.
Mr. Zackson said he had the backing of "mainland China and Asian investors" to do his total rehabilitation of the distinctive brick trapezoidal former United Auto Workers headquarters at 21 Astor Place, between Broadway and Lafayette Street, the property he purchased at a bankruptcy auction last January. And Mr. Trump's affiliation with several well-respected Hong Kong investment groups for his huge Riverside South project has been well-publicized.
On the Upper East Side, Ian Bruce Eichner, a developer known for some of the most publicized development difficulties in the 80's -- his Cityspire building on West 56th Street and what is now the Bertelsmann Building at 1540 Broadway were involved in bankruptcy procedings -- said he had the backing of Union Labor Life Insurance Company for his condominium apartment building at 80th Street and Third Avenue.
Mr. Eichner also said he had another asset for a developer these days: a committed retail tenant, preferably one of the chain superstores. A glossy sign has been wrapped around the construction fence in front of Mr. Eichner's building, a former storage warehouse, announcing the imminent arrival of a Toys "R" Us.
But while Mr. Eichner expressed total optimism about the project -- he said the site had been purchased and the toy store had paid more than 50 percent of the cost of the site for its three-floor condo section -- other observers are less sanguine. There have been reports that the relationship between Toys "R" Us and the developer has soured, and that the financial backers are nervous -- reports both Mr. Eichner and Toys "R" Us deny.
Michael Freitag, a spokesman for the chain, said that there had been "minor difficulties with the neighborhood" but that he expected the store to open this fall, as scheduled.
Mr. Freitag was referring to a community group, calling itself "Neighbors 'R' Us," that has filed a complaint against the toy store with the city's Board of Standards and Appeals. The complaint argues that a grandfather clause allowing further commercial use of the ground floors of the former storage warehouse has elapsed, making such use illegal.
In addition, to build the tower "as of right" -- that is, without any special permits or variances -- Mr. Eichner's architect, Mr. Claman, must devise a plan to "core" the building: turn the inside 16 stories into 22 stories. It is a feat the architect himself called "very, very difficult.".
For these reasons, Mr. Eichner's project, despite its superstore partner, its financial backers and its location, is generally classified by real-estate professionals as a "wild card" in today's development picture; it may happen as planned and it may not.
These are the projects generally considered by other developers and those involved in development circles to be "go" projects, either because work has already begun or is expected to begin in 1995:
Trump International Hotel and Tower: When the tenants' leases expire at the end of April, a high-tech $ 250 million revamping of the whole building will start, with the notoriously swaying structure to be made more rigid by the addition of new columns and trusses and a gold-colored curtain wall applied on the outside.
Philip Johnson, the architect for the exterior conversion, said Mr. Trump "won on the gold color, but it's really not a garish gold; it's much warmer than black." The project is to have 167 hotel suites and 166 condominium apartments.
1965 Broadway, between 66th and 67th Streets: Mr. Aarons said that demolition of the old five-story building on this third Millennium Partners site, which is just across Broadway from Lincoln Triangle and is the current home of the Tower Records and Tower Video stores, would begin in 30 to 45 days. Construction of a new 27-story building will begin in three months, he said. There are to be 325 units in an as-yet-undecided combination of rentals, condominiums and "approximately 100 one-bedroom suites for long-term-stay/hotel occupancy," Mr. Aarons said. A new, larger, Tower Record and Video store is to occupy the street-level retail space, he said; during construction, Tower is moving to Broadway and 73d Street, in the Ansonia Hotel.
300 East 64th Street, at the southeast corner of Second Avenue: A 26-story, 100-unit rental building is to be built by Davis & Partners, along with a New York subsidiary of Rosen Development of Frankfurt, Germany. In order to build a taller building than zoning would have allowed, the partners bought air rights from the neighboring movie theater.
306 East 72d Street: Eighty-two large condominium units are planned in a 21-story building, to be built by the Jack Parker Organization, reportedly with conventional financing. Demolition has been completed and the excavation has started.
South side of Union Square, between 13th and 14th Streets and Broadway and Fourth Avenue: Within the last month, Stephen M. Ross of the Related Companies signed a contract to purchase the last holdout on the site, where he wants to build 300,000 square feet of retail space with 250 rental apartments above. Mr. Ross said he would start construction on the 22-story building by "midsummer" after obtaining regular bank financing. He is reportedly trying to interest retail tenants like Caldor, Sports Authority and Virgin Records.
21 Astor Place: Mr. Zackson's auction purchase is a prominent 1908 trapezoidal brick building that is to become 71 loft condominiums, priced from $ 300,000 to $ 1 million. Interior demolition has already begun. Downstairs, Mr. Zackson's Dynamic Realty has already signed leases with the Starbucks Coffee and Kinko's Copy chains. Ms. Schlam said the leases totaled $ 700,000 a year, "and that takes a lot of the risk out."
100 Jane Street: A nine-story low-rise, with 148 rental units, 20 percent of them for subsidized low- and middle-income tenants, is to be developed by Rockrose, a continuation of that developer's rebuilding of what was once a no-man's land between the West Village and the meat-market district. While Rockrose waits for the final phase of approvals from the Federal Department of Housing and Urban Development necessary to begin the Jane Street project, the developer has opened its renting office at its rehabilitated Plaza East, at 340 East 34th Street.
K. Thomas Elghanayan, president of Rockrose, said that in the case of the rehabilitation of Plaza East's 201 apartments, with rents ranging from $ 1,100 to $ 2,000 a month, the company put up $ 5 million of its own money and persuaded New York University, which owned the property, to assume $ 12.5 million of debt at 7 percent interest.
Northwest corner of Elizabeth and Houston Streets: A vacant site is to be developed into 195 units of rental housing by Donald Zucker. Mr. Zucker will get a 20-year 421A tax abatement without including any low- or moderate-income housing because this location in NoHo is just outside the 80-20 mandate's boundaries. Mr. Zucker said he had his foundation permit, approved plans and a mortgage commitment for the 12-story building.
There are also several projects that are expected to start in 1996, although an earlier starting date is possible in some cases.
The Battery Park City Authority is developing its own Site 22, just south of Stuyvesant High School at the corner of Chambers and West Streets. The project will include 200 market-rate units of family-oriented housing -- two- and three-bedroom apartments -- in a massive 22-story building to be designed by Mr. Kondylis that will also contain a K-8 school. Matthew Monahan, an authority spokesman, said this project was "at least eight or nine months" ahead of three other housing developments in the north end of the complex, which have been awarded to Rockrose, Related and the Gotham Organization (with E. T. Marshall).
Those other developments are expected to be under construction within two years and bring 1,000 more units of 80-20 rentals to the city.
The Brodsky Organization and a development partner, Robert Quinlan, have bought air rights over the landmark St. Jean Baptiste Roman Catholic Church on 76th Street between Lexington and Third Avenues. The convent has already been taken down and the existing rectory has been renovated to include the convent. Designed by Hugh Hardy, of Hardy Holzman Pfeiffer Associates, with Mr. Claman, the new 31-story condominium tower has already received Landmarks Preservation Commission approval and was presented to the local community board last week.
The east side of Amsterdam Avenue between 89th and 90th Street, known as the last urban renewal site in the city and now a community garden, was formally awarded more than a decade ago to the Related Companies, which plans to build 263 units of 80-20 rental housing. Last week Mr. Ross said he had not "nailed down" the site by coming up with the necessary financing, but expected to have the money ready in time to begin the 18-story building this spring.
There are also several projects with less predictable prospects. If legal or bureaucratic hurdles can be cleared on these sites, it is generally thought money could be obtained and work could proceed this year or next.
A Related Companies site at the southeast corner of 84th Street and First Avenue is at the center of a lawsuit filed by the East 84th Street Neighborhood Association and Civitas, a civic advocacy group.
The suit, which has halted the project, was lodged against the city's Board of Standards and Appeals for its decision to grant Mr. Ross's group a hardship variance to build a taller building than allowed by zoning regulations passed last year. The variance was granted because Related said the foundation was finished before the deadline after which the new architectural requirements went into effect -- a contention the community groups dispute.
The case is currently before the New York State Court of Appeals, and a decision is expected within three months. Mr. Ross contends he should be allowed to build 43 stories; if he loses the suit, he would only be able to build 30 "as of right."
The east side of the Avenue of the Americas, between 22d and 23d Streets, holds a parking lot that until two years ago had a weathered sign announcing the arrival of the New York Health and Racquet Club. Plans had long been dormant, but the site is once again active. Michelle de Milly, spokeswoman for the Manocherian family, which owns the lot and founded the health club, said that plans had been newly drawn and revised several times by Mr. Kondylis.
She said the proposal -- which shows a fat, prewar-looking 22-story building with rounded corners and a dome -- was scheduled to go before a public hearing at the city's Landmarks Commission "in February or March." The plan, she said, calls for 300 to 350 units, "probably rental.". Providing further details would be premature, she said, because community groups and commissions would be reviewing the project.
A zoning-map change for the site, allowing residential use, would be needed.
A long-vacant site between 41st and 42d Streets and 11th and 12th Avenues may finally be developed as 1,800 rental units in two high-rise buildings. Last week, Larry A. Silverstein, the developer, said he expected to "get a shovel in the ground" by the end of this year. Others involved in the project said the City Planning Commission was in the process of reviewing it.
The project labeled by a participant as "the biggest imponderable of them all" is the 5,700-unit Riverside South development along the Hudson River between 59th and 72d Streets. Philip Johnson is working on the exterior and Mr. Kondylis the interiors of the first four buildings, which are planned to resemble nothing so much as Central Park West pre-war apartment buildings.
"This is what the local people want and what they're getting," Mr. Johnson said. "They didn't want transparent buildings; they didn't want glass monsters." Mr. Trump, the original developer, sold 50 percent of the project to the New World Development Company and a large consortium in Hong Kong, which reportedly is to invest $ 2.5 billion. Mr. Trump said the first four buildings -- the tallest 40 stories -- with 1,600 rental units in the 80-20 program, would start to rise "within 10 months" from 65th to 69th Streets. Others in the industry, viewing the immensity of the project and the bureaucratic and financial hurdles remaining, are less certain.
Then there are the sites that no one will talk about; sites that are not yet nailed down, in development parlance, but are once again the focus of negotiations. At least two development teams are known to be competing for the site of the old Alexander's department store across from Bloomingdale's bounded by 58th and 59th Streets and Lexington and Third Avenues. Two more feel they have the inside track on a plot between 38th and 39th Street near the Queens-Midtown Tunnel.
Then there is the old Evyan perfume factory on the west side of First Avenue between 34th and 35th Streets. And there are valuable sites along Second Avenue in the 60's, several owned by local hospitals.
Even the developers occasionally have trouble keeping track of every deal, of every negotiation, of every boast. Steve Ross contends that real estate in New York City "is a very local game" that isn't easily picked up by neophytes and investors from other countries. Despite all the foreign investment in the past decade, Mr. Ross maintains that "almost all the foreigners who invested in new development here have been burned."
"They saw it as a glamour investment," he said, "and now they're very sorry." He said the foreign money now is headed for "Australia and different parts of the world, where it's a lot easier."
Peter Claman, who has been an architect in New York City since the 1950's, describes the development scene as a "poker game."
"But that's O.K.," he said, "because I've been playing it a very long time."

CORRECTION-DATE: January 22, 1995, Sunday

 CORRECTION:
Because of an editing error, an article last Sunday about new residential construction in New York included an outdated description of the method being used to strengthen the former Gulf and Western Building. In renovating it for use as a condominium and hotel, builders plan to erect a concrete wall rising through the center of the building to the 33d floor. An earlier plan, to reinforce the building with a series of columns and trusses, has been abandoned.

The New York Times

PUB-DATE: January 15, 1995

SECTION: Section 6; Page 22; Column 1; Magazine Desk 

LENGTH: 3069 words

HEADLINE: Governor Get-a-Job;
Tommy Thompson

BYLINE: By NORMAN ATKINS; Norman Atkins writes for Family Life and other magazines.

 BODY:
TWO YEARS AND YOU'RE OUT. THE words stand poised at the top of Gov. Tommy Thompson's trachea and march forth like a battle cry in his war on welfare. As career criminals are supposed to cower under the threat of "Three strikes and you're out!" so "recidivist" welfare mothers are meant to hear Thompson's slogan and shake a leg. The phrase is the core of the Republican Governor's "Work Not Welfare" experiment, which as of Jan. 1 put a 24-month limit on cash benefits through Aid to Families With Dependent Children.
Nobody has a clue to how many families will beat the clock or what will happen if they don't, but Wisconsinites appear downright ecstatic about Thompson's two-county test run, small scale though it is. Three-quarters of those polled support it, and last November a whopping 67 percent of the voters swept him into a third term. His eight-year war on welfare has given the G.O.P. a viable organizing principle in the post-Communist world; now Newt Gingrich and his counterrevolutionary forces have finally caught up with Tommy Thompson. "Tommy's a real hoss," says Haley Barbour, chairman of the Republican National Committee. "He's the leader of the country and the Republican pathfinder on welfare reform." 
 Thompson used to complain about going "to Washington on bended knee to kiss somebody's pinkie ring" to get dispensation for his unorthodox welfare experiments. Now with the G.O.P. in control of Congress, he exults in arriving there with "live ammunition, shootin' at real targets." Republican Congressmen seek his input and blessing on their proposals. But in their frenzy to see who can cut benefits faster, Thompson sounds downright moderate in comparison. He cautions that welfare reform will create no savings in the short run; they shudder when he argues that reform may cost even more up front, to pay for services like day care and job training. With his new status and his forum as the next chairman of the National Governors' Association, he's busy promoting no-strings-attached block grants to the states. His share would presumably go toward expansion of "two years and you're out" statewide.
Welcome to the wacky world of Wisconsin politics. At the start of the 20th century, Robert La Follette built the Progressive movement, trying to bust rapacious capitalist monopolies. Mid-century, Joe McCarthy created a witch hunt to root out secret Communists. Now, at the end of the century, Thompson has upended the state's political culture by targeting welfare moms. State Democrats played into his hands in late 1993 by calling for the termination of the welfare program in Wisconsin by 1999. Many believe it was a political stunt designed to embarrass the Governor by forcing him to veto the end of welfare. But Thompson says he looked at that bill on his desk as a "gift, the greatest opportunity in the world." He signed away. "It's time to cut the umbilical cord."
THOMPSON IS AN UNPOLISHED ORATOR, THE LETTER G asleep at the end of his gerunds. He doesn't deliver speeches so much as conduct pep rallies, grabbing credit for all good news occurring during his tenure: welfare rolls dropped 19 percent in Wisconsin while climbing 32 percent nationally; the state has seen a net increase of 382,000 jobs, and the University of Wisconsin won the Rose Bowl last year, as he guaranteed. His foes believe that Thompson has benefited from a streak of Forrest Gump-like luck: Wisconsin was recovering from a wrenching recession before his election; rapid job growth is largely responsible for the welfare decline, and Barry Alvarez is a mighty fine football coach. But in his next four years, the Governor promises more jobs, fewer welfare recipients and a Super Bowl victory for the Green Bay Packers.
Tommy G. Thompson, incorrigible optimist, was born in 1941 in Elroy, a poky midpoint for trains roaring from Chicago to the Twin Cities. His mother's kin migrated here during Ireland's potato famine to avail themselves of one of the most generous public-assistance programs in United States history, the Homestead Act of 1862, which gave settlers 160 acres of land for a song. Thompson still owns a piece of the property, though he seems eager to sell. ("Wanna buy a farm?" he asks.) His mother's father, a La Follette socialist, organized a farmers' union. Although Thompson was raised a Catholic under his mother's wing and insists that his grandfather's compassion for the downtrodden courses through his veins, his values were largely inculcated by his father, an exacting taskmaster of English and German stock. When, at the tender age of 4, Tommy asked for a tricycle, his father introduced him to a concept that would become the quiddity of his welfare philosophy: no more something for nothing. The elder Thompson, a grocer, handed Tommy a piece of sandpaper and set him to work at 25 cents an hour scraping chicken droppings off the eggs that poor farmers had swapped for food. "I had to pay for everything myself," Thompson recalls. "But he always gave me the opportunity to work for what I needed."
In the 60's, earning undergraduate and law degrees at the University of Wisconsin in Madison, Thompson rebelled against campus liberalism and soaked up Barry Goldwater's "Conscience of a Conservative." He started out shy, but "I pushed myself to be outgoing like my father because I realized that bein' bashful was a deficit." He emerged as a gregarious bartender and hearty partier. His conversion to extroversion culminated, recalls his former roommate, Richard Wright, in approaching total strangers with an extended right hand. "I'm Tommy Thompson," he'd say, "and I appreciate your vote and support." Says Wright: "It was a joke, a way to meet people. Tommy wasn't really running for anything."
Thompson's mitts are like a bear's, and they wrap around whole arms and necks and backs. (When I first met the Governor, he pressed his palms into my shoulders and practically lifted me, Herman Munster-like, into the air.) In 1966, Tommy put his hand-shaking to good use. He bought a '59 celery green Ford for $100, drove down every dirt road in his legislative district, glad-handed in 80 percent of the homes and got himself elected to the Assembly, where he would stay for two decades.
Thompson missed most every vote in his first session, doing National Guard duty down in Texas. In 1968, he married Sue Ann Mashak, a teacher who had come to Madison to lobby for higher salaries. They have three children. Still a teacher, she is on medical leave for breast-cancer surgery. They continue to argue over the teachers' union. Thompson's deep antipathy for it was forged in his early Assembly days, when he fell in with a cadre of tightwads whose mission was to prevent the growth of government on the taxpayers' dime. At a time when Madison was a seedbed of radicalism, recalls Thompson, "We had a thumb-in-the-dike philosophy." The dike burst in September 1969, when hundreds of welfare mothers marched to the capital behind a radical Catholic priest named James Groppi to press for more aid. They stormed the Assembly chamber, raised the red flags and ejected Thompson and the other legislators from their seats. Years later, Governor Thompson would lead the charge to shoo the mothers out of theirs.
ON A BRIGHT MORNING IN SPRING Green, where Frank Lloyd Wright built Taliesen, Thompson jauntily scissors a ribbon on the visitor's center, another of the architect's landmark buildings. The Governor came up with a financing plan for its restoration after decades of neglect when his more liberal predecessors ignored pleas for help. In a speech to a crowd that includes Wright's acolytes, Thompson confesses that Frank Lloyd never really turned him on. (Later, as we're leaving, he notes that Wright was "socialistic" and "didn't pay his bills.") So how did a pro-business Governor whose artistic taste tends toward Schwarzenegger flicks become the savior of a notoriously left-wing architect's work? Thompson says he had an epiphany about Wright's worth during a trade mission to Japan. He was having the darnedest time getting the Japanese psyched about Wisconsin. Finally he mentioned that Wright was a native son and his audience applauded wildly. "Then," says Thompson, "I knew I had something I could sell." The liberal chairman of the preservation committee whispers to the Governor, "It's like Nixon going to China." Tommy gets a kick out of the line and minutes later tells a local TV reporter, "I'm like Nixon going to China!"
In 1986, during his first gubernatorial campaign, liberals likened Thompson to the shadier side of Tricky Dick. "They tried to paint him as this Nixonian character, darkly complected and untrustworthy," John MacIver, his campaign chairman, recalls. For Thompson's propensity as minority leader to scream about virtually every bill the Democrats proposed, they tagged him "Dr. No." Despite the mockery, Dr. No won by blaming the Democratic incumbent, Anthony Earl, for the recession and for turning Wisconsin into a welfare magnet. "In one of the debates, Tony Earl used a classic line: 'Tommy Thompson wants to reform welfare and make Wisconsin like Mississippi,' " recalls Thompson. "I came back immediately: 'With you in charge, we're attractin' all the people from Mississippi up here anyway.' "
Once elected, Thompson slashed welfare benefits 6 percent; they've been frozen ever since. Even so, he's forever lamenting a migration of welfare families. "Twenty-eight percent of the newest people on welfare in Milwaukee County -- their last known address is Chicago. We're still 45 percent higher than Illinois -- for an $8 bus ticket, you can get $200 more coming to Wisconsin." Last July, he stood on the border to warn would-be welfare migrants that they will continue to receive the A.F.D.C. level of their native state for six months after arriving here.
Wisconsinites "are just fed up to their eyeteeth with people comin' in from other states, not working," Thompson says. "People in Wisconsin expect people to work -- maybe it's the old Germanic heritage, the old European heritage." More than half the state claims German ancestry. The majority leader of the Assembly, Scott Jensen, who ran Thompson's campaign in 1990, recalls polling undecided voters, mostly Reagan Democrats in Milwaukee's Germanic, blue-collar neighborhoods: "The thing that went off the Richter scale" -- in Thompson's favor -- was welfare reform."
Ed Garvey, a Madison-based attorney and labor consultant and a failed Democratic senatorial candidate, believes that the Governor's rhetoric and welfare reforms appeal to the electorate's basest instincts: "When it comes to welfare, Tommy has been a very successful demagogue, playing on racial fear and tension." State Senator Gwendolynne Moore, a Democrat who represents a poor district in Milwaukee, says: "Tommy Thompson has done a very good job of creating a class war here between working poor and A.F.D.C. recipients."
But over the years Thompson has gained favor with virtually every segment of the population: in 1986, he won 10 percent of the African-American vote; in 1990, 20 percent; and in 1994, by his count, more than 40 percent of that vote. John Gard, the Republicans' welfare expert in the State Assembly, argues that Thompson broke through the liberals' rhetorical wall in 1987 with "Learnfare," which docked welfare benefits of parents whose children were truants. Though evaluations show no clear evidence of success or cost-effectiveness, Thompson has hailed Learnfare as a triumph and expanded the program statewide. "Learnfare was such a no-brainer in most people's eyes," says Gard. "How can you be against forcing kids to go to school? Tommy used the phrase 'tough love' and it sold. Two years after the Governor first took office, a lot of Democrats who fought it lost. So others became fearful of standing in the way of more welfare initiatives."
The initiatives kept coming in the form of small experiments, none of which have yet to yield conclusive results. Children First tells noncustodial fathers: support your kid or go to jail. Bridefare, begun last July, encourages teen-age parents to marry by offering a hike in benefits. Now Thompson is trying to sell a Family Cap, to end additional payments for each child a woman bears. "Does The Milwaukee Journal give you extra money when you have extra children?" he asks a reporter. "I don't know anybody that does."
"TWO YEARS AND YOU'RE out!" Thompson's biggest little experiment yet, began two weeks ago in Fond du Lac and Pierce Counties. Edward Schilling, Fond du Lac's director of social services, says the word is going out: "From the moment you receive your first welfare check, the clock is ticking." Move to another county and "the clock goes with you." Each time I press the Governor on how many welfare moms won't find a job before time runs out, he says, "I expect to hit 1,000 percent."
Is he fantasizing? Perhaps not entirely. The two counties selected are almost exclusively white, have very low unemployment rates and a combined A.F.D.C. caseload of roughly 900, many of whom are not risks for long-term dependency. What's more, the Governor has jacked up portions of the welfare budgets to pay for more counseling, job training, child care and transportation. New applicants enter the program immediately; others will be phased in by June 30.
And Thompson is already pressuring his pals in private industry to hire welfare recipients so nobody hits the cliff. Welfare mothers will have to start working off their A.F.D.C. benefits in approved job-readiness activities immediately, but the program converts their food stamps into cash and guarantees them child care. "You know the result that is wanted," says the Assembly speaker, David Prosser Jr. "They will move heaven and earth to get those people jobs."
But even Thompson's closest allies don't really expect everyone to beat the clock. John Gard, the state representative who sponsored Work-Not-Welfare in the Assembly, conservatively estimates that three-quarters will be working after two years. The secretary of administration, James Klauser, Thompson's brilliant alter ego, says simply, "You will have some klinkers."
Thompson himself finally admits it. "Maybe you're right, maybe we won't place all of them," he says. "If, in fact, we can't, there has to be some way to subsidize employers for that person to work in the private sector."
How long will the subsidy last?
"We'll have to see," he says.
You'll improvise as you go?
"Yes."
And if recipients don't show up for work?
"They don't get paid."
What happens to their kids?
"The kids will continue to get their welfare and food stamps."
How can a 4-year-old cash welfare checks and go grocery shopping?
"We may have to set up guardians for them."
So the parents will lose their kids?
"Not necessarily," he says. "You can allow the guardian to pay for the food and shelter, but the end result could be that if the parent still refuses to take care of the child, we'll look after the child. The children will be taken care of. There won't be any children starving on the streets."
Successful or not in these small counties, Democrats contend, the experiment covers only 1 percent of the state's welfare population. None are in Milwaukee, where nearly half the A.F.D.C. recipients live, where jobs are scarce and public transportation weak. When Democrats blew up Wisconsin's welfare system with their 1993 legislative gambit, they had control of the State Assembly and hoped for guaranteed community service jobs as the new safety net. Now that Republicans have won back the Assembly, it looks as if some version of "Two years and you're out!" will go statewide by 1997.
The outcome of Tommy Thompson's welfare reforms will not be clear for some time, but Michael Wiseman, associate director of the La Follette Institute at the University of Wisconsin, says he's making huge political hay in the meantime. "The Governor's genius is in dramatically building a large number of welfare reforms and postponing the consequences. If you look closely, you discover that many so-called reforms either haven't been implemented, are very small or the evaluations are postponed for a very long period of time."
Wisconsin's constitution assigns the Governor broad veto power, but in Thompson's hands it has become a kind of veto Veg-o-matic -- slicing and dicing paragraphs, words and numbers to find new and sometimes contrary meanings for what the Legislature intended. In his first term, Thompson even employed what the local media dubbed "the Vanna White veto," striking individual letters to form entirely new words, until a constitutional amendment reined him in a bit. Still, in eight years, Thompson has executed nearly 1,500 vetoes to slash about $800 million in proposed spending.
The Governor talks about the veto as a sign of manliness envied by his friend George Bush. "He loved the fact that I had the power to use it," says Thompson. "I tried to convince Boyden Gray to issue an opinion that President Bush could use the line-item veto." But the White House counsel raised obvious Constitutional objections. Objections don't bother Tommy: "If I was president, I would use the line-item veto right now. I would make the court stop me from using it."
Does Tommy Thompson mean to be the man with the ultimate veto? He recently told me he soon would "look" at making a Presidential bid, while plugged-in the G.O.P. strategist Vin Weber says he understands the Governor is already running. "But it's going to be tough for him to get into the top ranks, tough to raise the money," says Weber. "I know that's not what he wants to hear, but he's got strong potential to be a Vice-Presidential nominee."
Meanwhile, Thompson sounds positively eager to compete with his fellow Governors in what he conceives as a kind of N.F.L. playoffs of welfare systems. "Other states may want to try orphanages -- let 'em try it," he says. "Then let us see what is doin' the best. That's the beauty of settin' up all these little laboratories of democracy across the country, and we can stand back and compete. Washington should be sort of the referee and say: 'Here are 50 states. You have 50 different solutions to moving people off of welfare. Now go to it, and in five years we're going to come back and see which ones make the Super Bowl.' "

GRAPHIC: Photo: Thompson was swept back into the Governor's chair with a whopping 67 percent of the vote. (PHOTOGRAPH BY RICH SAAL FOR THE NEW YORK TIMES)

SECTION: Section 2; Page 31; Column 3; Arts & Leisure Desk 

LENGTH: 1388 words

HEADLINE: ART VIEW;
Bric-a-Brac Art: The Obsessions Of a Collagist

BYLINE: By Pepe Karmel 

DATELINE: PARIS

 BODY:
KURT SCHWITTERS HAS always inspired fanatical devotion in his admirers, but the retrospective of his work now at the Pompidou Center in Paris takes this devotion to new extremes. Organized by Serge Lemoine, head curator of the Musee de Grenoble and a professor at the Sorbonne, it includes well over 300 works of art by Schwitters (paintings, collages, assemblages, sculptures and drawings), as well as 150 typographic works (poems, postcards, magazines, bureaucratic forms).
The obsessive quality of the exhibition seems perfectly appropriate to its subject. Schwitters (1887-1948), best known for his collages mixing snippets of typography with colored geometric shapes, was an obsessive kind of artist. His lifelong friend and collaborator, the German Dadaist Raoul Hausmann, recalled encountering Schwitters in a train station, kneeling on the floor with a bag full of paper strips that looked like entrails of a butchered animal. Schwitters was working with scissors and glue on a scrap of cardboard. "Kurt, what are you doing?" Hausmann asked. Schwitters answered that he had suddenly realized that he needed to add a piece of blue paper to the corner of a collage and so had set to work there and then. 
 Schwitters's collage technique represented a conscious decision to make art from what other people thought of as garbage: "old tram tickets, scraps of wood, coat checks, iron bars or pieces of wheels, buttons, old bric-a-brac from attics." He called his work Merz, a nonsense word he explained alternatively as coming from an advertisement for a Kommerz-bank (commercial bank) or from the verb ausmerzen, meaning "to discard." Schwitters's embrace of the trivial, the discarded and the disdained made him the patron saint of numerous later artists: Americans like Robert Rauschenberg, Jasper Johns and Allan Kaprow (inventor of the "happening"), and Europeans like Jacques Villegle, Mimmo Rotella and Daniel Spoerri, who made pictures from torn movie posters or household objects.
After his death in 1948, Schwitters's reputation remained strong in the United States. He appealed to the Walt Whitman strain in American culture: the democratic desire to believe that no aspect of life is so humble that it can't become material for art. In Europe, however, Schwitters went into something of an eclipse. He was particularly neglected in France: the Pompidou exhibition, which runs though Feb. 20, marks his first retrospective in a French museum.
Schwitters's parents ran a successful women's clothing shop in the provincial city of Hanover. He studied art at the Dresden Royal Academy, demonstrating an unexceptional talent for conventional painting. In June 1918 his canvases were exhibited at the gallery Der Sturm, nerve center of the German Expressionist movement. Soon after, he moved to Berlin, hoping to become part of the new, more radical avant-garde movement Dada. Abandoning realism, he turned to abstraction and collage.
Schwitters's first collages were exhibited in June 1919, with paradoxical results: he received good reviews and began to sell to important collectors, but he was rejected by the German Dadaists he yearned to join; they were fervent Communists and found Schwitters hopelessly bourgeois. Schwitters didn't disagree: he once described himself to a friend as "a bourgeois and an idiot." But the rejection stung. Although befriended by some members of the Dada group (including Raoul Hausmann, Hannah Hoch, Max Ernst and Tristan Tzara), he moved back to Hanover and declared himself the inventor of a new artistic movement: Merz. In 1923, he began publishing an art magazine under this title.
By this time Schwitters was arguably better known as a poet than as an artist. His surrealist love poem "Anna Blume" was a kind of pop hit, translated into a half-dozen languages, and his first collection of poetry sold a remarkable 13,000 copies. Schwitters and his friends toured Germany, Czechoslovakia and Holland with a series of Dada theatrical performances that proved surprisingly popular. His "Ursonate" ("Sonata of Primal Sounds") won over even conservative audiences. (It plays continuously in one room of the Pompidou exhibition and is available on CD.)
SCHWITTERS'S ATTRACTION TO trash and nonsense came from Dada, but the formal organization of his work reflected the examples first of Cubism and later of Russian Constructivism and the Dutch movement De Stijl. By the end of the decade, Schwitters had expanded the term Merz to include art, poetry and performance. "At present," he said, "I call myself Merz." Bit by bit, he transformed his studio into a larger-than-life collage, the Merzbau (Merz-structure), which is often seen as anticipating the art-world "environments" and "happenings" of the 1960's. To supplement his inherited income, he opened a typographic studio in Hanover, designing clean, modern posters and advertisements for department stores, industrial associations and the municipal government.
The idyll came to an end with Hitler's rise to power in the 1930's. Schwitters's books were burned by the Nazis in 1934; his collages were held up for scorn in the "Degenerate Art" exhibition of 1937. He went into exile in Norway, fleeing to England in 1940. He survived by painting realistic portraits and landscapes. The Hanover Merzbau was destroyed in the war, and his plans to reconstruct it were cut short by his death in 1948.
The Pompidou show stakes out a claim for the importance of Schwitters's sculptures, drawings, poems, typographical work and realistic paintings, as well as his abstract collages and paintings.
This would certainly have pleased Schwitters, who stated in 1925 that "everything an artist spits out is art." But the inclusion of a large number of Schwitters's undistinguished realistic paintings is problematic. His Merz work is also uneven. A good deal of it looks like generic modernism. His surrealist "i-drawings" are mediocre essays in the manners of Marc Chagall, Max Ernst and Paul Klee. His abstract reliefs echo those of Ivan Puni. His freestanding sculptures of the 1930's and 40's seem to be modeled, alternately, on the rectangular "arkhitektons" of Kasimir Malevich and the early, Surrealist sculptures of Alberto Giacometti.
The Pompidou show ends up confirming that Schwitters's greatest talent was for collage. Schwitters himself saw the harmonious combination of diverse materials in his collages as a symbol of alienation overcome, a demonstration of how modern man could be saved from "the tragic chaos of life." In the mammoth (398-page) catalogue, several essayists suggest that Schwitters remained far more of an Expressionist than is usually acknowledged. The violence of his early work is still evident in his collages, where the geometrical forms and colors infuse the mute fragments of printed material with a remarkable degree of emotional power.
Letters and numbers, detached from their contexts, reveal the beauty of their arches and columns, while suggesting an open-ended universe of potential meaning. The very banality of the printed matter in Schwitters's collages imbues it with a kind of magic. Tickets and schedules evoke the familiar routines of everyday life. Chocolate wrappers, cigarette packets and ads for coffee recall quotidian pleasures that had become unaffordable in the inflationary chaos of postwar Germany.
In a work like the 1939 collage "Prikken Paa I en," done in Norway, the seemingly haphazard selection of printed matter transforms the significance of the abstract composition. The stacked rectangles that the Russian Constructivists had used to symbolize the bright future of the socialist revolution here serve to anchor the debris of a world sliding into war.
Pages torn from a calendar evoke the slow passage of time spent in exile. The semi-italic "i" near the center of the composition quotes the entire text of Schwitters's 1922 "i-Poem," which he explained as follows: "You go up, you go down, you go up, and a little point on top." Below, a fragment from a typed letter recalls the artist's lost home at Waldhausenstrasse 5, in Hanover. Schwitters's best collages, like this one, seem to sum up not just the history of modern art but the larger history of the 20th century, with its terrifying mixture of euphoria and despair.

GRAPHIC: Photo: "Point Over the I" from 1939 -- beauty that originates in banality. (Ph. Migeat/Musee d'art Moderne, Centre Georges Pompidou)

HEADLINE: Surrounded by Zealots

BYLINE: By Fouad Ajami; Fouad Ajami is the Majid Khadduri Professor of Middle Eastern Studies at the School of Advanced International Studies of Johns Hopkins University. Among his books is "The Arab Predicament."

 BODY:

ALLAH O AKBAR
A Journey Through Militant Islam.
By Abbas.
Illustrated. 319 pp. San Francisco:
Phaidon Press/Chronicle Books. $60. 
WHEN the daguerreotype went to the Middle East in the mid-19th century, it brought with it a sense of hubris. The first photographers -- the French who came in search of the romance of the East, the British who were entranced by biblical landscape -- claimed for their medium a measure of infallible truthfulness, and promised that it would dispense with the subjectivity of the lithograph and render the East as it really was. All that was, of course, innocence. The photograph, too, as Kiku Adatto put it in her recent book, "Picture Perfect," was both art and artifice, a work of interpretation and of commentary and selection.
Now Abbas, an Iranian-born photojournalist who lives in Paris and works with the Magnum agency, has given us in photos and text his own interpretation of the world of Islam. His book, "Allah O Akbar: A Journey Through Militant Islam," culled from photographs taken during travels through 29 countries, is the product of a long journey that begins in Iran, in the throes of revolution in 1978-79, and closes with the ordeal of Sarajevo. This was no ordinary era in the life of Muslim civilization. It was a time of great agitation and of breakdown, and Abbas's photos, a few exceptions aside, capture a world in turmoil and on edge. "Allah O Akbar" is not a joyous book. It could not be. A man with a camera, a man who himself is part of his own story, threatened by it and by the excess he is drawn to, has returned with what he has seen and heard in the vast expanses of Islam.
The men are armed, the women are veiled, the children are joyless, and everywhere the faith is a weapon, an alibi or a ruler's prop: this in the main is the world that Abbas's photos and text render. Had Abbas not written a single word, had he not told us in his text, and in the subtitle of his book, of his intent, we would still see his will at work, imposing itself on the material, leveling that vast and varied Islamic world -- all the way from Timbuktu to Sarajevo, from Kabul to the Muslims of France, from Pakistan to New York's Seventh Avenue, where a group of Muslim Shiites enact an old ritual of their faith -- into an undifferentiated mass of "militant" believers. Though the Iranian revolution has been unable to remake the Muslim world in its own image, Abbas is convinced that the hurricane is coming. He has traveled widely but always deeply into that fear. In its turn, the fear simplified and disfigured so much of what he saw along the way. Abbas cannot explain, for one, why the suffering city of Sarajevo belongs in a book on militant Islam. Its proper place, I would think, is in an inquiry into militant Slavism and the pitiless nationalisms of the post-Communist world.
For me, the defect of Abbas's vision and his willful determination to have us see only what he wants us to see were given away in his exploration of Malaysia. In that Conradian setting of river and forest, where Islam spread through commerce and made its peace with older ideas and civilizations, in a place of potentially great wonder for a Muslim from the Arab and Iranian heartland of Islam, Abbas finds his true believers: scattered villages and communes where the Bumiputras (the indigenous Malays, the "sons of the earth") have set up miniature Islamic republics, far away from the temptations of the city, from the modern economy dominated by the Malaysian Chinese. "My most powerful images," Abbas writes, "the ones that I will use in my book," will come from these villages. "I know that, even before looking at the contact sheets. But is it fair to show only these somber images of a many-faceted Malaysia? Will my journey through Islam, which is undergoing a resurgence everywhere, for better or for worse, be a record only of its excesses?"
When Abbas took to the road, shortly after Khomeini's revolution had triumphed in Iran, he knew, he recalls, that he needed a new "photographic language" that would go beyond the action in the streets and capture the inner workings of the places he would explore. "I had to move from the essay to the novel," he writes. But novels are about ambiguity, surprise and the meanderings of fate, and these are missing from Abbas's journey. Everywhere he went in the umma (the Islamic community), Abbas found re-enactments of what he left behind in Khomeini's Iran. His themes repeat themselves, and the geographical and cultural space he traverses grows familiar and constricting. The scenes of ritual slaughter and sacrifice of animals are repeated; so are funerals and visits to morgues, and photos of amputees. Few take time out from the rigors of the faith in Abbas's world. Even those occasions where joy and frivolity and the routine of life could have corrected for the excess -- a Cairo fashion show; a Kabul bride staring into the camera next to a photo of the groom, who is away in Germany; a belly dancer in France entertaining a group of Renault factory workers in celebration of the end of Ramadan, the month of fasting -- do not lift the gloom. Those, too, are not photos of people at peace. The gloom in the world and the photographer's gloom -- the circle is closed.
The rihla, the voyage, was once a great and beloved genre in the literature of Islam: the believer roaming "God's lands," making the pilgrimage to Mecca, bringing home tales of differing peoples and climes. Abbas has that genre on his mind. A friend of his, he tells us, gave him a chronicle of the famous 14th-century North African traveler Ibn Battuta (the Marco Polo of Islam, he has been called), who left his Moroccan birthplace, at the age of 21, on travels that took him, over the course of 30 years, eastward to India and China, northward to Central Asia and deep into Africa. But Abbas drew no comfort from Ibn Battuta; he found him a flatterer of the grandees whose hospitality he always sought, and a bigot interested only in the lives of Muslims, dismissive of all "infidels." Fair enough. Perhaps Ibn Battuta had a better run than he deserved; many of his contemporaries saw through his boastings and limitations.
Yet, for all the failings of that medieval traveler, his sense of wonder and awe at what he had seen always intruded and kept readers returning to his tales. This is where Abbas shortchanged himself and his craft and his subject and his audience. Had he been ready to look and inquire, had he been willing to be surprised, the traveler's luck might have saved him, given him a new view of things, added to his knowledge of the world and stilled his anxieties.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Muslim children learning the Koran by rote at a Koranic school in Egypt. (ABBAS/MAGNUM/FROM "ALLAH O AKBAR")

HEADLINE: Mystery Of an Old Carousel

BYLINE: By ELLEN MITCHELL 

 BODY:
OLD habits die hard. Perhaps that explains why Northrop Grumman has cloaked its carousel in a mantle of mystery befitting a military secret. The carousel nestles in a wood shelter in a grove of trees at Calverton, where Grumman once tested aircraft.
Now that the plant is being decommissioned and the Navy has announced its intention to give the site to the Riverhead Community Development Agency, the fate of the carousel is in question. 
 The Town of Riverhead and the Village of Greenport have expressed interest. A spokesman for Northrop Grumman, Richard C. Dunne, said an amusement park in New Jersey and the Veterans of Foreign Wars had also asked about the carousel.
Since 1955 the carousel had been a feature at the annual picnics for Grumman employees and their families. The picnic grounds also boast a midget-horse ride and two miniature railroads. No one would say whether a tiny roller coaster with a caterpillarlike top remains at the site.
Memorabilia about the rides has been packed in Grumman archives, until the company, can "evaluate what will be deemed excess at the Calverton facility," a vice president, Marvin Elkin, said. Eventually the archives are to be moved to the Smithsonian Institution, said Edward J. Smits, the Nassau County Historian. In a written response to inquiries from Greenport residents, Mr. Elkin said Northrop Grumman wanted to establish the worth of the equipment in preparation for a sale or a donation.
"It's not certain to me what we will do with it," Mr. Dunne said. "It may not even stay on Long Island."
He said the carousel was probably worth "something in the six-figure range. It's a beautiful looking thing. It's in decent shape and it has a calliope. The only thing it doesn't have is a brass ring."
Mayor David Kapell of Greenport said he noticed the carousel several years ago, boarded up in its pavilion, while driving past Calverton on Route 25. Having grown up in New York City as a devotee of the Merry-Go-Round in Central Park, Mr. Kapell could not erase the specter of the Grumman carousel. When he learned that the site was to be decommissioned, Mr. Kapell convinced the Greenport Village Board that a carousel would be the perfect centerpiece to revitalize the business district.
Mr. Kapell, who also sells antiques, said he had not been permitted to inspect the carousel, adding: "I understand it is a vintage carousel with hand-carved horses. That's very unusual. It's a great treasure and it should stay on Long Island. Typically such a carousel would be sold off for the horses. They'd go to an antiques auction and that would be a shame."
Mr. Kapell's effort is bolstered by the Greenport Merchants Committee, which says the carousel would encourage tourism and help reverse the decline that it says has affected Greenport since World War II.
The idea is also being applauded by third and fourth graders in Greenport, 59 of whom sent letters to Northrop Grumman. One said:
"Dear Grumman, how are you today? May Greenport have this carousel? We need it! Please. There is nothing in this town for kids and it would be nice. I'd love a carousel. If you let us have it that would be nice. Please! From the desk of Mark DeLano."
"Dear Grumman," another student wrote, "we're asking you nicely so could we please, please, please have that carousel. Because you don't need it. Katria Nieves."
"Dear Mr. Grumman," a third letter said, "if we get your carousel we will put it in a big building and clean it every time it gets dirty. Your Friend, Adam Nitsch."
The heaviest competition is from Riverhead, which will take over the site when Northrop Grumman disposes of its assets, including the carousel. A commission has been established to advise Riverhead on the best economic use for the property. That panel has taken no position on the carousel, according to its chairman Bob Goodale.
"Perhaps the picnic grounds and the things that work well on that site should remain," Mr. Goodale said. "But Northrop Grumman will decide what to do with its property and how to dispose of it. In the case of the carousel, perhaps there would be an auction. Northrop Grumman would, of course, like to get as much money as possible."
The carousel was installed in 1955. A retiree, Stephen Haizlip, who used to inspect it for safety problems, recalled a manufacturer's nameplate dating from the 1930's. Mr. Haizlip said the carousel was brought out in the summer for the last Grumman picnic.
"I took my 8-year-old grandson for a ride on it," Mr. Haizlip recounted. "It worked like a charm."
"Oh, it was wonderful," recalled Sharon Grosser, a Grumman employee for 27 years. As the child of Grumman parents, she first rode the carousel and all the other rides at the age of 4. "It was like Disneyland, but it was free," Ms. Grosser said. "You could go back on again and again. And it was so pretty. You were awestruck."
