HEADLINE: Plainfield's Gambling, a First, in Need of New Blood

BYLINE: By ROBERT A. HAMILTON 

 BODY:
ONCE, the 4,000-car parking lot at Plainfield Greyhound Park was filled nearly to overflowing every time Ike, the mechanical rabbit the dogs chase around the track, began his run.
But today, even on a good day, there are acres of parking space available for the matinees, and within an easy walk to the door at night. 
 By any measure, business is seriously diminished at the track. Racing started in 1976, bettors plunked down almost $125 million that year; then the betting settled down to about $100 million a year for the next 14 years. This year the track expects its "handle" to be in the range of $40 million. Attendance last year was 421,685, down from 933,557 a decade ago.
Rachel Allard, a clerk at the Plainfield Yankee Motor Inn, a 49-unit hotel adjoining the greyhound track, said "Five or six years ago, about 75 percent of the people coming in here were going to the track. Now, maybe it's 50 percent on weekends, and we don't have any during the week."
A poor economy in the late 1980's might have started the track's decline, but competition from the Foxwoods casino in Ledyard has hastened it considerably, said Dennis Buden, spokesman for the track.
And another Indian casino expected to open next year in Montville, coupled with a $111 million greyhound park going up in Bridgeport, could be the death knell for what was Connecticut's first parimutuel operation. Mr. Buden said the racetrack will seek legislation to add slot machines and gaming tables to its gambling lineup. With many new legislators and a new governor, he has more hope than before November, he said. The track's employees, and many townspeople, have become politically active to support the change.
Mr. Buden said in the almost 20 years since the Plainfield track opened, the nature of gaming has changed, with demand rising for the simpler forms of gambling.
"While we're proud of the history of our sport, you have to spend quite a bit of time learning about racing, handicapping and so forth, before it makes sense," Mr. Buden said. "People want to come, drop the quarter in the slot, find out right away whether they've won or lost, and then move on."
Unlike the case in Ledyard, where neighboring towns have done everything they can to fight the traffic and other problems from the casino, the greyhound track enjoys tremendous local support.
Mr. Buden said the track employs 350 people, primarily from the Danielson area, which traditionally has some of the highest unemployment and lowest wages in the state. The track has provided steady jobs, with some people there since its opening.
"Families have been brought up on the track," Mr. Buden said. "Moms who clerked here in the 1970's, their daughters are here today. The legislature has to make a determination that this industry is worth preserving, that these jobs are worth saving."
People locally worry that the once-bustling 120,000-square-foot racing track and 10 kennel buildings on 82 acres just off Interstate 395 could be vacant before long if there is not some legislative relief.
"We welcomed the track when it came in because it brought so many jobs with it," said Debra E. Pepin, president of the Plainfield Chamber of Commerce and one of the owners of DV Television and Appliance, a family-owned business in Plainfield since 1949.
At the time the track came in, the mills that were the lifeblood of the town were closing down, and people had no money to spend anywhere. Afterward, the hotels and restaurants boomed, and with the track created jobs that boosted the economy, she said.
And despite its own misfortunes, the track continues to be civic-minded, helping out with food baskets for the needy at the holidays and other charitable causes.
"They're one of the biggest supporters of our high school in terms of scholarship money, and when any organization needs help they're always right there," Ms. Pepin said.
The track is also the town's biggest taxpayer, said Plainfield First Selectman Paul E. Sweet, a Democrat serving his third term. Each spring he leads a delegation to Hartford to plead for legislative backing to keep the track in business. In the last 10 years alone, the track has paid more than $100 million in state and local taxes.
Mr. Sweet said he did a survey recently in which he sent out questionnaires to the 2,000 families that live closest to the track, asking if they would approve of slot machines at the track. Of the 1,800 returned, more than 1,500 were in favor. "They take good care of their place, they take good care of their employees, and there's no fear that it would go bad just because they get slot machines," Mr. Sweet said. "The principal attitude is, 'If they can do it down in Ledyard, we should be able to do it here.' We're not looking for slot machines in every hotel or motel around. But just in the track -- no one objects."
He said in the last few years, Plainfield Greyhound Park has been prevented from bringing in slot machines because of an agreement Gov. Lowell P. Weicker Jr. signed with the Mashantucket Pequot tribe giving them exclusive rights to run slot machines at their Foxwoods Resort & Casino in Ledyard.
"You have to question the constitutionality of this arrangement, because it's giving one business a monopoly," Mr. Sweet said. "For the state to put somebody out of business while propping up somebody else is just wrong. There's going to be a big lobbying effort. This is the year we're either going to survive -- or not."
Peter C. Smith, executive director of the Connecticut Pari-Mutuel Association, headquartered in Hamden, said wagering at the state's parimutuel operations has dropped $180 million since Foxwoods opened. Attendance at the tracks dropped 9 percent in 1992, the year Foxwoods opened, and 16.2 percent in 1993.
Mr. Smith said all the parimutuels will seek permission to put in slots or table games this year to boost their business. Several other states have already allowed it, he said, and in California, at least one racetrack saw its racing handle increased after it put in table games.
Mr. Smith agreed that the fast pace of gaming is driving the change. People can place 6 to 12 bets at a slot machine each minute, compared with 6 to 12 races the whole evening at a track.
"Tracks really don't want to run away from their base," Mr. Smith said. "But they need that other segment of business to complement their live product."
Mr. Buden said the legislature has been generous to the track so far. The tax rate on greyhound racing betting had dropped twice in the last two years, from 7.25 percent on evert dollar bet to a sliding scale that begins at 2 percent on the first $50 million each year. In 1991 the track was allowed to put in Simulcasting screens to show and take bets on races at other tracks.
Even with those improvements, "At best, we are marginally profitable," Mr. Buden said. Half the building is closed off during the week to cut costs for cleaning and staff. But the track also has put in a new dining operation this year, and improved its Simulcast equipment. "We're not just sitting on our hands, waiting for a gift from Hartford," Mr. Buden said. "We're doing everything we can. The question is, is it going to be enough?"
Slot machines, which typically account for 60 to 70 percent of casino revenues, are generating $450 million a year at Foxwoods.
The new Montville casino will make the drain from dog racing worse, Mr. Buden said. As far as the Bridgeport complex, said there are two schools of thought: that it will draw away business from the western end of the state; or form a "critical mass" of greyhound racing that might draw more people to the state.
"That was kind of our hope when Foxwoods came on line too, that the interest the casino would generate in gaming would translate to more business at the track," Mr. Buden said. "But it never materialized in any significant way. We obviously won't know until Bridgeport is up and running."
Mr. Buden said without slot machines, there's a real danger Plainfield could close.
"Every time I think we've bottomed out, it turns out that we haven't -- I thought we hit bottom in 1991," Mr. Buden said. "Everything the legislature has done for us so far has been a stopgap measure. Now we're talking about survival."

HEADLINE: Peace Talks Resume in Mexico Even as Disputes in South Deepen

BYLINE: By TIM GOLDEN, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: SAN CRISTOBAL DE LAS CASAS, Mexico, Jan. 15

 BODY:
Peasant rebel leaders met today with representatives of President Ernesto Zedillo Ponce de Leon for the first formal negotiations in almost a year to end the uprising in the southern state of Chiapas.
There was a dramatic air to the encounter, held at a rebel strongholdin the Lacandon rain forest and announced in this outlying city only as it got under way. But hopes for peace were tempered by conflicts over politics and land that have deepened even as the threat of new fighting has waned. 
 Although the demands of the rebels range from economic support for poor farmers to the replacement of Mr. Zedillo's administration by a transitional Government, they said in a statement before the talks began that they would focus only on "measures to defuse the hostile climate and distance the danger of armed clashes between the two armies."
The chief mediator in the dialogue, Bishop Samuel Ruiz Garcia, said tonight that the two sides had held more than three hours of "frank, sincere" and "intense" discussions near the rebel capital of Guadalupe Tepeyac. He said the Government's three representatives were led by the Interior Minister, Esteban Moctezuma, while the Zapatista National Liberation Army delegation was headed by the rebel leader known as Subcommander Marcos.
Bishop Ruiz declined to provide details beyond that, suggesting that the talks were still preliminary and saying the negotiators would report publicly on them on Monday.
The meeting comes five months after elections that defrauded hopes for an easing of tensions in the state, giving way instead to further polarization. While Zapatistas have backed away recently from their threats to break a cease-fire that has held for the last year, the prospects for a lasting peace have appeared to grow steadily more remote.
The paradox of Chiapas remains that, while support for the insurgents has waned elsewhere in Mexico, the tensions fed by their rebellion have spread steadily out from the rebels' strongholds in the Lacandon rain forest.
The principal legacy of the election in August may in fact be that the forces on either side of the political divide are now more organized and militant than ever. Peasant groups and the Democratic Revolutionary Party are on the left, with big landholders and the governing Institutional Revolutionary Party on the right.
Peasants who have seized tens of thousands of acres of land are digging in on their new holdings and vowing not to give up. In response, the conservative ranchers who have always held sway in the region are setting up new alliances, stockpiling arms, running off some invaders and threatening others.
The state government that took office last month hoping to find a middle ground in the struggle has increasingly sided with the property owners, further alienating the peasants. A recent pledge by the Government to address the land problem in Chiapas by parceling out some larger holdings has seemed to have had almost no impact.
Groups loyal to Amado Avendano, the rumpled former newspaper publisher who ran as the left's gubernatorial candidate in August, have seized or tried to seize dozens of town halls around the state.
The situation has become so complicated that many political analysts say a settlement will be more difficult to fashion now than after the Zapatistas launched their war on Jan. 1, 1994.
"People are much more polarized now, and on both sides," a Government official said. "If it was tough before, it is going to be harder now."
The economic crisis set off by the sharp devaluation of the peso last month has done little to diminish the urgency.
The Government's forced reduction in its dependence on short-term foreign capital should ultimately reduce the economy's vulnerability to political shocks like those produced by the Zapatistas. But Chiapas remains a focus of Mexican and foreign investors, who have come to doubt Mr. Zedillo's leadership. After months in which officials confidently dismissed the possibility that the conflict might spread beyond the state, the country's sudden impoverishment has also prompted at least some of them to think again.
Shortly after the uprising began, peasants within the Zapatistas' area of influence seized thousands of acres of private land. But last summer the occupations began spreading to areas where the rebels have never been.
Since August, for example, the ski masks made famous by the insurgents have become a fixture at a sprawling coffee farm called Liquidambar, worn there by members of a radical peasant group that takes its name not from the Mexican revolutionary Emiliano Zapata, but from his northern counterpart, Francisco (Pancho) Villa.
Peasants from a semi-communal farm nearby suggested that they had simply taken advantage of the breakdown of order to take lands that they had long claimed as their own. "We have always thought that this land would be ours," one of the leaders of the group, Tomas Perez, said through his mask as he sat on the estate's veranda. "But we gave thanks on that 1st of January."
But it was the Villa group rather than the nearby farmers that organized the occupation, bringing in scores of families from outside to work the farm as a collective.
Leaders of the occupation claimed they had documents attesting to their rightful ownership of the land, but they did not produce any. Nor did they see any possible solution to their situation in the recent pledge by Mr. Zedillo's Government to begin to apply land-reform laws more forcefully.
"This is not our Government; it is the Government of the rich," said another leader of the collective, Audelino Chavez, 43. "What is there to talk about with them?"
Ranchers and farmers have begun organizing more vigorously, both to lobby for the return of their properties and, in some instances, to act against the invaders.
The takeovers of town halls by leftist peasant and political groups have brought on similar confrontations.
Some of these have appeared almost entirely spontaneous, inspired to some extent by the Zapatistas, but clearly driven by local disputes. In the town of Amatenango del Valle last week, peasants who took over the municipal offices agreed to accept the results of a traditional Mayan Indian plebiscite, in which each side gathers its supporters to be counted one by one. When the vote was held on Friday, the peasants won, 1,095 bodies to 892.
But the tactic has increasingly been pushed by the self-styled "Government in Rebellion" that Mr. Avendano leads.
The parallel administration has encouraged the takeovers for much the same reasons that the Democratic Revolutionary Party has used them in other states where it claimed to have lost elections by fraud. In pressing for the ouster of the new Governor, Eduardo Robledo Rincon, Mr. Avendano has tried to make Chiapas ungovernable.
The party ordered at least a temporary end to the takeovers on Thursday, after a clash between peasants and police two days earlier in the town of Chicomuselo, near the border with Guatemala, that left at least six people dead. The episode made it evident, however, that the state's polarization was already well advanced.
At about midday Thursday the state attorney general, Jorge Enrique Hernandez Aguilar, arrived on the scene by helicopter. Upon failing to persuade the peasants to negotiate, he stormed away in disgust, apparently leaving behind orders to clear the town plaza. Numerous telephone calls requesting comment from him on the incident were not returned.
Moments later, witnesses said, the local and state police, backed up by heavily armed ranchers, began the violence again.
Mr. Hernandez blamed the violence squarely on Mr. Avendano, contending that he had ordered the takeover, and Mr. Avendano blamed the attorney general.
The two men know one another well: Mr. Hernandez, a lawyer and former leader of the state's corn farmers, once helped Mr. Avendano edit one of his rabble-rousing newspapers. When Mr. Hernandez was jailed for two years in the late 1980's for leading protests by the farmers, Mr. Avendano was a spearhead of his defense.

HEADLINE: Christopher Chides Yeltsin

BYLINE: Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Jan. 15

 BODY:
Under fire for strongly backing President Boris N. Yeltsin during the Chechnya crisis, Secretary of State Warren Christopher announced a modest change today in policy, warning Mr. Yeltsin that he could lose Washington's support if he forsakes democracy or free markets.
Mr. Christopher seemed to put new conditions on American support for the Russian leader. Appearing on the NBC News program, "Meet the Press," he said, "Our concern is for reform in Russia. We'll continue to support President Yeltsin as long as he is moving in the right direction." 
 After noting that Mr. Yeltsin has turned to Russia' right wing for support, Mr. Christopher said that when the crisis is over, "I hope he will move to re-engage himself with the reformers and bring them back to his side."

HEADLINE: MUSIC REVIEW;
Bruckner Works and a Look at How They Came to Be

BYLINE: By JAMES R. OESTREICH 

 BODY:
Probably no one who has spent much of his career immersed in the music of Mahler and Bruckner qualifies as a cockeyed optimist. But when Deryck Cooke published his blithely titled, influential little essay "The Bruckner Problem Simplified," in 1969, he reckoned without a new era of problematization, as academics like to call it.
And he surely reckoned without the gleeful musical problematizer Leon Botstein. "The spurious Schalk score," Mr. Cooke wrote with reference to the first published edition of Bruckner's Fifth Symphony, "has been abandoned by everybody." But here was Mr. Botstein, on Friday evening, conducting the American Symphony Orchestra in the Franz Schalk edition of the Fifth at Avery Fisher Hall. 
 Mr. Botstein, of course, is always happy to explain. The argument, growing out of a 1994 symposium at Connecticut College, "Perspectives on Anton Bruckner," and persuasively presented here in program notes and in a preconcert panel discussion, was that Cooke (though never mentioned by name) and others have grossly oversimplified the complex issue of the Bruckner editions.
Several of Bruckner's symphonies were first performed and published in versions prepared with help from his well-meaning friends, like Franz and Josef Schalk. In the 1930's, even before the early-music movement focused attention on original versions and composers' intentions, many began to argue that Bruckner's friends had taken advantage of his naive, malleable nature (traits since thrown into question) and foisted off inferior goods: only Bruckner's original manuscript versions, as eventually published in editions by Robert Haas, Leopold Nowak and others, were to be performed.
But what has been almost universally overlooked, when not actively concealed, is the seminal role of Nazi ideology in this makeover of a composer favored by the party. Reversion to the original, blunter, more blocklike scores, combined with a monumental performance style, carried Bruckner closer to Wagner (a Nazi deity), it was suggested in the discussion by Bryan Gilliam of Duke University, than to Schubert, who was perhaps nearer kin.
Mr. Botstein "de-Nazified" Bruckner in sound, presenting the Fifth Symphony in Schalk's sparer, more mercurial printed edition of 1896. He also imposed a leaner, lither, swifter performance style and, by and large, made a good case for it as one plausible approach among many.
Best of all, the orchestra's well-rehearsed exertions sounded like a performance rather than a demonstration. That cannot be said for the reading of Bruckner's "Psalm 146," a large-scale choral work, in the first half of the program. Evidently written in the late 1850's and never before performed or published, it was given here in an edition by Paul Hawkshaw of Yale University (another preconcert panelist), to be published next year.
To judge from its rote repetitiveness in parts, Bruckner had not yet learned what little he ever knew of economy. But a full appreciation of the work will have to await a more secure and purposeful orchestral performance and an acceptable gathering of vocal soloists.
The Canticum Novum Festival Singers, on the other hand, showed the benefit of Harold Rosenbaum's training here and in two sentimental bits of Bruckneriana for male chorus, "Germanenzug" ("The Teutons' Campaign") and "Abendzauber" ("Evening Magic"). Elias Mokole, a baritone, was a passable soloist in "Abendzauber," but the ditty's quaint charm derives chiefly from its coloristic use of three yodelers. Rick Karabetsus, Bruce Schuetz and Otto Weidner, imported for the occasion and presumably making their Avery Fisher Hall debuts, warbled delightfully.

The Economy
 Federal statisticians have begun the most ambitious effort since the late 1950's to remedy deficiencies in measuring the nation's economic performance. Government and private analysts worry that the statistical system increasingly fails to capture the numbing array of new technologies and structural changes in the economy, and it is widely believed that Government policies along with monetary regulation by the Federal Reserve have, to some extent, been thrown off by misleading data. [Page A1.] 
 If anyone in Orange County, Calif., has a right to say, "I told you so," it is John M. W. Moorlach -- the man who foresaw the county's investment problems even as he lost a bid for the county treasurer's job to Robert L. Citron, the incumbent. More than $2 billion in losses later, Mr. Citron has resigned, the county has filed for bankruptcy protection and Mr. Moorlach is talking with county supervisors hoping to be chosen as the replacement. HEADLINE: In Newark, Immigration Without Fear;
A Neighborhood Remade By Unexpected Hands

BYLINE: By ASHLEY DUNN, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: NEWARK, Jan. 11

 BODY:
Jack Santos, the owner of a restaurant in the Ironbound section of Newark, remembered how easy it was 30 years ago picking out the Portuguese illegal immigrants who had begun settling in what was then a gritty neighborhood of factories and small shops. They were the ones running down Ferry Street whenever an immigration van appeared.
The raids took place just about every week, he said, leaving scores of workers hiding in their apartments and rows of driverless delivery trucks along the main thoroughfare of Ferry Street. 
 "They would pick up people left and right," said Mr. Santos, who came to this country illegally in 1966.
While the prowling immigration van hasn't been seen in the neighborhood in decades, Mr. Santos notes with satisfaction that many of the same people who scattered down the street are now legal residents and own many of the stores on Ferry Street, turning it into a bustling market of Portuguese bakeries, clothing stores and coffee shops.
"If you go through each business, one by one, almost every one started off illegally," said Mr. Santos, 54, now a legal resident, as he took a break over an espresso at his restaurant, the Portuguese Pavilion, near Ferry Street.
In the space of 30 years, the Ironbound -- a name drawn from the two railroad lines that mark its boundaries -- has been transformed from a dingy industrial haven to a thriving enclave of Portuguese life. The transformation comes in large part from the entrepreneurship of the thousands of Portuguese illegal immigrants.
The Ironbound provides a snapshot of illegal immigration in the Northeast, a world that is strikingly different from that of the border states, which have dominated the debate over illegal immigration. The Portuguese are the largest group of illegal immigrants in New Jersey, with a population of about 17,000, but they have easily melted into the mass of legal immigrants.
While the pervasive image of illegal immigration is one of a shadowy nether world where impoverished immigrants live in hovels and work under harsh conditions, the Ironbound provides an example of an illegal immigrant life that is open, draws little scrutiny, and is virtually indistinguishable from that in the legal world.
In the compact 4.5-square miles of the Ironbound, illegal immigrants own businesses, pay taxes and, in contrast to the raids of 30 years ago, walk the streets with little fear of arrest.
"We are totally invisible," said Paul Quintela, 32, a bar manager who illegally came to the country in 1990. "No one knows about us. Being illegal is just a label that doesn't mean anything."
Sitting with a steaming cup of espresso at the Jackson Cafe just off Ferry Street, Mr. Quintela said that he never really thought of himself as an illegal immigrant, but rather just an immigrant out to make a better life for himself. From the beginning, he was the image of middle-class America -- a maitre d'hotel at a tony French restaurant in Morristown, with a nice home in the suburbs and a new Volkswagen sedan parked in the driveway.
He paid his taxes like everyone else, even using a Social Security number that he made up from nine randomly picked digits. Even though the Internal Revenue Service complained about the number every year, he said he always got his tax refund. "No problem," he said.
Before coming to the United States, he had owned an ice cream parlor, but saw little future for himself in Portugal. He found a job as a waiter on a cruise ship, and after two years, simply left one day to join a friend in the Ironbound.
He was startled to hear people speaking Portuguese everywhere on the street. He smelled the familiar aroma of baking custard tarts and Portuguese bread. In the taverns, he could linger at a table over a glass of Licor Beirao and espresso, just like back home.
"I thought I was still in Portugal," said Mr. Quintela, who eventually became a legal resident of the United States through the sponsorship of his employer at the restaurant. "In a lot of ways, this is more home to me than Portugal. It was built by people like me."
Fernando Santos, senior editor of Luso-Americano, a Portugese-language newspaper in the Ironbound, said the neighborhood has drawn Portuguese immigrants since the turn of the century, although they were just a small part of the flow of Italians, Lithuanians, Irish, Polish and Germans who also settled in the area to work in the nearby factories.
The area, roughly bounded by the Passaic River on the north, Amtrak tracks on the west and Conrail tracks on the east, is still dotted with churches of various denominations that serve as a reminder of the earlier multiethnic influx, even though many of their original parishioners have long since left for the suburbs.
Mr. Santos said that the Portuguese began to arrive in greater numbers after a change in the immigration law in 1965 that gave preference to relatives of immigrants already here. But the largest flow began after the 1974 military coup in Portugal, which sparked a new migration of urban professionals, tradesmen and entrepreneurs.
By the mid-1970's, the Italian and Cuban shops that had lined Ferry Street gave way to a burst of Portuguese investment.
Today, out of about 40,000 residents who live in the modest brick and clapboard homes in the Ironbound, at least 40 percent are Portuguese.
And now Ferry Street is a blend of Portugal and America, where Dunkin' Donuts stores stand next to shops like Coutinho's Bakery and the Roque and Rebelo restaurant.
"In Portugal, everyone knows where Newark and New Jersey are now," said Alvaro Zanbujinho, who came as an illegal immigrant 10 years ago and is now a legal resident and co-owner of Delicias Bakery on Ferry Street.
For some immigrants, however, the passage to America has not been as smooth. For seven years, a man who would only give his name as Agostinho C. said that he and his family have struggled to survive in the Ironbound on his wife's $300-a-month salary as a baby sitter.
He came to the United States in 1987 on a tourist visa and easily found work in one of the dozens of Portuguese construction companies in Newark. But after a year, he suffered a severe head injury in a truck accident and has been unable to work. Since then, he spends most of his time with friends. "I never go outside of the Portuguese community," he said.
He remembered that when he and his family first came to this country, he sat down with his 8-year-old daughter and explained that they were in the United States illegally and warned her not to tell anyone.
"It bothers me, and it bothers her, too," said Agostinho, who is 37. "This is a very hard time now. I'm more worried about being illegal than before."
But he said that in another three or four months, the family will probably become permanent residents of the United States through the sponsorship of his wife's employer.
"I thought it would take three years, but it's taken seven," he said. "I feel good for my daughter. She will be going to college soon and she won't face what we did. Soon my ordeal will be over."
He said that since 1986, the economy in Portugal has improved and there are fewer and fewer illegal immigrants coming to the United States. Many have even begun returning home because of the prolonged recession in this country during the late 1980's and early 90's.
But even as the influx of Portuguese has slowed, the next generation of immigrants to the Ironbound have already begun to establish themselves.
Drawn by their common language of Portuguese, Brazilian immigrants have been flocking to the Ironbound over the last five to 10 years.
Brazilian shops and restaurants now dot the area, taking the place of Portuguese stores that have moved outside the Ironbound to places like Elizabeth and Union City.
"You see a lot of Brazilians now," Agostinho said. "They are going through the same phase as the Portuguese 30 years ago."

HEADLINE: A Bad Week In the Asian Markets, Too

BYLINE: By PHILIP SHENON, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: SINGAPORE, Jan. 15

 BODY:
Traders in the stock and currency markets of East Asia braced for another hard week as the aftershocks of Mexico's financial crisis continued to pound emerging markets in the region.
Despite economists' assurances that major Asian currencies were unlikely to be devalued and that markets in this part of the world bore little resemblance to their counterparts in Mexico and elsewhere in Latin America, investors pulled money out of Asian currency and stocks. 
 Traders said many large foreign mutual funds unloaded Asian stocks at the demand of investors, who suddenly wanted their money out of emerging markets. Monetary officials across Southeast Asia were forced to step in to support their currencies, and to issue denials that they were considering devaluations.
"Our situation is very different from that in Mexico," Indonesia's Finance Minister, Marie Muhammad, said Friday, when the Indonesian rupiah fell to a record low -- 2,230 to the United States dollar. "We remain with our prudent fiscal and monetary policy."
A banking official in Thailand, speaking on condition that he not be identified, put it more bluntly: "This is crazy. There is no comparison between Southeast Asia and Mexico. Our economies are well planned, and our currencies are properly valued. In Mexico, none of that is true."
On Friday, every major Asian stock exchange fell except those in India and Pakistan.
In Thailand, the market index dropped 5.8 percent for the week. The Thai currency, the baht, fell to a low against the dollar on Thursday before steadying at 25.1 to the dollar Friday as a result of Government intervention, including repeated vows that the baht would not be devalued.
In Malaysia, the stock exchange's composite index fell 1.8 percent on Friday, while in Manila, trading in the Philippine peso had to be temporarily suspended when its value fell by more than 1.5 percent against the dollar. The Manila stock index plunged nearly 6 percent on Friday.
Hong Kong's monetary authority moved to prop up the Hong Kong dollar by withdrawing nearly $1.7 billion from the British crown colony's banking system, forcing up interest rates to foil speculators.
The Hang Seng stock index slumped 2.23 percent Friday and 5.6 percent for the week. The drop was largely attributed to reports that China's senior leader, Deng Xiaoping, was gravely ill, including an interview in The New York Times in which one of Mr. Deng's daughters acknowledged that his health had significantly declined.
To be sure, the distress in Asian markets has been going on longer than the three and a half weeks since Mexico devalued its peso. 1994 was a bad year for most of Asia, with losses in Hong Kong, for instance, of 25 percent in market value since Nov. 1, and 40 percent since 1994's high mark in February. Most other Asian markets also suffered.
Economists said the movement of foreign money out of Asia in recent days represented an overreaction by foreign investors, who did not understand that there were more differences than similarities between the major economies of Southeast Asia and of Mexico.
While Mexico has huge foreign debts and weak exports, most major Asian nations have trade surpluses, strong export-led economic growth and effective economic planning.
The Thai economy has been booming for years, with growth projected at more than 8 percent in 1995 on the basis of strong agricultural and manufacturing exports. Thailand has been especially attractive to foreign investors because of the steadiness of its exchange-rate system, with its money pegged to the value of a group of foreign currencies dominated by the American dollar.
But the system was threatened last week, when the Thai central bank was forced to steady a panicky currency market by announcing that the Government would buy or sell either Thai baht or dollars at a set exchange rate -- 25.08 baht to the dollar -- in an effort to foil speculators driving down the baht's value.
"The Thailand of today is far different from many years ago," said Ekamol Khiriwat, chief of the nation's Securities and Exchange Commission, expressing exasperation at foreign investors' actions.
Out of fear that this week could also be volatile, the Government has announced that foreign exchange trading rooms in Bangkok can remain open until midnight "until the situation returns to normal."

HEADLINE: Heady Days for Young Conservatives

BYLINE: Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Jan. 15

 BODY:
Life around here is sweet these days for young Republicans.
Forget the aimlessness and pessimism that is emblematic of so many in Generation X. Since the Nov. 8 elections, conservative young Republicans have been euphoric and filled with a sense of purpose. For the under-30 crowd in Washington, at least, grunge is out and buttoned-down is in. 
 Seated under a portrait of his political mentor, David Wilson, 27, looks very like a young Bob Dole: starched collar, gray suit, shiny brown hair swept back. This is not mere coincidence; Mr. Wilson has spent the last five years working for the Senator, who is once again the majority leader.
"For somebody who started out in my background -- my mother's a teacher and my father's a truck driver -- I guess people would say I'm a natural-born constituent of the Democratic Party," Mr. Wilson said.
But he is most definitely not. While still in college, at the University of Washington, Mr. Wilson set his political course, and his career, by going to work for Senator Dole as a summer intern; he is now the Kansas Republican's legislative assistant for telecommunications, education and Indian affairs.
The ascendancy of Mr. Wilson and his eager young partisans is a familiar phenomenon to their Democratic counterparts, many of whom hold bittersweet memories of riding the crest of another wave that swept Bill Clinton into the White House not so long ago. Many found jobs on Capitol Hill, but just two years later, as the Democrats abruptly become the minority party, scores of these young people are either out of a job or fear they soon will be.
Chris Gillespie is one of the luckier ones. After serving in the Clinton campaign's press office, he landed a job as a research analyst at the Democratic National Committee.
Already a political veteran at age 27, Mr. Gillespie suggests that the current crop of young Republicans not put too much stock in the November election results or the prospects for a long tenure on the Hill.
"It wasn't as much of an ideological shift as the Republicans want to believe," he said, and offered a reminder to the new House Speaker. "Newt Gingrich and others have painted a picture of this place as a fat, disgusting institution. Now they're going to have to live with it."
By outward appearances, it is hard to distinguish the young Republicans from the preceding class of young Democrats. The newer arrivals are perhaps a little more polished, but like Washington's young Democrats they bear little resemblance to the shiftless, dispirited "slacker" image often assigned to their generation.
Mr. Wilson, who grew up near Seattle, the grunge capital of America, was never part of the slacker scene, whose icon was the late singer Kurt Cobain of the group Nirvana. "I don't think my parents would ever have allowed me to be," he said. "Kurt Cobain was in my class, then I think he dropped out or moved. I just thought he was strange."
A couple of miles west of Capitol Hill, at Farragut Square, Jane Cournan, a stock broker at Prudential Securities, is pleased with the new political landscape. "The elections showed that everyone wanted freedom back," said Ms. Cournan, 26. "The Government's been taking in billions and billions of dollars, and people aren't better off."
Yet Ms. Cournan sees herself as an anomaly among people her age, whom she regards as favoring President Clinton and a political philosophy more in tune with the Democrats than with the Republicans.
For her, being a Republican boils down to a basic understanding of dollars and cents. And more people would be Republicans, she said, "if people understood economics better, if it was a required course about raising interest rates and raising taxes and what it does to the economy."
Economics is of secondary importance to Jennifer Pyne, a 24-year-old kindergarten teacher at Our Lady of Lourdes School, a Roman Catholic elementary school in Bethesda, Md. For her, the underlying appeal of conservative politics is in the realm of social issues.
"I sort of want this nice, traditional little perfect family," she said. "I definitely think family values have declined. I'm not saying that every mother has to stay at home, but I think it's an important message."
Despite the enthusiasm of conservatives at their leaders' taking the helm atop Capitol Hill, liberals like Mr. Gillespie caution that the challenges of transforming campaign oratory into successful public policy are formidable.
"You know the old saying, 'Any jackass can kick down a barn, but it takes a real genius to build one up,' " he said. "They've kicked down the barn -- let's see if they can build a new one."

HEADLINE: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Television;
In a Bid for Hits, Networks Buy Pieces of Rivals' Shows

BYLINE: By BILL CARTER, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: PASADENA, Calif., Jan. 13

 BODY:
When Jeffrey Katzenberg and Steven Spielberg turned up at an ABC news conference here this week to describe their plans for the partnership between the network and their new studio, Dreamworks SKG, they had only one announcement to make: The first show to be developed by the previously announced joint venture would be produced by Gary David Goldberg, the creator of "Family Ties," and it would be made for CBS.
CBS? Aren't those the wrong initials? Why did ABC put up $100 million so that Mr. Katzenberg and Mr. Spielberg (the third Dreamworks partner, David Geffen, was off putting up sandbags to protect his house in Malibu against the latest California monsoon) could turn out a show for CBS? 
 The answer has something to do with what time periods ABC had available and a previous commitment Mr. Goldberg had with CBS. But mainly it has to do with the changing economics of network television. Even though the show will be on CBS, ABC will own a share in its future profits.
It is all part of the often unpredictable television industry dance, where people are not so much changing partners as they are dancing indiscriminately with whoever seems promising.
Surprisingly, as Mr. Katzenberg said, "The possibilities in television are taking much more of our time than we first imagined they would." Mr. Spielberg has already begun working on a possible mini-series intended for ABC.
Another production company, Brillstein/Grey, also has a deal with ABC under which shows it produces will be co-owned with the network. The first show developed under this deal, a comedy tentatively titled "The Station," will go on the air soon -- on NBC.
Ted Harbert, president of ABC Entertainment, mused about this circumstance, where ABC can root for shows to succeed on other networks, and said, "It's incredibly bizarre."
Mr. Harbert schedules the network's programs, among them the shows that will compete for viewers against the program on CBS owned by Dreamworks and ABC and the program on NBC owned by Brillstein/Grey and ABC. "It's not just my parochial 8 to 11 P.M. schedule anymore," Mr. Harbert said. "It's a bigger business than that."
The biggest factor now affecting network programming schedules is the increasing opportunity for networks to take a financial interest in shows. Most shows make their biggest profits in syndication. Federal regulations that prohibit networks from taking a share in those profits expire in November.
As a result, the networks are adding more shows from their own production companies and, in ABC's case, from companies with which they are partners. The main suppliers of prime-time programs have reacted with alarm because they foresee shrinking opportunities to have their own programs seen by the public. They also question whether the networks will logically favor the shows they have a stake in every time they have to make a tough decision about which shows to keep and which to cancel.
These concerns were behind the decisions by Paramount and Warner Brothers to start their own networks this year. But those start-ups have only added to the worries of some network executives.
"It's difficult to deal from a business standpoint with suppliers who are also your competitors," said Don Ohlmeyer, president of NBC's West Coast division. "It's a little bit of a minefield we're walking through now. We're trying to figure out what the new ground rules are."
Mr. Ohlmeyer noted that some of the programs appearing on these fledgling networks were ones NBC executives had paid to develop, then decided they were not interested in and finally passed on. He questioned why NBC should absorb the cost of developing shows that may wind up in direct competition with other NBC programs. "I'm saying this changes the relationship" that NBC has with Warner Brothers and Paramount, Mr. Ohlmeyer said.
Fox Television is already in the position that Warner and Paramount are hoping to be in because Fox develops programs for every network but has also created a fiercely competitive network of its own. "We do very little business with Fox," Mr. Ohlmeyer said. "As small as our business is with Fox, it's actually too large. It should be smaller -- and it will be."
ABC has been the most aggressive network in investing in program suppliers to increase its chances of owning a share of a hit show. Such hits, like ABC's "Home Improvement" (owned by Disney), often generate hundreds of millions of dollars in syndication profits.
The incentive to have a stake in that kind of windfall is so great that ABC increasingly finds itself with mixed priorities. Mr. Harbert cited the example of "The Station," a show about an all-news radio station for which NBC executives have high hopes.
"The most fun I've had in a long time was working with Brad Grey on selling that show to NBC," Mr. Harbert said, referring to one of the partners in Brillstein/Grey.
He said the show's creator, Paul Simms, came to him with the idea for the series. "It was a 9:30 show," Mr. Harbert said. "I decided that given our strength in 9:30 comedies with 'Ellen' and 'Grace Under Fire,' I was not going to be able to take care of this producer at ABC."
Mr. Harbert also knew that NBC had two very attractive 9:30 time periods, on Tuesday and Thursday, that needed to be filled. So "The Station" was sold to NBC, where, Mr. Harbert acknowledged, it has a chance to hurt ABC's 9:30 shows. Theoretically, at least, the show could put "Ellen" or "Grace Under Fire" out of business.
"Sure it's bizarre," he said. "But frankly, I couldn't be happier about it because here's a chance for a show co-owned by ABC to go into a terrific time period and maybe make itself a hit." And then maybe make ABC's shareholders very happy by generating millions in syndication profits.
"You want to grow the company," Mr. Harbert said. That is apparently true even when it means an ABC-owned show does damage to shows not owned by ABC that are bringing in ratings for the network.
"Do I have a harder job now because I can be helping out another network with a hit show?" Mr. Harbert asked. "Yeah, I do. But it's fun."

HEADLINE: Comfortable Germans, Slow to Change (Especially if It Means More Work)

BYLINE: By CRAIG R. WHITNEY, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: DUSSELDORF, Germany

 BODY:
Life for the 16 million people in the former East Germany has been transformed since reunification in 1990, but change has come slower among the 64 million people here in the prosperous west despite warnings that their comfortable and costly welfare state must be cut back in a new era of global economic competition.
Pleas to work longer or harder are not easy to sell in a country where the 35-hour week is common, average hourly wages are higher than those in the United States and even first-year employees get four weeks' paid vacation. 
 The difficulty was made especially clear this month, when Walter Deuss, chairman of the Karstadt department store chain, suggested that retail stores be given the option of extending their hours to 8 P.M. on weekdays and 6 P.M. on Saturdays, bringing German hours closer to those in other European countries.
Store owners and employees balked at the proposal, demonstrating just how hard it is to get Germans to take another look at what Chancellor Helmut Kohl has called Germany's encrusted habits -- ways that might have worked during the cold war but that some now fear are threatening to choke economic growth.
"Nothing will really begin to change until Germans stop believing that the workweek should end at noon on Friday," said Hermann Franzen, who heads the 100,000-member German Retail Trade Association and owns a family porcelain store on the fashionable Konigsallee, the flagship retail street here in this city on the Rhine.
German retail trading hours are the most restrictive in Europe because of a 1956 law that was originally written to protect employees and to regulate demand in the booming postwar German economy.
But economic growth in Germany has been sluggish in recent years, and with unemployment at 9.6 percent of the labor force, advocates of longer opening hours suggest that they would stimulate domestic demand and create tens of thousands of jobs.
Since 1956, except for convenience stores in railroad stations, airports and gas stations, not a single supermarket, bakery, boutique or department store in Germany has been allowed to stay open past 6:30 P.M. on any weekday except Thursday, when closing time is extended to 8:30 P.M.
On Saturdays, except the four before Christmas and the first of every month, stores must close by 2 P.M., and shopping on Sunday is almost totally prohibited. In small towns, moreover, stores traditionally close for lunch.
"It is a typically German kind of law," said Mr. Franzen, referring to the limited retail hours. But like most of his fellow shopkeepers, he does not want longer hours because he is convinced that they would not bring in enough extra customers to cover the additional operating costs. And owners and employees alike worry that longer hours would cut into their time off.
"Germans need rules and regulations, and want a well-ordered, harmonious society, not the law of the jungle," he said. "They don't need more hours to shop, and my employees and I want time with our families."
Bernhard Jager, who manages the Saale Park shopping center near Leipzig, said he got official permission to open the center's 100 stores for a couple of Sundays last fall, but could not get the shop employees' union to permit it.
"We just wanted to show people on a completely free day what we had to offer," he said. "Normally, people have to rush out and shop in the last minute after they finish work."
Proponents of extending the shopping hours say the old law makes social change difficult. The law, for example, is one reason only 58.5 percent of the women in Germany hold jobs outside the home, compared with about 85 percent in East Germany before 1989. Moreover, for dual-income households with young children, it makes having to shop on Saturdays a family ordeal.
But in a German industrial and political culture that remains heavily patriarchal, shopping hours have withstood almost every attempt to extend them.
In 1988, the last time the shopping-hours debate produced change, legislators voted to permit Thursday evening shopping, overcoming resistance by shopkeepers and employees' unions. But they also cut back on Saturday hours to compensate employees.
With nearly 18 million unemployed in the 15 countries of the European Union, Mr. Kohl and his European counterparts called for more flexible working hours at their summit in Essen in December. They also urged a reduction of legally mandated surcharges on salaries, like social security payments and health insurance.
Even so, Mr. Kohl's Government coalition, re-elected with only a narrow majority last October, is not planning to try to change the law on retail hours, which can only be exteneded if the labor Unions and the opposition Social Democratic Party agree.
To solve the unemployment problem, labor unions and the Social Democrats have been fighting for nearly the opposite -- for employees to have a shorter workweek. Their logic is that employers would hire additional workers to make up the difference in hours.
Many retailers, too, are not convinced that longer hours will mean more jobs, or at least not many good ones.
Margret Monig-Raane, the acting head of the 560,000-member union representing German retail trade, bank and insurance employees, said: "After the Thursday shopping evenings came in, it was mainly 'bad jobs' that were added," meaning part-time jobs paying less than 560 marks ($360) a month, without the government-mandated social security, pension, or medical premiums that have to be paid on higher salaries.
Longer hours for full-time shop employees who now work 38.5 hours a week would also be "unsozial," she said, using a word often heard here to describe a range of economic offenses from uncompensated layoffs to reduced unemployment benefits.
Both she and Mr. Franzen, who heads the German Retail Trade Association, agreed that longer hours would not create many more jobs. If longer shopping hours did come to Germany, Mr. Franzen said he would just spread them around among his existing staff -- it wouldn't pay to add workers because consumer demand has been flat.
While the German economy is expected to grow over 2 percent this year, it has largely been driven by foreign demand for German exports. Domestic retail trade last year was only about level with 1993.
"People aren't buying much because they don't have the money," said Helena Bohne, who works in a women's clothing store in Bad Godesberg. "The politicians are saying we should get pay raises less than the rate of inflation to make Germany more competitive -- but it's the little guy who bears the burden, not big business."

HEADLINE: New Era for Orange County Jeremiah

BYLINE: By LESLIE WAYNE, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: SAN CLEMENTE, Calif., Jan. 11

 BODY:
If anyone in Orange County has a right to say, "I told you so," it is John M. W. Moorlach. And while he may not use exactly those words, it is clear that he is thriving as the most obvious choice to be appointed county treasurer -- the man who foresaw the Southern California county's investment problems.
Mr. Moorlach, a Republican in a predominantly Republican county, lost his bid for the treasurer's job by a 2-to-1 margin in November to Robert L. Citron, the incumbent for two decades. Now, more than $2 billion in losses later, Mr. Citron has resigned, Orange County has filed for bankruptcy protection and Mr. Moorlach is negotiating with a new county Board of Supervisors, hoping to be appointed as his replacement. 
 Mr. Moorlach, who wants the job very much, would like to step into office on April 15. And Thomas Fuentes, the county's Republican chairman, said, "The clamor, if John Moorlach is not appointed treasurer, will be deafening."
Yet some people close to the negotiations say Mr. Moorlach's appointment is far from certain. One adviser to Orange County, insisting on anonymity, said Mr. Moorlach might be overstating the interest in him.
These days, Mr. Moorlach is making speeches, appearing on radio shows and trying to capitalize on his new image as a Paul Revere of municipal finance. He keeps "Don't blame me! I voted for Moorlach" bumper stickers displayed in his Costa Mesa office and readily ticks off the television shows he has been on -- with Peter Jennings, Dan Rather and Connie Chung. In a half-serious way, he suggests he might be a candidate for Time magazine's Man of the Year.
Last summer, gathering a brain trust of local accountants and investment managers, he led a shoestring campaign against Mr. Citron and his investment policies. Many people feared that his warnings cast a troubling shadow over Orange County and would cut off investment dollars. Now he is in the position of having been proved right through financial disaster.
"This is no way to be vindicated," Mr. Moorlach, 39, said recently in one of his frequent speeches -- this one to a gathering at the Pacific Country Club here of 100 members of the San Clemente Area Republican Women's Federation. "It's a sad day. Two billion dollars is an astronomical loss. But if there is a God, you can win by losing."
If named treasurer, Mr. Moorlach said, he will recommend using local financial experts rather than continuing with Eastern-based advisers like Salomon Brothers and Arthur Andersen and will use local brokers to buy securities instead of New York brokers. "We put a lot of Ferraris in a lot of garages in New York," he told the Republican women.
He also took aim at the press, citing the dominant local daily, The Orange County Register, and the reporter who covered his campaign as "not only missing the story but missing the Pulitzer Prize," and adding, "You can take a reporter to water, but you can't make them think."
When it comes to determining where Orange County should go next, he said the situation was unclear. He is generally against tax increases and holds to the supply-side economics view that reducing taxes will increase personal and corporate spending and help the county. He suggested that perhaps reducing the county sales tax by one percentage point might encourage purchases at stores there, though he said he had not yet run computations to test the idea.
A tax accountant, Mr. Moorlach has long been active in local Republican politics, appearing as a frequent guest on local cable television. He allies himself with the party's conservative side.
Last year, he preferred to run for the state Assembly, he said, but after someone else declared his candidacy, Mr. Moorlach was persuaded to challenge Mr. Citron, the lone Democratic official in the overwhelmingly Republican county.
At that time, no one else in the Republican Party seemed concerned over Mr. Citron's aggressive investment tactics, but they wanted him out because they felt that he was politically too liberal.
Once he sought office, Mr. Moorlach and his group began to look at Mr. Citron's investment policies -- primarily his use of borrowed money to make heavy bets on interest rates.
In an interview that began in his office in Costa Mesa and continued in his car as he went to San Clemente, Mr. Moorlach recalled: "I froze and asked, 'How are we doing this with public dollars?' Orange County was a major house of cards."
When Mr. Moorlach announced his candidacy in February, only one reporter showed up. Through the summer, as he pressed Mr. Citron, often unsuccessfully, for more information on the county's investments, he was assailed by Republicans and Democrats.
Indeed, the five county supervisors of the time, all Republicans, endorsed Mr. Citron, and the county administrator said Mr. Moorlach's assertions were "putting the taxpayers of this county in jeopardy" by impugning Orange County's financial reputation.
The Los Angeles Times editorialized, "The cloud drawn over Citron increasingly looks like a bum rap."
"I spent many sleepless nights during the campaign," Mr. Moorlach said. "People here were indignant. If I said anything, it was that I was trying to hurt the credit rating of the county or that I wanted to cause a run on the investment pool. But I was talking to all my investment managers, and they knew that this portfolio was going to blow. I felt a moral obligation to keep going."
Some of the strongest criticism came from the Board of Supervisors. Thomas F. Riley, its former chairman, said of Mr. Citron, in a quote that has since become famous: "I don't know how the hell he does it, but he makes us all look good."
When Mr. Moorlach, in May, sent a detailed letter about the portfolio's problems to Mr. Riley and the other supervisors, it was largely ignored. The death knell for his campaign came when Marian Bergeson, a popular Republican state senator who was running for supervisor, resigned from Mr. Moorlach's campaign committee.
"It was vicious," said Mr. Fuentes, the county Republican chairman. "There was a calculated and manipulative effort by key county government bureaucrats to create a charade that a challenge to the great Citron would jeopardize the credit ratings and standing of the Orange County treasury."
Even after Election Day, Mr. Moorlach kept pressing, warning the supervisors and trying to get his city where he lives, Costa Mesa, to pull some money out of the county pool.
When the county filed for bankruptcy in December, Mr. Moorlach said: "I had never cried as an adult, and I couldn't stop crying. I had spent a year trying to tell them, and now our county was bankrupt. Then I started doing the radio shows."

HEADLINE: Synagogue Says Misleading Advice by a Brokerage Firm Resulted in a $650,000 Loss

BYLINE: By JACQUES STEINBERG, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: MAMARONECK, N.Y., Jan. 13

 BODY:
In a miniature version of the investment disaster that plunged Orange County, Calif., into bankruptcy, a Westchester synagogue says it lost $650,000 from its capital campaign last year through investments in highly speculative securities.
But unlike Orange County, whose treasurer knew the risks he was taking, the synagogue, the Westchester Jewish Center in Mamaroneck, contends that its treasurer was misled by a Wall Street brokerage into thinking the securities were virtually risk free. The synagogue also says it did not know it would be charged more than $100,000 in commissions for the investments. 
 The losses represent one-third of the $2 million the synagogue had invested with the brokerage, Gruntal & Company, over 11 months, ending last August. The nearly 50-year-old conservative synagogue had planned to use the money -- which it had borrowed through a new mortgage -- for renovations to its chapel and Hebrew school, which were completed last fall.
The synagogue has asked a New York Stock Exchange arbitration panel to order Gruntal to reimburse it for its losses. A hearing is scheduled in mid-March. Like most clients and brokers, the synagogue and Gruntal agreed at the outset of their transaction that they would not sue each other.
Harry D. Frisch, assistant general counsel of Gruntal, said today that the synagogue's accusations were "completely unfounded."
In a statement filed with the exchange in November, Mr. Frisch said responsibility for the loss rested with the synagogue's part-time volunteer treasurer, Miles Federman, who authorized Gruntal to invest the money in mortgage-backed securities known as collateralized mortgage obligations, or C.M.O.'s.
Synagogue officials said the congregation -- with a membership of 450 families -- was not in danger of bankruptcy, considering that since 1990 it had been able to raise $3 million in pledges for capital improvements.
But the chairman of a synagogue committee investigating the matter, Marc Jacoby, said that the loss was substantial and that "the synagogue membership is universally outraged" at Gruntal for putting "funds intended to pay for the construction of a prayer chapel and classrooms into the most unsuitable, risky securities."
Since many of the pledges were not due until 1998, the synagogue took out the $2 million mortgage in the fall of 1993 to pay for the renovations as they were completed. The synagogue had hoped that by temporarily investing the money in securities, it could offset its interest payments.
In a complaint filed with the arbitration panel in September, the synagogue said its treasurer, Mr. Federman, had been repeatedly assured by a Gruntal broker, Erwin Roberts, that investing in C.M.O.'s -- pools of mortgages whose value is tied to interest rates -- was "safe" and would provide "high yields" over a short period.
Included in the synagogue complaint was a letter, apparently signed by Mr. Roberts in May, describing the synagogue's portfolio as having "the highest, safest income investments."
But in fact, collateralized mortgage obligations are "highly speculative" and similar to the securities that led to the bankruptcy of Orange County and the financial troubles of untold other municipalities across the country, as interest rates rose sharply last year, said Louis Lowenstein, professor of finance and law at Columbia University.
"They're about as predictable as which way the bird will fly when it leaves a tree," said Professor Lowenstein, who noted that he was not familiar with the details of the synagogue's investment. "That doesn't sound like anything remotely appropriate for a short-term investment."
In its formal response to the synagogue's claim, according to arbitration records, Gruntal said that Mr. Federman, a managing director and senior analyst in the electric, gas and water utilities section at Standard & Poor's, "was not an unsophisticated investor" and "was more than capable of understanding the nature of investing in C.M.O.'s."
Gruntal said that its broker, Mr. Roberts, had sent Mr. Federman a brochure titled "An Investor's Guide to Mortgage Securities," which explained that "the cash flow on mortgage securities is irregular."
But Mr. Federman said in an interview that he recalled seeing no such brochure and, as an expert on utility securities, was not familiar with mortgage-backed securities. Instead, he said, he relied on the advice of Mr. Roberts. Mr. Federman said he had done personal business with Mr. Roberts for more than 15 years and was responsible, in his capacity as treasurer, for setting up a synagogue account with him in 1987.
"They did not make it clear to me that there were any risks here," Mr. Federman said, adding that Mr. Roberts had "blatantly told me things that were not true."
The synagogue said it first learned it had sustained losses in May, when it tried to withdraw money from its account. It eventually sold its entire investment in August.
Mr. Roberts declined to comment today, referring calls to Mr. Frisch, the Gruntal lawyer, who said the synagogue had been "fully informed" of all risks and brokerage commissions. He declined to say how much the brokerage had charged the synagogue.
Mr. Jacoby, the chairman of the synagogue committee, said the synagogue supports Mr. Federman.
"No one," he said, "blames the synagogue treasurer, who is an unpaid volunteer, for accepting the recommendation of a broker with whom he had dealt for many years but who grossly misled the treasurer in this instance."

HEADLINE: U.S. IS CONSIDERING A LARGE OVERHAUL OF ECONOMIC DATA

BYLINE: By ROBERT D. HERSHEY Jr., Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Jan. 15

 BODY:
Federal statisticians have begun the most ambitious effort since the late 1950's to remedy mounting deficiencies in measuring the nation's economic performance.
Government and private analysts worry that the statistical system increasingly fails to capture the numbing array of new technologies and structural changes in today's $7 trillion economy. 
 Indeed, it is widely believed that Government tax and spending policies along with monetary regulation by the Federal Reserve have been thrown off to some extent by misleading data.
For example, had the "true severity" of the 1990-1991 recession been known earlier, the Bush Administration's Council of Economic Advisers wrote in January 1993, "policy might have been conducted in a different fashion" to counter it more aggressively.
And Alan Greenspan, the chairman of the Federal Reserve, told Congress last week that the Consumer Price Index overstates inflation by as much as 1.5 percentage points. With Social Security and other entitlement spending as well as adjustments in tax brackets pegged to the inflation rate, Republicans in Congress were quick to seize on the corollary -- by changing the index's formula, they could free $150 billion in Federal funds over the next five years without a single specific budget cut.
The private sector is also frustrated by various Government figures. "When you read that capacity utilization is close to its historic maximum, that doesn't mean much of anything," said Vladi Catto, chief economist at Texas Instruments, referring to a widely followed gauge of inflation potential calculated by the Federal Reserve.
To a large extent, the officials responsible for Federal statistics -- which cost taxpayers $2.6 billion a year to amass -- acknowledge the gaps and distortions and say they are working hard on improvements in a climate of rapid economic shifts and tight budgets for data collection.
Having last week formally identified gaps and shortcomings, the Commerce Department will decide in the next several weeks which statistics most urgently need repairs and will recommend specific remedies. In March, the department plans to convene a "town meeting" here of statistics users whose views will be incorporated in the plan.
The Labor Department, which sweepingly updated its monthly employment report last January, is well along with an overhaul of the Consumer Price Index, which would take effect in January 1998. And by this June it plans to switch methodology to make the closely scrutinized tabulation of payrolls more accurate by telling states which establishments to survey instead of giving them industry quotas.
"Our statistical system can only meet the expectations of its users by changing as rapidly as the economy it measures," said Everett M. Ehrlich, Under Secretary for Economic Affairs at the Commerce Department, in announcing in late December the review of its national income and product accounts, which make up the gross domestic product.
This is the set of figures, created in the late 1920's when goods were more important than services, that provides quarterly totals of economic activity and the degree to which it is expanding or contracting. The Commerce and Labor departments are the chief purveyors of nonagricultural statistics.
The struggle to keep up, Mr. Ehrlich said, means adapting to "the changing composition of the economy, the implications of technological progress, the greater level of global economic integration and a variety of other forces."
The problems cited by Mr. Greenspan and the others do not mean that the policies that follow from the statistics are topsy-turvy. Mr. Greenspan, for instance, did not say that he was conducting monetary policy on the assumption that inflation might be only half the rate published by the Labor Department. But others believe the overstatement has at least some effect on the central bank.
"It probably leads to slightly tighter monetary policy," said William D. Nordhaus, an economics professor at Yale University. Benefit programs linked to inflation are "surely" overly generous, said Mr. Nordhaus, who has pioneered development of alternative ways to measure national income.
So far, according to private analysts and a Commerce Department review team that published its findings on Wednesday, the official figures still reliably tell in which direction the economy is moving, whether the pace is accelerating or decelerating and whether it is high or low relative to the trend.
But these accounts involving total output of goods and services are not capturing the full effect of such things as computer software -- is it part of the nation's stock of capital assets? -- securities-market derivatives that vault international boundaries and advances in telecommunications technology that defy attempts at adjustment for the higher quality and lower prices.
The traditional metaphor of the gross domestic product as the bottom line on a cash-register tape tallying a cart full of toasters, haircuts, Cheerios and gallstone surgery "is becoming evermore inappropriate," Mr. Ehrlich said.
Joseph W. Duncan, a Dun & Bradstreet economist and a former chief statistician at the Office of Management and Budget and the Commerce Department, said, "Conceptually is where we have the trouble."
He pointed, for example, to Wall Street investment bankers who are working on deals abroad. "They are in effect exporting U.S. know-how, but that doesn't get measured," Mr. Duncan said.
Related to the problem of constructing the right statistical net is the frequency figures must be significantly revised. On Friday, for example, a big downward adjustment in retail sales for November contributed to a mood swing that prompted one Wall Street house to declare that "the Commerce Department stole Christmas."
The economists at the S. G. Warburg investment banking firm added, "If the latest retail sales readings are anywhere near accurate, which we doubt, then they put a very different light on the momentum of the economy at year's end."
Such skepticism came despite the Commerce Department's warning that the first sales results for each month are based on a small subsample of retailers, causing a large margin for error, and are thus subject to sizable revision.
Still, the department acknowledged in review documents that revisions to G.D.P. "appear to account for a substantial share of the errors in short-term econometric forecasts used for business and macroeconomic policy purposes."
Revisions of the quarterly figures averaged 1.4 points from first estimate to final tabulation during the 1980-1991 period but with no apparent bias in either direction. And officials say they are not at all sure the new conceptualizing now under way will result in higher, rather than lower, G.D.P.
"I see it as a toss-up," Mr. Ehrlich said, suggesting that underestimation for telecommunications and computer software might be offset by reduced figures for, say, education and health.
Officials also note that because of deregulation, they no longer get some information on figures that various industries were once required to supply.
As for the Consumer Price Index, officials at the Labor Department acknowledge possible overstatement of perhaps as much as five-tenths of a point a year, but they balk at Mr. Greenspan's suggestion that it may be three times that much.
"That's really very much driven by a belief that we miss a lot of quality improvements," responded Katharine G. Abraham, the Commissioner of Labor Statistics. She added that not only did she think there was "great uncertainty" about the magnitude, it was even possible that the C.P.I. might understate inflation since for each computer that becomes cheaper and better by the week there is probably some other product about which it is said "they don't make them like they used to."
