HEADLINE: Curbing the Costs of Job Injuries

BYLINE: By MILT FREUDENHEIM 

 BODY:
Many employers are taking tighter control over the rising cost of treatment for on-the-job injuries. They are turning to remedies that they have long used to rein in all other employee health costs.
The cost of treating workplace injuries had risen to $28.39 billion in 1993. Medical spending in workers' compensation cases rose more than tenfold from 1970 to 1990, almost twice the rate of general medical inflation. 
 But even so, these costs were only a small fraction of overall spending for employee health benefits, so there was not great pressure to reduce spending. That was until the early 1990's, when workers' compensation jumped to 11 percent of employee health benefits. Alarmed employers and the insurance companies that provided coverage began trying to control costs by steering injured workers to networks of physicians that offer reduced fees.
Now some employers are going further. They are switching to managed-care programs that direct injured workers to health maintenance organizations, which promise stricter restraints on costs.
Raymond Graeme, a 23-year-old Epsom, N.H., iron worker, lost the use of two fingers of his left hand in a workplace accident last September. Until last year, he could have gone to any doctor he liked, but under a 1994 New Hampshire law, he had to go to a network doctor. Healthsource, an H.M.O. that handles workplace injuries for his employer, chose a doctor, who referred Mr. Graeme to Concord Orthopedics for physical therapy. All his care had to be approved by the H.M.O.
Proposals in Washington last year to combine workers' compensation with general health insurance encouraged the managed-care trend, and insurance companies and health maintenance organizations have been rushing to get the business.
"Everyone knows there's a huge opportunity out there," said Kenneth S. Abramowitz, a managed-care analyst with Sanford C. Bernstein & Company, a securities firm.
The Liberty Mutual Group, the biggest workers' compensation insurer, has announced alliances with H.M.O.'s across the country: Humana Inc. in Florida, Pacificare Health System in California, Blue Cross and Blue Shield in Massachusetts, and Healthsource in New Hampshire and Vermont. Liberty Mutual, which has about 10 percent of the workers' compensation market, said it was negotiating with other H.M.O.'s as well.
The Travelers and Metropolitan Life insurance companies are seeking new workers' compensation business for Metrahealth, their joint venture in managed health care. They are combining their physician discount networks and will offer Metropolitan's H.M.O.'s, said Patrick Kinney, a vice president of Travelers, which has about 5 percent of the workers' compensation market.
Big independent health maintenance organizations including Kaiser Permanente, FHP Inc. and Foundation Health Systems in California; Blue Cross associations in a number of states; United Health Care in the Midwest and Southeast, and United States Health Care in the mid-Atlantic states are all promoting workers' compensation services.
Value Health Inc., which provides managed care for mental health and pharmacy programs, last year bought CCN Community Care Workers, one of the biggest California workers' compensation physician networks. The Corvel Corporation, which monitors workers' compensation claims, has applied for a license under a new California managed- care program that sets rules for workers' compensation coverage. State officials said 26 such applications had been received and more were expected.
"The California market is going berserk," said David Appel, a workers' compensation expert in New York with Milliman & Robertson, an actuarial and benefits consulting firm. "Everybody is looking to negotiate managed-care programs."
Beverly Enterprises, a big nursing home chain that also operates physical rehabilitation units, jumped into the market on Dec. 28, announcing an agreement to buy Pharmacy Management Services, a company that operates a network of workers' compensation physicians and a mail-order pharmacy.
Robert Woltil, chief financial officer of Beverly, said it planned to develop the workers' compensation business to feed its rehabilitation units, especially in California where both Beverly and Pharmacy Management do considerable business. He said Beverly was not trying to compete with the insurance companies, which are customers of Pharmacy Management. "We want to offer them a one-stop shop," he said.
About half of all employers, including many who are self-insured, were using managed care in workers' compensation in 1993, up from 20 percent in 1991, according to a survey by the Towers Perrin benefits consulting firm.
But many states make it hard for employers to use managed care for workers' compensation. Many workers' compensation laws were enacted with labor union support before World War I, an era of relatively inexpensive (and uncomplicated) medical treatment. Workers were urged to accept help under the compensation laws rather than bring lawsuits, which even today can raise costs sixfold.
Workers' compensation is regulated by state laws that provide for medical care and stipends to replace lost wages. Except in Texas, employers must pay for the coverage, which cost $63.1 billion in 1993, including $33.1 billion in insurance company premiums, $20 billion spent by self-insured employers and $10 billion from state insurance funds.
The average cost of recent workers' compensation claims in California, for example, was $3,564, said Dr. Arnold Milstein, a medical consultant in San Francisco with William M. Mercer, benefits consultants. For workers who bring lawsuits, the average, including settlements and jury awards, was $26,393.
In New York, workers can choose any physician from a state-approved list, leaving employers little leverage to push them into managed care. In Connecticut, the employer chooses the doctor but the workers can change to another physician, though they may have to pick from an employer's managed-care list.
Employers in New Jersey control the choice of physician. At least 29 states, including New Jersey and Connecticut, have amended workers' compensation laws to help employers use managed care.
Just last year, Kentucky, New Hampshire, Pennsylvania, Rhode Island, South Dakota, Virginia and New York enacted amendments "that promote managed care," a Blue Cross survey found.
James Ellenburger, a workers' compensation spokesman in Washington for the A.F.L.-C.I.O., said the unions were working with New York state officials and employers on a "limited pilot project" to try out managed care.
Unions have often resisted managed-care proposals. The A.F.L.-C.I.O. in Ohio, for example, unsuccessfully opposed changes last year intended to foster managed care.
Medical costs are now about 45 percent of workers' compensation, with most of the rest going for wage replacement. State officials and industry experts say managed-care programs can save 10 percent to 30 percent of the medical costs.
But Mr. Appel at Milliman & Robertson said many offered little more than access to a network of specialists in occupational medicine who charge discounted fees. Some go further and provide case managers who telephone doctors to urge them to hold costs down and arrange with employers to offer workers untaxing temporary assignments so they can return to work instead of just collecting wage replacement checks.
In a more tightly structured program, Pacificare, the big California-based H.M.O., is working with Liberty Mutual and others to offer coverage based on a per capita monthly fee. Charges can range from $1.50 each for bank employees in low-crime, low-risk areas to $150 for police officers and firefighters, Vicki Merrill, head of Pacificare's workers' compensation unit, said.
Florida recently approved managed-care alliances that 22 insurance companies have made with Florida H.M.O.'s and physician networks. The alliances will cut their charges to employers by 10 percent in expectation of saving at least that much in costs.
But as is the case in managed health care generally, some experts have their doubts. "There has been a lot of verbiage," said Richard A. Victor, executive director of the nonprofit Workers Compensation Research Institute in Cambridge, Mass. "It remains to be seen how much actual savings and reality there is."

HEADLINE: Japan Is Likely to Meet Goal on U.S. Auto Parts

BYLINE: By ANDREW POLLACK, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: TOKYO, Jan. 15

 BODY:
Japan's automobile industry is almost certain to achieve a target set three years ago to purchase $19 billion in American-made automobile parts this fiscal year, Government and industry officials said.
The likelihood of reaching the goal became clear on Friday when the Japan Automobile Manufacturers Association announced that for the first half of the fiscal year, purchases of American parts and materials spurted 32 percent to $9.53 billion, half the required total. 
 The $19 billion voluntary goal for the year ending this March was announced in January 1992 as an attempt to soothe relatiions in an unusually tense visit to Japan by President George Bush, who was accompanied by the top executives of the Big Three American car makers. If the goal is achieved, it would mean that purchases of American parts by Japan's industry will have more than doubled from the $9 billion recorded in the fiscal year ended March 1991.
Most of the purchases will be used in Japanese-owned automobile factories in North America, which have been expanding their production. Imports of American parts into Japan, however, are not growing as fast, reaching $1.5 billion in the first half of the fiscal year. Imports are supposed to account for $4 billion of the $19 billion goal.
The release of the new figures comes as American and Japanese negotiators get ready to resume stalled trade talks on automobiles and auto parts later this month.
One of the key American demands is for Japanese companies to set new, higher voluntary goals for foreign parts purchases beyond this year. Japan's five largest car makers announced new voluntary plans last year, but Washington termed them inadequate and has been pressing for more ambitious goals.
Walter F. Mondale, the American Ambassador to Japan, said in Detroit recently that Japan faced "serious consequences" if its auto makers did not agree to increase their purchases of American auto parts by March.
The fact that Japan now looks likely to achieve the $19 billion level, something that had been in doubt until recently, could be received favorably by the United States. But industry officials here fear that this will only embolden the Americans to raise the bar even higher.
Japan's Government has said it will not negotiate such targets because that is a matter for private business. The Clinton Administration is expected to talk directly to Japanese companies.
But the companies have been saying that they have no intention of increasing their plans beyond what they announced last March. Moreover, they say, it is inappropriate for the American Government to negotiate with them.
"It is not our intention to go into direct negotiations with the U.S. Government," Nobuhiko Kawamoto, president of the Honda Motor Company, said at a news conference on Wednesday. He said that the level of Honda's foreign parts purchases would be decided strictly on a business basis.
Still, the rise in purchases of American parts as the March deadline nears seems to lend credence to Washington's belief that targets, even voluntary ones, are effective in opening Japan's market.
Clyde Prestowitz, president of the Economic Strategy Institute, a Washington-based research organization, said the news was "very important because it means they are buying more American parts and that will create jobs here, and because it indicates that despite a lot of denials, targets and commitments we set do have an effect."
"The only question is, why is it not more than $19 billion? Just a couple of weeks ago, there was an announcement from Japan that the Japanese cars made in the U.K. have 85 percent European content. It's nowhere near 85 percent here, despite the $19 billion. It is more like 65 percent."
In the fiscal year that ended last March, purchases of American parts grew only 14.1 percent to $15.54 billion, making the $19 billion goal look unreachable. But as with semiconductors, Japanese purchases of foreign chips made a sudden sharp surge just in time to achieve the goal that foreign chips would hold 20 percent of the market by the end of 1992.
Japanese officials said that purchases of American parts had grown so fast because production of cars in Japanese-owned factories in the United States has been growing sharply as a result of a strong American car market. Also, the rising value of the yen has prompted Japan to shift more production to North America.
But auto makers say that it has been difficult to increase imports of American parts because an economic slump and the strong yen have slowed car production in Japan.
The strength of the yen would seem to make American parts cheaper than Japanese parts, but officials insist that this is not always the case. "At the moment, American parts are not very cheap," Mr. Kawamoto of Honda said.
He and others said that Japanese parts manufacturers had been forced by car companies to make drastic cost cuts while American parts suppliers, basking in strong demand in the United States, had not been subject to the same pressure.
Moreover, some Japanese companies say they want to localize procurement as much as possible. Toyota is planning to decrease parts imports in the future, a spokesman said.
The strong demand for cars and parts in the United States, combined with sluggish demand in Japan, has meant that the American trade deficit with Japan in the automobile sector continued to rise in 1994, reaching an estimated $36.1 billion compared with $33.4 billion in 1993, according to the Commerce Department. The automobile sector accounts for the largest chunk by far of the United States deficit with Japan.

HEADLINE: THE MEDIA BUSINESS;
U.S. Business Magazines Thriving on Foreign Ads

BYLINE: By DEIRDRE CARMODY 

 BODY:
A significant increase in advertising from international sources like foreign governments, tourist agencies, banks and a range of industries helped make 1994 the best year for advertising pages in United States magazines in at least five years.
The principal benefactors were domestic editions of business magazines. Forbes reported a 46 percent increase in foreign ad pages last year in the magazine and its two supplements, Forbes FYI and ASAP, compared with 1993. Fortune saw ads from Asia increase 60 percent and ads from Europe rise 12 percent. 
 Business Week, which provides figures for ad revenue rather than ad pages because of its internal auditing procedures, reported an 18 percent increase in revenue from international sources last year. Foreign ads now account for 8 percent of Business Week's total ad revenue.
Among the foreign advertisers responsible for the increases in the three magazines were computer companies, airlines, insurance companies and makers of luxury goods.
Christopher Forbes, vice chairman of Forbes Inc., said banks, hotels, luxury travel and business travel were prominent categories for his magazine. A large part of the increase in foreign advertising in Forbes came from multipage supplements from government agencies and business groups in Ireland, Brazil, Japan, Taiwan, Malaysia and Hong Kong.
Stuart Arnold, publisher of Fortune, said the greatest increase in foreign ads came from Asia last year. "All of the increase comes outside of Japan -- Korea, Hong Kong, Singapore, Thailand, Taiwan and Malaysia," he said. "It's just company after company that you never heard of, selling services and making products."
David G. Ferm, publisher of Business Week, said that while ads from Asia showed significant increases in his magazine, "Europe was lagging in 1994." He said Business Week's international edition also had increases in overseas advertising. Fortune and Business Week have international editions. Forbes has editions in German, Japanese and Chinese, each with its own editorial material.
Comparing the ad pages of different publications is tricky because the methods of tabulating pages are not precisely the same. To complicate matters, ads sold out of the American offices of foreign companies usually count as domestic ads. An ad for Singapore Airlines sold by the airline's Los Angeles office, for instance, is not counted as an international ad.
Page counts from the Publishers Information Bureau, the industry's official measuring stick, are also misleading because they do not factor in discounts. One magazine may have a particular bonus plan that gives an advertiser a cash discount for buying a certain number of ad pages. Another magazine may have the same deal but instead of giving a cash discount it may provide free ad pages.
Peter Schoff, international advertising director for Forbes, said much of the increase in his magazine's foreign ad pages came as a result of an aggressive sales effort to expand into new foreign markets.
Forbes opened an ad sales office in Hong Kong and has been particularly active in the Pacific Rim. "Those markets are probably growing faster than any other place in the world," he said.
Mr. Schoff said Europe was coming back to life after a recession that lasted from 1991 to 1993. The same is true of Japan, he said, after a recession that began soon after the start of the slowdown in Europe. Forbes extended its sales efforts into India last year and has also been active in Mexico, Brazil and Argentina.
Judy Jorgensen, a spokeswoman for the Publishers Information Bureau, said recent figures showed ads for European and Asian cars to be up "dramatically" in magazines across the board through November, compared with the first 11 months of 1993. Ads for European cars were up 15 percent and those for Asian cars were up 9 percent. She said industry figures also showed that ad pages for foreign hotels and resorts were up 15 percent, while those for American hotels and resorts were flat.
Russia and China are being wooed by the American business magazines, but little business has been forthcoming.
"Our people are going into China to try and figure out how to organize things, but currently we do not have a structure set up," Mr. Arnold of Fortune said. "Russia is the same as China. They have no money and basically your strategy has to be build some awareness and circulation so that when they are able to promote products, at least you will be there."

HEADLINE: U.S. Stance On Mexico

BYLINE: Reuters 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Jan. 15

 BODY:
The United States is setting "strong" conditions for a $40 billion loan-guarantee package to bail Mexico out of its currency crisis, Treasury Secretary Robert Rubin said today.
Mr. Rubin, on the ABC program "This Week With David Brinkley," did not elaborate on conditions for the package, now being negotiated in an effort to restore investor confidence in the battered peso and shore up the Mexican economy. 
 In Mexico City, Finance Ministry officials said on Friday that Mexico would use future oil export revenues as collateral for the proposed loan guarantees.
The plan would help Mexico reschedule short-term debt by assuring investors that they would eventually be repaid.

HEADLINE: Ford Plans Plant Expansion

BYLINE: By Bloomberg Business News 

DATELINE: DEARBORN, Mich., Jan. 15

 BODY:
The Ford Motor Company is investing $400 million to expand production at its F-series pickup and Bronco sport-utility truck plant in Wayne, Mich.
The expansion, which includes a new body shop, is to accommodate production of all-new models for 1997, Ford, the No. 2 United States auto maker, said on Friday. 
 About 350 workers will be hired as part of the expansion plan, a Ford spokesman said. The hirings are part of a longer-range plan announced by Ford in August to add 900 jobs at the Wayne plant and increase annual capacity there by more than 15 percent.
The expansion shows that Ford is betting that demand for light-duty trucks will continue to grow even as interest rates rise. Light-truck sales in the United States last year accounted for 40.1 percent of all vehicle sales, up from 38.5 percent in 1993.

HEADLINE: BOOKS OF THE TIMES;
Lost by U.S.: The Sense of a Right to Triumph

BYLINE: By CHRISTOPHER LEHMANN-HAUPT 

 BODY:
THE END OF VICTORY CULTURE
Cold War America and the Disillusioning of a Generation
By Tom Engelhardt
351 pages. Basic Books/HarperCollins. $25.
In broadest outline, what Tom Engelhardt argues in "The End of Victory Culture" is neither startling nor particularly original. He writes that in the two decades between the end of World War II and America's entry into Vietnam in force, this country lost its culture of victory, which he defines as the sense of a right to triumph over American Indians, Japanese, Indochinese or any other supposedly lesser people. 
 His explanation for this loss can be boiled down to the creation of nuclear weapons, the war with the Soviet Union that stayed cold because of them and the outbreak of lesser conflicts in which their use would have been unacceptably disproportionate. To sum up his case in a tiny nutshell: the Japanese sneak attack on Pearl Harbor fit into our national fantasy of having settled the American continent in the face of the ambush warfare of Indians. But with the massacre at My Lai, we became the Indians and the Vietnamese the settlers.
As oversimplified as this outline may sound, Mr. Engelhardt is absorbing and provocative when he traces how these changes in attitudes were reflected in American popular culture, particularly in movies and comic books and in the way children play war games. Of the last he writes: "Crucial as it was to boys' lives, war play was so little in the thoughts or concerns of adults that, except as it is hinted at in memoirs of childhood (especially those of Vietnam veterans), remarkably little has been written about it."
In the dazzling weave of his thesis, the thread that stands out is one that begins with the middle-class exodus to suburbia in the 1950's, when, as the author writes, "the economy was churning out the most peaceable and the most warlike of big-ticket items," and the "country was reimagining itself as a magic kingdom, a cornucopic mechanism for turning out the world's play toys and pleasure environments."
Yet threatening this idyll, in his view, was what he terms the Great Fear and the Little Fear. The former was the McCarthyite overreaction to the menace of Communist subversion. The latter, as he defines it, was anxiety over the freedom of the "commercial media -- record and comic book companies, radio stations, the movies and television -- to concretize both the fantasies of the young and the nightmarish fears of grown-ups into potent products." Two examples of such potent products are rock-and-roll, which at first was watered down by white musicians, and the comic-book tales of horror created by William Gaines and Harvey Kurtzman, which, thanks to the protests of Dr. Frederick Wertham, the psychiatrist, were diluted into Mad magazine.
What Mr. Engelhardt's narrative argues is that the Great Fear, hysteria over Communism, led to Vietnam. And the Little Fear, anxiety about youth culture, was realized in the protests over Vietnam. As he writes: "Countless demonstrators sallied forth to a new sort of battle garbed in cast-off 'good war' paraphernalia -- secondhand Army jackets, bombardier coats, bush hats. Initially without significant access to the media, the young reconceived the images of their childhood on themselves. They became distinctly modernist endeavors, living critiques or parodies of the familiar, their own Mad magazines."
Now a lot of what Mr. Engelhardt writes here is debatable, even where he shades in the needed nuances. Some readers will doubt his contention that on the home front during World War II "the greatest fear of the American public, according to pollsters, was not defeat abroad but the possibility that peace might bring another economic collapse." Others may dispute his assumption that dropping nuclear weapons on Japan was an atrocity equal to the Nazis' treatment of European Jews.
No one will easily follow his contrived attempt to align the careers of two people who called themselves X: George F. Kennan, who made the case for containing the Soviet Union in a Foreign Affairs magazine article signed X, and Malcolm Little, part of whose strategy to escape containment by white America involved replacing his surname with X. And not a few readers will protest the impressions he somehow creates that American Indians were not that great a threat to European settlers, that there was little ground for concern about Communist subversion during the cold war and that nothing more than irrational rage lay at the root of the My Lai massacre.
In short, Mr. Engelhardt, a freelance writer and media critic whose previous book was "Beyond Our Control: America in the Mid-70's," neglects to emphasize the most obvious change that occurred during the era he writes about, namely the transition from territorial to guerrilla warfare. As he implies by his comments on George Lucas's film "Star Wars" and on the allies' execution of the war in the Persian Gulf, if a certain kind of enemy came along and posed a particular sort of challenge, the United States would re-embrace victory culture in the snap of a cap gun.
Of course, Mr. Engelhardt's book, with its subtitle "Cold War America and the Disillusioning of a Generation," is at heart an analysis of the author's own growing up. And since, as he reports, his childhood was marked by his father's failure to find a satisfying profession after experiencing success as an officer in World War II, the reader can at least understand the basis of his emotions.
Moreover, his thesis touches upon many curious things in American culture: the decline of the film western about the time of the Vietnam War, the rise of children as consumers, the invoking of Nazi war crimes instead of Japanese atrocities when America began to doubt its conduct in Vietnam and the refusal to demonize Ho Chi Minh the way Japan's World War II leaders were caricatured. Mr. Engelhardt's views are, of course, a particular way of seeing the world. But they offer the satisfactions of coherence. Despite his sometimes questionable premises, everything he writes is of a satisfyingly congruent piece.

GRAPHIC: Photo of Tom Engelhardt (Laura Dwight/Basic Books)

HEADLINE: CHAMPIONSHIPS: Sports of The Times;
In the Final Analysis, Jones and Cowboys Die With Their Boots

BYLINE: By DAVE ANDERSON 

DATELINE: SAN FRANCISCO

 BODY:
OUTSIDE, after he accepted the National Conference trophy, Eddie DeBartolo's voice thundered through Candlestick Park's public-address system.
"We are going to Miami," the 49ers' owner said, alluding to Super Bowl XXIX, "and we are going to bring back another championship." 
 The championship that the Cowboys had hoped to win, the unprecedented "threepeat" Super Bowl championship that owner Jerry Jones had demanded upon hiring Barry Switzer to succeed Jimmy Johnson as coach after their clash of egos.
"We will win," Jones had decreed that day. "We must win."
But the Cowboys died with their boots. And while Jimmy Johnson, perched in the Fox network's pregame and post-game studio above the doorway to the Cowboy locker room, reacted clinically on camera, he must have been chuckling quietly about Jones's words that ignited their smouldering relationship despite a two-time Super Bowl reign.
"A hundred coaches," Jones had growled that March midnight in an Orlando, Fla., hotel bar, "could've won with this team."
Barry Switzer evidently was not one of the hundred. Not that Switzer should take the rap for yesterday's 38-28 loss in the N.F.C. championship game. Not even when his 15-yard penalty for bumping an official over the absence of a interference call on Deion Sanders wrecked the drive that might have pulled the Cowboys to within 3 points with more than 5 minutes remaining.
"I don't care if Bear Bryant or Vince Lombardi was coaching," wide receiver Alvin Harper said. "Those things happen."
Those "things" were the interception and two fumbles that enabled the 49ers to drop the Cowboys into a 21-0 hole in less than eight minutes. Even so, Jones, Johnson, Switzer and the Cowboys will always wonder if they would be in the Super Bowl again if Johnson were still the coach. Maybe those "things" would not have happened if Johnson still stalked the Dallas sidelines.
Jones, of course, wouldn't second-guess himself.
"There will be a lot of speculation about if Jimmy were still the coach," the owner was saying now in the Cowboy locker room, "but it doesn't influence me as to any decision I made. I recognized when I made the change that we might not get back to the Super Bowl."
Jones also didn't second-guess Switzer's penalty.
"I've never criticized or second-guessed what any Cowboy coach has done, whether it's play-calling or critiquing an official," the owner said. "I'm not going to start now."
But if Jones did second-guess Switzer, he really would be second-guessing his decision to let Johnson depart and hire Switzer.
Switzer, meanwhile, was growling about the noncall on Sanders, who was jostling Michael Irvin on Troy Aikman's pass near the goal line.
"If the ref makes the same call he made on Deion Sanders that he made on Larry Brown, it's 38-35," the coach said, referring to an earlier pass-interference penalty on the Cowboy cornerback. "Just treat us the same way. Sanders knocked him off stride. It was a mistake to give 'em 15 yards, but I make mistakes, too. The coach is part of the team."
Switzer complained about the soggy Candlestick Park grass even though it had been covered by a tarpaulin during recent rainstorms.
"That's a disgrace to play a championship game on a field like that," Switzer said. "Why didn't the league take charge?"
The N.F.L., not the home team, supposedly is in charge of the field for a conference championship game. Jones also was annoyed.
"I was told they couldn't find any dry sod," Jones said. "If they had put a little more sod in the middle where all that mud was, it would have been better."
But after dropping into that 21-0 hole, the word for the Cowboys was gallant, especially Emmitt Smith, their hamstrung running back.
"I pulled the other hamstring too," said Smith, who was favoring a pulled hamstring in his left thigh before toppling with a pull in his right hamstring in the final quarter. "It may have been a case of overcompensating. I put a lot more pressure on my right leg to save my left. Trying to get the job done on one leg is not easy."
Smith netted 74 yards on 20 carries, including 4-yard and 1-yard touchdown bursts. But after the 21-0 shocker, the Cowboys all but abandoned their running game. Troy Aikman, completing 30 of 53 passes, threw for 380 yards and 2 touchdowns, but had 3 interceptions.
While the 49ers found ways and means to live with the $34.6 million salary cap, the Cowboys didn't. They lost four starters from their two-time champions: guards John Gesek (to the Redskins) and Kevin Gogan (to the Raiders), safety Thomas Everett (to the Buccaneers) and linebacker Ken Norton Jr. (to, of all teams, the 49ers).
Now the Cowboys have more free-agent decisions to make on wide receivers Michael Irvin and Alvin Harper, tight end Jay Novacek, center Mark Stepnoski, defensive end Tony Tolbert and safety James Washington.
"I think the nucleus will be back," said Aikman, who is signed to a long-term contract, as is Emmitt Smith. "But to see what we accomplished taken away because of the way the bargaining rules came down is disappointing."
It's not always the offensive line or the defensive line that makes the difference now. Sometimes it's the bottom line that the salary cap creates. But with the Cowboys, it wasn't only economics. They'll always wonder if it was the egonomics involving Jerry Jones and Jimmy Johnson that made the difference.

GRAPHIC: Photo: The Cowboys' Emmitt Smith sitting dejectedly in the fourth quarter after a hamstring injury forced him out of yesterday's game against the 49ers. (Reuters)

HEADLINE: TELEVISION REVIEW;
A 5-Part Eulogy to the War on Poverty

BYLINE: By WALTER GOODMAN 

 BODY:
"America's War on Poverty," a five-hour series produced by Henry Hampton that begins tonight on PBS, is a eulogy to the nation's effort in the 1960's to raise up the down-and-out, particularly by giving poor people a voice in the way money from Washington was used. As seen in the glow of the memories of Government planners and community organizers, it is a story of idealistic innovators running up against the tough realities of politics in America.
The scene-setting opening hour, "In This Affluent Society," focuses on areas like Appalachia that remained untouched by America's postwar prosperity. Demand for coal, the area's main resource, was down, and automation was eliminating jobs in the mines. Miners tell of finding themselves suddenly without work or usable skills. 
 In the 1950's, 1.5 million Appalachians and 1 million blacks from the Deep South moved north. The program gives faces to the statistics. Some found new opportunities in cities like Chicago; others found just an urban version of poverty, discrimination and a desperation that was brought to national attention by Michael Harrington's influential book "The Other America: Poverty in the United States."
Mr. Hampton, best known for his documentary on the civil-rights movement, "Eyes on the Prize," again uses strong photographs and newsreels, personal experiences and evocative music. Now he shows how hard times sent the civil-rights forces into battle against economic as well as political barriers. In Appalachia there were violent confrontations between miners and mine operators; in big cities of the North there were demonstrations.
The first hour ends with the start of Lyndon B. Johnson's Presidency and the appointment of R. Sargent Shriver, much heard from here, to head what the President called an "unconditional war on poverty in America." But August 1964, when Johnson signed the Economic Opportunity Act, also brought the Tonkin Gulf Resolution, which was used as a basis for increasing America's military involvement in Vietnam. The coincidence, as the narrator suggests, would prove a dire one for Johnson's vision of the Great Society.
The strength of this melancholy retrospective is its front-line view of the domestic war; it brings us close to the action on the ground. Tonight's second hour turns to Mississippi, which one veteran of the civil-rights campaigns recalls as a third-world country. Campaigners tell how the Head Start program, which would change the course of antipoverty efforts, ran into the state's segregationist establishment, led by Senator John C. Stennis.
Tomorrow the focus is on Newark and the clash between Washington planners and their local allies on the one hand and the city's political machine on the other. Similar conflicts developed wherever money and power were at stake, notably in California, where Cesar Chavez began to organize migrant workers
Although critical voices are heard, "America's War on Poverty," which was paid for in large part by liberal foundations, is a tribute to the idea of "maximum feasible participation" by the poor in programs created for their benefit. Long after the considerable achievements and resounding defeats recounted here, the way that principle was applied in practice remains a matter of contention, along with much else about the commotions of the 1960's.
Today the war on poverty has become a war on welfare. You may be persuaded by Mr. Hampton that the idealists were done in by the vested interests, or you may skeptical of the pretensions of the Washington planners and the intentions of some power-to-the-people advocates, or you may simply find the social upheavals of the last 40 years beyond anyone's control. Whatever your reaction, the progression from the dream of opening up opportunities for the poor to the demand for cracking down makes this a troubling history of our times.

HEADLINE: Usery and Owners To Meet Thursday

BYLINE: Special to The New York Times 

 BODY:
Resumption of talks in baseball's labor dispute is not visible on the horizon, but a meeting in Washington on Thursday may lead to a return to the bargaining table.
Bill Usery Jr., the mediator asked by the Clinton Administration to try to lead owners and players to a settlement, has asked the owners' 12-person negotiating committee to meet with him. After that session, he will decide if there is reason to summon both sides to a meeting. 
 "He wants to talk to the owners first to see if it would be useful to follow that up with a joint meeting, but there are no plans on that now," Dick Conn, a spokesman for Usery, said from Washington yesterday.
It was the owners' negotiating team that broke off talks on Dec. 22 after rejecting a new tax proposal from the players. The owners declared an impasse and implemented a salary cap the following day.
Whether the two sides return to the table to negotiate their differences on the game's economic system, the owners' negotiators will very likely ask for a meeting soon so they can present to the union their new rules for replacement players.

HEADLINE: The Mark: Refuge in Risky Days

BYLINE: By NATHANIEL C. NASH, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: FRANKFURT, Jan. 16

 BODY:
With political and economic troubles shaking markets not only in Latin America, but also in European countries like Spain, Italy and Sweden, investors in search of safety and stability have been fleeing to the German mark.
So intense has been the demand for the mark that an index calculated by Germany's central bank, pitting the mark against 18 other major currencies, soared last week to 198.6, its highest postwar level. This bolstered the mark's reputation as rock-solid and underlined the confidence investors have in German monetary policies. 
 The mark dropped slightly today, to 197.8. The index uses a base of 100 for 1973, illustrating that the mark's value has nearly doubled against a basket of other currencies in a little more than two decades.
"Risk-averse investors are pulling out of currencies they see are possible candidates for future depreciation and taking refuge in the mark," said Adrian Cunningham, a senior economist at the Union Bank of Switzerland in London. "People want a safe haven."
Analysts said the flight to the mark, which has included heavy selling of dollars, reflected the belief of many investors that Germany's central bank remained more committed to fighting inflation than even the American Federal Reserve.
The dollar drifted lower today in quiet trading, closing at 1.5289 marks in late European trading, compared with 1.5318 marks last Friday. It slipped to 1.5316 marks a few hours later in New York.
Currency traders' rush to the mark was also seen by analysts as a warning to central banks and governments that their policies aimed at combating inflation would be more closely scrutinized and that governments would be penalized for not reducing budget deficits.
Indeed, the last few weeks have provided roller-coaster rides for currency speculators in Europe, as investors fled the money of nations where the speculators thought that big budget deficits and political instability increased the likelihood of higher inflation in the future.
In Italy, the recent collapse of Prime Minister Silvio Berlusconi's conservative coalition sent the lira into a nose dive. It rebounded slightly today to 1,047 against the mark. The lira had closed Friday at 1,059.6 to the mark, before the Italian Treasury Minister, Lamberto Dini, was asked to form a government to succeed Mr. Berlusconi's.
In Spain, Prime Minister Felipe Gonzalez has come under intense pressure to step down in the wake of allegations that his Government sanctioned hit squads to kill Basque separatists in the 1980's.
That crisis last week pushed Spain's currency, the peseta, down so far that many analysts speculated it would drop out of the European Monetary System. It gained only slightly today.
And in Sweden, the Government introduced a budget aimed at cutting back the welfare state, a week after Moody's Investors Service cut the credit rating on Swedish bonds, citing large-scale social welfare programs that it said were crippling the economy. But currency traders apparently judged the Government's step as too little, too late.
Those developments, coming on top of the dollar's weakness with the economic crisis in Mexico, generated the heaviest buying in months of marks, Swiss francs and Japanese yen, traders said.
Continued nervousness about currency instability in Europe and the problems that an excessively strong mark presents to the European Union were reflected today in a flurry of statements by European finance ministers and officials in Brussels, the union's headquarters, trying to calm the waters.
The Spanish Foreign Minister, Javier Solana, called on his countrymen to help the peseta, while Finance Minster Pedro Solbes said the crisis was over. But when journalists asked Germany's Finance Minister, Theo Waigel, whether the peseta was undervalued at its current levels, Mr. Waigel replied, "On the basis of fundamentals, you can argue that is the case."
There was even rosy talk about the possibility of a common currency among some European countries by the end of next year, apparently aimed at calming investors' fears and underlining the Continent's renewed economic growth.
Jean-Luc Dehaene, the Belgian Prime Minister, said the likelihood of monetary union by the end of 1996 was now "more realistic."
In order for European Union countries like Germany, France, Belgium and Austria to achieve monetary union, as called for under the Maastricht Treaty of 1992, a majority of members, meaning eight nations, must meet criteria that include budget deficits of no more than 3 percent of economic output, and total debt equal to no more than 60 percent of their gross domestic products. Greater tax revenue from strong economic growth means that the governments can more easily reach those goals.
Even if the markets calm down this week, as many predict, analysts warn that investors, after losing heavily in Mexico, Argentina, Italy, Spain and Sweden recently, will insist on credit quality in the future.
Brian Mullaney, chief international economist at Morgan Stanley's London office, said: "Investors will be looking at government reforms to fight inflation and bring down budget deficits in all countries, not just Mexico and Latin America, but in Spain, Italy, Sweden and countries like Thailand. Will governments continue down the road that will insure low inflation?"
Germany, Mr. Mullaney said, "is one of those countries where you are going to be comfortable that inflation will stay low."
"The Bundesbank," he said, "provides you that."

The Economy
 
Alan Greenspan is stepping into the limelight with greater frequency, pushing Congressional leaders to support the rescue plan for Mexico and volunteering solutions to the budget deficit. While previous Federal Reserve chairmen have preferred to keep their policy roles behind the scenes, Mr. Greenspan has been willing to take public stands on issues beyond the Fed's usual direct concerns. That exposure carries risk for a central bank known for its status apart from the executive branch. [Page D1.]
The life insurance industry is trying to improve its image with a new booklet that explains the purchase of life insurance. [D2.] 

International
 
Mexican markets showed a nervousness the day before an auction of Government bonds. But discussions about United States loan guarantees may be more crucial to Mexico's stability. International bankers say Mexico is likely to use the guarantees to raise a substantial sum on the international bond markets. [D1.]
The peso's fall is being felt by Texas retailers near the border, who have seen their sales tumble. Before the devaluation of the peso, Mexican shoppers had turned the Rio Grande Valley into one of the fastest-growing retail markets in the United States. [D1.]
 
Markets

Eddie Bauer is out of the woods. The apparel retailer, known for its outdoor-oriented casual wear, plans to add dress clothes to cash in on what it sees as a consumer trend toward dresswear for the corporate workplace that is more casual. [D4.]

HEADLINE: Mexican Stocks Rise on Eve of Bond Sale

BYLINE: By ANTHONY DePALMA, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: MEXICO CITY, Jan. 16

 BODY:
The Mexican stock market staged another modest rally today but most investors were more preoccupied with Tuesday's scheduled auction of $300 million in Government bonds, which will be widely interpreted as a gauge of confidence in Mexico's ability to recover from the country's economic crisis.
The Mexican market's price index rose 1.19 percent today, closing at 2,243. Mexican stocks traded in New York did not fare as well. Telefonos de Mexico, the leading Mexican depository receipt traded in the United States, was down 87.5 cents, closing at $33.75. 
 The peso lost about 3 percent of its value against the dollar, partly on fears of low demand at Tuesday's bond auction. The Bank of Mexico reported the peso's final exchange rate today as 5.48 to the dollar, a slight drop from this morning's opening rate of 5.35.
All the markets showed a nervousness about the approaching auction.
"People are focusing a lot on tomorrow and perhaps that's a bit misguided," Brian M. Barish, head of emerging market research at Lazard, Freres & Company in New York, said today.
Mr. Barish said the key issue now in regard to the ability of Mexico to pay off its obligations was not the auction but the huge package of loan guarantees for as much as $40 billion that the United States said it was willing to provide. President Clinton and Congressional leaders announced their support for the guarantees last week.
The Finance Minister, Guillermo Ortiz; the president of Mexico's central bank, Miguel Mancera Aguayo, and the Foreign Minister, Jose Angel Gurria, flew to Washington on Sunday to join discussions about the loan guarantees.
International bankers say Mexico is likely to use these guarantees to raise a substantial sum on the international bond market for use in trying to stabilize the peso and paying off maturing foreign debts.
A crucial issue to be determined is how much the United States Government will charge Mexico for guaranteeing the loans. United States officials, speaking on condition that they not be identified, said a proposal was being considered to charge Mexico an additional fee on top of the risk premium. The officials said the Mexicans might have some flexibility in choosing the duration of the loans issued with United States backing.
In New York, Citibank said today that it expected to have firm commitments for a new $3 billion line of credit for Mexico from a group of major international banks by the end of this week.
The bank credit is part of an $18 billion rescue package announced after Mexico floated the peso. That package also includes a $9 billion credit from the United States, $1 billion from Canada and $5 billion from the Bank for International Settlements.
A vice chairman of Citibank, William R. Rhodes, met on Friday evening with President Ernesto Zedillo Ponce de Leon in Mexico City as well as with Mr. Ortiz and Mr. Mancera. Mr. Rhodes said in a statement today that the Mexican leaders "expressed their determination to implement rapidly Mexico's economic program."
Auctions of Mexican Government bonds have gone poorly since the peso was devalued on Dec. 20, suggesting that investors are unwilling to keep their money in Mexico.
The bonds are denominated in pesos but pegged to prevailing peso-dollar exchange rates. The enormous amount of bonds outstanding -- about $28 billion -- and the economic uncertainty in Mexico have led many investors to fear that so many bonds will be redeemed when they come due in the coming months that Mexico might not be able to meet its obligations.
To persuade investors who hold maturing bonds to renew them instead of withdrawing their money, the Government raised interest rates on the bonds to almost 20 percent last Tuesday. But even that was not enough to sway investors.
The Governmment sold fewer than 20 percent of the bonds it offered last Tuesday, touching off near-panic selling on the Mexican stock exchange. Since then, investors have been reassured by the loan guarantees from the United States.
The trading day began in Mexico today with substantial losses, especially after the largest banking-financial group, Banamex-Accival, released fourth-quarter results that showed an extraordinary loss of 1.8 billion pesos. The loss resulted from the devaluation, which shaved more than a third off the peso's value.
The Banamex-Accival report is one of the first from a major Mexican company to reflect fully the impact of the current crisis.
But Kenneth R. James, senior analyst at James Capel Emerging Markets Sales in New York, said that after the initial disappointment, investors changed their reaction to the report. "They were disappointing numbers, but the bank took charges where it could and put itself in a positive position" for the rest of the year, Mr. James said.
The Mexican market also reacted positively to developments in the southern state of Chiapas, where rebels sat down with Government officials on Sunday night to discuss the resumption of peace talks.

HEADLINE: North of the Border, Peso's Drop Is Hurting Stores

BYLINE: By ALLEN R. MYERSON, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: BROWNSVILLE, Tex., Jan. 13

 BODY:
When Bernard L. Levin filled the racks with winter jackets at his Tienda Amigo store a block from the border he had no idea that he was a currency speculator.
But more than two-thirds of his customers come across the border bridge carrying pesos whose value has shriveled. His jackets still hang undisturbed. His saleswomen straighten and tidy counters untouched since their last sweep. His markdown signs seldom stop, or even slow, anyone passing by outside. 
 "I'll tell you," said Mr. Levin, with a strained, sardonic grin. "Business is terrific and one of these days it's going to get better. When a person has to pay almost double for his merchandise overnight and doesn't have much to begin with, they don't buy anything. Our sales are down considerably. Way, way down."
Hordes of Mexican shoppers from near and far had turned the Rio Grande Valley into one of the fastest-growing retail markets in the United States, but they now have decided to stay home and pray for a peso recovery. Those who still cross the border spend less. Some Americans, meanwhile, are heading into Mexico now that the bargains on liquor and medicines are even better.
Texas retailers console themselves by saying how much worse the peso's collapse was in 1982. Some Mexican customers now have American bank accounts and investments or confidence that they can raise their prices and fees fast enough in pesos to compensate for lost purchasing power.
But retailers who are used to double-digit annual sales increases have started this year with sales that are at best flat and in most cases down.
Just a few weeks ago Don Parker, manager of the Sears, Roebuck store in McAllen, Tex., welcomed Sears's top executives, presenting them with binders of charts, maps and articles pointing to an even brighter future. The McAllen area has added two million square feet of store space, equal to 20 stores like his, in just two years.
"Now I am flat since New Year's Day," he said as he scanned spring clothing crowding his leftover winter stock. "I've never been flat." The city of McAllen, fearing lower sales tax receipts, is likely to postpone buying some municipal vans.
The Sears store was still among the busier at La Plaza Mall, the region's largest. Ramiro T. Hernandez, a lawyer from across the border in Matamoras, stood at the entrance, looking over a flier and noting the discounts on wrench sets.
"It was cheaper at three pesos, but it's still O.K.," he said, reflecting on an exchange rate now close to six pesos to the dollar. "I can raise my fees and it won't bother me."
Mr. Parker is all for him, hoping that within a few months Mexican inflation will push peso prices back up and shoppers back across the Rio Grande.
But the border economy leans so heavily on Mexico that residents on the Texas side are also turning more conservative. Oscar Flores found his mind wandering from the Sears display of power tools to the homes he wasn't building. He had designed houses in McAllen for two clients from Reynosa, across the border, but they had just called telling him to hold off on the building.
"It's a mess," he said. "It will not be the year I'm waiting for."
At La Plaza Mall even the most prosperous Mexican shoppers readily agreed. Few were to be found under the crystal chandeliers at Jones & Jones, calculating how many bushels of pesos they would need for the $3,510 Judith Lieber hand-beaded evening bag or the $72,000 Lalique crystal table.
"We're not shopping," said Griselda Escobar, as she dawdled with her husband and two daughters around the Ferragamo and Bruno Magli shoes. They had flown up from near Mexico City for a sale that offered them few bargains. "We're just looking -- at the prices and the conversion," she said.
"Yesterday it was 5.80," her husband, Gabriel, said.
"This morning, 5.90," Mrs. Escobar added.
Mexicans are no less currency-conscious elsewhere along the border. In downtown El Paso, some stores have been closing early and a few have even taken holidays, said Irma Gutierrez, manager of the Payless Shoe Source close to the international bridge. Her store is normally among the chain's 10 busiest, but even after extending a clearance sale for two weeks, her store missed sales targets by about 40 percent last week and 53 percent the week before.
With the peso economy of Texas now stretching hundreds of miles from the border, even the Galleria in Houston felt the absence of Mexican shoppers.
For Mexican stores that cater to Texans, however, the Christmas season continues without end. "Now Your Dollar Buys More," shouted the block letters on the Garcia's advertisement in The Brownsville Herald.
For Winter Texans, retirees who migrate from the North, Garcia's, over the border in Matamoras, was by last week a favorite roost.
"This is the same as in the United States?" asked Eileen Schultz as she piled asthma and arthritis medicine for her and her husband on the pharmacy counter.
"The same," responded the pharmacist.
"You're sure it's the same thing?" she persisted.
"Yes, I'm sure," said Emigdio Manuel Garcia, behind the counter but in a business suit rather than a white coat. "I'm the owner."
Her husband, Art, laid a $100 bill on the counter and got back change. "It went down 40 percent," he said. "We can buy a year's supply for what a month costs in the United States."
Around the store, peso shock was working in reverse. Becky Gibson seldom buys silver, but a necklace and earrings caught her eye. "When they told me how much they were -- $25 -- I thought, 'Why not?' "
Although most merchants on the Texas side still take pesos, the rates often cause buyers to put their selections back.
Mr. Levin, the Brownsville store owner, said he guessed that some Mexicans might simply go downscale. But because he fills his store with manufacturers' remainders and seconds, the only places on the Texas side able to beat his prices -- $12.97 for a winter jacket, $1.97 for a sweatshirt -- are the used clothing shops common along the border.
At Casa Reyna, a few blocks away, nothing on the pipe racks or in the bins costs more than a few dollars. Clothing that arrives in bulk every week goes for $2.75 a pound on Monday, falling to $1 by Saturday.
though usually four-fifths of the shoppers are Mexican, all five who were pawing through the piles one afternoon last week were American. For many Mexicans with watery pesos, even American castoffs are now too dear.

HEADLINE: Dow Up 23.88 Points, to 3,932.34, in Heavy Trading

BYLINE: By ANTHONY RAMIREZ 

 BODY:
The stock market rose for a second day in heavy trading yesterday, hitting its highest level in more than two months. Stock traders persisted in their hope that the Federal Reserve would moderate or even forgo an expected increase in interest rates, which would mean a boon to stocks.
Indeed, a respected market strategist, Michael Metz of Oppenheimer & Company, doubled his model stock allocation to 40 percent from 20 percent yesterday, halving his cash allocation to 20 percent. 
 Mr. Metz also said that in contrast to 1994, when many stocks made their gains for the year in the first few months, "all of 1995's movement may come in the next few weeks."
Yesterday, the Dow Jones industrial average rose to its highest point since Oct. 19. It advanced 23.88 points, to 3,932.34, while the broader Standard & Poor's 500 rose 3.41 points, to 469.38, its highest point since Oct. 31. The smaller-company Nasdaq composite index rose 6.00 points, to 768.16, its highest level since Nov. 15.
Few traders were on the sidelines yesterday, in part because some closely followed corporations report earnings this week. The Intel Corporation will report today and the Microsoft Corporation tomorrow, probably after the market closes, said Tim Grazioso, manager of Nasdaq trading at Cantor Fitzgerald and Company. "You got people paying attention because of that," he said.
At 315 million shares, volume on the New York Stock Exchange was unusually heavy, both for a Monday and a Government holiday. The bond market and some important foreign markets, like Tokyo, were closed.
On Friday, the Government reported a slump in December retail sales, which shook traders' assumption that Fed officials would again raise rates at their policy meeting that begins Jan. 31. The Fed has raised rates to slow an apparently overheating economy, but Friday's report was one of the first major indicators that the economy may already be cooling.
Still, the Fed may still find inflation in data yet to come this month, such as December industrial production and factory use, scheduled for release this morning; November business inventories, set for Wednesday, and December housing starts, to be released on Friday.
Also, higher prices may simply be slow in appearing. For example, Goodyear Tire and Rubber and other tire makers rallied yesterday after Goodyear said it would raise tire prices 3 percent, effective Feb. 15.
At least one thing is certain, Mr. Metz said, and that is that the crisis in Mexico has upended traders' and investors' assumptions about emerging markets around the world, even those in Asia. Much of that disappointed money will move to American stocks, he said.
A wide variety of interest-rate- sensitive stocks rose yesterday, including Wells Fargo & Company and First Interstate Bancorp. Even Wall Street firms, whose businesses have been savaged by rising interest rates, saw their share prices rise. Dean Witter, Discover & Company rose 1 5/8 to 36 1/4; Salomon Inc. rose 1 3/8, to 38 5/8, and Merrill Lynch & Company rose 1, to 37 5/8.
Perhaps most tellingly, traders bid up the prices of two of the stocks most sensitive to interest rate movements: The Federal National Mortgage Association -- also known as Fannie Mae -- the nation's largest source of home mortgages, and the Federal Home Loan Mortgage Corporation, or Freddie Mac, which creates securities out of home mortgages. Fannie Mae rose 5/8, to 72 1/4, and Freddie Mac rose 1/2, to 52 7/8. Traders had bid down the shares on Thursday, when Fannie Mae reported lower-than-expected earnings.
One of the day's biggest gainers was Grey Advertising Inc., which rose 15, to 164, after an stock strategist with Oppenheimer & Company said in an interview with Barron's that the shares were undervalued. Grey said in December that it would take a $35 million noncash write-off that would lead to a loss for the 1994 year but improve its balance sheet.

HEADLINE: Lately, a Much More Visible Fed Chief

BYLINE: By KEITH BRADSHER, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Jan. 16

 BODY:
When the Clinton Administration announced its latest package of assistance to Mexico on Thursday, two men emerged from the back rooms where the deal was being shaped to explain the plan to the White House press corps. One was the new Treasury Secretary, Robert E. Rubin. The other, however, has no formal connection to the Administration: Alan Greenspan, the chairman of the Federal Reserve.
Officials at the notoriously reticent Federal Reserve say they have seldom seen anything like it. Not only did Mr. Greenspan join President Clinton at the White House to persuade Congressional leaders to accept the plan, he also went on to plead to a large gathering of senators and representatives to pass the necessary legislation quickly. 
 And that is not the only time recently that Mr. Greenspan has made himself so uncharacteristically visible. Last Tuesday, he volunteered a specific solution to the nation's budget problems at a joint hearing of the House and Senate Budget Committees. Mr. Greenspan proposed that the Federal deficit could be reduced tens of billions of dollars a year by cutting the annual increases for inflation that are paid to Social Security recipients and veterans with Government pensions.
While Federal Reserve chairmen have long played key policy-making roles behind the scenes, they have usually sought to avoid the political limelight. Unlike Paul A. Volcker, for example, who almost always confined his public statements to matters of monetary policy or broad statements on the budget and economy, Mr. Greenspan is operating much more openly.
Moreover, he is even more visible these days than in previous years. The day after the stock market fell 508 points on Oct. 19, 1987, for example, Mr. Greenspan canceled a long-planned appearance after traveling the previous evening all the way to Dallas for a speech. He returned to Washington, where the Fed did nothing more in public than issue a one-sentence statement to help calm the markets.
At the time, Mr. Greenspan slipped in and out of the White House for many meetings on the market crash that were not publicly disclosed. "He was there," said a Fed official who insisted on anonymity, "but he wasn't this visible."
Mr. Greenspan declined to comment on his heightened activism of the last week. But his willingness to become more visible coincides with deep worries at the Fed about the threat to international financial stability from Mexico's currency crisis, and with frustration at the Fed about the reluctance of Congress to reduce the budget deficit. The broad respect and influence that Mr. Greenspan commands among his fellow Republicans have given him much more power and credibility now that Republicans control both houses of Congress for the first time in 40 years.
Mr. Greenspan's increasing political exposure may carry some risk for a central bank known for its status apart from the executive branch. Long identified as a conservative, Mr. Greenspan ran into considerable flak when he sat next to Hillary Rodham Clinton at President Clinton's first State of the Union address. Many Republicans complained loudly that he had undermined the Fed's carefully nurtured independence. More recently, Representative Jim Saxton, the New Jersey Republican who is the vice chairman of the Joint Economic Committee, said just last week that Mr. Greenspan was giving too much back-channel advice to the Clinton Administration on budget policy.
Mr. Greenspan's close cooperation with the Treasury Department on a foreign policy issue like the Mexico bailout also raises constitutional issues, some critics say, because the Federal Reserve is technically a creation of Congress. The Constitution specifies that the executive branch handles foreign affairs, and Federal Reserve officials have long emphasized that for this reason, they only intervene in foreign exchange markets under instructions from the Treasury Department.
"It's troublesome to see the chairman of the Federal Reserve leading the charge on an issue on Capitol Hill," said Walker Todd, a former lawyer at the Federal Reserve Banks of New York and Cleveland. The reason is "that it looks like the Federal Reserve has become part of the executive branch when he does that."
To be sure, there is plenty of precedent for Mr. Greenspan's involvement in an international financial crisis. Mr. Volcker, the chairman of the Federal Reserve from 1979 until Mr. Greenspan replaced him in 1987, was active behind the scenes during the last bailout of Mexico in 1982. And some would say Mr. Greenspan's visibility may ultimately prove more helpful to the situation than Mr. Volcker's obscurity.
In an appearance before the House Budget Committee last summer, Mr. Greenspan described his philosophy on contacts between the Fed and the White House.
"What actually happens and what should happen is that there should be a coordinated policy between the central bank and the executive branch, because there is one economy and there is one government," he said. "There is, nonetheless, a very crucial issue that the Federal Reserve has to be independent in its actions and as an institution, because if Federal Reserve independence is in any way compromised, it undercuts our capability of protecting the value of the currency in the society."
At that same hearing, Mr. Greenspan said that it was not appropriate for Federal Reserve officials to prescribe specific ways to reduce the budget deficit. But Mr. Greenspan is known to be deeply frustrated that Congress has done little to tackle the explosion in costs for Social Security and other inflation-linked social programs. Indeed, that frustration seemed evident when he volunteered last Tuesday his idea of revising Government measurements of inflation or amending Federal law so that these programs rise more slowly than the Consumer Price Index, which tends to exaggerate the actual rate of inflation.
Current and former Federal Reserve officials point out that Mr. Greenspan has legitimate reasons for being so outspoken on issues outside the Fed's traditional purview. And Mr. Greenspan, while not emphasizing the point during his Congressional testimony, did start with the caveat that "the views I will be expressing are my own and not necessarily those of the Federal Reserve Board."
Edward G. Boehne, the president of the Federal Reserve Bank of Philadelphia, said that Mr. Greenspan's background as a budget expert meant that his views were of legitimate interest to Congress. "If I were a congressman or a senator, I would want to hear what Alan Greenspan" had to say, Mr. Boehne said. Before joining the Federal Reserve, Mr. Greenspan served as the chairman of a two-year Federal commission that reviewed ways to improve the financing of the Social Security program.
Lyle E. Gramley, a former governor of the Federal Reserve Board, said that the problems in Mexico were so severe that Mr. Greenspan had to be involved.
Several former Federal Reserve officials with long memories recalled that Arthur F. Burns, who was the Fed's chairman from 1970 to 1978, had served as chairman of a commission that President Richard M. Nixon established in 1971 to control interest rates and dividends.
Nor has Mr. Greenspan particularly sought to be identified with the Administration. When he stepped to the podium in the White House press room last week, the lights were dimmed. That was so that the television cameras -- which had captured his arrival along with that of Treasury Secretary Rubin -- -- could not record the session. It was supposed to be a background briefing, where the two men were to be identified only as "senior United States officials."
The effect was eerily appropriate: with the lights dimmed, Mr. Greenspan was silhouetted against the glow of a single bulb.

HEADLINE: Merrill Lynch Is Facing Challenge to Credibility

BYLINE: By LAURENCE ZUCKERMAN 

 BODY:
Ever since Orange County, Calif., declared bankruptcy last month, Merrill Lynch & Company has trumpeted its claim that it had retained about $2 billion worth of securities as collateral for loans made to the county while other Wall Street lenders quickly cashed out.
But now, as the county mounts a legal onslaught against the securities firm, what Merrill has tried to portray as a gesture of support for its longtime client has turned into a major challenge to its credibility. 
 At a hearing scheduled for today, lawyers for the county plan to ask Judge John Ryan of bankruptcy court to order Merrill to set aside the proceeds from the remaining sales of collateral into a fund that the county can draw against if it wins its $3 billion lawsuit against the brokerage.
Merrill, under instructions from Salomon Brothers, the financial adviser to the county, has sold about $1.3 billion in securities in the last few weeks. The county says that about $1.06 billion worth of its securities are still being held by Merrill Lynch and should be set aside in a special escrow account. But Merrill, which opposes such an account, says that only about $260 million remains.
In addition to the amount of money that Merrill will be forced to set aside if Judge Ryan grants the county's request, at stake in the disagreement is the trustworthiness of Merrill's public statements since the firm became embroiled in the fingerpointing following the county's financial meltdown.
Although Merrill was not the only securities company to lend money to Orange County, its involvement was by far the largest. Merrill reportedly supplied 95 percent of the derivative securities held in the county's portfolio, according to a 1993 letter written by Robert L. Citron, the former treasurer who resigned after the fund's more than $2 billion in losses began to come to light in early December.
It was Michael G. Stamenson, a Merrill salesman, who played a central role in Mr. Citron's investment strategy that led to the county's bankruptcy.
Last summer Merrill also underwrote $600 million in one-year notes issued by the county. The money was injected into the portfolio at a time when its cash was rapidly drying up -- a fact that was not disclosed in the offering's prospectus.
The Securities and Exchange Commission, the Orange County District Attorney and the United States Attorney in Los Angeles are currently investigating Merrill's actions.
Both Mr. Citron and Mr. Stamenson are scheduled to testify publicly for the first time today, when they are to appear before a California State Senate committee.
Through it all, Merrill has said that it did nothing wrong. As late as last week, Merrill's chairman and chief executive, Daniel P. Tully, held the firm's behavior above Wall Street rivals'.
"Merrill Lynch stood virtually alone in its decision not to liquidate our approximately $2 billion in collateral," he wrote in a memo to the company's employees in Southern California. "Instead, we have cooperated fully with the county and its financial advisers, Salomon Brothers, in their plan for the orderly sale of portfolio assets to stem further losses."
Two days later, the county filed suit against Merrill, seeking $3 billion in compensation. Lawyers for the county said yesterday that they believed Merrill had illegally disposed of the $800 million in securities put up as collateral by the county in exchange for loans.
Merrill's lawyers countered that the $800 million consisted of "reverse to maturity" agreements that allowed the company to dispose of the securities as it wished, requiring it only to make an interest payment to the county when the securities reached maturity. Merrill said the securities were cashed in about a year ago.
Whatever the case, Merrill had difficulty tallying up just how much collateral it received from the county. Early yesterday, a lawyer representing the firm said that the $800 million had never been considered as collateral because the county received the principal from the securities in cash. Merrill had $1.6 billion in reverse repurchase agreements with the county on the day it declared bankruptcy, not including the $800 million, a spokesman said. The $1.6 billion figure had been rounded up to "approximately $2 billion" in the public statements by Mr. Tully and others, he said.
But later in the day, the spokesman said that the $800 million had indeed been included as collateral from the county. Merrill had $2.4 billion in securities when the county filed for bankruptcy, he said. That figure had been rounded down to about $2 billion, he added.
Merrill said that even putting $260 million into escrow, much less the full $1.06 billion Orange County was seeking, would be unnecessarily damaging to its bottom line.
A Merrill executive said that the company would be able to pay any judgment against it, but county attorneys said that they had requested the fund because of concerns about Merrill's credit.

HEADLINE: COMPANY REPORTS;
FIRST INTERSTATE BANCORP (I,N)

 BODY:
First Interstate Bancorp reported a nearly 45 percent increase in fourth-quarter earnings yesterday, an advance that reflected an improved California economy and strong loan growth.
First Interstate, which is based in Los Angeles, made $211.3 million, or $2.65 a share, in the quarter compared with $146.1 million, or $1.78 a share, a year earlier. 
 The results exceeded Wall Street's estimate of $2.55 a share, according to a survey of analysts by Zacks Investment Research.
The company said economic recovery in California helped loan demand. Loans also increased as a result of new marketing programs and acquisitions, it said. Average loans were up $7 billion, from $31.8 billion a year earlier.
Net interest income -- interest earned from loans and investments minus interest paid on deposits and the company's own borrowing -- rose nearly 18 percent, to $621.7 million, compared with the quarter a year earlier.
First Interstate, a Western and Southwestern regional banking power and the nation's 14th-largest banking company, also reduced its bad loans. Foreclosures and loans in default totaled $258.2 million as of Dec. 31, down 16.4 percent from the total a year earlier. (AP)

HEADLINE: Insurers Offer Advice to Consumers

BYLINE: By MICHAEL QUINT 

 BODY:
Stung by flat sales and a declining public image, the life insurance industry is trying to repair the damage with a new booklet that it hopes will make buying life insurance a less daunting task.
The new booklet explains why insurance should be bought, describes the main features of various types of policies and tells customers what to expect from a sales agent. It also suggests questions consumers might ask and concludes with a few tips for buyers. 
 After questioning groups of consumers, industry officials decided to replace an old brochure "which was more about products and less about how to buy," said Barbara E. Bey, vice president at the American Council of Life Insurance, which produced the booklet with other industry groups.
Insurance experts at consumer groups said the booklet offered sound advice to insurance customers, but noted that the glossy, color brochure was no substitute for reforms in the industry. Improper sales tactics -- including the replacing of existing policies with new policies and inaccurate descriptions of life insurance policies as retirement plans -- have led to a wave of investigations by state regulators in the last few years.
Mary Griffin, an insurance expert at Consumers Union, the Washington group that publishes Consumer Reports, praised the booklet for explaining that the primary purpose of life insurance policies is to protect against financial disaster in case of death.
While life insurance policies can help in paying for retirement or education, customers who are not looking primarily for the death benefit "should consider what other financial products are available to meet those goals," the booklet says.
The booklet notes that death benefits from life insurance are not taxed. But it is silent on one feature that many agents use as one of their strongest selling points: the exemption from income tax on the dividends paid by companies on some policies or the accumulation of interest and appreciating stock prices in other kinds of policies.
The booklet is also silent on other issues. It does not mention that companies might contest, or refuse to immediately pay, claims filed within a few years after a policy is issued because of misleading statements about an insured person's health.
The booklet also describes the "illustrations" that agents use to show how some kinds of policies can accumulate cash value from payments that insurers make routinely but are not guaranteed. But Jim Hunt, an adviser to the National Insurance Consumer Organization, noted that despite the descriptions of the illustrations, the booklet still left customers in the dark about judging the illustrations' accuracy and fairness.
"One of the crying needs in life insurance is for uniform disclosure, something like the annual percentage rate in loans, so that consumers could evaluate the policies," he said.
Robert E. Wilcox, Utah's insurance commissioner, said state regulators were nearing completion of new rules to stop some companies and agents from using overly optimistic illustrations as part of their sales pitch. He said regulators wanted to require that illustrations be based on the companies' actual experience and include an example of what would happen if the company reduced the so-called dividend payments on whole life policies, which accumulate value as premiums are paid.
Mr. Hunt also faulted the booklet for understating the high costs incurred by customers who drop whole life policies. The booklet advised against dropping such policies in "early years" when, in fact, Mr. Hunt noted that consumers might need to hold their policies for 10 or even 15 years to reap the full benefits of their policies' value as an investment. That is a result of the high price of sales commissions paid in the early years of new policies.
The insurance council started work on the booklet nearly a year ago, and last week mailed the first of what it expects will be millions of copies to insurance companies for distribution to their customers. The booklet is 23 pages long and can be read in less than half an hour. It is written in the plain English that many consumers will wish they could find in insurance policies. A copy may be ordered by calling (800) 942-4242.
