HEADLINE: FUTURES MARKETS;
Energy Prices Rise Briskly On Colder Weather Outlook

BYLINE: By The Associated Press 

 BODY:
Natural gas prices surged yesterday on the New York Mercantile Exchange, halting a nine-session slide.
Heating oil, gasoline and crude oil prices also rose. Traders attributed the upturn in energy prices to forecasts for colder, more seasonal weather in the northern United States. 
 On other commodity markets, cotton and copper prices fell sharply, reversing their recent trends. The Commodity Research Bureau's index of 21 commodities slipped 0.22 point, to 232.96.
Natural gas for February delivery jumped 6.7 cents, or about 5 percent, to $1.39 for a million British thermal units. February home heating oil rose 0.67 cent, to 47.35 cents a gallon; February unleaded gasoline jumped 1.88 cents, to 56.88 a gallon; February crude oil rose 36 cents, to $17.88 a barrel.
Natural gas prices have been trading at their lowest levels in nearly three years. The declines have been attributed by some analysts to unseasonably warm temperatures in both the Midwest, the main consumption region for natural gas, and in the Northeast, the biggest consumer of heating oil.
The selling ended abruptly yesterday after meteorologists revised their forecasts, which now predict a return to seasonal temperatures later this week.
"There really hasn't been anything to cling onto until now," said George Ellis, a trader at GSC Energy in Atlanta, a division of the Grain Service Corporation. "It's an opportunity to stop the punishment here, to see how cold it gets or not."
Natural gas prices are affected by weather more than other energy contracts because supplies are more than adequate. The American Gas Association, a trade group, reported last week that natural gas in storage was up 8 percent from a year ago.
The March cotton contract fell 2 cents, the maximum one-day loss allowed by the New York Cotton Exchange, to 88.94 cents a pound.
Strong world demand has lifted cotton prices to three-and-a-half-year highs but nervous speculators are starting to leave the market, analysts said.
On the Commodity Exchange of New York, March copper fell 2.3 cents, to $1.3565 a pound.
Steve Platt, a Dean Witter analyst, attributed some of the copper selling to investors growing leery of developing nations in light of Mexico's financial crisis.

HEADLINE: New York City's Undying Deficit: Slash It, and It Just Grows Back

BYLINE: By ALISON MITCHELL 

 BODY:
Although he has already slashed $2 billion from city programs, Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani still faces another budget gap in the next 18 months that will be as large, if not larger.
And those grim figures do not take into account the real possibility of large cuts in aid from Washington and from Albany, where Gov. George E. Pataki is looking for ways to solve the state's own budget gaps and make good on his campaign promise of major cuts in taxes and spending. 
 "It's very, very bad," said City Comptroller Alan G. Hevesi. "The decisions are increasingly painful."
With business, sales and personal income tax collections all running lower than expected in December, the administration's first task is to close a gap now estimated at $600 million to $700 million in the $31.6 billion budget before the fiscal year ends in June.
At the same time, the Mayor must prepare a budget for next year to close a gap ranging from $2 billion, as his budget director predicts, to well above $2.5 billion, as several outside monitors expect.
To get through the year, administration officials are scrutinizing everything from a one-shot debt refinancing to cuts in contracts with nonprofit social-service providers. Next year, they are looking at vast reductions in welfare and Medicaid, as well as the elimination and consolidation of scores of city programs. The municipal unions, which all open new rounds of contract talks with the city this year, have been told that there will be no raises that are not paid for through increased productivity.
The recurrence of annual $2 billion deficits testifies to the depth of the city's fiscal problems. When he came into office a year ago, inheriting a $2.3 billion deficit, Mr. Giuliani, the first Republican Mayor in more than two decades, promised to end New York City's long tradition of expansive government. And he has worked single-mindedly to carry out that pledge, despite demonstrations by constituent groups, a court battle with the City Council and growing criticisms from parents troubled by reductions in school aid and closing youth programs.
He won City Council approval for a budget that reduced city spending for the first time in 16 years, and removed 15,000 workers from the city payroll. When those actions rapidly proved insufficient to deal with the magnitude of the deficit he inherited, Mr. Giuliani called for the elimination of 7,000 more jobs and a raft of new spending cuts. He put nearly $800 million of them in place unilaterally last month.
But an unexpected halt in the region's economic expansion has eaten away at the gains Mr. Giuliani has made, forcing the administration to lower its forecasts of tax revenue twice within a year. Indeed, the midyear deficit the Mayor is now grappling with is one of the largest since at least 1981, when the city switched to its new accounting system, according to Rosemary Scanlon, the assistant deputy state comptroller who tracks the city's economy.
Part of the current deficit stems from management problems or overoptimistic assumptions.
The Giuliani administration had counted on selling the United Nations Plaza Hotel for $65 million and renegotiating airport leases with the Port Authority for another $75 million. But neither the lease negotiation nor the hotel sale has been concluded. The collection of parking fines is millions of dollars below what had been expected, and overtime costs are running over budget.
But the heart of the persistent problems, officials say, is the stagnant regional economy, which is not producing enough job growth and tax receipts to keep pace with the city's rising poverty rolls, health insurance costs and obligations to pay off borrowing.
With New York still feeling the aftereffects of the collapse of the real estate market in the late 1980's, property tax collections are expected to see only a minuscule rise from $7 billion in the current fiscal year to $7.13 billion next year.
"You can't support normal growth in expenses if your most important tax -- the one that produces a third of all revenue -- is growing 1 percent a year," said Abraham Biderman, one of Mr. Giuliani's appointees to the Municipal Assistance Corporation, which monitors the city's finances.
Making matters worse is the slump in the financial industry, which had been the engine pulling the New York region out of recession, but was the primary cause of the poor tax performance in December. "Wall Street has been injured terribly and 17 percent of our tax revenues flow from Wall Street," said Mr. Hevesi.
In contrast, debt service on the city's borrowing has been increasing and is expected to consume as much as 18 percent of tax revenues next year. The rate of increase in the costs of fringe benefits for city workers is outstripping tax growth. The welfare rolls have continued to rise. And officials now believe that the city will have to make $300 million to $500 million more in pension contributions next year than it had expected because of a change in actuarial assumptions.
Some of the analysts who study city finances said they were beginning to worry that the halt in the region's expansion could signal that New York is at the edge of a further economic slowdown. Historically, the city enters a recession earlier than the rest of the nation and takes longer to recover.
But Marc V. Shaw, Mr. Giuliani's new budget director, disputed such negative assessments. "We don't read the revenue picture as the beginning of a downhill slide," he said.
He said that the precipitous drop in property tax collections over the last two years had bottomed out. And he said he did not expect other taxes to continue to run below expectations as they did in December, when they were affected by poor year-end bonuses on Wall Street. He also noted that while sales-tax revenue had fallen below predictions in December, it was still running higher than a year ago. "If it was negative it would raise eyebrows," he said.
Mr. Shaw said the Mayor planned to begin negotiations with the City Council this week on a third round of budget cuts to address the latest deficit of $600 million to $700 million. He said the administration was committed to finding recurring savings to whittle down next year's gap.
But he acknowledged that the administration was considering achieving some savings -- as much as $150 million to $175 million, according to other city officials -- by refinancing debt, a move that provides one-shot budget relief.
One city official who spoke on the condition of anonymity said that the credit-rating agencies had warned that they would look dimly on such a refinancing because it would be the second one in less than a year. How the rating agencies react is important, because they determine the city's credit rating and the amount it can charge for its bonds.
Richard P. Larkin, managing director of the Standard & Poor's bond-rating agency, said of a refinancing: "Most people know what we think of this kind of gimmick. It is certainly not a positive development for the city, and it would cause us concern."
While Mr. Shaw declined to be specific on the administration's other proposals to achieve the savings, he said that layoffs would not be considered, in part because it is too late in the fiscal year for them to produce significant savings. He said the administration would be concentrating on other areas, including cuts in contracts with nonprofit agencies that provide social services.
Administration officials have identified 10 day care centers for closing, saying that the city is paying too much rent for the sites, though Giuliani aides say they hope to make other arrangements for the families using those centers. And the city's Youth Services Commissioner, Alfred B. Curtis Jr., told a Council committee on Friday that 114 youth service agencies around the city were shutting down because they could no longer afford to provide further services after a previous round of budget cuts.
City Council officials predicted that the coming choices would be grim. "We have no choice but to do very huge cuts," said Herbert E. Berman, the chairman of the Council's Finance Committee. "Cuts have to be more Draconian, more severe, and you have to be colder about what you're doing."
Even as the city makes cuts, a major unknown is what will happen to its state and Federal aid. Mr. Giuliani has sought to paint the new political climate in Albany and Washington as an opportunity for the city to rid itself of spending mandates imposed by the other levels of government. Such mandates require the city to provide generous welfare and Medicaid benefits and to comply with environmental protection laws.
But many city officials fear that the Republican Governor and Republican Congress will not just reduce mandates but substantially cut aid to localities, further compounding the city's problems. Mr. Pataki himself faces a $100 million shortfall in the state fiscal year that ends in March and a $4 billion gap in the following year even before he moves forward with his tax cut plans.
In Washington, House Republicans have talked of consolidating scores of Federal programs into block grants that would go directly to the states, but reduce the overall amount of aid.
"The real unknown is Newt Gingrich and George Pataki," said Mr. Biderman. "They have commitments of their own and it's not clear where they are going to be. If they are really serious about the things they are saying, particularly at the Federal level, it could be beyond people's worst expectations."


GRAPHIC: JULY: The 1995 fiscal year begins after the Mayor and the Council agree on more than $1 billion oncuts and other actions to close a potential gap of $2.3 billion in a $31.6 billion budget.
Chronology: "Tracking the City's Deepening Fiscal Problems"
 OCTOBER: After tax revenues fall and anticipated Federal and state aid fails to materialize over the summer, the Mayor proposes a second round of cuts to close a new gap of $1.1 billion that has opened in the budget.
 NOVEMBER: Unable to reach an agreement with the Mayor on cuts to educations, youth services and social programs, the City Council passes its own version of budget cuts, restoring $96 million in spending in some areas and replacing it with equal cuts in other agencies. Mr. Giuliani vetoes the Council's plan, calling it "blatantly illegal."
 DECEMBER: With Mr. Giuliani saying he will ignore the override of his veto, the City Council sues the Mayor for the first time since it was created in 1938. A state judge throws out both the Mayor's plan and the Council's version. As the year ends, theMayor announces that he will unilaterally impose $800 million in spending cuts to keep the budget balanced.
 JANUARY: With business, sales and personal income tax collections all running lower than expected in December, the city faces a budget gap now estimated at $600 million to $700 million in the $31.6 billion budget before the fiscal year ends in June. The size of the budget gap for the next fiscal year has grown to $2 billion, city officials say; outside monitors say it could be well above $2.5 billion. With cuts in state and Federal aid a very real possibility, the gap could grow even larger, forcing still more cuts in services.
 
(pg. B3)

HEADLINE: At an Atlanta Celebration: Hope, Resolve And Memories

BYLINE: By RONALD SMOTHERS, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: ATLANTA, Jan. 16

 BODY:
In what is likely to be her last annual "State of the Dream" speech, Coretta Scott King, the widow of the slain civil rights leader, scanned the international horizon today and said she saw reasons for hope as well as reasons to redouble the efforts to build the "beloved community of Martin Luther King Jr.'s dream."
Late last year, Mrs. King, the 67-year-old founder of the Martin Luther King Jr. Center for Nonviolent Social Change here, announced that she was stepping down as chairwoman and chief executive of the nonprofit, educational organization. Dexter Scott King, 33, the youngest son among the four King children, has succeeded succeed her.
Speaking to nearly 400 people gathered at Ebenezer Baptist Church on the 10th annual observance of the King holiday to mark what would have been Dr. King's 66th birthday, Mrs. King said she saw reasons for hope as crises abated in places like Rwanda, Haiti and parts of the Middle East, even though civil strife continued in places like Nigeria, Bosnia and Russia.
"The most positive development for the state of the dream worldwide since we last met has been the establishment of a great new democracy in South Africa," she said.
Domestically, she said, political leaders seemed focused on budget deficits when the nation had a serious "compassion deficit." Nevertheless, Mrs. King said she was optimistic about the future as she left the leadership of the King center to write about her life after her husband's assassination and to pursue some "long overdue" musical projects that would put her conservatory training as a singer to use.
"I am leaving this ship of hope in good hands," she said of her son.
Since taking over last month, Mr. King has been involved in a public dispute with the National Park Service over control of a main site in the King Historic District here and the right to construct a major memorial to his father.
Only oblique mention was made of that dispute today as some who have been critical of the King center in the dispute, like Representative John Lewis of Georgia and Mayor Bill Campbell of Atlanta, sat on the dais alongside King family members for the official observance of the holiday.
But a reminder of the dispute was just outside the door of the church and across the street. There stood the half-demolished hulk of the city's Martin Luther King Jr. Community Center, which city officials have deeded to the National Park Service over the objections of the King family for the construction of an $11 million visitors' center. If completed, the center is likely to become the gateway to the historic district, setting the tone for an estimated three million visitors a year, and possibly eclipsing the King family's plans for a high-tech, interactive museum.
In a voice strikingly reminiscent of the cadence and phrasing of his father, Dexter King said that Dr. King was part of American history and "belonged to everyone spiritually" but that his family was the guardian of his legacy until his dream was fulfilled.
"My father delivered political freedom and I would like to deliver economic freedom," Mr. King said, sketching a goal that he said the King center was likely to pursue under his leadership. "Had his life not been cut short, I believe economic empowerment would have been the next step and the King center should be the catalyst in that goal," he said. "I'm calling home all those freedom fighters who marched with my father. Dexter Scott King is going to be there with you this time, and we will make it to the promise land."

HEADLINE: G.O.P. Plan For Welfare Is Criticized

BYLINE: By ROBERT PEAR, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Jan. 16

 BODY:
The Clinton Administration today denounced a major element of the House Republicans' welfare bill, which would replace most Federal food and nutrition programs with cash grants to be administered by the states.
The Administration said the Republican proposal would cut at least $5.2 billion -- almost 13 percent --from the $40.8 billion that would otherwise be spent on food assistance next year. 
 In a report analyzing the bill, the Agriculture Department said today that the Republican proposal also would eliminate "all uniform nutrition standards" now set by the Federal Government for school lunches, the Supplemental Nutrition Program for Women, Infants and Children, and other food programs. The programs were developed in response to evidence of malnutrition documented by the Government over the last half century and many studies suggest that they have improved the diets and nutritional status of low-income people, the report says.
The welfare changes are in the proposed Personal Responsibility Act, one of 10 bills introduced by House Republicans as part of their "Contract With America." The bill authorizes a lump sum payment of $35.6 billion from the Government to the states for food assistance next year.
People who now qualify for Federal programs would not necessarily be entitled to assistance under the state programs.
The Agriculture Department said 42 states would lose money under the proposed Republican formula for distributing the food assistance money and eight states -- California, Colorado, Idaho, Montana, Nevada, New Hampshire, Utah and Wyoming -- would gain.
But the report says, "There is no guarantee that Congress would appropriate the full amount authorized in any given year." Senator Patrick J. Leahy of Vermont, the ranking Democrat on the Committee on Agriculture, Nutrition and Forestry, said, for example, that Congress might appropriate less than the maximum of $35.6 billion next year and could substantially reduce the appropriation in later years, under pressure to eliminate the Federal budget deficit.
"I am afraid that the Republicans will vote for the rhetoric but not the reality," Mr. Leahy said. "They will want the symbolism of the 'Contract With America,' but will not live up to their part of the bargain by voting for the full appropriation."
The Republicans say that states will be able to reduce administrative costs far below current Federal levels. Under the Republican proposal, the maximum lump sum grant to the states would be adjusted for changes in population and food prices but not for increases in the proportion of residents who were unemployed or poor.In that case, the Agriculture Department said that "food assistance programs would be unable to respond to changing economic circumstances."
Historically, the report said, "the food stamp and child nutrition programs have automatically expanded to meet increased need when the economy is in recession." But the report said the Republican proposal would burden states with demands for assistance "at precisely the time when state economies are in recession and tax bases are shrinking."
Republicans who support the proposal say Congress could simply appropriate more money for food assistance in a recession or other emergency.
In its report, the Agriculture Department says the Republican bill "could lead to the termination of benefits for six million food stamp recipients" if states tightened eligibility to accommodate the proposed reduction in Federal spending.
The food stamp program serves more than 27 million people a month. Average monthly benefits were $69 a person last year. Congress appropriated $27.7 billion for the program this year.
The Administration asserted that the Republican proposal, by cutting the amount spent on food aid, "would lower retail food sales, reduce farm income and increase unemployment," especially in rural areas.
The Agriculture Department said that the proposal would allow states to provide assistance in cash, rather than as food stamp coupons or as scrip earmarked for food products rich in nutrients like calcium, iron and vitamins A and C.
"Under the proposed block grant," it said, "states could immediately cash-out any and all food assistance programs," in spite of evidence that noncash benefits like food stamps are more effective in stimulating the purchase of food.

HEADLINE: The Mark: Refuge in Risky Days;
Losses for the Dollar

BYLINE: By Reuters 

 BODY:
The dollar slipped against most leading currencies yesterday.
Trading was thin because banks in the United States were closed in observance of the birthday of the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr., and markets in Japan were closed for a holiday there, Adult Day. 
 Some traders attributed the weakness in the dollar to speculation that the Federal Reserve might refrain from raising short-term interest rates later this month, as had been expected. Higher interest rates typically strengthen the dollar by making investments in dollar-denominated securities more attractive than those from abroad.
"There is now a 50-50 chance the Fed will hike rates," said Steven Jury, chief currency dealer at Union Bank of Switzerland in New York, "and that has caused sentiment to turn a bit negative toward the dollar in the past few days."
In late New York trading, the dollar fell to 1.5316 German marks, from 1.5337 marks on Friday. The dollar sagged to 98.05 Japanese yen, its lowest level since Nov. 23, before recovering to 98.42 yen, down from 98.50 yen on Friday.
It also fell to 1.2835 Swiss francs, from 1.2880 francs on Friday. The British pound edged up to $1.5683 from $1.5680.

SECTION: Section A; Page 18; Column 1; Editorial Desk 

LENGTH: 610 words

HEADLINE: Go After Corporate Welfare

 BODY:
Republicans will have to cut over $1 trillion out of the Federal budget over seven years in order to pay for their promise to cut taxes and balance the budget. If Social Security and defense are exempted, as many Republican leaders insist, that means the remaining programs must be cut by 30 to 40 percent. This benighted pledge, if fulfilled, will wreck Government programs, good and bad.
The damage could be mitigated by requiring defense to absorb its fair share of the cuts, as this page has urged -- and by eliminating the huge, unjustified Federal subsidies and tax breaks doled out every year to wealthy companies and other special interests. 
 Republicans have already declared war on Aid to Dependent Children and other forms of welfare -- including food stamps, housing assistance and child nutrition -- that cost about $50 billion a year. Secretary of Labor Robert Reich challenges them to go after another form of welfare, equally large or larger, which he mockingly labels "Aid to Dependent Corporations." Corporate welfare, according to a meticulous though partial list drawn up by the Democratic Leadership Council, exceeds $40 billion a year. The Leadership Council estimates that a thorough search would turn up between $60 billion and $75 billion a year.
That pile of wasteful giveaways should provide plump pickings for John Kasich, the forthright head of the House Budget Committee, and other G.O.P. budget cutters. By going after corporate welfare they can invest more in training, education, infrastructure and scientific research as well as preserve help for the needy -- even as they proceed with their frenzied attack on Federal spending.
Some Federal handouts are justified. Government should underwrite basic research, for example in biotechnology or materials science, that has the potential to enrich society even if any one company is unlikely to translate its discovery into large profits. Government also has a responsibility to provide housing and health care to the poor. But a quick scan of the Federal budget shows scores of subsidies that amount to little more than payback to politically powerful constituents.
A Leadership Council think tank lists 68 tax and spending programs that cost more than $40 billion a year but that, it argues, do little to benefit the economy. A few items on the list can be defended, but most cannot. For example, taxpayers spend billions subsidizing the sale of food to foreigners (to bail out growers) and of timber (to bail out loggers). Washington pays dairy farmers and sugar growers to keep prices high and pays oil companies to drill hard-to-reach wells. Congress subsidizes private utilities that serve rural areas long after electrification of those areas, the original purpose of the program, has been achieved.
None of the beneficiaries of these Federal handouts will relinquish their subsidies without a ferocious fight. The Leadership Council proposes that a commission be set up -- similar to the one that recommended which military bases to close -- to draw up a plan to cut corporate welfare, which Congress would then vote upon without amendment. Even without such a commission, the G.O.P. promises to bring to a vote a menu of cuts that, as Mr. Kasich has promised, exempts "no Federal program, agency or department." But the Republicans seem allergic to closing corporate loopholes.
The G.O.P. owes America more than budget balancing and tax cuts. Despite its anti-welfare rhetoric, it has a duty to protect vulnerable minorities. It must invest in the economy. It must not sacrifice one set of welfare recipients while protecting the fortunes of another.

HEADLINE: Observer;
Those Vital Paupers

BYLINE: By RUSSELL BAKER 

 BODY:
There is probably no solution to the welfare problem. It is the inescapable product of an economic system with which the powers that be are quite content.
This is why politicians and social planners are limited to tinkering with the going welfare system. Attacking the problem at its root would mean admitting it is rooted in the structure of American capitalism. 
 Nobody in public life wants to concede any shortcoming in that structure. Capitalism has just triumphed over its great enemy. Nobody argues with success, least of all in politics. That's why politicians calling for welfare reform sometimes seem to be talking nonsense. For instance:
The health of the American economy obviously depends on keeping a percentage of the work force unemployed. The Federal Reserve Board sees to this by constantly raising interest rates to prevent the economy from "overheating."
Among other things, "overheating" means fewer out-of-work people looking for jobs. This is said to make wages rise and promote inflation. Inflation is now widely considered one of the greatest perils facing the American economy.
By raising interest rates, the Fed's economic wizards choose the lesser evil: better to keep people unemployed than open the door to Ole Devil Inflation. In short, the system requires a degree of permanent unemployment to stay healthy. Something around 5 percent seems to be just about right.
The economy's need for unemployment is gratified not just by the Fed's police work, but also by the existence of a marginal class of people highly qualified to be out of work.
The chief qualification, of course, is lack of education. America is rich nowadays in lack of education. It abounds not merely in the profoundly hopeless ignorance of the high-school student who can't read, but also in the sadder ignorance of smart-enough people whom dismal schools leave unfit for the technological and professional jobs that pay off in this age of sedentary labor.
Despite the need for a safe cushion of unemployed people, despite the existence of an education system highly skilled at supplying such people, despite an established nonwork force of great experience, what do our leaders propose?
To make welfare recipients go to work. The absurdity of this work-or-do-without theory is surely obvious to the politicians.
They know they're talking about people whom the economy has sedulously prepared for unemployment. They know that if any significant number of them should nevertheless find jobs the Federal Reserve Board would have to raise interest rates once more to prevent "overheating" with a dose of disemployment.
Yet what can the poor politician propose as reform? Obviously something is wrong in Welfare World. With the working classes in an uncharitable lather about paying taxes to keep the nonworking class afloat, politicians cannot just stand there. They must do something.
The polls, those eternal polls that have replaced politicians' brains, insist that welfare be reformed.
What a pickle for a pol. Can he say, "The welfare mess exists because our basic economic system demands that we have mess-making people living in society's margins"?
Can he say, "If sound economic reasons didn't require us to maintain a force of marginal people, do you think we would have educated so many for marginal citizenship?"
Not likely. It makes him sound like a malcontent who doesn't like the capitalistic system. Doesn't he know it won the cold war?
So we have this tinkering, which cannot do much about the welfare problem except to buck it back to the states, or counties, or towns, which can't cope with it except by courting bankruptcy or practicing cruelty.
A few politicians are talking about Federal job training programs and improving education. This approach rests on Andrew Undershaft's theory, propounded by George Bernard Shaw in "Major Barbara," that a well-paid citizen working in a factory that makes weapons of war is better for world peace and stability than a pauper taking handouts from the Salvation Army.
That theory founders, however, in a system whose health demands a goodly supply of paupers living on handouts.

HEADLINE: Is the Future of China in Deng's Iron Hand?;
The Copyright Idea

 BODY:
To the Editor:
Re Thomas L. Friedman's Jan. 8 column on Chinese violations of international copyright protections: 
 Mr. Friedman characterizes as "chutzpah" a Chinese publisher's request to Joseph Stiglitz that he write a preface for the pirated edition of his economics textbook, "for which he was receiving no royalties." However, the publisher more likely meant to flatter Mr. Stiglitz, as well as increase the edition's authority.
According to Confucian ideals, the "superior man" does not seek personal profit but strives to improve the world. Through writings, his wisdom is disseminated.
Also, unauthorized reprinting of texts has been a practice of Chinese publishing since the 11th century. Government efforts to restrict it were driven by concerns about textual corruption and ideological control, rather than protecting profits.
Hectoring the Chinese will not shame them into giving up the practice. They will see our tirades as Western chauvinism, refusing to bow to them. Some other negotiating mode must be used instead.
Mr. Friedman's "chutzpah" in flaunting his own pirated-goods purchase, while intended to stir indignation over Chinese pirateering, unwittingly disqualified him from condemning the Chinese for violating "norms of international commerce."
 
JULIA K. MURRAY
Washington, Jan. 10, 1995
 
The writer is associate professor of Chinese art, U. of Wisconsin-Madison.

HEADLINE: Is the Future of China in Deng's Iron Hand?;
Going Back

 BODY:
To the Editor:
William Safire (column, Jan. 9) argues that "Russia is in better political shape than China" because its new openness insures a long-run stability that China's "totalitarian state" can only simulate. Perhaps, but listen to my Chinese friend. 
 Leaving a good teaching job in the United States, he is returning, with his wife and children, to help build a new research institute in Beijing. Other Chinese are doing likewise.
I noted that few Russian and East European emigres have returned. Why was he going? "Two reasons," he said. "First, those people were often ethnic or religious minorities. Even after the fall of Communism, they might have felt oppressed."
And the second reason? "Well," he replied softly: "I'm a Chinese. China was once a strong country. I want to see it strong again someday."
In most countries, ethnicity, more than political liberties, creates the common ground on which political stability rests. The United States is an anomaly: a multiethnic country whose Constitution and civil society are central to its political identity.
Perhaps because Mr. Safire assumes that others are like us, he overstates the extent to which a free press can help Russia find its political bearings. And he misses a key reason for China's stable transition to the industrial age: ethnic nationalism, not some iron control from the top.
 
BRUCE L. REYNOLDS
Editor, China Economic Review
Ithaca, N.Y., Jan. 10, 1995

HEADLINE: QUAKE IN JAPAN: THE OVERVIEW;
DEATH COUNT IN JAPAN QUAKE EXCEEDS 2,000; HUNDREDS STILL TRAPPED IN KOBE WRECKAGE

BYLINE: By NICHOLAS D. KRISTOF, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: TOKYO, Wednesday, Jan. 18

 BODY:
Rescue teams dug frantically through the rubble in western Japan today and contained huge fires that had raged out of control and darkened the skies with smoke, the aftermath of a catastrophic earthquake on Tuesday in which thousands of people were killed or injured.
The earthquake lasted just 20 seconds but heaved trains on their sides, toppled elevated highways and knocked over buildings, some as cleanly as if they had been severed with a knife. 
 Sections of Kobe, a city of 1.4 million people, are in ruins not unlike those in which it found itself at the end of World War II.
Japan's sixth largest city and a major commercial hub, Kobe (pronounced koh-beh) was still smoldering today after firefighters succeeded in controlling dozens of blazes that had engulfed entire city blocks.
The police reported that as of 2:45 P.M. today ( 12:45 A.M. Eastern time), 2,053 people had been confirmed killed and 12,263 injured. In addition, 1,159 people are unaccounted for, the authorities said, so the casualty lists are expected to grow.
A million homes remained without electricity, and thousands of people spent Tuesday night outside, huddled in the open air. They rubbed their hands over bonfires for warmth, afraid to go inside for fear of the hundreds of aftershocks that continue to rattle the area.
The earthquake, which measured 7.2 on the Richter scale, was the worst to strike urban parts of Japan since the great Tokyo Earthquake of 1923. While most quakes recently have struck rural areas, the latest temblor struck a crucial economic zone that encompasses Kobe and Osaka, Japan's second-largest city and a financial center.
Newspapers across the country put out extra editions, and television stations provided round-the-clock coverage of blazing buildings and of rescuers searching through the rubble. In Tokyo, which is 280 miles away and scarcely felt the quake, many people were transfixed by the television scenes and by the grim drama of the efforts to rescue the hundreds of people believed trapped in collapsed buildings.
The quake also seemed to strike a blow at the Japanese psyche, for this is a nation that has prided itself on its earthquake preparedness. People are raised since childhood knowing just what to do if the "big one" strikes, and roads and buildings are supposed to be made to withstand the temblors.
But the quake on Tuesday was a reminder of the power of nature, a way of showing that buildings can be made earthquake-resistant but not earthquake-proof. Many Japanese who had seen images of the damage from the quake a year ago in Los Angeles and had assumed that such a thing could not happen here, discovered that it could.
"The roof just blew off all of a sudden," a woman in Kobe told Japanese television, describing her ordeal. "Glass shattered and flew all over."
Another woman, a store owner, still wearing the pajamas in which she had fled, told the television crew: "My home is all gone. The roof collapsed, and then I couldn't open the door. I had to climb out a window. I can't believe I'm alive."
Prime Minister Tomiichi Murayama said at a news conference today that he would "do everything possible" to help the victims of the quake. The Government sent troops, along with specially trained dogs, to search through the rubble for hundreds of people who remain missing and are believed to be buried in the debris.
Traditionally, most of the casualties in Japanese earthquakes come not so much from the quakes themselves as from the fires or tsunami waves that follow. Today, in contrast, most of the deaths came from people buried in the debris, with fewer casualties attributed to the fires.
The police reported that more than 7,000 buildings had been destroyed, mostly in the Kobe area. Seismologists reported 616 aftershocks, but none of those were serious.
Mr. Murayama said he would visit the disaster area, and he set up a Government task force to help arrange relief efforts. People made homeless by the quake were accommodated in school gymnasiums and other emergency centers, but shortages of food and clothing were reported.
The earthquake cut off from the rest of the world one of the great hubs of global economic activity. Railroads, commerce and shipping all came to a halt. Even corporate headquarters in Osaka could not initially be reached by telephone from Tokyo, and business activity came to a standstill.
Economists said the cost of repairs would be huge, perhaps $10 billion to $20 billion. But in a paradox, they noted that the spending might give a boost to Japan's economy, which is the world's largest after America's and has only recently appeared to be emerging from a long recession.
The Construction Minister, Koken Nosaka, said it would take two or three years to rebuild Kobe. The city's port, through which 12 percent of Japan's exports pass, is inoperable, and shipping is being diverted to ports in South Korea and elsewhere.
Earthquakes have long been central to the consciousness of the Japanese people, who live on a series of seismic fault lines. There are few words so feared in Japanese as "ji shin" (pronounced gee sheen), or earthquake, for devastating temblors have been around in Japan as long as history records.
The last huge earthquake destroyed much of Tokyo in 1923 and killed about 140,000 people in collapsed buildings and in the fire that followed. A temblor and subsequent tsunami wave killed 27,000 people in 1896. A quake in 1948 in Fukui in central Japan killed more than 3,700 people, but it measured 7.1 on the Richter scale, a bit less severe than Tuesday's quake.
Schoolchildren are drilled about how to respond to earthquakes, and the Government has installed a nationwide system of seismic monitors. Whenever seismographs detect a temblor, computers automatically alert bullet trains to stop, so they do not derail at high speed.
The bullet trains had not yet begun to run at the time of the quake on Tuesday, but at least seven ordinary trains were derailed. Most or all were apparently carrying cargo rather than passengers.
The earthquake was centered below Awaji-shima, an island in the inland sea near Kobe and Osaka, and there was no tsunami. Hundreds of buildings were reported toppled on Awaji-shima, and 52 people died there, but the worst damage was in the much more densely populated areas of Kobe.
The earthquake struck at 5:46 A.M. Tuesday (3:46 P.M. Monday, Eastern time), when most people were in their beds. It jammed many doors, making it difficult for people to escape, and phones were out of order, so it was impossible to call for help or to report fires.
One hospital in Kobe collapsed during the quake. Rescue workers pulled 20 people from the rubble but said 20 more were still missing.
Television broadcasts added to the air of alarm by reporting that some experts believed that the latest quake could trigger others, or that Japan may be entering a new stage of greater seismic activity. A series of earthquakes have occurred in the last month, including one that struck rural areas in northern and central Japan on Dec. 28. That measured 7.5 on the Richter scale but killed only two people.
Robert J. Geller, an earthquake expert who teaches at Tokyo University, said there was no evidence suggesting that Japan should expect more strong quakes soon.
"Earthquakes are essentially a random phenomenon," he said. "When you look at it historically, there appear to be periods of greater and lesser seismic activity, but we're unable at this time to say whether that's real or just by chance."
Japanese newspapers reported this morning that an American woman, whom they identified as Bonnie Wong, a resident of the badly damaged city of Ashiya, was among the dead. The American Embassy also reported that an American had died, but did not identify the victim.
Some 10,000 Americans are reported to be living in the Osaka and Kobe area. Most apparently live in Osaka, where international companies like Matsushita and Sharp are situated, and which suffered much less damage than Kobe did.
President Clinton sent a high-level team to Japan today to offer assistance to the country in recovering from the earthquake. He said United States military forces in Japan would also be available to help "in any appropriate way."
Speaking in Los Angeles on the first anniversary of the quake that devastated that city, Mr. Clinton spoke of the "extraordinary fury" of the temblor in Japan and asked his audience of 20,000 to join in a moment of silence for its victims.
"I know all of you join with me in extending our profound condolences to the families of those in the Osaka-Kobe area of Japan who have suffered such a tremendous loss in the last day," the President said.
"You know what they're going through," he told the Los Angeles audience.
Leaders of Taiwan, France, Germany, Italy and Britain also promised aid, and condolences were sent by leaders of countries all over the world.
Only five of the deaths occurred in Osaka, and the damage there was mostly shattered windows and cracked walls rather than collapsed buildings. The Osaka Stock Exchange remained closed for the day because of the confusion in the city.
In Kyoto, the ancient capital of Japan and a tourist center, residents said that they had felt the quake very strongly but that there was little damage. Still, three Buddhist statues at a temple in Kyoto were knocked over and badly damaged, and some walls were cracked.
One of the hardest-hit areas was Nishinomiya, a city outside Kobe. Buildings were knocked down there, and the elevated Hanshin Expressway connecting Nishinomiya with Kobe was knocked on its side.
Until Tuesday morning, some people in western Japan had felt that they were at less risk of a major earthquake than residents of Tokyo. The quake was the worst in the Kobe area in hundreds of years, seismologists said.
Partly because Kobe was so isolated by the quake -- impossible to reach by air, train, car or ferry -- reports were often incomplete and even contradictory. At one point the authorities said 13,000 people had been injured, but then abruptly lowered the figure to 1,300, saying they had made a mistake.
Television stations broadcast lists of the names of people who had been confirmed killed, and people studied them anxiously since it was often impossible to reach family members in the region.
Many Japanese were particularly surprised by the collapse of the expressway in Kobe and Nishinomiya. Prime Minister Murayama, asked about the failure of such structures, said that the priority was relief efforts but that an investigation would be opened later.
"The Government should conduct an exhaustive probe into why these structures collapsed," the Yomiuri Shimbun newspaper said in an editorial today. "It is vital that the national and local governments re-examine facilities and infrastructure considered quake-resistant throughout the nation."

HEADLINE: QUAKE IN JAPAN: PAYING FOR IT;
Whatever the Repair Bill, Insurance Companies Spread the Cost Around

BYLINE: By MICHAEL QUINT 

 BODY:
Japanese insurance companies have learned to protect themselves against massive losses from earthquakes and will bear very little of the burden of rebuilding the area devastated by the earthquake near Kobe.
Instead, Japanese homeowners and companies have been left to bear the brunt of property damages from the earthquake themselves, or to rely on help from the Government. 
 Even so, analysts expect that the latest earthquake will result in higher premiums for individuals and businesses around the world.
"The Californian who was looking to buy a home and was already finding it hard to get coverage is likely to find it even harder as a result of the Japanese earthquake," said Sean Mooney, chief economist for the Insurance Information Institute.
After last year's earthquake in Northridge, Calif., where insured losses are now estimated at more than $10 billion and still rising, most insurers in the state stopped accepting new customers and have applied with state regulators to double the price of earthquake insurance. Allstate, the second largest insurer in the state, yesterday raised its own estimated loss to $1.5 billion.
American insurers, with a few exceptions like the American International Group, do not have enough business in Japan to face significant losses from the earthquake there. But they do rely on other companies, called reinsurance companies, to sell policies that cover very large losses from catastrophes like earthquakes.
Such disasters have become much more frequent in the past several years, and each new event pushes reinsurers to raise their prices or cut back on the amount of coverage they sell. Insurance companies that deal directly with individuals or businesses must then either pass on those changes to their customers or accept greater risk of loss.
Although Japanese are avid buyers of insurance, spending far more per person on life insurance than Americans, they have been forced by their geological circumstances to accept the risk of earthquakes.
Harold Talbot, a managing director in charge of Japanese business at Guy Carpenter & Company, a reinsurance broker, noted that the frequency of earthquakes in many highly developed parts of Japan means that there is not enough insurance capacity in the world to fully insure Japanese households and industry. Guy Carpenter is a subsidiary of the Marsh & McLennan Companies, the world's largest insurance broker.
To limit their risk of loss from earthquakes, Takeshi Sanuki, manager of the New York office of Taisei Fire & Marine, noted that companies follow "very tough underwriting standards," meaning that they simply decline to sell insurance for buildings they think are especially vulnerable to earthquakes. Another defense is to charge very high prices.
Although the Japanese Government is the major backer for an insurance industry pool to share losses of up to $18 billion in homeowners insurance, earthquake insurance is not widespread in Japan. In 1990, the latest year for which data was available, fewer than 8 percent of Japanese homes had earthquake insurance.
Because there is no government safety net for earthquake insurance policies for businesses, Japanese insurers carefully limit the amount they will sell. In the risky Tokyo area, earthquake policies are limited to only 15 percent of the amount of fire insurance. In the district that includes Kobe, earthquake coverage is limited to 30 percent of fire insurance.

HEADLINE: QUAKE IN JAPAN: THE AMERICANS;
One American Reported Dead Among 20,000 in Quake Area

BYLINE: KENNETH N. GILPIN 

 BODY:
Initial reports of American casualties from the earthquake in Japan put the death toll at one, out of an estimated 20,000 in the affected region, the United States Embassy in Tokyo said today. In most cases American businesses with operations in the Osaka-Kobe region said damage to their operations appeared to be slight.
Shortly after news of the quake reached the United States, the State Department set up telephone lines and a task force yesterday to handle calls about the disaster. 
 The embassy in Tokyo withheld details about the American death pending notification of next of kin. The Yomiuri Shimbun, Japan's largest newspaper, said an American woman named Bonnie Wong, a resident of Ashiya City, had been killed. It was not immediately clear whether the newspaper was referring to the person whose death had been announced by the embassy.
American companies spent a good part of yesterday trying to make contact with their employees, and get an initial reading on damage to plants and equipment.
"We have been in touch with 60 percent to 70 percent of our employees, and found no injuries among them," said Fritz Frommeyer, a spokesman for Eli Lily & Company. Lily employs about 700 people in Japan, 250 in the Kobe area. Few of the company's employees in Japan, or in Kobe, are Americans, Mr. Frommeyer said.
But Lily, which investment bankers familiar with Japan said yesterday has the largest presence in the region of any American company, did not escape unscathed.
The company's headquarters, two floors it leased in a Kobe office building, suffered "fairly extensive damage," Mr. Frommeyer said. And a laboratory and production-distribution center in Seishin, a Kobe suburb, was damaged but is still standing.
The Seishin center was scheduled to begin production operations in March. For now, those plans have been put on hold, Mr. Frommeyer said.
Proctor & Gamble, which also has its Japan headquarters in Kobe as well as a paper manufacturing plant in nearby Akashi, where among other products it makes Pampers diapers, said its installations had suffered limited damage.
"We are not aware of any injuries to our employees," said Terry Loftus, a company spokesman.
A joint venture of Texas Instruments with Kobe Steel, Ltd. located 30 miles north of Kobe, also apparently escaped structural damage and injuries to its 400 employees.
Buddy Price, a Texas Instruments' spokesman, said the plant, which is 25 percent owned by the Dallas-based company, had temporarily shut down pending repairs on production equipment that shifted during the quake.
Major oil companies said operations in the area had also been shut down temporarily.
Cynthia Michener, a Texaco spokeswoman, said an Osaka refinery in which Texaco has an interest had been shut down to assess damage, which was thought to be minor.
At the Exxon Corporation, Tom Cirigliano, a spokesman, said all the company's employees "have been accounted for."
Two refineries in the area in which Exxon has a major interest were "slightly affected," Mr. Cirigliano said, adding that gasoline delivery was disrupted and that a "small number" of gasoline stations owned by Japanese affiliates were damaged.
Caterpillar Inc., the giant construction equipment company, was not so lucky.
Yesterday the Peoria, Ill.-based company reported that a joint venture plant it owns with Mitsubishi Heavy Industries Ltd. and a nearby hydraulic excavator design center had been damaged and temporarily closed. No one was injured, Caterpillar said.
The rapid response to the disaster by Washington and the private sector underscores the economic interdependence of the United States and Japan, links that in this case were threatened by natural forces instead of man-made ones like tariffs and quotas.
 
Hot Lines Are Set Up
 By The Associated Press
 The United States Government has a hot line for Americans who want to inquire about the safety of friends or relatives after the earthquake in Japan. That number is (202) 647-0900. To find out about American military personnel in Japan, friends or relatives can call (703) 697-5737.

HEADLINE: Mexico Eases Crisis, Selling All Bonds Offered

BYLINE: By ANTHONY DePALMA, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: MEXICO CITY, Jan. 17

 BODY:
Mexico's halting economic recovery passed a crucial test of confidence today as foreign and domestic investors bought $400 million worth of a type of Government bond that had prompted nervousness only last week.
In a similar auction last Tuesday, only 20 percent of the bonds the Government offered were sold, sending signals of uncertainty that caused Mexican stocks to plummet. 
 But despite the apparent success of today's bond auction, other concerns about the crippling effect of high interest rates on Mexican banks, and the growing list of possible demands that might be attached to a loan-guarantee package from the United States, held down the stock market, which dropped nearly 1.5 percent.
The value of the peso against the dollar strengthened, however. Mexico's central bank gave the closing rate here at 5.3 to the dollar, compared with 5.53 yesterday, and in late New York trading, the peso was a little stronger yet, at 5.25 to the dollar. The currency's devaluation from a level of 3.46 to the dollar less than a month ago set off the current financial crisis.
Today's bond auction was a do-or-die event for Mexico. The bonds up for sale, called tesobonos, are paid off in pesos but indexed to the dollar-peso exchange rate. About $28 billion worth of such bonds fall due this year, and the peso's devaluation created uncertainty about Mexico's ability to meet those obligations. In the last four auctions, held weekly on Tuesday, the Government was unable to sell all the bonds it offered.
Mexican officials were determined not to make mistakes with today's auction. On Monday night, about two dozen fund managers from the United States and other countries were invited to the executive mansion for dinner with President Ernesto Zedillo Ponce de Leon and other high-ranking Government officials.
Mr. Zedillo explained the economic-recovery plan in detail. "People were pretty positively impressed," said an American investor at the dinner.
To insure sufficient demand, the Government initially pared the amount of bonds it would auction to $300 million, compared with $400 million on the block last week. It was reported willing to give virtually whatever interest rate investors demanded to make sure that all the bonds were taken.
Some analysts said they further suspected that Mexico's development bank had taken part in the auction today to make sure that everything offered was sold.
At an auction like today's, investors choose the interest rate at which they are willing to buy bonds. Depending on the demand, the Government then decides how much to sell and at what rate. Today, it settled on rates just shy of 20 percent for bonds with terms of 91 days, six months and a year. Investors had anticipated higher rates, but were satisfied enough to take all $300 million offered as well as $100 million more that was made available when the results looked favorable.
The country's bond problems had been diluted somewhat on Monday, when the Mexican central bank removed $1.06 billion worth of bonds from the market in swaps with Mexican commercial banks.
"All this was taken as a very good signal," said Francisco Blanco, director of analysis at Arka, a brokerage firm here. "But it's still too early to think that this is any kind of lasting trend."
On the stock exchange today, the benchmark index fell 33.52 points, closing at 2,209.49
An explanation was offered by Jaime Campbell of C.B.I. brokerage here. "The market is tired," he said. "The bottom fell out last Wednesday, and then in five days it recuperated about 15 percent. You shouldn't be ashamed of taking a profit of 15 percent in one week."
Many investors remain worried about details of the loan-guarantee package from Washington. The United States has not yet made clear what Mexico will pay for the guarantees. American officials have said it could be as much as 10 percent of the loans.
Many Mexicans have been offended by reports that some members of the United States Congress are seeking further concessions from Mexico like commitments to reduce illegal immigration or to use Mexican oil revenue as collateral.
In an interview today in El Financiero, a business daily here, the central bank's president, Miguel Mancera Aguayo, said he and the country's foreign and finance ministers had traveled to Washington on Sunday "to explain, not to negotiate" Mexico's needs.

HEADLINE: Mexico Crisis Seen Spurring Flow of Aliens

BYLINE: By DAVID E. SANGER, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Jan. 17

 BODY:
With its $40 billion rescue plan for Mexico running into opposition from members of President Clinton's own party, the Administration told leaders of Congress today that the number of illegal immigrants crossing the border into Texas and California would increase by 430,000 this year if the Mexican financial crisis deepened.
That estimate would mean a rise of 30 percent over earlier projections of illegal 1995 border crossings, as Mexican workers are drawn to a dollar that has become 35 percent more valuable relative to the peso since the devaluation of the Mexican currency began just before Christmas. 
 But the numbers did little to quell growing objections to the rescue. The opposition is led by Democrats who were pressured to vote for the North American Free Trade Agreement in 1993 and who now say American taxpayer dollars should not be put at risk to bail out one of the country's economic competitors.
Under the President's plan, announced last week, the United States would offer Mexico loan guarantees of up to $40 billion, meaning that the Treasury would have to lay out money only if Mexico defaulted on any of its huge borrowings.
The Administration has declined to say how much of a fee, akin to an insurance premium, Mexico will be asked to pay the United States in return for the loan guarantees.
But participants in meetings that lawmakers held on Capitol Hill today with Treasury Secretary Robert E. Rubin and the chairman of the Federal Reserve, Alan Greenspan, said that to build support for the program, the Administration had set a steep price: about 8 percent of the amount of the loan guarantees. That means that if Mexico used the full guarantees, it would pay the United States Treasury about $3.2 billion, money the Government would pocket as a profit if the loans were repaid.
Mr. Clinton's plan was initially endorsed by top Republicans, led by the Senate majority leader, Bob Dole of Kansas. But today Mr. Dole seemed to back away, saying the President should not depend on Republicans to pass legislation authorizing the bailout program unless he could bring along Democrats.
"He needs to work within his party," Mr. Dole said. "We're not going to carry the whole load here and get hung out to dry."
The White House tried to minimize the depth of the opposition and said Mr. Clinton would probably meet with members of Congress on Wednesday to win support. The Administration hopes to bring the authorizing legislation to Congressional votes within a week or so, Administration officials said.
"The President is very encouraged by what he's heard from his Treasury Secretary about the discussions on the deal with members of Congress concerning the loan guarantee package," said Michael D. McCurry, the White House press secretary, who was traveling with Mr. Clinton in California. "They gave a very positive response. It's been very reassuring to the markets and financial experts. Conversations with the Government of Mexico have been very positive, and they understand that we are going to have some concerns that will be raised in the provision of these guarantees. Those discussions are proceeding."
But participants in today's meetings on Capitol Hill provided a less enthusiastic account. By this account, several Democratic lawmakers told Administration officials that they were unconvinced that the bailout would help anyone except wealthy investors who had bought Mexico's short-term Government bonds, which were used to cover the country's growing long-term debt.
"We must not be sending money to Mexico just to prop up a nation with the fastest-growing number of billionaires in the world," said Representative David E. Bonior of Michigan, the House Democratic whip.
Mr. Bonior has asked the Administration to establish much more stringent conditions for the loan guarantees, including promises by Mexico to buy more American products and an agreement that Mexican wages will be tied to increases in productivity, a step that the Mexican authorities fear would fuel inflation in their rapidly growing country.
The tensions the Administration faces within its own party were evident at one session today when Lawrence Summers, the Under Secretary of the Treasury, was asked why the United States was not demanding that Mexico put up collateral, in the form of shares in the nationally held oil company, Pemex, which is considered the crown jewel of the Mexican economy.
"The Government would fall," a participant in the meeting quoted Mr. Summers as responding.

HEADLINE: In Michigan, Uncertainty and Unhappiness Over New Method to Finance the Schools

BYLINE: Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: SOUTHFIELD, Mich., Jan. 17

 BODY:
For two years, the symbol of the need to change the state's method of financing public education was the rural northern Michigan school district of Kalkaska, which ran out of money in March 1993 and closed until the fall term. Voters in the district had repeatedly refused to raise their property taxes, which financed education.
So it might seem that Doyle Disbrow, the Kalkaska superintendent of schools, would be an enthusiastic backer of Michigan's new education financing plan, which guarantees the state's 570 school districts at least $4,200 a year for each pupil. 
 He is not.
"I would not support it; I will never support it," Mr. Disbrow said, calling the new system underfinanced.
"It hasn't hurt us," he said of the plan, which went into effect last May and is known as Proposal A, "but it didn't help us either."
Kalkaska, a working-class and resort district of 2,100 students, had been spending an average of $3,800 a year per pupil, Mr. Disbrow said, and much of the extra $400 a pupil it now receives goes for additional costs imposed by the plan.
When Michigan residents voted 10 months ago to amend their state Constitution to replace the 100-year-old property tax method of financing public schools with the experimental state-financed system, they drew national attention.
Republicans, including Patricia A. Woodworth, then the Michigan Director of Management and Budget, praised Proposal A as a model for fairer, securer financing of education.
Admirers of Ms. Woodworth cited her role in Proposal A when Gov. George E. Pataki of New York asked her to leave her Michigan's post to become New York State's budget director. But John Truscott, a spokesman for Gov. John Engler, said last week that she had little involvement with the plan. Through a spokeswoman, Ms. Woodworth declined comment.
The constitutional amendment, which received 69 percent approval, permanently reduced property taxes when inflation is taken into account and raised the sales tax to 6 percent from 4 percent. Taxes on tobacco products were also raised to help finance schools.
Some Michigan educators like Mr. Disbrow note that the plan saddles districts with new expenses, including the costs of employees' Social Security and retirement plans, which had previously been paid by the state.
Educators also worry that the state school tax revenue may not be sufficient when the economy is in a slump. And some administrators fear that the state financing of schools will mean a gradual end to local control and lead to a decline to the quality of education in richer districts.
Ruth Beier, an economic research consultant for the Michigan Education Association, a union representing about 90 percent of the state's teachers, said: "The whole idea was not to reform education as much as it was to cut property taxes. The goal was also to achieve some kind of equity, but there is, in general, a huge misunderstanding of how Proposal A works."
Many voters believed that they would no longer have to pay any school property tax, Ms. Beier said, and were startled to learn after Proposal A passed that they would still have to approve some property taxes for their schools to maintain the same spending per pupil. But districts that spent considerably more than the average are now prevented from increasing spending by more than 1.5 percent a year.
Angry voters here in Southfield, one of Detroit's larger suburban districts, voted down a school property tax renewal last spring soon after Proposal A was passed. But voters changed their minds a month later after the district slashed school spending and pleaded with residents.
The Administration of Governor Engler, a Republican, was not sympathetic. "Southfield was what was wrong with the system before," said Bobbie McKennon, a special assistant to State Treasurer Douglas Roberts, a major architect of Proposal A.
Because Southfield has a lot of commercial property, Ms. McKennon said, "residents were unfairly taking advantage of business" and, as a result, homeowners were paying comparatively little for their children's expensive education.
Under Proposal A, the state based its payments to districts on the rate of their previous spending, so that payments range up to $6,500 a pupil. Districts are required to levy a minimal amount of school property tax, which is slightly less than one-third of the former average. The state is paying 79 percent of total public school costs as against 33 percent previously.
Districts are also limited in how much revenue they can collect from commercial property. If a district that spends more than $6,500 a student wants to increase property taxes, it can usually do so only by leveling additional property taxes on homeowners.
As a result, Ms. McKennon said, homeowners in the Southfield district, which currently spends $9,470 a student, may see very little reduction in their property taxes.
In Birmingham, a fashionable Detroit suburb that spends $10,390 per pupil, Robert Lentz, principal of Birmingham Groves High School, said he feared a loss of autonomy.
"The state is becoming much more of a factor in day-to-day operations, and people who are disbursing the money can call the shots," Mr. Lentz said.

HEADLINE: Russia Assures Anxious U.S. Of Its Commitment to Reforms

BYLINE: By ELAINE SCIOLINO, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: GENEVA, Jan. 17

 BODY:
Russia's Foreign Minister assured Secretary of State Warren Christopher of his country's commitment to democracy and market reform and its determination to negotiate a peaceful settlement of the conflict in Chechnya, but did not say what concrete steps his country intended to take, senior Administration officials said tonight.
The sweeping but vague assurances by Foreign Minister Andrei V. Kozyrev came during a three-hour dinner with Mr. Christopher that opened two days of intense discussions to repair a relationship between the two countries that was declining even before Russia's military offensive in the breakaway region of Chechnya. 
 During the private dinner Mr. Christopher stressed that the Chechnya crisis was having a negative impact on the American public and that Russia needed to find a solution now, a senior official said.
"He gave Kozyrev this strong advice: 'Find a way out of this politically so you can have a normal relationship with other countries,' " a senior official paraphrased Mr. Christopher as saying.
Mr. Kozyrev agreed, but then laid out the obstacles. He said, for example, that Russia wants to hold peace talks, but cannot find Chechen leaders willing to negotiate. And although Mr. Kozyrev said that Russia was willing to allow the Organization for Security and Cooperation in Europe to play a "significant role" in resolving the crisis, he did not say how.
In laying out the Administration's view today, Mr. Christopher struggled to deliver a two-pronged message: praise for Russia's leaders but a criticism of their policies.
It was a difficult exercise, Administration officials admitted, and one that a senior European diplomat portrayed in theological terms. "It's hate the sin but love the sinner," he said.
At a news conference just before dinner with Mr. Kozyrev, Mr. Christopher alluded to several issues that have put the Russian-American relationship on a downward spiral for the past several months: its determination to sell arms to Iran, its eagerness to end the international embargo against Iraq, its refusal to provide information about its chemical weapons program and, most important, its unwillingness to halt attacks on civilians in prosecuting its war in Chechnya.
But Mr. Christopher brushed aside criticism that the United States was too closely tied to Mr. Yeltsin, not only because he is the first elected President in Russia, but also because he is "the most committed democrat in the country who is in a high position."
The assessment of Yeltsin-as-democrat contrasts sharply with an analysis by the Central Intelligence Agency last month, just after the war in Chechnya began.
The analysis concluded that Mr. Yeltsin had "retreated to a small circle of advisers" and laid out four negative scenarios for what it called a "major turning point" for the Yeltsin Government: that Mr. Yeltsin would become a figurehead with hard-liners dictating policy, that he would be deposed by hard-liners who will impose emergency rule and suspend the Constitution, that he would become an "authoritarian" ruler who imposes emergency rule to deal with the Chechen crisis, or that he would dismiss several advisers in an effort to show the world that he is back in charge.
[In Washington, the acting Director of Central Intelligence, William O. Studeman, predicted on Tuesday that the war in Chechnya would bring far-reaching realignments in the Kremlin. "One might perhaps project that the major power brokers may have to be sacrificed," he said.]
The two days of meetings were scheduled at Mr. Kozyrev's suggestion at an all-European summit meeting in Budapest last month, after Mr. Yeltsin infuriated Mr. Clinton by denouncing NATO expansion as anti-Russian and warned of the dangers of a one-superpower world. A few days before, Mr. Kozyrev had stunned NATO by refusing to sign on to a plan for ushering Russia into military cooperation with it.
Mr. Kozyrev told Mr. Christopher that the two of them had to try to get the relationship back on track. A few days later, Russia sent its tanks, planes and artillery into Chechnya, a move that has put the relationship with Washington under its greatest strain since Russia became an independent state.
In Geneva, Mr. Kozyrev and Mr. Christopher have accentuated the positive. Mr. Kozyrev said shortly after arriving in Geneva on Monday that Russia would not allow the "tragedy" in Chechnya to derail relations between Washington and Moscow. "We are not going to talk tough to each other," he said of his meetings with Mr. Christopher.
During their dinner tonight, Mr. Christopher thanked Mr. Kozyrev for Mr. Yeltsin's invitation to Moscow in May for a celebration of the 50th anniversary of V-E Day, the Allied victory over Germany.
Mr. Christopher told him that for the moment, President Clinton could not make a firm commitment.

HEADLINE: A Grand Party as Gov. Bush Is Sworn In

BYLINE: By SAM HOWE VERHOVEK, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: AUSTIN, Tex., Jan. 17

 BODY:
George Walker Bush was sworn in as Texas's 46th Governor today, vowing to "use every resource at my disposal to make the Federal Government in Washington heed this simple truth: Texans can run Texas."
The 48-year-old Mr. Bush, only the state's second Republican Governor since Reconstruction, strode to the podium under raised swords and the six flags of Texas with his wife, Laura, followed by his twin teen-age daughters, Jenna and Barbara. Later they celebrated with a parade, three inaugural balls, a barbecue and a Mexican-style luncheon on the State Capitol grounds for roughly 9,000 of his closest friends. 
 Former President George Bush and his wife, Barbara, sat beaming in the front row of the podium as their eldest son was sworn in.
Governor Bush's predecessor, Ann W. Richards, the Democrat whom he ousted in November's election, was not present at the swearing-in, an absence that aides to her and Mr. Bush said was customary for departing governors. Mr. Bush praised her in his speech for giving "heart to those who battle adversity and hope to those who wonder if opportunity is limited."
Ms. Richards, who vacated the Governor's mansion last week, was in California today working on future plans that are expected to keep her in the public eye, on the speech circuit and in television commercials. She says she has no intention of running for public office again.
After acknowledging his family, Governor Bush introduced five "special guests," the Mexican Governors of states along or near the Texas border.
"Their presence is a clear sign of the importance of the relationship between Texas and Mexico," Mr. Bush said. "Friends bring out the best in each other. May our friendship bring much good to both of our countries."
Mexico gets about half of all its American imports from Texas. During his campaign, Mr. Bush repeatedly emphasized his state's economic and cultural links to Mexico and said he would oppose any measure like California's Proposition 187 aimed at cracking down on services to illegal immigrants.
Minutes before Mr. Bush was sworn in, Chief Justice Thomas R. Phillips administered the oath to the popularly elected Lieutenant Governor, Bob Bullock, a Democrat who has broad powers under the state's constitution. Mr. Bush and Mr. Bullock will have to negotiate a potentially thorny agenda in the coming weeks that includes everything from a welfare overhaul and school financing to a court-ordered Congressional redistricting plan.
Today's inaugural marked the beginning of a new era of political ascendancy for the Grand Old Party in Texas. For the first time, the Governor and two United States Senators are Republicans.
In his brief speech, Mr. Bush offered no specific promises, although he said he wants to usher in an era of "personal responsibility." And he suggested that changing a welfare system that "diminishes personal responsibility and rewards illegitimacy" would be a top priority.
"For the last 30 years, our culture has steadily replaced personal responsibility with collective guilt," he said. "The new freedom Texas seeks must be matched with renewed personal responsibility. The very future of our society depends on it."
The new Governor also contended that Federal requirements were too burdensome on the states, and he vowed to fight for tort revamping that would bring a halt to "junk lawsuits that clog our courts and threaten our producers."
Mr. Bush, who has resigned his position as managing partner of the Texas Rangers baseball club, has never held elective office before.
"He doesn't have much of a track record, but it looks as if his style is closer to his father than to Newt Gingrich in the sense that he's taken relatively modest positions on a lot of issues," said Bruce Buchanan, a professor of government at the University of Texas at Austin. "This guy is more likely to be a moderate centrist than a firebrand."
The invocation at the noontime swearing-in was delivered by the Rev. Billy Graham. After the service, Mr. Bush held a private luncheon at the Governor's Mansion and then attended an inaugural parade downtown.
Among those in the crowd today, dressed in his trademark 10-gallon hat, was Clayton Williams, who narrowly lost to Ms. Richards four years ago in a memorably raucous campaign that made last November's encounter seem downright genteel by comparison. "I made some mistakes," said Mr. Williams, a West Texas oilman. "I've drilled dry holes before. You make them, you fill them and you go forward."
At the inaugural balls and at a gala Monday night, titled "What Texans Can Dream, Texans Can Do" (a line Mr. Bush used over and over on the campaign trail), country was the dominant music form. Among the entertainers were the Dixie Chicks, the Oak Ridge Boys, the Geezinslaw Brothers, and Johnny D and the Rocket 88's.
Asked on Monday if he had taken dancing lessons to prepare for today's celebrations, Mr. Bush said only: "The last time I danced was when I got married. This will be the last time I dance for probably another 17 years."

GRAPHIC: Photo: George Walker Bush and his wife, Laura, striding to the podium where he was sworn in yesterday as Governor of Texas. Mr. Bush is only the second Republican Governor of Texas since Reconstruction. (Associated Press)
