HEADLINE: THE 104TH CONGRESS: LOBBYING;
The 'Contract' Gets New Ally On the Right

BYLINE: By RICHARD L. BERKE, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Jan. 17

 BODY:
Muffling for the time being the Christian Coalition's rallying cries on school prayer, abortion and homosexuality, the group's leader said today that the coalition would mount its most ambitious lobbying drive ever for passage of the House Republicans' legislative agenda.
In an address at the Detroit Economic Club, Ralph Reed, the group's executive director, said religious conservatives deserved credit for the Republican successes at the polls last November. And he made it clear that his group expected to be a central player in pressing for the Republicans' "Contract With America." 
 "We will launch the largest single lobbying effort in our history," Mr. Reed said, "beginning tomorrow when all 50 of our state chairmen fly to Washington to personally work for passage of the balanced budget amendment."
Mr. Reed said the coalition would spend more than $1 million on a lobbying campaign through "phone banks, fax networks, satellite television, computerized bulletin boards, talk radio and direct mail." Just as the group distributed literature in the 1994 elections on candidates' positions on issues, Mr. Reed said it would publish more than 60 million pieces of literature in the next two years "informing people of faith" how lawmakers voted on elements of the contract.
His speech today at a club that is a meeting place for Detroit's business establishment was Mr. Reed's latest effort to win broader acceptance for his organization and to expand its purview beyond a short list of social matters.
"Ralph Reed and the Christian Coalition have cast their lot with the Republican Party," said John C. Green, a political science professor at the University of Akron who is an authority on religious conservatives. "The Republican control of Congress makes it more likely that their agendas will be dealt with."
While the coalition did not embrace the contract -- the blueprint on which many House Republican candidates, including the new Speaker, Newt Gingrich, ran in last year's campaign -- the group's shift in tactics to seek greater legitimacy by highlighting economic issues was apparent within months after President Clinton's election. At that time, the coalition mobilized against the Administration's budget and economic proposals, and later opposed Mr. Clinton's health care plan.
In today's speech, Mr. Reed said his group's concerns are "much broader than voluntary school prayer" and include "limiting the size of government, replacing the welfare state with a compassionate society and securing religious freedom for all."
Mr. Reed also made clear that the Christian Coalition would continue to inject itself into the political fray. In the speech, he recalled the Democratic attacks on religious conservatives in the campaign last fall and called on Senator Christopher J. Dodd of Connecticut, who Mr. Clinton picked last week to head the Democratic National Committee, to "repudiate the religious bigotry employed by your party during the last campaign."
In response, Senator Dodd said that "intolerance of any kind is unacceptable," and that he hoped Mr. Reed's challenge "applies to all political points of view."

HEADLINE: Affirmative Action Challenge Seems to Perplex High Court

BYLINE: By LINDA GREENHOUSE, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Jan. 17

 BODY:
As a vehicle for a major Supreme Court pronouncement on the constitutionality of Government-sponsored affirmative action, a case that came before the Court today appeared an unlikely, even a poor candidate by the end of an hourlong argument that left some of the Court's strongest opponents of affirmative action visibly frustrated.
"We may have a case here in which we can't decide an issue we thought we were going to decide," Justice Antonin Scalia said at one point after Solicitor General Drew S. Days 3d, defending the highway construction program at issue on behalf of the Clinton Administration, said the case might not properly be before the Court. 
 Based on the Constitution's guarantee of equal protection, the case is a challenge by a white contractor to a Federal program that offers a financial bonus to general contractors on Federal projects who subcontract part of the work to small companies that have been certified as "disadvantaged business enterprises."
The white-owned construction company, Adarand Constructors, of Colorado Springs, underbid a Hispanic-owned company by $1,700 on a $100,000 Federal highway guardrail project in southwestern Colorado. But Adarand lost the job because the general contractor chose to earn a $10,000 bonus by hiring the "disadvantaged business," the Gonzales Construction Company.
Under the Federal Small Business Act and a 1987 Federal highway law, the category of "disadvantaged business enterprise" is not based exclusively on race and can include white-owned companies. Companies owned by members of racial and ethnic minority groups are presumed to be "socially and economically disadvantaged," although that presumption is open to challenge as applied to any particular company. Adarand did not bring such a challenge but went to Federal court with its constitutional case instead, challenging what it described as an unconstitutional preference on the basis of race.
Two lower Federal courts in Colorado ruled against the company on the basis of Supreme Court precedent. So when the Justices agreed last September to hear Adarand's appeal, the constitutional and practical stakes were obviously substantial, not only for Adarand and the small business contracting program but for the increasingly tenuous underpinning for Government-sponsored affirmative action in general.
Support on the Court for affirmative action, never enthusiastic even when the Court's membership was markedly more liberal, has dwindled to the vanishing point over the last five years. Minority set-aside programs administered by state and local governments must meet stringent tests under a 1989 Supreme Court decision, City of Richmond v. Croson. Federal Government programs have remained subject to a less exacting standard of review, but the Court's willingness to adhere to those precedents is open to substantial question.
But the moment of truth for Federal affirmative action may not yet have arrived. The argument today made clear that the Adarand case has procedural problems and factual idiosyncracies that threaten either to derail it or to produce a decision of less than sweeping significance.
The most obvious problem is the question of whether Adarand had standing to bring its challenge in the first place, since it failed to show in the lower courts that the Gonzales Construction Company had been included in the "disadvantaged business" category because of race or that it did not deserve to be on the list for racially neutral reasons.
Several Justices suggested by their questions that since Adarand is challenging the presumptive equation of race with economic disadvantage, it should be required to show that the presumption worked to Adarand's disadvantage in this case and that Gonzales did not have another valid basis for its inclusion on the special subcontractor list. The Clinton Administration has strongly argued this point in its effort to minimize the potential impact of the case.
Another factor that makes a sweeping ruling less likely is the operation of the law itself, which does not work as a mandatory set-aside or numerical quota. The Small Business Act program differs from the program the Court considered in its most directly relevant precedent, a 1980 decision called Fullilove v. Klutznick, in which the Court upheld a requirement that 10 percent of the money spent on a Federal public works program go to companies owned by members of minority groups.
Under the Small Business Act, by contrast, the general contractors are not required to participate, and race gives only a presumptive rather than an automatic preference.
William Perry Pendley, the Adarand company's lawyer, had apparently made a strategic decision not to ask the Court to overrule the Fullilove decision in this case, Adarand Constructors v. Pena, No. 93-1841. But that left him in the awkward position of arguing that the Court could strike down the Small Business Act program without disturbing the Fullilove precedent.
"But how can you say that?" Justice Ruth Bader Ginsburg asked Mr. Pendley. "Fullilove involved a straight-out set-aside, with no flexibility at all," she continued. "Here, it's as flexible as possible."
Mr. Pendley replied that the prime contractor is "economically compelled" as a practical matter to agree to hire a minority subcontractor in order to qualify for the bonus, which can be as much as 2 percent of the total contract. He also argued that the law's provision for challenges to be brought to the designation of a minority-owned company as a disadvantaged business enterprise was "not consistent with the real world" because, without subpoena power or the ability to gather information, small white-owned companies like his client could not make such challenges.
Several Justices, including Sandra Day O'Connor, whose vote may well control the outcome of the case, questioned Solicitor General Days closely about the means for bringing challenges. Mr. Days said the regulations for the program listed 25 reasons for removing a company's eligibility to participate. He said that "hundreds" of companies have been removed. But he could not cite a specific challenge that had been brought by a competing subcontractor.
"What limit is there, if any, to the Government's ability to use race as a presumption in its programs?" Justice Scalia asked Mr. Days. He asked whether the space program, with a "critical need for perfection," could employ a presumption that whites, because they are generally better educated, should be hired, although non-whites would be free to try to prove that they were qualified.
"You're overlooking the remedial purpose" of the contracting program at issue, Mr. Days replied. He said that had a "unique and comprehensive power to legislate to remedy the effects of racial discrimination."
"No question," Justice Scalia said, "but can it do it through race-based presumptions?"
Yes, Mr. Days replied, citing the Fullilove case as a precedent.
There was one light moment during the argument, when Justice David H. Souter asked Mr. Pendley to identify the "flaw" in the statute. Justice Souter is a New Hampshire native who, like his fellow northern New Englanders, drops final "r's" from some words and adds them to others.
Mr. Pendley looked puzzled. "Excuse me, the floor?" he repeated.
No, flaw, Justice Souter said, this time in standard English. "Excuse me, it's my regional accent," he said, grinning.

HEADLINE: Mayor Acts To Stave Off School Cuts

BYLINE: By ALISON MITCHELL 

 BODY:
Acknowledging for the first time that the city schools cannot handle further funding cuts before the summer, Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani said yesterday that the city would borrow money to help close its budget gap instead of turning to the Board of Education to find savings this school year.
But the plan prompted a major credit-rating agency to put the city on a negative credit watch, which is one step short of lowering the city's credit rating. The agency, Standard & Poor's, said the city's intention to save $120 million by borrowing to pay off debt owed on Feb. 1 is a fiscal gimmick that simply shifts the cost to future years. 
 If the rating were lowered, that would make it more costly for the city to do business because its bonds, which it issues to borrow money, would be more expensive and more difficult to sell to investors. It would also be a blow to Mr. Giuliani, who has already slashed $2 billion from city spending and has held himself out as more fiscally prudent than his predecessors.
The Mayor's retreat from more Board of Education cuts underscored both the practical difficulties and the political pain of grappling with fiscal problems that have left the city still trying to close a $650 million gap in the fiscal year that ends in June.
Although the Mayor has repeatedly insisted that bureaucratic bloat remains at the Board of Education, his stand has caused him problems with the City Council and brought growing protests from parents.
Sandra Feldman, the president of the United Federation of Teachers, has mounted a campaign to stave off mid-year school budget cuts. Bert Shanas, a spokesman for the teachers union, said Ms. Feldman had spent hours on the telephone with city officials, including Peter J. Powers, the First Deputy Mayor, and Randy L. Levine, the Labor Commissioner.
She even called them from Brussels yesterday morning, where she was attending a conference of an international teachers union.
"The Mayor realized that mid-year cuts at the board would be very destructive to the children and the classrooms," Mr. Powers said at a City Hall news conference, adding that the Mayor's flexibility showed that he meant it when he pledged in his annual address to the Council last week that he was open to other ideas.
"He spoke to a lot of people who believe -- and convinced him -- that it would be destructive at this point in time," Mr. Powers said.
Mr. Powers also acknowledged that eliminating Board of Education workers this late in the fiscal year would bring little practical savings, because it would take weeks to remove them from the payroll and would result in costs for unemployment insurance and cumulative leave time.
At an impromptu news conference earlier in the day, Mr. Giuliani stressed that Schools Chancellor Ramon C. Cortines had agreed to make $120 million in savings in the next fiscal year on top of any other cuts that the city will require then.
Mr. Cortines yesterday praised the Mayor for deferring the cuts. "This is very good news, and I am deeply appreciative of the Mayor's efforts to make it happen," he said.
Other city officials said they saw the Mayor's decision to link the borrowing to relief for the Board of Education as a politically canny way to buy goodwill from the City Council, parents and teachers.
Seeking to prevent the lowering of the city's A minus rating on its general obligation bonds, Mr. Giuliani made his case personally with municipal finance experts from Standard & Poor's in a private meeting on Monday. At the meeting, he spelled out his understanding with Mr. Cortines.
Mr. Giuliani said yesterday that the administration also scaled back the amount of money it planned to save by refinancing city debt from $170 million to $120 million in order to alleviate some of the rating agency's concerns.
Richard P. Larkin, managing director of Standard & Poor's, said that in response to Mr. Giuliani and his yearlong efforts at reducing city government the rating agency "stopped short of a downgrade" and would reconsider the city's bond rating in April.
But in a notice to investors, the agency said New York City bonds had been placed on a negative credit watch, a move that officials in the City Comptroller's office said might make it slightly more costly for the city to market its bonds in February.
Standard and Poor's called the city's move to issue new debt to pay off older borrowing "fiscally counterproductive." But the bond-rating agency also noted that the administration said the borrowing was a temporary measure to deal with an unexpected tax shortfall and was not a step away from efforts to bring longterm balance to the city budget.
The rating agency said it would review Mr. Giuliani's preliminary budget plan for next year and would also scrutinize Gov. George E. Pataki's state budget proposal to determine whether it granted the city relief from mandated social service, health care and educational expenditures.
"By April 1995, plans which continue to incorporate renewed one-shots and gimmicks, or fail to reflect ongoing budget relief from the state, will result in a lowering of the rating to the 'BBB' category for New York City's general obligation bonds," the agency said.
Mr. Larkin said only three major cities carry a bond rating that low or lower: Detroit, St. Louis and Philadelphia.
At a meeting in Syracuse among Governor Pataki, Mr. Giuliani and other big-city mayors, Mr. Pataki said he supported state legislation proposed by the Mayor that would give the city far greater control over education spending.
Mr. Giuliani's proposed bill would allow the Mayor and the City Council to determine how much of the state's aid to schools would go to individual schools, leaving the remainder to pay for administration at the Board of Education.
The refinancing is only one part of the city's plan to close a $650 million budget gap by the end of June. Mr. Powers said the Giuliani administration will seek approval from the City Council to cut $205 million from city agencies and that the administration plans to save another $45 million by deferring raises for managers.
In addition, he said, the city expects that it will receive a $200 million refund from the Federal government for overpayment of Social Security taxes and $80 million from the state for social service programs.
The remaining savings would be made, he said, through book-keeping adjustments.
In one piece of good news for the city, the Finance Department reported yesterday that the preliminary real estate assessment roll for the next fiscal year showed that the city's real estate market had stabilized after four years of decline.

HEADLINE: State Deficit Up Threefold, Officials Say

BYLINE: By JAMES DAO, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: ALBANY, Jan. 17

 BODY:
The Pataki administration said today that the state deficit for the current fiscal year has grown threefold since last month, to $300 million, because of continuing problems in the banking, insurance and securities industries.
Administration officials said they believed that simple belt-tightening by state agencies, like cutting back travel allowances, could close the gap by the end of the fiscal year on March 31, as is required under state law. But they left open the possibility that more drastic measures, including layoffs, might be taken if the deficit continued to grow. 
 Gov. George E. Pataki said today that the deficit was not large enough to deter him from his goal of cutting state income taxes. "I remain committed to closing this gap honestly and to having a balanced budget next year that cuts spending and cuts taxes," Mr. Pataki said in a statement. "New Yorkers will accept nothing less."
Officials with Wall Street firms that rate New York State's bonds said that a $300 million deficit was smaller than some of the deficits the state had to cope with in the early 1990's and that the deficit did not indicate that the state's fiscal situation was dire. In late 1990, the state faced a $824 million deficit that it closed through layoffs and borrowing.
But the Wall Street officials warned that any efforts by the Pataki administration to close the deficit for the current year by borrowing would jeopardize its efforts to have its bond rating, the lowest in the nation, upgraded.
"It woud be taking a step backward," said Richard J. Marino, a director of Standard & Poor's. "That's what got the state into trouble initially: running a continuous defict and then borrowing to cover it."
Mr. Pataki has already taken several steps toward reducing the deficit. His first act in office was to sign an order freezing all nonessential state hiring. He has also released more than 100 state employees appointed by his predecessor, Gov. Mario M. Cuomo. And he has ordered the heads of all state agencies to cut nonessential costs.
State Comptroller H. Carl McCall issued a report today showing that state tax revenues for the first nine months of the fiscal year were actually $428 million lower than expected. But projected spending was also down by $109 million, leaving a shortfall of $319 million.
Mr. McCall said the decline in revenues was most pronounced in personal income, bank and insurance taxes. State officials attributed the decline to rising interest rates, shrinking bonuses on Wall Street, falling profits in the banking industry and lower profits among insurance companies caused by the Midwestern floods and the Los Angeles earthquake.
"This is the second consecutive month where collections were well below expectations," Mr. McCall said. "It indicates negative and possibly very serious economic trends in New York."
Falling tax revenues may also mean that the projected $5 billion shortfall will grow for the next fiscal year, starting April 1. State officials said the current dip in tax revenues could be a temporary problem.
But groups that monitor the state's finances said Mr. Pataki should move quickly to close the current year's deficit by cutting state programs that have produced recurring budget shortfalls.
"This is a serious problem, big enough that it needs major action," said Cynthia B. Green, vice president of the Citizens Budget Commission, a nonprofit fiscal watchdog group financed by businesses. "It's actually a good opportunity for Governor Pataki to get a running start on next year and demonstrate his fiscal leadership."
Just which programs will be cut is likely to be a matter of debate in the Legislature. Though Mr. Pataki can make some unilateral spending cuts, like delaying contracts or equipment purchases, he cannot slash most services without the Legislature's approval.
Mr. Pataki said he planned to release a detailed plan for closing the $300 million deficit on Feb. 1, when he also must issue his proposed budget for the next fiscal year.
In Syracuse, where he was meeting with the mayors of five cities, Mr. Pataki said the growing deficit would be "very difficult" to close. "We're having to look at cuts in the areas where we didn't want to cut," he said.

HEADLINE: Revolt Against School Spending Reaches the Wealthiest Suburbs

BYLINE: By RAYMOND HERNANDEZ, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: IRVINGTON, N.Y., Jan. 15

 BODY:
Martin Halpin and his family left the Bronx two decades ago and moved to this affluent riverfront village to take advantage of one of the most alluring trappings of suburbia: good public schools.
But a few years ago, Mr. Halpin started feeling crushed under the weight of escalating school taxes. His last tax bill climbed to roughly $7,500, and he has had to put off expensive house repairs, like replacing the plumbing in the bathrooms of his modest split-level home. 
 The situation has become so frustrating that Mr. Halpin, like a growing number of residents of wealthy suburbs, recently joined a band of anti-tax protesters. The group here has been fighting budget increases for the Irvington Union Free School District, where the median teacher salary was $67,680 during the previous school year, more than 50 percent greater than New York City teachers were paid.
"I know this isn't going to make me popular," said Mr. Halpin, who worries that his daughter, a high school student, might be affected adversely by his protest. "But the school district is basically pricing itself out of the middle class. It can't go on like this."
Mr. Halpin's about-face illustrates how even the wealthiest suburban communities in the New York metropolitan region and across the country have begun to revolt against school spending -- particularly growing teacher salaries -- after years of supporting public education at almost any expense. In Westchester, one of the wealthiest suburban counties in America, voters rejected 12 out of 34 local school budgets proposed for the 1993-94, the highest rate of rejection in the county in memory, and for this school year, seven were rejected.
In New Jersey, voters rejected 48.4 percent of school budgets last April, the highest rejection rate ever, and in Connecticut, a majority of school districts have won either salary freezes or give-backs from teachers in the last few years.
School administrators have been trying to persuade angry residents that if the local districts are to maintain their quality, they must raise more money through the local property tax to offset state and Federal aid cuts. But the anti-tax fervor has spread rapidly in recent years, even into more prosperous districts that traditionally enjoyed almost unequivocal community support.
In Westchester, the teacher's union in the village of Mamaroneck, where the median salary for teachers was $70,000 last year, reopened its contract and agreed to lower its salary increase amid taxpayer protests. In northern Westchester, three members of a new antitax organization were elected last spring to the school board of the Lakeland School District. And the teachers in the prosperous Long Island village of Sag Harbor have been working without a contract for two years, the longest contractual deadlock ever in the district.
Skirmishes over school spending have broken out across the country in recent years in other affluent suburbs, including Upper Arlington, Ohio, near Columbus; Pittsford, N.Y., outside Rochester; Centerville, a Dayton suburb, and the Denver suburb of Cherry Creek.
"People are starting to say enough is enough," said Eric Hanushek, a professor of economics and public policy at the University of Rochester who recently wrote a book called "Making Schools Work: Improving Performances and Controlling Cost." "Questions about school quality and spending are no longer confined to central city schools."
Many of the antitax protesters simply want to know what they are getting for their money? In addition, local protesters wonder whether suburban teachers deserve to make so much more than their New York City counterparts, who in many cases, teach children with educational disadvantages. The median teacher salary in New York City was $43,014 last year, compared with $62,316 in Westchester, $63,576 in Suffolk County and $61,835 in Nassau County, according to figures from the New York State Department of Education.
"Schools are very important, but it's never been proven that throwing money at education improves it," said Victoria Nikolov, one of two people who was elected to the school board in Irvington with the endorsement of a local antitax group called the Irvington Taxpayers Association. "The problem is we've had school boards that thought no budget was too big."
Nevertheless, school administrators contend that local school budgets have been singled out unfairly, in large part because school taxes are the only taxes subject to voter approval. (City school districts in New York State do not have to submit their budgets to public votes the way districts in villages and towns do.)
The administrators also note that the recent campaigns against school spending are often driven by groups whose members include childless homeowners, many of them elderly people on fixed incomes, who have no immediate stake in the local public schools.
To teachers, the antispending furor has been especially disconcerting. They contend that the current salaries have insured quality education by attracting teachers with talent and experience to suburban schools.
"Teachers are the heart of a good education," said Linda Rosenblatt, a spokeswoman for the New York State United Teachers union. "And I don't think we can afford to lose them to other professions.
"Competitive salaries are what have strengthened many schools in Westchester County, by making them an option for bright and creative people who might have otherwise taken their talents elsewhere."
Consider the case of Joseph T. McLaughlin, a teacher in the Harrison Central School District, which saw its budget for the 1994-95 school year rejected by voters. Mr. McLaughlin defends his annual salary of $80,000 by pointing to his qualifications: He has taught for 25 years, has a master's degree in English and another 60 college credits on top of that. He also spends much of his own time tutoring his students after school without pay, and returning phone calls from concerned parents.
"This is the kind of service people expect and deserve from teachers," said Mr. McLaughlin, who teaches English at Harrison High School. "But we also expect to be compensated for that kind of dedication."
Indeed, teaching is a labor-intensive profession, and suburban teachers are expected to take part in numerous extracurricular activities. As a result, salaries, particularly those of teachers, are the largest expense in any school district. Statewide, 75 percent of school budgets go to salaries, and 40 percent of the budgets go to teacher salaries.
But taxpayer groups have been critical of teachers for taking yearly salary increases at a time when many people in the private sector are being laid off, taking salary cuts or losing their benefits. Some of the protesters have even called for cutting teacher salaries and increasing class sizes.
In short, they have concluded that the role of money in education is largely overrated. "I think there comes a point when you start getting diminishing returns," said Helen Steinman, a member of a grass-roots organization that monitors spending in the prosperous Edgemont School District in Westchester.
William J. Volckman, a financial consultant who lives in the Lakeland School District, typifies the mood of many taxpayers. He moved there with his family about 20 years ago, partly because of the schools.
But he has become increasingly frustrated over teachers' pay in Lakeland. Last year, the median teacher salary climbed to about $61,000, and Mr. Volckman decided that enough was enough.
"What worried me was that educational programs were being cut while salaries kept going up," said Mr. Volckman, who also expressed frustration over his growing property tax bill, which was roughly $10,000 last year.
Eventually, he and several like-minded neighbors met in the living room of one of their homes and formed a group called the Lakeland Taxpayers Coalition. But they didn't stop there.
Last spring, three members of the group, including Mr. Volckman, were elected to the school board, all of them defeating incumbents who had been criticized for not responding to taxpayer concerns.
"We felt it was an overwhelming mandate," said Mr. Volckman, who believes teacher raises should be tied to performance. "We've found that much of the community agrees with us."

HEADLINE: Wall St., So Far, Is Weathering Japan's Disaster

BYLINE: By DIANA B. HENRIQUES 

 BODY:
In the 1980's, it was Wall Street's worst nightmare: A powerful earthquake hits Japan, damaging high-priced real estate. Japanese insurers and other institutional investors pull their money home to finance the rebuilding. And that, in turn, creates a selling panic in the United States securities markets, which had come to rely heavily on Japanese capital.
Yesterday, Wall Street awakened to what seemed to be exactly this financial "doomsday scenario." A devastating earthquake had hit the industrial region around Kobe and Osaka, causing a tragic loss of life and extensive commercial damage. 
 But for the global financial markets, doomsday did not happen yesterday. Still, because of the uncertain reaction of American mutual funds, the lack of widespread insurance coverage in Japan and the cloudy assessment of the scope of the damage and who will pay to repair it, it is still possible that the quake will send aftershocks into the global markets.
As Tokyo assessed the spreading horror of the quake yesterday, stock and bond markets here and abroad remained stable and calm, reflecting both the declining participation of Japanese investors in the American markets since 1988 and the increasing diversity in the international investment arena.
On the Tokyo Stock Exchange, the Nikkei index of 225 stocks lost almost 90 points yesterday. But the Nikkei stablized today, dropping 18.01 points to close at 19,223.31.
In the currency markets, the dollar strengthened modestly against the yen and there were sharp but isolated declines in individual Japanese stocks traded in New York. Otherwise, "if you didn't know there had been an earthquake, you could not have told there was one by looking at the financial markets today," Neal M. Soss of Soss & Cotton, a New York investment management firm, said yesterday.
One reason for that, said David G. Strongin, the international analyst for the Securities Industry Association, is that "the buildup of Japanese capital here in the United States has not been nearly as large as many people had predicted."
Beneath this eerie calm, however, there are financial fault lines that are being watched carefully.
One is the American mutual fund industry. Funds investing in Japan and the Pacific region have expanded enormously in the last five years, and now have assets exceeding $13.6 billion. If the quake or its economic aftershocks cause a panic among fund investors, the "doomsday" sequence might unfold in reverse, with Tokyo suffering from a sudden withdrawal of foreign investment.
"We have yet another example of the risks of investing abroad," said David Resler, chief economist for Nomura Securities in New York. "We learned about the risk of economic instability from Mexico, and about the risk of political instability from Russia. Now, we've learned about the risk of geological instability from Japan."
Another source of uncertainty is the lack of widespread industrial and residential earthquake insurance coverage in Japan. While that defuses the fear that insurance companies will sell foreign securities to cover claims, it also raises questions about how quickly the rebuilding will occur and what impact it will have on corporate balance sheets.
Most analysts predicted that the rebuilding effort in Japan, regardless of who pays for it, would give at least a temporary lift to the economy. "You don't want to be crass at a time of such tragedy," Mr. Soss said, "but the fact is that natural disasters are bullish for the economy. And if there is a global flight to quality, Japan would be one of the markets investors would fly to."
Finally, many longtime Wall Street traders cautioned that the market's reaction yesterday was based on fragmentary information. Most Asian markets had closed before the full magnitude of the disaster was reported, and the situation continued to change during the American trading day. Thus, what seemed like studied calm may have been a "wait and see" attitude.
"The fire is not out yet, and we don't know what the final tally on the damage will be," said Seung Kwak of Scudder, Stevens & Clark, the lead manager of the Japan Fund, the largest American mutual fund investing in Japan, "but clearly there has been a great destruction of wealth."
John Alkire, a principal in Morgan Stanley Asset Management in Tokyo who was raised in the quake-hit region, reported by telephone from Tokyo last night that traders in Japan "are glued to their television sets and radio" trying to assess the damage. "But having said that, this is still not 'the big one,' the one that people have been waiting for and fearing," Mr. Alkire said. "It did not happen, thank God, in Tokyo."
Even as uncertainty lingers, however, it is clear that the role of Japan in the American markets has changed profoundly since the days when the doomsday theories first emerged -- days when Japan was the leading buyer of the Treasury securities that financed the growing Federal budget deficit, and when Japanese investment in the American stock market was substantial.
Today, the financial ties between Japan and the United States are broader and more reciprocal, with funds flowing smoothly in both directions and with Japan investing in many American markets and playing a less dominant role in each.
While net Japanese investment in all American securities totaled roughly $32.5 billion in 1993 and $16.1 billion in the first half of 1994, those figures were inflated by official trades by the Japanese Government, which was trying to support the dollar against the yen. Not since 1987 have Japanese investors been substantial buyers of American stocks.
And the global marketplace itself has become deeper and more experienced in the last 10 years, Mr. Resler said. "Even if you assume that all of the capital required to build back Osaka and Kobe will come out of funds that would otherwise have gone into the global marketplace, the impact on the United States will be minimal," he said.

HEADLINE: Max Schnapp, 90, Labor Activist And an Animal Rights Advocate

BYLINE: By WOLFGANG SAXON 

 BODY:
Max Schnapp, a labor activist turned advocate of pets and their owners, died on Jan. 10 at Interfaith Hospital in Brooklyn. He was 90 and lived in Brighton Beach.
He had a lengthy illness, his family said. 
 Mr. Schnapp founded and was president of the Pet Owners Protective Association. For many years, he was a highly visible, vociferous presence at hearings and meetings about no-pets clauses in leases, rules on owners' having to clean up after their dogs, and the like.
He was born in Austro-Hungary, where he committed himself to political and social causes as a member of the Socialist Party. He came to the United States in 1923 and worked as a knitting-machine mechanic.
In the 1930's, he led strikes and organized factory workers for the International Ladies Garment Workers Union. He also belonged to the International Workers Order and taught unemployed tenants during the Depression how to organize against evictions and homelessness.
In the early 1950's, Mr. Schnapp said, he found that unions had grown too bureaucratic and corrupt for his taste. He shopped around for another cause and decided on animals.
He joined the Sierra Club to save endangered species. He fought for humane kosher slaughter. Eventually, he became involved in just about every aspect of what he called the "humane movement."
He founded his association -- known as POPA -- in 1970. He lobbied for a law that barred the eviction of elderly tenants with pets from rent-controlled apartments and for an end to the sale of shelter animals for research. He also helped to persuade department stores to drop plans for selling dog-skin coats imported from South Africa.
He is survived by his wife of 46 years, Paulette Asche Schnapp; a daughter, Charlotte Klein of Mamaroneck, N.Y., three grandchildren and two great-grandchildren. His first wife, Sarah Felsenfeld Schnapp, died in 1936.

HEADLINE: The Neediest Cases;
Finding Help Until Job Search Pays Off

BYLINE: By ABBY GOODNOUGH 

 BODY:
The leather satchel is faded, creased and bulging with testaments to a grueling job search: resumes, references and rejection letters. Leafing through its contents, Aida D.'s hands start to shake.
She worked at a savings bank for 14 years, starting as a clerk and eventually becoming the head teller. But in 1987, she lost her job to the recession. She found a new position as a bookkeeper, but it lasted only three years, again because of the poor economy. Since then, Miss D. has juggled temporary jobs and searched doggedly for full-time work. 
 So far, she has failed.
"I have been forced to take whatever I can get, and that means temp jobs, waitressing, no lunch break, minimum wage," said Miss D., who is 45 and lives in Flatbush, Brooklyn. "I am out in the cold, and as hard as I try, I can't do anything about it."
After her unemployment benefits ran out in 1991, Miss D. had to apply for public assistance. She joined the Work Experience Program, in which welfare recipients work off their grants by helping out at public offices. She spent the next three years doing secretarial work at two government agencies and received glowing recommendations. But neither could offer her a permanent job.
"They really liked me, and they had all this work for me to do," she said. "But they didn't have the money to keep me."
Last spring, while she worked as a temporary secretary, Miss D. mailed dozens of resumes. At one point, she went from floor to floor in the World Trade Center, filling out several hundred job applications. She kept a record of each one, and the list fills a thick notebook. But her efforts resulted in a pile of rejection letters, which she keeps alphabetized in her satchel.
"I speak Spanish, I have an education and good experience, but nobody wants to give me a break," she said, her voice cracking. "Maybe I ask too many questions. Maybe I look too old."
With her parents dead and her siblings facing their own financial problems, Miss D. did not know where to find help. She stopped receiving public assistance in 1992 and is determined to stay off. In August, as she was falling behind on her rent and utility bills, she went to Catholic Charities, Diocese of Brooklyn and Queens, which is supported by The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund.
For 83 years, the fund has enabled Catholic Charities and six other organizations to help poor, sick, elderly and disabled people throughout the city. Catholic Charities gave Miss D. $387 to pay a month of back rent. Although it did not end her problems, the grant eased her worries, and social workers at the agency offered her emotional support.
"They're very wonderful here," she said during a visit to the charity's Brooklyn South Family Center. "I thank God that I came into contact with people who are so willing to help."
She considers herself a survivor, but at the moment, Miss D. is barely hanging on. Her last temporary job, with a real estate agency, ended on Dec. 16. She caught the flu at Christmas, and because she has no health insurance, she had to use savings to pay for an emergency-room visit. Her typewriter broke several weeks ago, and she has resorted to writing cover letters by hand.
"I would be an asset to the business that hires me," they read in delicate script. "Please give me a chance."

HEADLINE: U.S. Ends A $4 Billion Visit to India

BYLINE: By JOHN F. BURNS, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: NEW DELHI, Jan. 17

 BODY:
A delegation of American business leaders concluded a visit to the Indian capital today after signing documents covering new trade and investment deals said to exceed $4 billion.
Secretary of Commerce Ronald H. Brown, leading the largest American business group ever to visit India, said the deals were just the beginning for American companies ready to exploit India's free-market economic changes. He said a further $12 billion in potential deals between Indian and American companies was under negotiation. 
 Since 1991, India has slashed some of the world's highest taxes and tariffs, eased tight restrictions on foreign investment, and begun dismantling controls on business.
The $4 billion in deals underlined by signing ceremonies here in the last two days -- some in the form of completed contracts, others in the formative stage -- covered industries thought likely to make the fastest strides under the new economy. They included areas like petrochemicals, power generation, telecommunications and transportation, as well as fields barely touched by foreign investment so far, like financial services and health care.
Mr. Brown said the delegation had served as a capstone for a new relationship between India and the United States, making a memory of cold-war-era tensions, when India maintained close relations with Moscow. American companies have been in the forefront in exploring the Indian market, outstripping companies from Western Europe and Japan.
Under the Clinton Administration, stepped-up efforts to promote American exports have focused on 10 emerging markets identified by the Commerce Department. India is among those.
The President, in a letter to Prime Minister P. V. Narasimha Rao delivered by Mr. Brown today, said the United States' goal was for its companies to consolidate the leading position they have established.
According to figures released by officials traveling with Mr. Brown, the United States, with its trade with India valued at $7.4 billion in 1993, was New Delhi's biggest trade partner. With $800 million in direct investment, American companies have also been the largest investors.

HEADLINE: Merrill Tied to Orange County Loss

BYLINE: By LESLIE WAYNE, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: SACRAMENTO, Calif., Jan. 17

 BODY:
The man who managed a $20 billion portfolio for Orange County, Calif., before his risky investment strategy drove the county into bankruptcy, defended himself today as a financial innocent. He blamed his broker, Merrill Lynch & Company, for leading him astray.
"I was an inexperienced investor," declared Robert L. Citron, who served more than two decades as treasurer of Orange County and the man in charge of its investments. It was Mr. Citron's first public appearance since he resigned that post last month. 
 "In retrospect, it is clear that I followed the wrong course," Mr. Citron told a special committee of the California State Senate. "I will carry that burden the rest of my life."
As the battle between Orange County and Merrill heats up in the aftermath of the $2 billion loss that left the county's finances in ruin, Mr. Citron said today that he had relied on advice from "financial professionals," primarily at Merrill, in fashioning an aggressive investment strategy using highly risky securities and borrowed funds. "I followed an investment course that I believed was prudent and suitable," he said.
In response, Merrill denied that it had served as financial adviser to the Orange County investment pool Mr. Citron ran, saying that it "didn't create or implement the strategy."
Paul Critchlow, head of Merrill's media relations department, said Mr. Citron's testimony rings "hollow when he claims he didn't know what he was doing." He said that Mr. Citron "chose to ignore repeated warnings" from Merrill that his huge investment fund -- $7.4 billion in taxpayer money from the county and other local governments supplemented by $13 million in borrowed funds -- was becoming dangerously vulnerable to big losses as interest rates rose.
Mr. Citron also portrayed himself as under pressure from local county officials to produce high investment returns at a time of increasingly tight municipal budgets.
Mr. Citron, who spoke in a calm voice throughout his testimony, singled out two Merrill officials: Michael G. Stamenson, the broker who sold Orange County securities and Charles L. Clough, the firm's chief investment strategist. The investment strategy, Mr. Citron said, was based on advice from Mr. Clough, who he said told him at a breakfast meeting in March that interest rate increases "weren't sustainable." The Federal Reserve, which raised interest rates for the first time in February, subsequently increased rates five more times last year. "I trusted Mr. Clough's judgment," Mr. Citron said.
Economists are notoriously unreliable in forecasting interest rates and nearly all analysts failed to predict the sharp rate increases of last year. Investors lost hundreds of billions of dollars in the bond market crash of 1994, but few investors took the risks that Mr. Citron did. And Mr. Citron, Merrill said, ignored its advice to reduce his borrowing and speculation as interest rates rose.
Mr. Citron, describing what he said were daily telephone conversations with the Merrill broker, said that Mr. Stamenson "repeatedly encouraged the county to engage in greater leverage and to enhance yields by purchasing more derivatives."
Mr. Stamenson, in a prepared copy of his remarks that he delivered later today, described Mr. Citron as "a highly sophisticated, experienced and knowledgeable investor," adding, "I learned a lot from him."
Mr. Stamenson continued: "Neither I, nor anyone else at Merrill Lynch, designed or structured the county's investment strategy or controlled the county's investment. Mr. Citron did."
The Orange County debacle has increasingly come down to a finger-pointing exercise between local officials and Merrill. Just last week, relations soured even further when Orange County filed a $3 billion lawsuit against Merrill, which disclosed that it had been selling off collateral backing investments in the Orange County fund. The bankruptcy court in Santa Ana, Calif., held a hearing on the status of the collateral today, but no ruling was expected.
Mr. Citron contended that Orange County's decision to file for bankruptcy was "premature," saying that the Wall Street investment firms that pulled the rug from under his shaky investments by demanding the collateral they held on the borrowed funds would not have done so had he stayed in office. The Wall Street firms, however, have said they were unable to reach Mr. Citron over the crucial weekend before Orange County filed for bankruptcy on Dec. 5.
Mr. Citron also said he did not pick the county's bond lawyers or underwriters, that he never read the warnings from his opponent for the treasurer's job last July, and that the county's Board of Supervisors never asked him for monthly reports as required by California law.
He defended his investments by saying that not only had bond rating agencies reviewed his portfolio, but the Securities and Exchange Commission had also found nothing amiss in mid-1994.
At the hearing, several state senators and officials expressed incredulity over Mr. Citron's testimony. Matt Fong, the California State Treasurer, said: "Mr. Citron's trying to portray himself as an innocent lamb led to slaughter by investment houses is wrong. He was a knowledgeable, sophisticated investor and he dropped the ball."
George M. Lintz, head of Pacific Matrix Financial Group, one of several advisers to the committee, said: "People didn't want to face the truth. Orange County was hooked on that pool."
To this, Mr. Citron, in a tired voice, responded, "There could be a good deal of validity in that."

HEADLINE: U.S. Industry Pace Spurts, Reviving Talk of a Rate Rise

BYLINE: By ROBERT D. HERSHEY Jr., Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Jan. 17

 BODY:
American industry ran at its highest level in 15 years last month as an unexpectedly strong burst of year-end activity pushed capacity utilization to 85.4 percent, the Federal Reserve reported today.
With output of the nation's factories, mines and utilities rising 1 percent, the biggest gain in two years, many analysts said the industrial sector now had such potential for reigniting inflation that the central bank could not avoid further increases in short-term interest rates. 
 Additional monetary tightening has been widely assumed since the preceding rate increase on Nov. 15 but some analysts had come to think that Mexico's economic crisis and then a report on Friday of flat retail sales for the final two months of the year might cause the Fed to stay its hand.
Higher United States interest rates could make the already-battered peso even less attractive relative to the dollar.
"We continue to expect a policy firming" at the next meeting of the Fed's Open Market Committee, Marilyn Schaja, an economist at Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette, said in a report to clients today. The committee, the policy-making arm of the Fed, is scheduled to meet for two days beginning Jan. 31.
"The Fed will be increasingly concerned about the high levels of capacity utilization in the manufacturing sector and the low rate of unemployment in the labor market," Ms. Schaja said.
For manufacturing alone, output rose 1 percent last month to lift the 1994 gain to 6.7 percent, the Fed's report showed. Mining surged 1.2 percent after two straight declines while the nation's utilities continued to reflect exceptionally warm weather as production fell eight-tenths of 1 percent.
Industrial production expanded at an annual pace of 5.4 percent in the October-December quarter, up from a pace of 4.9 percent in the July-September quarter.
The Fed has raised short-term rates six times since last February. It is known to pay particular attention to the utilization rate, which it calculates itself and which has now surpassed the 85 percent threshold that is often associated with accelerating price pressures.
Paul W. Boltz, a former Fed staff economist who is now a vice president at T. Rowe Price Associates in Baltimore, called today's figures "a matter of serious concern" and said it would be "worrisome" if the Fed did not act.
"The economy has a big head of steam up," Mr. Boltz said. "At least the production side of the economy was booming" as 1994 ended.
Other analysts, though not necessarily contending that a rate rise could be avoided, expressed reservations about the figures, particularly the operating rate.
"I have deep skepticism about the validity of them as predictors of inflation," said David H. Resler, chief economist at Nomura Securities International in New York. He noted that the three most recent occasions in which utilization reached about 85 percent -- in 1980, in the late 1980's and now -- have been times of widely varied inflation: annual rates of about 12 1/2 percent, 4 1/2 percent and 2 1/2 percent, respectively.
Other commonly expressed complaints about the figures are that they do not account for a greater openness of the economy to foreign goods or for rapidly rising productivity in various industries. But the Federal Reserve Bank of Kansas City has examined those factors and found them wanting.
"The capacity-utilization rate in the manufacturing sector remains a reliable indicator of inflationary pressures," a study by C. Alan Garner concluded in the current Economic Review published by the Kansas City Fed. He found that the utilization rate associated with stable inflation seemed to hold at roughly 82 percent.
The 85.4 percent operating rate last month, which was the highest since October 1979, compared with 84.7 in November and 84.3 in October. The utilization rate for primary-processing industries jumped seven-tenths of a point, to 90 percent.
Jerry Jasinowski, president of the National Association of Manufacturers, said the most significant aspect of the rise in output last month was the fact that it was broadly based to include both business equipment -- up nearly 10 percent for the year -- as well as automobiles and other consumer goods.
At the same time, he found "embryonic signs" of an impending economic slowdown, such as a negligible rise in production of construction materials, which is a possible indication that rate increases have taken a toll on the housing market.

HEADLINE: Market Place;
Are merely good sales good enough? Wall Street's appetite rages on.

BYLINE: By Kenneth N. Gilpin 

 BODY:
IN the hot-new-issues market of 1993, few initial public offerings had as much sizzle as the Gymboree Corporation.
Lately, though, signs of lagging demand at the children's apparel retailer are causing some analysts to question whether the stock is on the verge of a cyclical downturn. 
 Doubts are beginning to be heard because early in January, Gymboree reported sales figures that for the third straight month were lower than expected.
Compared with other retailers, the 5 percent gain was respectable. But it wasn't good enough for investors or analysts, who had been expecting gains of 8 to 10 percent. On Jan. 5, the day the results were announced, the stock plunged $4, to $23 a share, in heavy Nasdaq trading, sharply down from a record high of $31.50 in October.
"When you have a strong company that is already valued as a strong company, with a high price-earnings ratio and all the rest, everything has to go right," said Jean-Michel Valette, a managing director at Hambrecht & Quist in San Francisco. "This is the first time they have had single-digit same-store sales increases for three straight months since they went public."
Indeed, over the last 19 months, investors may have gotten a little spoiled.
When it went public on March 31, 1993, Gymboree shares were tentatively priced between $6.50 and $7.50, adjusted for a 2-for-1 stock split last August. But demand was so great that the target price was raised to $10, and the size of the offering increased. By the close of the first day, the stock rose nearly 58 percent, to $15.75 a share.
Though it has been overblown, there has indeed been some basis for the enthusiasm about Gymboree.
This year, analysts expect the company to report revenue of $187 million, more than double the level recorded in 1992, its last year of operation as a private company. Earnings for 1994 are expected to reach $21 million, three times the 1992 level.
Since 1992, the number of Gymboree stores has nearly doubled, to 209. A further 65 are expected to be opened this year.
Analysts said they were not worried about the company's management, products or marketing strategy, all of which are deemed first rate. If Gymboree stumbles, it will be caused by broader forces, they said.
"Consumer spending in apparel has been weak for some time, but has been strong in children's clothing," said Robert Buchanan, a retailing analyst at NatWest Securities. "I am not a genius, and would like to think this is just a few bad innings for this company. But children's clothing sales may be wilting. Since the stock is trading at more than twice anticipated 1995 revenues, there is very little room for error."
Not everyone is cautious.
Returning from a recent visit to Gymboree, Alice A. Ruth, a retailing analyst at Montgomery Securities, which was one of the underwriters of the stock, said, "I am as enthusiastic about this company's prospects as I have ever been," adding that she had no problems with a stock currently trading about 30 times earnings.
Ms. Ruth applauded Gymboree's plans, which include the introduction of a catalogue business, restructuring of franchise operations and a move to expand overseas, probably late in 1996.
Gymboree shares closed yesterday at $24.75, up $1.

HEADLINE: THE MEDIA BUSINESS;
Redford and Showtime Plan New Cable Movie Channel

BYLINE: By BILL CARTER 

 BODY:
The actor and director Robert Redford and executives from Showtime Networks Inc. announced yesterday that they were forming a new cable channel devoted to independent films, a broad category that will include films distributed by Hollywood studios as well as some foreign films and many films that have never been widely seen.
The new channel, which will begin operating in the fall, is a 50-50 partnership between Showtime and Mr. Redford. The financial terms of the deal were not disclosed. 
 Mr. Redford said the channel, called the Sundance Film Channel, had been a dream of his for some time. Mr. Redford has long been associated with independent films through the annual Sundance Film Festival in Utah, which is sponsored by his Sundance Institute.
The new channel will be devoted to "quality films," Mr. Redford said.
"There is enough junk coming out all the time," he added. "These will be films of real quality. There is a lot of wonderful product out there that has never really gotten a chance to be seen."
Among the more than 300 titles on Showtime's roster that will be available are "Four Weddings and a Funeral," "Orlando," "Belle Epoque" and "Raise the Red Lantern."
Mr. Redford defined independent films as those in which film makers were able to execute their own visions. That could range from films made with some connection to Hollywood studios to those made independently on shoestring budgets.
In a telephone interview from Los Angeles, Mr. Redford said he would provide the creative control of the channel, assisted by his staff at the Sundance Institute and employees from Showtime. "I'm going to shape the creative aspects of the programming," he said.
In addition to full-length feature movies, the channel plans to offer documentaries, short subjects, animated films and programs about film makers and the movie-making process.
Winston H. Cox, chairman of Showtime, said the Sundance Film Channel would be offered both as a premium cable channel for which subscribers would be charged a monthly fee and in packages with other premium channels.
"I think you could expect a good audience on the Upper West Side of Manhattan to be willing to pay $6.95 a month for a channel like this," Mr. Cox said. "But in other parts of the country it may have to be marketed in different ways."
Mr. Cox said a sampling of the service would initially be provided to viewers of Showtime and the Movie Channel, which are both owned by Showtime Networks.
"We have created an economic model for the channel," Mr. Cox said. "With direct broadcast satellite expanding and the telephone companies coming into cable faster than expected, we believe there will be distribution for the channel. I can't wait to take Mr. Redford on the first sales call." No cable operators have made commitments yet to carry the channel.
The Sundance Film Channel will be the second cable channel devoted to independent films. The Independent Film Channel, started in September by the Bravo Channel, has a similar format to that described by Mr. Redford and Mr. Cox yesterday.
Indeed, Mr. Redford held negotiations with Bravo executives before that channel was started, said Kathleen Dore, general manager of the Independent Film Channel.
"For the most part we talked with Mr. Redford's representatives from Creative Artists Agency," Ms. Dore said, referring to Hollywood's most powerful talent agency. "Mr. Redford wanted creative control. He wanted to program it himself and he insisted that it have the name Sundance. We became somewhat uncomfortable with the level of Hollywood influence. With Mr. Redford and Showtime involved, we think that channel will be very tied to Hollywood."
Showtime is owned by Viacom Inc., which is also the corporate parent of Paramount Pictures.
Mr. Redford said he chose Showtime because it was "a strong organization with global impact."

HEADLINE: Jimmy Carter, It Turns Out, Is a Poet, Too

BYLINE: By MICHAEL T. KAUFMAN 

 BODY:
Stoically, with the economy of an engineer or a time-study man, the former President kept signing his new book of poems for customers lining up at Rizzoli's bookstore in the World Financial Center. "JCarter," he wrote with a felt-tip pen, paring off the first name so as to squeeze in more signatures in the time allotted.
For two hours yesterday he signed, never even pausing for a drink of water. "He's the best signer I ever saw," said Mary Beth Roche, the director of publicity for his publisher, Times Books. "He's better than Tip O'Neill, better than Kirk Douglas. He not only signs, he makes eye contact. He says 'hi.' " 
 Mr. Carter did indeed say "hi" and "nice to see you" as he maintained a steady pace of about 20 books a minute. And when he had signed the last copy of "Always a Reckoning," he showed no sign of weariness. "The most I ever signed in a single day was 3,700," he said, heading back to a storeroom where, over a sandwich and coffee, he explained how this book was made.
"I've written poetry off and on ever since I was in high school," he said. "I had always been extremely interested in poetry and I used to regret that I just had an engineering and nuclear physics background."
He went on to say that about five years ago, he began to study poetry in a serious way with two mentors, Jim Whitehead and Miller Williams, both poets and professors at the University of Arkansas. He had met them after he left the White House, when they came to offer him their separate poems about his term as President. He liked them and he had them down to his home in Plains, Ga., to lecture.
One of the 47 mostly short poems in the collection deals with that meeting. It is entitled, "Itinerant Songsters Visit Our Village," and it begins:
When some poets came to Plains one night,
two with guitars, their poems taught
us how to look and maybe laugh
at what we were and felt and thought.
After that, I rushed to write
in fumbling lines why we should care
about a distant starving child.
Mr. Carter explained how, under the tutelage of his guides he began to study poetry systematically. "I had always written as an engineer, as briefly and concisely and clearly as possible," he said, "and I never was interested in anything but the most simple words. With poetry I experience kind of a mind expander as I search for the most appropriate word, study the derivation of words and learn what their original meanings might have been."
"I went public in a very cautious way," he said, explaining how, encouraged by the professors, he submitted his poems to such journals as New England Review, New Orleans Review and North Dakota Review, which accepted them. "I asked them not to take note of the fact that I had been President," he said, "and they agreed."
After he received what he described as a good and constructive response, he thought about a book. He selected the 47 poems because of the range of feelings and themes they reflect. He arrayed them in four sections, headed People, Places, Politics and Private Lives. The book, which sells for $18, is illustrated with drawings made by Sarah Elizabeth Chuldenko, a Carter granddaughter.
Many of the poems are set in Mr. Carter's hometown, and though they deal with modest rather than heroic exploits, they nonetheless evoke the boyhood lives of Presidents as they have been described since Parson Weems first portrayed a Washington who would not lie. For his part, Mr. Carter writes of hunting buddies, trout fishing, killing an old sick dog, the inspiring example of a black neighbor. There are sketches of his mother, a poem about selling peanuts and a piece describing the flight of geese over the Capitol as seen from the roof of the White House.
Mr. Carter said he had found poetry to be a "more deeply self-revelatory experience" than other writing. "There were things that appeared in poems that I would never have said verbally or put in prose," said the man who while running for President once invited assured criticism by candidly admitting: "I've looked on a lot of women with lust. I've committed adultery in my heart many times." That is a good line in poetry but not in politics.
The new book does not have anything more to add on this subject, but there is a poem about human rights, "Hollow Eyes, Bellies, Hearts," written in the White House, which, in a sardonic voice, asks:
Why think of slaves, nameless deaths?
Best be still, as in other days.
Response was bland to Hitler's deeds --
Should we condemn our fathers' ways?
Recently, Mr. Carter has been criticized for meeting with and praising the leader of the Bosnian Serbs. When asked whether this amounted to the appeasement he had deplored in his poem, he replied, "Well, I don't see it that way."
And in another poem, called "I Wanted to Share My Father's World," he writes:
This is a pain I mostly hide,
but ties of blood, or seed endure,
and even now I feel inside
the hunger for his outstretched hand,
a man's embrace to take me in,
the need for just a word of praise.
Yes, he said, that was one of the poems that had even surprised his wife with its openness. "I was was proud of my father," Mr. Carter said. "I knew he loved me, but he was very restrained about showing it."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Jimmy Carter during impromptu lunch yesterday while signing his book of poems at Rizzoli's in World Financial Center. (Jim Estrin/The New York Times)

HEADLINE: TELEVISION REVIEW;
Overcoming In the South Of the 60's

BYLINE: By WALTER GOODMAN 

 BODY:
Tonight's edition of "Dateline" looks back at some brutal aspects of Mississippi's resistance to the civil rights movement in the 1960's. Stone Phillips talks with a repentant undercover informer for the Sovereignty Commission, a state agency that kept track of civil rights workers. The assertion here is that information was passed by the commission to the Klan-infiltrated police, with dire results.
Mr. Phillips also tells how the commission checked out potential jurors for the benefit of the defense in Byron de la Beckwith's trial in the murder of Medgar Evers, and he names a black businessman and state official as having alerted the commission to the plans of James Chaney, Andrew Goodman and Michael Schwerner, the three young civil rights workers who were killed in June 1964. 
 The program is not much of a scoop; many of the details have been reported elsewhere. Still, it can't hurt to remind a prime-time network audience, in a week that began with the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr.'s birthday, of what the civil rights movement in the South endured and overcame.
 
'Adam Smith'
'From Raj to Riches'
 PBS, tomorrow at 8 P.M.
 (Channel 13 in New York)
 Tomorrow night's offering from "Adam Smith" is the first of a two-part report on the economic boom in India. The programs intersperse picturesque scenes from old India with the rosy views of businessmen and officials of new India's commercial prospects.
Credit is given to the economic reforms of Prime Minister P. V. Narasimha Rao and Finance Minister Manmohan Singh, both interviewed here. Mr. Smith, a k a Jerry Goodman, does not fail to note that political opposition to a free market and multinational connections remains strong and that most Indians remain in deep poverty. But the emphasis is on the fast-growing middle class and the bustling Bombay Stock Exchange. It's an enlightening hour about the sort of subject that doesn't often make it onto the tube.

HEADLINE: Composing a Kinship Between Classical and Pop

BYLINE: By BERNARD HOLLAND 

 BODY:
William Bolcom's music, which New York Philharmonic audiences will hear a lot of this week, is a wordless rebuttal to ideas of rank and category. As a ragtime pianist and espouser of American popular song who writes operas and symphonies, Mr. Bolcom works hard to erase the lines between the elite and the vulgar, the intellectual and the visceral, the select and the popular.
Music, he seems to be telling us, has pulled itself apart from both ends of the cultural spectrum: the classical extremity eager to isolate high-mindedness and rise above the everyday; the pop end cornered by a concern for the bottom line and an obsession with rigid species and subspecies of style. Neither Mr. Bolcom's "Commedia" nor his Fifth Symphony, which Leonard Slatkin will conduct tomorrow, Friday and Saturday at Avery Fisher Hall, are new pieces. Both, however, create what the composer calls an "axis": a fulcrum on which the classical and the popular can sway in happy balance. 
 "We got away from this after World War I," he said in a conversation last weekend. "Evenings in the Victorian theater used to be grab bags. They lasted four hours. The cost of a ticket was roughly what people would spend on gas if they had stayed at home, so coming to the theater or the concert hall was an easy, natural thing to do. We have made it less friendly."
Blame economics for some of classical music's shrinking, graying audience, Mr. Bolcom suggests. "Classical concerts, like Broadway shows, have become events by necessity," he said. "They aren't normal activity anymore. The tickets are expensive. Parking is expensive. Dinner afterward is expensive. People are going to these things perhaps two or three times a year, not every week. There used to be 120 theaters around Broadway. Now only a few spectacles survive."
Yet attitudes toward art are entwined with the business end, he thinks. "The emerging bourgeois in the 19th century really started the high-culture movement," he said. "They were rising in the world and they wanted an art to take with them as they went up, something to identify as theirs and to separate them from the classes they were rising above. Before that, Haydn and a lot of other composers used popular songs. Monteverdi is full of dances of the day."
"Commedia" takes off from the stock characters of commedia dell'arte, a comedy style of the people that is now reverenced and dissected among academics. The Fifth Symphony, like so many great works of the 18th century, was written to specification.
"Dennis Russell Davies, the conductor, asked for something to come last on a program and have a loud ending, also something not too long," Mr. Bolcom said. "The Fifth, at 20 minutes, is half the length of my Fourth. It begins with a sonata allegro in the old symphonic way. The Scherzo balances the fox trot against 19th-century dances of death. The last movement plays a grand theme against against machinelike techno-pop."
Mr. Bolcom bridles at being called an eclectic. "I'm not a synthesizer either," he said. "I'm interested in showing how different elements relate. My music tries to make the relationships clear. The more I look to the future in music the more I keep coming back to the past. They come together. Maybe if we can find these axes between old and new, serious and popular, we can keep music afloat."
Mr. Bolcom, who is 56, paddles for all he is worth: performing standards with his wife, the soprano Joan Morris, using nightclub settings; responding to commissions from opera houses like the Chicago Lyric, and teaching as a full professor of composition at the University of Michigan. His own wide and international training centered, not surprisingly, around Darius Milhaud, a subtle purveyor of jazz elements.
"I think the interest in music is out there," Mr. Bolcom said, "but not just one kind of music. We have made concert life hard for listeners, a little foreign to them. After-work rush concerts at low prices work. The Lyric Opera in Chicago does a wonderful job of preparing audiences for unknown music and is over 100 percent sold out. Look at restaurants. They were in trouble a while back, but they changed their ways, became creative. Classical institutions became purified in an artificial way. It's made them ossified."

GRAPHIC: Photo: The composer William Bolcom at his home in Ann Arbor, Mich. (Peter Yates)

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Treasury Securities Fall in Price

BYLINE: By ROBERT HURTADO 

 BODY:
With the exception of the long bond, prices of Treasury securities fell yesterday, dragged down by a strong industrial production report.
The Federal Reserve reported yesterday that industrial production rose a strong 1 percent in December, the biggest gain in two years. The data showed an industrial sector robust enough to withstand a series of increases in short-term interest rates, suggesting that the Fed will be forced to keep raising rates, traders said. 
 But the market trimmed back its losses later in the day. One trader said that one reason the selloff was not heavier was investors who sold short going into Friday's retail sales report and were looking for the first drop in prices to cover their short positions.
The price of the 30-year bond rose 6/32 , to 9628/32. Its yield, which moves in the opposite direction from price, fell to 7.77 percent, from 7.78 on Friday. The Treasury market was closed on Monday in observance of the birthday of the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr.
But shorter maturities came under pressure yesterday as the market priced in the next interest rate increases by the Fed. Yields in the short end of the market rose an average 8 basis points. A basis point is one-hundredth of a percentage point.
Fears that Japanese insurers might sell paper to raise cash to cover losses from the earthquake did worry some investors. But some traders saw the possibility of the opposite effect if investors sold yen-denominated securities.
With regard to the strong production report, Donald J. Fine, chief market analyst for Chase Securities, said: "Last Friday's weak retail sales and today's strong industrial production confused many market participants.
"But the net result is that the market still expects a Fed tightening move on Feb. 1, but one that is limited to 50 basis points."
Stuart G. Hoffman, chief economist at the PNC Bank Corporation in Pittsburgh, noted that "the weak November and December retail sales data could be the first signs of a consumer spending slowdown, which means manufacturers may have to curtail output in the months ahead to prevent unwanted inventories to pile up."
"I don't think these numbers will dissuade the Fed from raising the Federal funds rate by 50 basis points," Mr. Hoffman said, "but it strongly argues against anything more agresesive than that. There are enough open questions so that anything more than a 50-basis-point interest rate increase will be unwarranted."
With each economic number out shifting the probablity of a rate increase by the Fed, Mr. Hoffman thinks the next important number that will likely attract the greatest market focus will be the preliminary report on the gross domestic product for the first quarter, which is due next week.
"Tomorrow's manufacturing and trade data could be interesting leading into the G.D.P," he said.
The Treasury held its weekly auction of three- and six-month bills yesterday because of the holiday on Monday.
Interest rates were down moderately, as the average rate for a three- month issue dropped 10 basis points, to 5.77 percent, the lowest since the end of December last year, and the six-month was down 23 basis points, to 6.19 percent, its lowest since the end of November last year.
Today the Treasury will announce the size of its two-year and five-year note auctions that will be held next week.
In the municipal bond market, were prices were little changed, with New York City bonds off a bit. The city's decision yesterday to sell refunding bonds to help close its budget deficit by lowering interest rate payments apparently lowered the prices on some of city's $23 billion general obligation debt.
Meanwhile as the city is preparing to sell $500 million in bonds next week to provide $120 million in savings in the fiscal year 1995 budget, Standard & Poor's says it may downgrade the city's A- rating because of the plan.

HEADLINE: FUTURES MARKETS;
Energy and Precious Metals Lead Rally in Commodities

BYLINE: By Reuters 

 BODY:
Energy and precious metals led a broad rally in commodities yesterday, with forecasts for colder weather in the United States, buoyant economic data and the earthquake in Japan driving markets.
Higher prices for cotton, sugar, coffee and cocoa helped lift the Commodity Research Bureau's index of 21 commodities 2.62 points, to 235.58. 
 The recovery in energy prices continued, based on forecasts that a spell of unseasonably warm weather would end by the weekend on the East Coast and in the Midwest, two areas where heating oil and natural gas are used extensively.
The warm weather has also encouraged motorists to take to the roads, increasing gasoline demand. All this as gale-force winds in the oil-rich North Sea have affected tanker loadings and could cut production of crude oil from offshore wells.
"I think the heating oil bottom reversal yesterday attracted buyers and the gasoline continues to attract speculative buyers," Morris Greenberg of Lehman Brothers said yesterday. "And crude going through $18 was a significant psychological factor," he said. "The technicals look good."
On the New York Mercantile Exchange, crude oil for February delivery jumped 44 cents, to a 10-week high of $18.32 a barrel.
February heating oil gained 1.32 cents, to 48.67 cents a gallon; February gasoline added 0.92 cent, to 57.80 cents, and February natural gas rose 4.4 cents, to $1.434 for one million British thermal units.
Copper prices bounced back strongly after the Federal Reserve reported that the output of the nation's factories, mines and utilities rose a strong 1 percent in December.
Expectations that Japan's rebuilding from the earthquake would increase demand for copper added to the buying, said Bette Raptoupolos, an analyst with Prudential Securities.
The March copper contract rose 3.2 cents, to $1.3885 a pound, on the Commodity Exchange in New York.
Gold and other precious metals rose. The February gold contract was up $2.30, to $380.60 an ounce, on the Commodity Exchange.
