HEADLINE: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising;
An increase in corporate campaigns points to a continuing recovery for Madison Avenue.

BYLINE: By Stuart Elliott 

 BODY:
IN another sign that Madison Avenue is continuing to recover from one of its worst slumps ever, an annual study is reporting a healthy increase in corporate advertising.
The 1994 Corporate Advertising Practices survey by the Association of National Advertisers, the New York-based trade organization of leading marketers, found that corporate ads -- aimed at improving consumer and investor perceptions of a company rather than directly selling its products or services -- "have begun to rebound to historically high levels after a recessionary downturn in the late 1980's." 
 Executives of companies belonging to the association who participated in the survey said they would spend $653.9 million on corporate advertising during 1994, a gain of 14.5 percent from the $570.9 million they said they spent in 1993. The 1993 figure represented an increase of 6.7 percent from the $535.2 million they said they spent in 1992.
And 61 percent of responding members said they had used corporate advertising from 1992 through 1994, compared with 53 percent that reported doing so from 1989 through 1991. From 1988 through 1990, 62.8 percent of respondents said they had used corporate advertising, compared with 70.4 percent from 1987 through 1989.
"The trend is up," James R. Gregory, a consultant hired by the association to analyze the study, said yesterday. "All you have to do is open up any publication to see there's more corporate ads than were running a year or so ago."
Mr. Gregory, who offered a preview of the survey in an interview, is chairman of the Corporate Branding Partnership in Stamford, Conn., a corporate image and brand consulting company, as well as chairman of a Stamford advertising agency, Gregory & Clyburne.
"It's good for advertising in general that corporate advertising is increasing," Mr. Gregory said, "because it's an indicator of the strength of all advertising. Usually, corporate advertising campaigns lead the way over product advertising campaigns."
The resiliency of corporate campaigns is somewhat surprising. The severity of the recession, and the dilatory rate at which consumer product marketers are overcoming its effects, suggested that corporate ads might be relegated to the site reserved for yellow "power ties," extravagant gifts and other trappings of the pre-crash 80's.
Yet the bouncing back of corporate advertising spending levels is not that unexpected to Mr. Gregory, who points to what he considers a fundamental change in the nature of corporate ads during the 90's.
"There are more corporate campaigns now about what I call corporate branding," he said, "than about corporate image."
The distinction, Mr. Gregory explained, is that corporate branding ads are "much more marketing-oriented, much more aggressive, much more savvy" than corporate image ads, which "are viewed as fluff and not really valuable, except for self-gratification."
"That type of corporate advertising is eyewash," he asserted, "and people don't pay attention to it."
The primary reason, Mr. Gregory said, is that "corporate image ads are the chairman of the company and the 100th anniversary of the company; they're past tense." He added, "What people are interested in is the future, the company's vision."
As examples of effective current corporate advertising that promotes corporate branding rather than corporate image, Mr. Gregory cited the opening phase of the global campaign for I.B.M. by Ogilvy & Mather Worldwide in New York, carrying the theme "There is a difference," and the campaign for the Cigna Corporation by DDB Needham New York, carrying the theme "The business of caring."
Mr. Gregory praised those campaigns for offering "one cohesive message," adding, "You can get a lot of benefit from that, relating to familiarity, reputation, cash flow -- even stock price."
To persuade skeptical chief financial officers and chief executives to approve spending scarce corporate dollars for corporate campaigns, Mr. Gregory said, advertising directors should concentrate on the tangible results that can be achieved by a corporate branding approach.

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
The Dollar Rises on Report Of Growth in U.S. Industry

BYLINE: By Bloomberg Business News 

 BODY:
The dollar gained against most leading currencies yesterday, bolstered by a report that showed strong growth in American industry.
The report, by the Federal Reserve, said capacity utilization at factories, mines and utilities rose to 85.4 percent in December, the highest since October 1979. 
 The report revived expectations that the Fed would raise short-term interest rates later his month.
"These numbers show that the Fed is going to have to raise rates, and that should help the dollar," said Richard Gilhooly, international bond strategist at Paribas Capital Markets.
Higher interest rates typically strengthen the dollar by making investments in dollar-denominated securities more attractive than those from abroad.
Even so, the dollar failed to hold most of yesterday's gains against the mark and other currencies, largely because many traders think the Fed may refrain from raising rates given Mexico's financial crisis and the slumping Canadian dollar.
In New York trading, the dollar rose to 1.5332 German marks, from 1.5316 marks on Monday, and to 1.2865 Swiss francs from 1.2835 francs. The British pound fell to $1.5667 from $1.5683.
Against the yen, the dollar rebounded from an eight-week low during a brief panic prompted by the earthquake that struck the western part of Japan. The dollar rose as high as 99.29 yen in London trading, before settling at 99.13 yen in New York, up from 98.42 on Monday.
In other trading, the Canadian dollar plunged to 70.25 United States cents, its lowest in nearly nine years, before recovering to 70.44 United States cents, down from 70.95 cents on Monday.
The decline came even as the Bank of Canada raised its key lending rate and the Bank of England intervened to buy Canadian dollars in an attempt to prop up the battered currency.
"It's really not in the Bank of Canada's hands" to halt the dollar's decline, said Josh Mendelsohn, chief economist at the Canadian Imperial Bank of Commerce. All the bank can do is "smooth" the currency's fall, he said.
Traders said the slump in Canada's currency accelerated after The Globe and Mail newspaper in Toronto quoted Al Friedberg, a Toronto money manager, as saying the Canadian dollar "will sink into a worthless piece of paper" unless the Government cuts spending.

HEADLINE: Foreign Affairs;
Good Morning, Vietnam

BYLINE: By THOMAS L. FRIEDMAN 

DATELINE: HANOI, Vietnam

 BODY:
In 1966, at the height of the Vietnam War, Senator George Aiken became famous for suggesting that we simply declare victory and bring American troops home. That victory was phony, but 29 years later we truly have one in Vietnam, if winning is measured by a Vietnam that is economically, politically and strategically pro-Western. Yet despite that victory, Washington is reluctant to open full diplomatic relations with Hanoi and consolidate its tentative move into America's orbit. It's time. It's time we started relating to Vietnam as a country, not a conflict. It's time that we declare victory and go back to Vietnam to reap it.
President Bush should have been the one to open relations. He knew it was the right thing to do, and he had the credibility with veterans' groups to do it. But he didn't. (Wouldn't be prudent.) President Clinton, despite his problems with Vietnam vets, has inched closer to Hanoi, by lifting economic sanctions last year and agreeing to a low-level liaison office this year. For months the State Department has been quietly recommending full normalization, but after the midterm Republican rout the White House said "Forget it." (Wouldn't be prudent.) That is America's loss. 
 Vietnam's 72 million industrious, literate people are building a market economy from the ground up. Because U.S. diplomats and businesses are not here in force as the foundation stones are laid and the legal system is reformed, this means U.S. standards, regulations and laws are not being wired in. Australia already dominates the phone system, British Petroleum has the oil sector and Singapore advises on the legal code.
I was riding in a taxi here the other day and the driver was studying English from BBC tapes. For 30 minutes I had to listen to a repetition of: "I like football. I like Manchester United," the prominent British soccer team. When they think football here they don't think Dallas Cowboys, and when they think telephones they don't think AT&T.
Strategically, the big issue in Asia will be the containment of China, whose military might, and appetite, will grow as China grows. There is no more powerful counterweight to Beijing than Hanoi, whose tiny army bludgeoned China's in their 1979 border war. China is Vietnam's historical enemy. Most of Hanoi's boulevards are named for heroes of the wars against China. The biggest display in the Hanoi Army Museum is not of Vietnam's victory over the U.S. in 1975, but its victory over the Mongols from the north in 1288. A U.S.-Vietnam entente would get China's attention -- and keep it.
As for our M.I.A.'s, every U.S. official dealing with this issue says Vietnamese cooperation has improved (not diminished, as opponents of relations predicted) since we lifted the economic embargo. The reason is not anything the Hanoi Government is doing, but because the Vietnamese people, villagers and veterans, are now coming forward with information about graves and bones that they were holding back as long as America was embargoing them economically. U.S. M.I.A. officials say normal relations and more Americans traveling here would only elicit more grass-roots cooperation, which is the only way the 1,621 remaining M.I.A. cases will be resolved.
It is pathetic that a small, vindictive cult of M.I.A. activists in America -- who broadcast U.F.O. sightings of P.O.W.'s roaming the Vietnamese countryside and demand we withhold normalization to punish Hanoi for a war we never should have fought -- have intimidated Washington into a Vietnam policy that is bad for M.I.A.'s and bad for America.
The Vietnamese, who have 300,000 M.I.A.'s, have let the future bury the past. As Deputy Foreign Minister Le Mai told me: "If we nursed all of our grudges with all the powers that we have fought against, we wouldn't have relations with anyone. The war divided your society; recognizing Vietnam would put this behind you. It would heal your own wounds."
He's right. It's time we too buried the past. Hue today is a cuisine, not a battle; Tet is a New Year's celebration, not an offensive; Haiphong is a harbor, not something to be bombed at Christmas; and Highway 1 is where they run the Hanoi Marathon, not the military artery of an enemy nation. President Clinton didn't start this war, and he didn't fight this war, but with a little bit of courage, he could finally end this war.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

TYPE: Op-Ed

HEADLINE: Don't Begrudge Veterans Medical Care

 BODY:
To the Editor:
William Safire says that money spent on America's veterans is "the most wasteful special-interest spending in Washington" (column, Jan. 12). Mr. Safire may begrudge the men and women whose health was impaired by military service, but neither taxpayers nor their representatives share his attitude. 
 The country's responsibility to its veterans hasn't and shouldn't lead to unchecked Government spending. Congress, the Department of Veterans Affairs, the White House and veterans demand tough-minded controls over programs, for a dollar wasted is a dollar unavailable to help a deserving former service member.
Besides providing medical care to veterans, the Department of Veterans Affairs provides education to more than half the country's doctors, conducting medical research and serving as primary backup medical provider to the Defense Department.
Despite an increasing number of veterans and skyrocketing private-sector medical expenses, rises in the medical budget for veterans lag behind the rate of medical inflation.
Only veterans with medical problems directly linked to their military service or elderly, sick, low-income wartime vets are guaranteed treatment in a Veterans Affairs medical facility. Many deserving veterans are fighting for high-priority access, including those injured by Agent Orange exposure, atomic testing, asbestos and Persian Gulf syndrome.
Medical centers aren't always in communities with the greatest need. Some veterans are denied benefits because of interpretations of Federal law, as the Supreme Court agreed in a Dec. 12 ruling that the Government has ignored the simple-English interpretation of Federal law on injuries caused by treatment in Veterans Affairs centers.
In 1991 we proposed a plan to improve health care for veterans to the Veterans Affairs Department, the White House and Congress. There are alternatives to long-term institutional care that can be less expensive and more appropriate for patients.
 
WILLIAM M. DETWEILER
National Commander
The American Legion
Washington, Jan. 12, 1995

HEADLINE: WNYC Shouldn't Go to a Commercial Buyer

 BODY:
To the Editor:
I served as director (1982-88) and chairman (1984-88) of the WNYC Foundation. Before I became chairman, New York City was suffering a severe financial crisis. Some of Mayor Edward I. Koch's advisers urged him to sell the television station, saying the city could not support it. 
 A group led by George Fox, then chairman, came up with the idea of selling the non-prime-time hours to commercial users to support the station and prime-time programs. When I became chairman it was my job to meet with the Mayor and Mary Perot Nichols, WNYC's president, and convince the Mayor the station should not be sold.
This was not very difficult because Mayor Koch believed that the city should not sell the station. He was concerned, however, that it not be a drain on the city. When we proposed selling the non-prime-time hours, the Mayor agreed.
The first year I negotiated contracts with groups from Japan and Italy, among others. One Japanese program, with voiceover, was a news program like our 6 P.M. news. It gave the Japanese community an opportunity to see what was happening in Japan and American audiences a program showing how the Japanese reported on world news.
Little did we dream that the television station would turn a profit and help support its sister radio stations, as noted in "The WNYC's Are Too Valuable to Sell" (editorial, Jan. 10).
When I moved to California I resigned from the foundation. To my regret I have not been involved in its work. But I agree that it would be a mistake to sell the station to a commercial buyer. I pray that the city accepts the foundation's offer to buy the station at a price the foundation can afford.
 
GERALD F. PHILLIPS
Los Angeles, Jan. 11, 1995

HEADLINE: QUAKE IN JAPAN: THE COST;
Through Kobe's Rubble, An Economic Rainbow

BYLINE: By NICHOLAS D. KRISTOF, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: TOKYO, Jan. 17

 BODY:
The earthquake that ripped through western Japan today has paralyzed one of the nation's commercial hubs, leaving rubble and smoke and panic. It caused colossal damage to Japan's roads, railways and communications and knocked out of commission a port that accounts for 12 percent of the nation's exports.
The quake was the worst in an urban area of Japan in 70 years, ever since the great Tokyo earthquake of 1923, and it struck in a crucial economic zone that includes the business center of Osaka, Japan's third largest city, as well as Kobe, the sixth largest. 
 For all the sophistication of Japanese telecommunications, for all the earthquake preparedness that is drilled into people since they are school children, both Kobe and Osaka were unreachable by telephone from Tokyo throughout today.
Despite the devastation, experts said today that the in some ways the earthquake could give a boost to an economy struggling to recover from a long recession.
It is not the kind of a boost that any country would hope for, but economists and other experts said that the capital spending to rebuild the port city of Kobe may give a stimulus to Japan's economy, the world's largest after America's.
Kobe, a major industrial center, was today isolated from the rest of the country, with roads and rail and ferry service all disrupted. Even the Tokyo office of Kobe municipal government said it had been unable to communicate with people there.
The steel mills of Kobe were closed today, and so was the Osaka Stock Exchange. Many factories in Kobe were also closed, either to assess the physical damage or to wait until roads improved so that employees could come to work again.
Japanese television quoted the Construction Minister, Koken Nosaka, as saying that it would take two or three years to rebuild Kobe.
Officials in the Economic Planning Agency, a Government agency attached to the Prime Minister's office, said they were preparing a report on the economic consequences of the earthquake, but that it was too soon to know what they would be.
One of the most serious consequences appears to be that shipping in and out of Kobe will be impossible until repairs have been made on the docks and on loading facilities.
"The port in Kobe has been badly damaged, and we don't know when it will be ready again," said Yukiko Isomura, of Mitsui OSK, a shipping company. Miss Isomura said that Mitsui had rerouted two ships to Pusan, South Korea, because other ports in Japan were full or inappropriate for the cargoes.
Several companies based in the Osaka area said, however, that they could find other routes to transport exports and imports, and that their facilities had not been seriously damaged.
Matsushita, which makes electronic products under the Panasonic and other brand names, said it had a five-year-old factory in Kobe that turns out personal computers and other products. The factory was not seriously damaged but was closed for the day because electricity had been cut off.
The head office of Matsushita, in Osaka, had some broken windows but no major damage.
At Sanyo Electric Company, the electronics conglomerate, which is also headquartered in Osaka, the only damage was to a factory on Owajishima, the island at the epicenter of the quake. Even that factory, which makes rechargable batteries and other products, was being brought back on line.
"So far it's been fairly minor," said David Lee, a Sanyo spokesman.
While the overall Tokyo stock market fell slightly today, the stocks of construction companies rose in anticipation of the profits to be made from rebuilding Kobe. Companies that make glass or cement, or that are involved in road-building, also saw gains.
The other immediate beneficiaries of the disaster were the "konbini," as convenience stores are known here, for those in the earthquake region immediately sold out of all their food.
"The damage was huge, and it'll have a major impact on the Japanese economy," said Masaru Takagi, chief economist of Fuji Research Institute in Tokyo. "But it won't affect the recovery phase. Japan's economy will continue to recover."
Robert Alan Feldman, a managing director in the Tokyo office of Salomon Brothers, the investment bank, said that in some ways the reconstruction of Northridge following the earthquake there a year ago had helped the southern Californian economy, and he suggested the same would happen in Japan.
"There definitely is going to be a stimulus," he said. "Ironically, this will probably help the economic recovery, although that doesn't mean that the country is better off."
Mr. Feldman and others, while emphasizing that it is much too early to tell with any precision, said that the total repair bill could end up in the range of $ 10 billion to $ 20 billion.
Robert J. Geller, an American earthquake expert who teaches at Tokyo University, said that many of the estimated 9,700 buildings that collapsed in the earthquake were older ones that in any case should have been replaced.
"Obviously you'd like to rebuild in less catastrophic ways, and there'll be a loss because these facilities are out of commission," Professor Geller said. But he noted that tremendous damage could spur growth instead of retard it.
In the United States, representatives of Japanese companies with manufacturing operations in the Osaka-Kobe area spent much of Tuesday trying to get through to the home office. Those who did said that physical damage to plants was negligible, and that most employees survived unscathed.
"We understand there has been no facility damage," said Nancy Levene, a spokeswoman for the Sharp Electronic Corporation, the American subsidiary of the Sharp Corporation, which is based in Osaka. She added that only 20 percent of the company's employees were able to get to work at Sharp's headquarters, where machines like copiers, calculators and faxes are manufactured.
At the Matsushita Electric Corporation of America, which manufactures Panasonic, Techniques and Quasar electronic equipment, Jim Reilly, a company spokesman, said the company's factories "did not suffer major damage."
Toshiba, which employs about 2,000 workers in two plants, one a joint venture with the International Business Machines Corporation, said in the United States that no damage was reported at either plant. The plants are located in Himeji, a town outside Osaka.

HEADLINE: Personal Health;
Dysthymia: help for chronic sadness.

BYLINE: By Jane E. Brody 

 BODY:
FOR more than 7 million Americans life is no bowl of cherries, the glass is nearly always half empty, the clouds have no silver lining. They have a little-known and often medically ignored yet treatable emotional disorder called dysthymia.
Dysthymia (pronounced dis-THIGH-mee-a) is a mild but chronic depression that can spread a veil of sadness over people's lives for years, even decades, sometimes seemingly from the cradle to the grave. Others may see the people with dysthymia as pessimistic, self-critical, underachieving and lacking in motivation, spontaneity or a sense of adventure. Sufferers may see themselves as suffering from a lack of energy, dissatisfaction, an overall negativism and a belief that things will never get better. They are less likely than others to get married and more likely to be divorced and unemployed or underemployed, although some become high achievers despite their depressed mood. 
 The sleep and appetite disorders common to major depression are less typical of dysthymia. But some patients are plagued by headaches and other pain and chronic fatigue; their multiple visits to doctors rarely result in an accurate diagnosis. Still, many people with dysthymia have joined the Prozac generation, often at the urging of friends who themselves have found that this or some other antidepressant lifts the cloudy filter from their lives.
 
Origins of Dysthymia
 The word dysthymia was coined in the late 1970's by Dr. Robert Spitzer, a psychiatrist at the New York State Psychiatric Institute in New York, to replace "neurotic depression" or "depressive personality," as the condition used to be called. First included in the psychiatric diagnostic manual in 1980, its definition was revised as more was learned.
A study of five communities conducted by Dr. Myrna M. Weissman and colleagues at the Psychiatric Institute found that at any given time about 3 percent of American adults have dysthymia. Other studies indicate that at least 6 percent of people, possibly many more, experience dysthymia at some time.
For some, the problem seems to have been present almost since birth. As children, they may have been irritable and difficult, had trouble making or keeping friends or fallen short of their potential in school. For others, the negative feelings do not begin until adolescence, young adulthood or midlife. Their low-grade depression may be precipitated by a life crisis, like a divorce, job loss or death of a loved one. Or their problem may begin with an episode of major depression that, with or without treatment, abates but never entirely disappears; a condition classified as "major depressive disorder in partial remission," its symptoms are indistinguishable from classic dysthymia.
People with dysthymia are also prone to intermittent attacks of major depression, a condition called double depression. If anything, it is the major depressive episode, not the chronic mild depression, that prompts someone with dysthymia to seek psychotherapeutic assistance.
"We often see dysthymic features in children or adolescents that are the precursors of major depression," said Dr. David Kupfer, director of research at Western Psychiatric Institute in Pittsburgh. Dysthymia runs in families, he added, and the children of people with major depression are at increased risk of developing the milder disorder.
 
Treating Dysthymia
 "Even if you've been depressed all your life, that's no reason not to seek treatment," said Dr. John C. Markowitz, a research psychiatrist at New York Hospital-Cornell Medical Center in New York.
Dr. Kupfer said: "Within the last few years, it's become increasingly clear that the usual treatments for depression are also very effective in dealing with dysthymia."
Dr. James H. Kocsis at New York Hospital-Cornell Medical Center has reported that about two-thirds of patients with dysthymia get significantly better with antidepressants. The same drugs used to treat major depression, including tricyclic antidepressants like imipramine (Tofranil), MAO inhibitors like phenelzine (Nardil) and serotonin uptake inhibitors like fluoxetine (Prozac), are effective for dysthymia.
However, many patients do not improve with medication and others resist taking drugs or find their side effects intolerable. For them one or more psychotherapeutic techniques may be very helpful. The two that have been most effective in treating depression are cognitive-behavioral therapy, developed by Dr. Aaron Beck at the University of Pennsylvania in Philadelphia, and interpersonal therapy, developed by the late Dr. Gerald L. Klerman at Cornell and now being studied for dysthymia by Dr. Markowitz. Both approaches are relatively brief and focus on reversing the negativistic thoughts and self-defeating behavior characteristic of depression.
Cognitive-behavioral therapy involves several months of weekly discussions with a therapist and written and behavioral homework assignments. Through scheduled activities, training in social competence and a modification of irrationally negative thoughts, depression often lifts. In interpersonal therapy, given weekly for about four to six months, the therapist helps patients recognize links between their moods and what is going on in their lives, particularly things like grief, role disputes at work or at home, role transitions like marriage or job loss, and trouble initiating or sustaining relationships.
In a recent review of psychotherapy for dysthymia, Dr. Markowitz wrote that long-term psychodynamic therapy -- Freudian based talk therapy -- is often prescribed though there is no evidence it helps. "Years of such treatment often provide insight into depression but little relief from it," he said. "Therapies that focus on the past are useful for understanding where problems come from, but they don't necessarily help people overcome them." He recommended that people suffering from depression see a psychiatrist or, if they do not want to take drugs, any mental health professional trained in psychotherapy for depression.

GRAPHIC: The current psychiatric manual lists these criteria among those for diagnosing dysthymia in patients who do not have other psychiatric disorders:
 
A depressed mood for most of the day, for more days than not, for at least two years, or for one year in children and adolescents.
 
The presence, along with the depression, of two or more of these conditions: poor appetite or overeating; insomnia or hypersomnia (a tendency to sleep too much); low energy or fatigue; low self-esteen; poor concentration or difficulty making decisions, and feelings of hopelessness.
 
As a result of the above symptoms, experiencing clinically significant distress or impairment in social, occupational or other important areas of functioning.
 
People in the New York area who meet the criteria for dysthymia may be eligible for participation in a free, confidential treatment study under way at New York Hospital-Cornell Medical Center. Interested people should call (212) 821-0722.

HEADLINE: QUAKE IN JAPAN: THE ENGINEERING;
Damage Survey Points to Design As a Weakness

BYLINE: By ANDREW POLLACK, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: KOBE, Japan, Jan. 18

 BODY:
Kunitomo Sugiura took one look at the 550-yard stretch of the Hanshin Expressway, lying on its side like an overturned banquet table, and saw immediately what was wrong.
In much of the elevated highway, which was heavily damaged on Tuesday in the earthquake here, the roadbed rests on horizontal steel girders. But exactly at the points where the toppled section begins and ends, the girders change from steel to reinforced concrete. 
 Concrete is less expensive than steel, and might have been chosen to cut costs in places where the soil was deemed suitable, said Dr. Sugiura, an associate professor of civil engineering at Kyoto University. But concrete is also heavier, he said, and that extra weight probably contributed to the collapse of the expressway, which has become perhaps the most visible symbol of the power of the earthquake.
A variety of design decisions made long ago, as well as the vagaries of location, accounted for the vast structural damage wrought by the earthquake, which destroyed or damaged at least 20,000 buildings.
The quake seemed to wreak its havoc in an almost arbitrary fashion. In some cases houses that were completely flattened lie next to others that seem not to have been scratched. In some tall office buildings and department stores, one floor seems to have completely disappeared while the floors above and below suffered far less damage.
Many of the houses destroyed seemed to be older ones made of wood frame with stucco walls and traditional tile roofs. But there were wooden houses that stood up well and concrete or steel-framed buildings that crumpled.
One factor is how the vibration characteristics of a building match with the vibration of the ground.
Another factor is the kind of soil. The damage was much greater near the coast, where the ground tends to be softer and earth movements therefore greater, than in the hills farther inland.
It will probably take weeks for scientists to sort things out and learn the lessons there are to be learned. But it is clear that the extent of the damage shocked and dismayed Japan's engineers, who prided themselves on earthquake engineering that is widely considered the best in the world.
"It's the first time I've ever seen such horrible damage," said Dr. Sugiura. "I cannot believe the collapse of the highway."
The professor, who did his Ph.D. research at the National Center for Earthquake Engineering Research at the State University of New York at Buffalo, accompanied a reporter on a several-hour survey of the structural damage in part of Kobe and nearby towns.
Much of the trip, coming in from Osaka, was on Route 43, a dark road that runs under the elevated Hanshin Expressway, the main thoroughfare connecting Osaka and the port city of Kobe.
Along the side streets, people could be seen huddled around bonfires, cooking or chatting. Many people were living in their cars, either because they had lost their homes or because they were afraid to stay in their homes because of the risk of aftershocks.
The car drove past massive round reinforced concrete pillars, at least three yards wide, that hold up the expressway. Like many such highways in Japan, the emphasis was on brute strength, not aesthetic appeal. "I don't think you can see such big columns in the United States, even in California," Dr. Sugiura said. But some of the columns were cracked, with their steel reinforcing bars visible inside the concrete.
The highway seemed to have collapsed in three different ways at the three locations that were examined.
At one place where the highway fell, crushing two trucks as if they had been made of paper, a concrete column holding up the roadway collapsed. But the adjacent columns on either side showed no damage. A river ran near the collapsed column, so Dr. Sugiura speculated that the soil had given way in that one spot.
Just down the road was another spot where the columns remained intact but a section of the roadbed had fallen, leaving a bus dangling precariously over a ledge. In this spot, Dr. Sugiura said, two adjacent columns probably vibrated in opposite directions and pulled far enough apart from each other that the roadbed fell off its supports.
The long section that turned on its side, with the roadbed now resembling a vertical wall, probably ended up that way because the ground shook back and forth perpendicular to highway, Professor Sugiura said. Since there is only a single row of pillars supporting the highway, the structure has less resistance to bending side to side than it would have had if there had been two rows of columns.
In perhaps a tribute to the solidness of the structure, the roadbed did not come apart over the 550-yard span, but rather the structure broke at the base of the columns. It seemed that one section tipping over had dragged the next section with it, and so on, in a giant twisting chain reaction.
Next to the fallen highway, most buildings seemed to have barely been damaged.
Many of the houses most heavily damaged were traditional ones built of a wooden frame and stucco walls, including old two-story apartments, known here as bunka jutaku or culture houses, that were built immediately after World War II.
Dr. Sugiura said the wooden structures were light and should therefore withstand an earthquake, and many did. Japan does not use stones and brick in construction because they are heavier and would not withstand quakes as well, he said.
Downtown Kobe, still mostly without electricity, was dark as night fell. But a few bright neon signs, apparently from buildings with their own generators, eerily cut the night. Some of the gleaming office buildings looked fine, but others were cracked or bent. One metal and glass building about 10 stories high was bent in the middle as if it were bowing to passersby.
A nine-story department store had lost its fifth floor. It is possible that on some floors, to allow for more space, support columns were removed, making those floors weaker than others, Dr. Sugiura said.
One big question is how violently the ground shook, which should be known once data from sensors are analyzed, said Dr. Sugiura. If the ground acceleration was truly great, then it would perhaps be no surprise that roads, trestles and buildings collapsed. But if the movement was not so great, it would mean that Japan's anti-earthquake construction codes might have to be tightened.
The code for buildings was tightened after a big earthquake in northern Japan in the late 1960's, Dr. Sugiura said. The code for bridges and highways was revised in 1990.
Before the 1990 revision, elevated structures were designed to withstand an acceleration equal to 20 percent that of gravity. But sensor data have indicated that in some really big earthquakes, perhaps like the one that leveled Tokyo in 1923, the ground acceleration can be 30 to 40 percent that of gravity.
Under the new code, Dr. Sugiura said, a bridge must be able to withstand a medium-size quake, with an acceleration of 20 to 30 percent that of gravity, without damage. It must be able to survive a very big quake, with ground acceleration up to 40 percent of gravity, without collapsing, although it might sustain damage.
This is a compromise between safety and economics, the professor said. Of course, he said, it is possible to design a structure to withstand even a giant earthquake without damage. "But what's the limit?" he asked. One could always imagine a bigger and bigger earthquake, and construction costs would increase endlessly.

GRAPHIC: Photos: Earthquake damage made travel hazardous and sometimes impossible for cyclists as well as motorists in Kobe yesterday.; Rescue workers found 47 patients trapped in the rubble of the crushed fifth floor of a seven-story hospital yesterday. All were rescued. (Photographs by Associated Press) (pg. A12)
 
Diagram: "Earthquakes and Buildings"
 The earthquake that hit Kobe caused many buildings to collapse of simply fall over. Many of the buildings in Kobe were built to conform to earthquake codes, but no amount of planning can compensate for extremely violent tremors near a city. On eoms residential blocks, houses collapsed while others with the same construction were spared, with no apparent pattern.
 
Soil Types:
Buildings built on rock suffer higher-frequency vibrations during an earthquake. They may not topple, but can become unusable because of structural faults.
Buildings on softer soilbeds need special braces because the building can resonate with the quake and vibrate apart. Most of the buildings in downtown Kobe sit on soft soil.
 
Structural Remedies:
High-rise buildings can be built with an elastic architecture that allows them to flex horizontally when the ground shifts.
Buildings constructed with a flexible or "soft" ground floor allow the upper floors to remain upright while the bottom shifts.
 
How Earthquakes Affect Different Building Types
Two wings at right angles with different motions cause damage at the connection pionts.
A building with different heights tends to break at the joints.
As shockwaves move up the building, they increasein amplitude.
Buildings close to one another can collide because the way they vibrate changes with location and height.
(Source: "Earthquakes," Bruce A. Bolt, W.H. Freeman and Company) (pg. A12)

HEADLINE: REPORT TO PATAKI CALLS FOR 13% CUT IN MEDICAID COSTS

BYLINE: By IAN FISHER 

 BODY:
A report commissioned by Gov. George E. Pataki calls for cutting state Medicaid costs by 13 percent, sharply reducing payments to hospitals and nursing homes and limiting home services, like housekeeping, feeding and bathing for the elderly.
Lieut. Gov. Betsy McCaughey drafted the proposal as a central part of Mr. Pataki's plan to cut taxes while balancing the state budget. The $1.2 billion in cuts Ms. McCaughey is seeking in her proposal represents about one-quarter of the $5 billion the Governor needs to close a $4 million budget gap and deliver $1 billion in income-tax cuts. 
 Medicaid, the health care program for the poor, disabled and some of the elderly, is one of the fastest-growing parts of the state budget and now represents about a fifth of total state spending. Although the program is sponsored by the Federal Government, states set their own standards for care and eligibility; New York's program is by far the most expansive and generous in the nation.
Ms. McCaughey's proposal would represent a major first step away from that standard, actually reducing the total cost of the program.
Pataki administration officials said that the Governor agrees with the plan's overall shape and, in fact, his aides pushed Ms. McCaughey to cut payments to hospitals and nursing homes, the most politically influential beneficiaries of the program. But he has not signed off on the specific cuts.
"Lieutenant Governor McCaughey is a nationally recognized expert on health care," Mr. Pataki said in a statement. "Her proposals warrant my full attention. Many of her ideas and proposals unquestionably will be made part of our executive budget."
Most changes to the Medicaid program must pass the two houses of the Legislature. Spokesmen for both the Republican-controlled Senate and the Democratic-controlled Assembly said yesterday that it was too early for them to comment on Ms. McCaughey's proposal.
While patient advocates and hospitals said yesterday that the quality of care could suffer, the cuts would also help the budgets of municipalities like New York City. Because the cost of Medicaid is divided among the Federal, state and local governments, a reduction by the state in what hospitals receive for services would have the effect of also cutting city payments for the same services.
The plan, announced at a news conference in Manhattan, would bring total state Medicaid spending to $5.2 billion in the next fiscal year, down from this year's estimated total of $5.9 billion. The $1.2 billion in cuts is the decrease from an estimated total of $6.4 billion in the state's share of the program next year. The total cost of the program is $19 billion.
Cuts to health care providers like hospitals, nursing homes, clinics and pharmacies would total $604 million, about half the total cut. The rest of the savings would come from putting more Medicaid patients in managed-care programs and through cuts in services like transportation to doctors' offices, occupational therapy for adults and a substantial reduction in a program used disproportionately in New York State, called personal care. That program provides nonmedical services like cooking and cleaning.
Patient groups said yesterday that the cuts were too deep to insure good care -- though not as deep, they acknowledged, as in Ms. McCaughey's earlier drafts. But Ms. McCaughey disputed that contention, arguing that more managed care could provide better service because patients would see one doctor on a continuing basis.
"We've tried very hard to identify ways to achieve these savings without taking care away from anyone who needs it," she said.
For hospitals, the program would eliminate the annual increases the state pays to hospitals to cover the cost of inflation and allow the state to pay hospitals at lower rates than private insurance companies pay for regular patients. The rates are the same now.
For nursing homes, the annual inflation rate would also be eliminated, and a cap would be placed on profits, along with a long list of smaller savings.
In an earlier draft, Ms. McCaughey had not included cuts for hospitals and nursing home for fear of hurting already weak hospitals -- indeed, her core advisory group was composed almost entirely of such providers. Yesterday, though, she said she could not make her $1.2 billion target without them.
"My job is to present the Governor with a list of options that will help close the deficit," she said. "I would like to do it in a way that didn't take care away from people who really needed it. So we've spread the burden around."
A Pataki administration official said that her plan had to contain those cuts to be credible in the Legislature, which has rejected many proposals similar to the ones advocated by Ms. McCaughey.
"There had to be fairness," said the official, speaking on the condition of anonymity. "Given the fiscal situation, in order to make the necessary cuts, everyone has to tighten their belts."
The plan proposes making it mandatory that all the state's poor patients, as well as some elderly people, enroll in a managed-care program, for a savings of $76 million, which is nearly a third less than Ms. McCaughey had initially estimated. Managed care, in place in New York since 1991, also means a cut in payments to hospitals, because more money is diverted to health-maintenance organizations, which are permitted to charge less than hospitals for Medicaid services.
Hospital and nursing home executives said the combination of lower rates and managed care is too heavy a burden and could cause layoffs of hospital employees that would ultimately hurt the quality of care.
Kenneth E. Raske, president of the Greater New York Hospital Association, said the cut would be worse than any attempted under Gov. Mario M. Cuomo. He said he intends to persuade the new Governor and individual lawmakers to work against it.
"I believe that hospitals are prepared to give up something in context of the fiscal crisis," he said. "But the magnitude, I believe, is so devastating that it is important that many of these cuts be called back."
In what may become one of most contentious elements of the plan, Ms. McCaughey proposed a limit of 100 hours a month on all personal-care services, like bathing or feeding. She would also drop services from anyone who receives only personal care not related to hygiene, like cooking or cleaning. Those savings would represent $87 million.
The proposal seeks to save $58 billion in so-called "optional services," most prominently routine dental care for adults. No services for children were cut, and the plan retained benefits like prescription drugs, artificial limbs and eyeglasses.
Her proposal would also seek to save $42 million in transportation costs.

HEADLINE: In Urgent Age of Newt, Byrd Slows the Pace

BYLINE: By ROBIN TONER, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Jan. 18

 BODY:
Over in the House, Republicans are intent on defying the traditional, ever-so-stately pace of the legislative process and pushing through their "Contract With America." But between the Republicans and their dream of a 100-day revolution stands the Senate.
More specifically, Senate Democrats. And most specifically of all, Senator Robert C. Byrd, Democrat of West Virginia. 
 Mr. Byrd, who has spent 36 of his 77 years in the Senate, reveres the deliberate gait of the legislative process. He boasts on the Senate floor of never having read the Contract With America, the campaign manifesto written by Speaker Newt Gingrich and other House Republicans, and which drives much of political Washington these days. He says he is not about to see his beloved institution fall victim to the "steamroller" of an upstart House, and rush through sweeping legislation without adequate debate and deliberation.
Since Mr. Byrd has served as majority leader, minority leader and President pro tem of the Senate, not to mention whip and committee chairman, he is steeped in the deep magic of the Senate's rules. Even in the urgent Age of Newt, he knows how to slow things down.
"We should not be cowed like whipped dogs," he said this afternoon in an interview that he occasionally interrupted to give arcane instructions to his staff on the filing of first- and second-degree amendments, marshaling his forces for the latest skirmish on the Senate floor. "We should be senators."
This week, Mr. Byrd was helping to lead the slowdown on a Republican bill to make it more difficult for Congress to pass "unfunded mandates" -- laws and regulations that impose new costs on state and local governments without their consent. Senator Bob Dole of Kansas, the majority leader, has scheduled a vote for Thursday to try to shut off debate, complaining that the Senate was in the grip of "Byrdlock."
Mr. Byrd responded with the elaborate civilities of an earlier time, saying he had great personal esteem for Senator Dole and valued him as a worthy adversary -- despite what he called the majority leader's penchant for "these little cutesy phrases." Mr. Byrd said he might end up supporting the unfunded mandate bill, but he wanted to make sure it is fully considered.
All week the Capitol has been buzzing as these two seasoned warriors began to maneuver around each other; it is considered part of the early testing for the battle over a constitutional amendment to require a balanced budget.
"I know the Senator from West Virginia is a master at the game," Mr. Dole observed wryly on the Senate floor the other night. "He knows the balanced budget amendment is somewhere on the horizon."
The amendment, of course, is a top priority for the Republicans, and some Democrats as well; it is anathema to Senator Byrd, who describes it as a gimmick being rammed through without giving the public "any idea of how we are going to enact over one trillion dollars of spending cuts and tax increases over the next seven years."
Mr. Byrd also argues that this amendment and the line item veto, which would allow the President to eliminate specific items from the budget, represent a fundamental shifting of power from the legislative to the executive and judicial branches of the Government.
Asked this afternoon how hard he will oppose the balanced budget amendment, the Senator replied in the gentle cadence of the West Virginia coal fields: "To me there is no 50 percent of the way, or 75 percent. It's 100 percent with me. I have reasons based on weeks, months, years of study."
Few relish the idea of matching wits and rules with Mr. Byrd. Senator Dirk Kempthorne, the 43-year-old Idaho Republican who is managing the unfunded mandate bill on the floor, acknowledged that he was on a "steep learning curve" but added, "I think I'll learn by watching him maneuver."
Mr. Byrd is a product of Depression-era West Virginia, and has watered his political roots with considerable Federal largesse through his role first as chairman and now as ranking member of the Appropriations Committee. He is for all intents and purposes free of electoral concerns. He won re-election last November with 69 percent of the vote -- a fact that he notes when confronted with the Republicans' claim of an electoral mandate for their Contract With America.
"I carried every county in West Virginia," he says. "I didn't get a mandate to roll over and play dead like a whipped dog."
At a time when much of the debate on the floor is packaged for television, Senator Byrd harkens back to an earlier time. To wit: "I have never been very convivial with respect to making the U.S. Senate a second House of Representatives." He muses on the framers of the Constitution, the role of a legislator, the sinfulness of man, the meaning of eternity, the virtues of the King James version of the Bible.
There are an array of rules that an individual senator can invoke to work his will, and Mr. Byrd is said to know more of them than almost anyone. This week, for example, he relied on a little used rule that said committees could meet freely only until the third hour of the Senate's legislative day, after which a senator could stop them by objecting.
He is also noted for his ability to structure amendments, which was at the heart of the battle over the Clinton Administration's economic stimulus package. In that case, Mr. Byrd's tactics helped stiffen opposition that ultimately scuttled the bill.
Mr. Dole vowed today to "try to keep up with Newt and the House Republicans," although asserting, "Senator Byrd feels so strongly about the balanced budget amendment that he'll do anything he can to prevent that coming to the floor."
Mr. Byrd, for his part, seemed unperturbed by the coming struggle. "Time is in the interest of good legislation," he said, coolly.

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Up on Revived Sense That Fed Will Raise Rates

BYLINE: By Reuters 

 BODY:
The dollar rose against most leading currencies yesterday on revived expectations that the Federal Reserve would raise interest rates at the end of the month.
Comments from a top Fed official and a regional survey of economic conditions by the central bank helped to underscore perceptions of a robust American economy, renewing expectations that the Fed would raise short-term interest rates after its policy-making committee meets on Jan. 31 and Feb. 1, currency dealers said. 
 Late last week, relatively weak retail sales figures were reported, arousing speculation that the Fed might limit or even forgo a rate rise.
Today, though, in an interview, the Federal Reserve's vice chairman, Alan S. Blinder, said the economy had so far shown few signs of slowing down. He added that he might be willing to back another increase in interest rates.
"Basically the comments from Blinder seemed to set the dollar off," said Curtis Perkins, vice president at the Chemical Bank.
The Fed, in a periodic survey of the economy in its 12 bank districts, said strong consumer spending was contributing to a vigorous economic expansion. The report also said inflationary expectations were rising.
Some dealers said the dollar was also aided by speculation that Germany's central bank might allow a short-term interest rate to trade lower this week. But several others said the chance of such a reduction was remote.
Over all, dealers saw the dollar confined to a relatively narrow range, with little to push the currency too far in either direction.
In New York trading late yesterday, the dollar rose to 1.5344 German marks from 1.5332 marks on Tuesday. The dollar advanced to 99.57 Japanese yen, from 99.13 on Tuesday. The British pound edged up to $1.5700 from $1.5667.
In other currency trading, the Canadian dollar continued to weaken. That currency has been under pressure because of investors' concerns over the country's high budget deficit and because interest rates in Canada continue to lag behind rising rates in the United States. The Canadian dollar has fallen 1.3 percent so far in 1995.
It reached an eight-year low of 70.16 United States cents yesterday before recovering to 70.423 cents, down from 70.44 cents on Tuesday.

HEADLINE: U.S. and Russia at Odds, Despite Talks

BYLINE: By ELAINE SCIOLINO, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: GENEVA, Jan. 18

 BODY:
The United States and Russia talked past each other today.
In intense meetings aimed at repairing the deteriorating relationship between their countries, Secretary of State Warren Christopher and Foreign Minister Andrei V. Kozyrev could not agree on how to resolve Russia's war in the rebel region of Chechnya or how to bridge the gaps on other issues. 
 Although both men noted at a news conference afterward that their countries' relationship was reaching "maturity," it was impossible to conceal their differences.
Mr. Kozyrev insisted that Russia's war in Chechnya was "a purely domestic affair," while Mr. Christopher warned that the war was exacting too high a price for Russia both at home and abroad.
"What we don't want to see is a Russia mired in a military quagmire that erodes reform and tends to isolate Russia," Mr. Christopher said in his opening statement to the media. "I reiterated to the Foreign Minister that the conflict must be brought to an end."
Mr. Kozyrev looked visibly uncomfortable as Mr. Christopher delivered his stern message. The Russian official stared down at the table in front of him, fiddling with his pen and shaking his left foot nervously.
By contrast, Mr. Kozyrev dismissed the American criticism of the repression of the Chechen rebellion, where thousands have been killed and tens of thousands wounded or made homeless in more than five weeks of fighting. He said that over the last two decades American presidents have deployed American troops inside the United States a number of times.
"Any democratically elected president, in accordance with the constitution, has the right and sometimes the obligation to give orders of that kind," he said.
Mr. Kozyrev offered no suggestion that President Boris N. Yeltsin, accused by many former supporters of adopting heavy-handed Soviet-style behavior, needed to make peace with the Russian reformers who have deserted him.
Rather, Mr. Kozyrev suggested half seriously that Mr. Yeltsin had no need for them. "I must say, as a kind of joke, but which has some truth in it, that in order to restore the relations with the reformists, the President needs only to come up to the mirror, because he himself is the major reformer," Mr. Kozyrev said.
Mr. Kozyrev also registered concerns that Congress may cut aid to Russia and delay ratification of the second strategic arms reduction accord. And he equated his concerns about Congress with Mr. Christopher's concerns about Chechnya.
During their six-and-a-half-hour meeting, Mr. Christopher raised other issues that have put the Russian-American relationship on a continuing downward spiral for the last several months -- its failure to provide the United States with a detailed accounting of its arms deals to Iran, as Mr. Yeltsin promised Mr. Clinton in Washington last fall; its eagerness to reward Iraq by lifting at least some economic sanctions, and its refusal to provide sufficent information about its chemical weapons stockpiles and manufacturing plants.
But more than once, Mr. Christopher recited positive pledges that Mr. Kozyrev had made to him in private -- a commitment to continue economic reform and democratization in Russia, a willingness to send relief and refugee aid to Chechnya and a determination to work for a peaceful settlement of the war and for democratic elections.
In addition, Mr. Christopher was unwilling to issue threats that the Administration would be loath to carry out. Although Mr. Kozyrev offered no concrete formula either in public or private for ending the fighting in Chechnya, Mr. Christopher assured him that the Administration would oppose any effort by the new Republican-dominated Congress to cut American aid to Russia.
On the contrary, the United States intends to ask Congress for "substantial" amounts of new aid for Russia in its budget requests, a senior aide to Mr. Christopher said.
In another conciliatory gesture, Mr. Christopher today began a formal dialogue with Russia on how it could someday be linked with NATO.
Last month in Brussels, Mr. Kozyrev stunned both Mr. Christopher and other NATO foreign ministers when he refused to sign documents to formalize Russia's participation in a plan for ushering Russia into military cooperation with NATO. Although Mr. Christopher urged Mr. Kozyrev to sign the documents as soon as possible, he declined to say when he would do so.
The positive gestures are part of the Administration's strategy throughout the Chechnya crisis -- to use every opportunity to back both Mr. Yeltsin and Mr. Kozyrev as reformers and democrats.
In an apparent effort at diplomatic damage control after the news conference, three senior aides to Mr. Christopher told reporters that Mr. Kozyrev's demeanor in private was more conciliatory than his public performance. One senior official even called the talks the "most productive" encounter ever between Mr. Christopher and his Russian counterpart.
Another said, "They weren't bad at all."
Indeed, Mr. Kozyrev injected a few positive comments into his critical ones.
Russia "will not permit" the emergence of a "cold peace" between Russia and the West, he said. His remarks apparently were intended as a corrective to Mr. Yeltsin's assault on the United States and its NATO allies at a European summit meeting in Budapest last month, in which he declared that the expansion of NATO was anti-Russian and that the West was "in danger of plunging into a cold peace."
Mr. Kozyrev also publicly expressed concern about "the lengthy nature" of the Chechen war as well as human rights violations in the breakaway republic. And he pledged, albeit in vague terms, that Russia is determined to find a political solution for Chechnya that would both keep it inside the Russian federation but allow its people to elect its own representatives.
But it is not at all certain that Mr. Kozyrev is able shape his country's foreign policy or the outcome of the Chechnya crisis. When asked by Mr. Christopher if he was sure that the recent Russian proposal for a cease-fire would go into effect, one senior American official said, Mr. Kozyrev bluntly replied that he was not.

HEADLINE: Survey by Fed Reports A 'Vibrant' Economy

BYLINE: By ROBERT D. HERSHEY Jr., Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Jan. 18

 BODY:
Growth of the economy "remained vibrant" into early January, with divergences narrowing among various parts of the country, a periodic survey of conditions in the 12 Federal Reserve districts showed today.
But the robust expansion, which is widely thought to have approached an annual rate of 5 percent in the final quarter of 1994, has begun to generate evidence of spreading inflation, the report said. 
 "Labor markets continued to strengthen," leading in some areas to upward pressure on wages, the Fed found in its so-called beige book survey that is conducted in preparation for meetings of its Federal Open Market Committee, the central bank's rate-setting group. "Price increases seemed somewhat more widespread than were reported in early December."
But there were other indications today that economic growth could be slowing. The Commerce Department said business inventories rose for an eighth month in November, suggesting that companies built up stocks in anticipation of strong holiday sales that did not materialize.
Still, the Fed's report, though dismissed by some economists as anecdotal, spurred expectations that the bank would again raise short-term interest rates, probably at its two-day meeting that begins on Jan. 31.
Adding to this belief today was the expression of inflation concern by Alan S. Blinder, the Fed's vice chairman. "I think a fair reading of the evidence is that whatever the danger was two months ago, it looks bigger now," Mr. Blinder said in an interview with Reuters.
In the survey published today, compiled by the Federal Reserve Bank of Chicago from information collected from business and other outside sources before Jan. 10, some districts showed rather strikingly that price pressures had spread beyond commodities and goods at relatively early stages of production.
The Minneapolis Fed, for example, cited tight job conditions, "higher wage increases than were common in recent years" and increasing shortages of some raw materials and semifinished items despite what have become common price rises.
Yet inquiries from the Cleveland Fed found "few indications of any broad-based wage pressures" and price pressures still largely confined to industrial commodities. Kansas City reported that pressure had eased in the market for skilled factory and construction workers.
In summarizing the overall findings, the Fed described retail sales as having increased at a "moderate pace" during the holiday shopping season, with "weather effects and other factors" restricting gains and masking "stronger underlying momentum in spending growth."
A Commerce Department tally last week, based on a small sample of outlets, showed retail sales essentially flat in December.
Mexico's economic crisis was cited by the Dallas and San Francisco district banks as quickly causing a drop in sales to Mexican shoppers now limited by a sharply devalued peso. Stores along the border were said by the Dallas bank to expect no pickup for at least three months.
"Manufacturers continued to provide some of the strongest reports within the districts, although the overall growth rate may have slowed modestly," the beige book declared.
Higher mortgage rates have curtailed house building in most regions, the survey found, but much of the slack has been taken up by commercial buildings and apartments.
In the New York district, recent developments indicate "some improvement" over all, with holiday sales meeting or slightly exceeding expectations and activity in office leasing vigorous enough to reduce vacancy rates in areas including downtown and midtown Manhattan.
The Commerce Department's report said business inventories rose seven-tenths of 1 percent in November, totaling a seasonally adjusted $919.8 billion in November. Analysts had expected the gain but said leaner stockpiles might be ahead.
The department also reported that all business sales, about a third of which are retail, rose 1 percent in November after advancing three-tenths of 1 percent in October. The inventory-to-sales ratio remained at 1.40 -- barely up from its low of 1.39 in August. It would take 1.4 months to exhaust stockpiles at the November sales rate.

HEADLINE: DIARY;
Developments in Congress

 BODY:
HOUSE: It was easily the most chaotic day since lawmakers convened two weeks ago. First there was a clash on the floor as Democrats pressed their attack on Speaker Newt Gingrich's book deal and Republicans sprang to his defense. On a party-line roll-call of 217 to 178, the House voted to strike from the record comments made by Representative Carrie P. Meek, a Florida Democrat who asked -- in a part of her text that Republicans prevented her from delivering -- "Who does this Speaker really work for? Is it the American people or his New York publishing house?" Then the Mexican financial crisis threatened to become a flash point. Republican leaders said they would demand that Democrats produce substantial votes for the $40 billion rescue measure the Clinton Administration is drafting. Representative Dick Armey of Texas, the majority leader, said he wanted more than half the Democratic caucus to support the measure. "It's their President," he said. 
 SENATE: By dawn's early light, members of the Senate Judiciary Committee gathered to take up the balanced-budget amendment to sidestep the parliamentary footwork of Senator Robert C. Byrd, Democrat of West Virginia. On Tuesday, Mr. Byrd tied the committee in knots by invoking an obscure Senate rule that allows any senator to block a committee from meeting more than two hours after the Senate has convened for the day. Senator Orrin G. Hatch, the Utah Republican who heads the committee, thanked panel members for showing up this morning at 8:30. The committee went on to approve the amendment -- intended to balance the Federal budget by 2002 -- by a vote of 15 to 3 and sent it to the full Senate for action. Constitutional amendments require a two-thirds vote of each house and ratification by 38 state legislatures.

HEADLINE: Top Prospect for C.I.A. Post Is Said to Have Doubts About Job

BYLINE: By DOUGLAS JEHL, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Jan. 18

 BODY:
Deputy Defense Secretary John M. Deutch, once regarded as the front-runner to become Director of Central Intelligence, has expressed serious reservations about taking the job, leaving the White House to widen its search.
Associates said today that Mr. Deutch was reluctant to give up his policy position at the Pentagon. They also said he had concluded that because of academic sensitivities about the Central Intelligence Agency his serving as its chief could prevent his becoming president of the Massachusetts Institute of Technology, where he was provost. 
 White House officials had described Mr. Deutch as an ideal candidate to succeed the former director, R. James Woolsey, who abruptly resigned last month. But aides to President Clinton said that while Mr. Deutch's decision had complicated their search the President would not try to persuade him to reconsider.
At the same time, officials said it now appeared unlikely that Erskine B. Bowles, the consensus choice to succeed Robert E. Rubin as head of the National Economic Council, would be installed in that post. The officials said that Mr. Bowles had done so well as deputy White House chief of staff for operations that Leon E. Panetta, the chief of staff, did not want to lose him. The officials said the job of coordinating Administration economic policy might instead go to Laura D'Andrea Tyson, chairman of the Council of Economic Advisers.
In addition to the economic and intelligence vacancies, two other top posts, White House political director and Cabinet liaison, remain unfilled, underscoring the difficulty Mr. Clinton has had in choosing people for important Administration positions.
In saying today that a decision on a new intelligence chief would probably not be made until next week, Administration officials noted that William J. Crowe Jr., a retired admiral who had also been mentioned as a candidate, had indicated that he would prefer to remain Ambassador to Britain.
Among the candidates still being considered, the officials said, is Senator William S. Cohen, the Maine Republican who is a former vice chairman of the Senate Intelligence Committee. But Mr. Cohen has said he has no plans to leave the Senate.
Others mentioned are Jamie Gorelick, the Deputy Attorney General; Adm. William A. Owens, vice chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff, and Samuel R. Berger, deputy national security adviser.
The officials cautioned that information about the search was being tightly held. Some said they suspected that only Mr. Clinton, Mr. Panetta, Vice President Al Gore and Anthony Lake, the national security adviser, knew precisely who was under consideration.
Mr. Deutch was highly regarded because he had showed himself an effective manager at the Pentagon, worked well with Congress and already knew a great deal about the intelligence agencies' operations. He and Mr. Woolsey have reviewed major intelligence issues, including photo reconnaissance and electronic eavesdropping, which together consume perhaps a third of the nation's $28 billion intelligence budget.

HEADLINE: Woman in the News: Elizabeth Peterken McCaughey;
Taking On a Challenge

BYLINE: By IAN FISHER 

 BODY:
When she wanted to sidestep a question during the campaign, Betsy McCaughey would often smile and say, "I'm an expert in policy, not politics."
Now, as New York's Lieutenant Governor, Ms. McCaughey, a constitutional scholar with no previous experience in government, has taken on her first test as a policy maker with one of the state's knottiest and most expensive problems: revamping the $19 billion Medicaid system, which provides health care for the poor, disabled and elderly. 
 In turning to Ms. McCaughey (pronounced muh-COY) to succeed where others have failed, Gov. George E. Pataki chose a person who rose to prominence, and earned her spot on his ticket, because of articles she wrote just a year ago meticulously criticizing President Clinton's health care plan.
Yesterday, she released a Medicaid cost-cutting proposal that subjects her to the same sort of detailed scrutiny as she strives to change to one of the nation's largest government-run health care programs -- a system protected by litigious patient groups as well as powerful special interests like the hospitals and nursing homes that donate generously to Republicans, including Mr. Pataki.
By seeking more than half of the $1.2 billion she wants to cut from those very hospitals and nursing homes, Ms. McCaughey has already shifted course from her initial intention to spare them -- suggesting a grasp of political and economic reality and a willingness to bend when it became clear the administration wanted to spread the pain evenly between patients and providers.
The real power behind her role remains in question: her work may well be ignored as the Legislature and the Governor hammer out a deal. But at the very least, Mr. Pataki has brought greater prominence to his Lieutenant Governor than many of her predecessors have had. (Ms. McCaughey herself was kept to the sidelines in the campaign.)
For Ms. McCaughey, 46, the role represents her first chance to create the better health care system she has written about for the last year -- in articles for The New Republic and The Wall Street Journal that were praised for their earnestness and persuasive use of detail, and criticized for what some called shoddy scholarship and a conservative bent.
By proposing to force nursing homes and hospitals to share the cost-cutting burden, she underlined what she has already said: that she does not want to balance the Medicaid budget on the backs of the poor. Though she now lives on Park Avenue in Manhattan and sends her three daughters to private schools, she said that commitment to the poor stretches back to childhood.
"I did not grow up as a wealthy person," she said in an interview late last year. "My dad was a factory worker. And my brother was a serious asthmatic as a child. I remember my parents sitting at the kitchen table wondering if they could afford to take my brother to the hospital. So I'm firmly committed to Medicaid as part of the social safety net."
Elizabeth Peterken McCaughey, who prefers to be called Betsy, was born with her twin brother William in Pittsburgh on Oct. 10, 1948. Her father, Albert Peterken, a maintenance man in a fingernail-clipper factory, moved his wife, Ramona, and their children around the Northeast before settling in Westport, Conn., when Elizabeth was 6.
In 11th grade, she won a scholarship to Mary Burnham School for Girls in Northampton, Mass., and then another scholarship to Vassar College. There, she said, she largely ignored Vietnam War protests, spending her time reading in the library. She was the first member of her family to graduate from college.
She received a master's degree from Vassar in 1972, then moved to New York City with her husband, Thomas K. McCaughey, a Yale student she met at college. Separated since 1992, they were divorced early last year. They have three daughters -- Amanda, 15, Caroline, 13, and Diana, 10 -- who live with their mother. Last month, she announced her engagement to Wilbur L. Ross Jr., an investment banker who was a fund-raiser for Gov. Mario M. Cuomo.
In 1976, she was awarded a doctorate in constitutional history by Columbia University, and she has taught there and at Vassar. Until a few years ago, she was registered to vote as an independent. "I always assumed her to be a middle-of-the road Democrat," said Henry Graff, the Presidential studies expert who taught her at Columbia.
Ms. McCaughey began to be noticed in political circles last February after her articles on the Clinton health care plan struck a chord, provoking a White House response.
A few weeks before the Republican State Convention in May, Mr. Pataki, who had read her articles, met with her for the first time, but she says he did not recruit her as a running mate until the night before her designation by the convention.
She attacked her task of Medicaid cost-cutting with what has become a familiar pattern: collecting and digesting scores of documents from which she spits out factoids at random. This was how she tackled the Clinton health care plan. This was also the way, as she tells the story, that she rose from her working-class roots. Study, she once said, "was my one big chance in life."
However, some critics of her health care articles, which argued that the Clinton health care bill would limit choices for medical care, say she deftly dissected the bill's language but showed little understanding of how that language would translate into real programs.
"It was the kind of reasoning, if you could find a loophole you wrote half a page about it and ignored the context," said John Rother, the legislative director for the American Association of Retired People, which supported health care reform but did not endorse the Clinton plan.
But John R. Zagame, executive director of the New York Association of Counties, which has lobbied to lighten Medicaid costs on localities, said she has to her advantage that "she has not been tainted by the cynicism and sense of helplessness people in Albany have about Medicaid -- that you cannot change it."
Ms. McCaughey's urgency about Medicaid flows over every detail-laden sentence she speaks. "It is the most interesting intellectual problem," she said. "It is the intersection of economics, ethics, science, medicine, public policy and politics."
Already, she has begun the transition from scholar to politician. "Academics are soloists," she said during the campaign, "and successful candidates are team players."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Lieut. Gov. Betsy McCaughey detailing a report yesterday on changes in Medicaid at a news conference. Gov. George E. Pataki turned to Ms. McCaughey to take on the challenge of revamping the $19 billion Medicaid system, a task at which others have previously failed. (Andrea Mohin/The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Orange County Sells Risky Securities and Cuts Its Loss

BYLINE: By LESLIE WAYNE, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: SACRAMENTO, Calif., Jan. 18

 BODY:
Officials of Orange County, Calif., announced today the sale of all risky securities in the county's ill-fated investment pool, leaving it with a loss of $1.69 billion rather than the $2.02 billion predicted earlier.
"The hemorrhaging has stopped," said Thomas W. Hayes, the former California state treasurer who was hired by the county to sell the portfolio. "The pool now has short-term liquid securities and is safe. The pool will continue as an investment entity." 
 In a rare bit of good news, county officials said that gains from the sale of securities in the investment fund, along with accounting adjustments, had led to the revised number. This means that, on average, the local governments and others that invested in the fund are now expected to lose 22.3 percent of their money, not 27.2 percent, as initially expected.
Heavy borrowing by the Orange County investment pool to finance a risky bet on falling interest rates led to the bankruptcy, on Dec. 6, of one of the nation's most affluent counties. On filing for bankruptcy, Mr. Hayes, aided by Salomon Brothers, began to dispose of the portfolio. They traded risky securities for safer ones, while trying to make an accurate accounting of all the money in the fund.
The task was necessary so that all investors in the fund -- including Orange County itself and 186 other local government entities -- would have an accurate sense of how much money they lost. The selling also stopped the fund from losing even more money from a change in interest rates.
The reorganization of the portfolio was completed ahead of the 90-day timetable.
Currently, there is $5.88 billion left in the pool, some $5.13 billion in marketable securities and $540 million in cash. Of the $20 billion once held by the investment pool, about $13 billion was borrowed. The amount of cash put into the investment fund by Orange County and 186 municipalities in the area is now estimated at $7.57 billion -- not the $7.42 billion initially cited by officials.
Mr. Hayes said that part of the improvement over initial loss estimates came after Arthur Andersen accountants, piecing together fund documents, found some securities and investments that had not previously been accounted for. These included $310 million in cash, $150 million more in pool investments, along with $92 million in previously unidentified securities.
In addition, gains from the sale of securities in the pool exceeded initial estimates by $36 million. It was not disclosed how much profit and fee income Salomon Brothers received for selling the wide variety of risky securities.
