HEADLINE: With Opposition Rising, Clinton Pleads for Mexico Rescue Package

BYLINE: By DAVID E. SANGER, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Jan. 18

 BODY:
With Democrats and freshman Republicans alike in open revolt over the Administration's plan for a financial rescue package for Mexico, President Clinton made an unusual, direct appeal today to keep that country afloat.
Making his case to a group of business leaders, Mr. Clinton warned that Mexico's economic problems were "plainly also a danger to the economic future of the United States." 
 Mr. Clinton's warnings came as he and senior members of the Administration tried to calm angry voices in Congress and to underscore their argument that stabilizing the United States' most-populous neighbor is a matter of national security, not economics.
But many Democrats and several freshman Republicans angrily responded that American taxpayers were being asked to bail out fiscally inept Mexican leaders and large American investors who had poured money into Mexican stocks and bonds, rather than helping the near-bankrupt District of Columbia or bankrupt Orange County, Calif.
For the first time, Mr. Clinton said today that he was also acting out of fear that Mexico's fiscal crisis could spread to other economies on which the United States is increasingly dependent.
"If we fail to act," the President said in the Cash Room of the Treasury, where a group of business executives had been hastily gathered, "the crisis of confidence in Mexico's economy could spread to other emerging countries in Latin America and Asia, the kind of markets that buy our goods and services today and that will buy far more of them in the future."
That Mr. Clinton felt compelled to make a public case for a package he has already negotiated with Congressional leaders seemed to underscore how much trouble the White House fears it may be facing. The confrontation is the most serious challenge yet to the guiding thought behind Mr. Clinton's foreign and domestic economic policy: That free trade and the exports it generates are the main fuel for new jobs and prosperity in the United States.
As an economic aide to Mr. Clinton said today, "What the White House is learning is that economic interdependence goes two ways, down as well as up."
Mr. Clinton's advisers said they believed that the $40 billion loan guarantee package would prevail on Capitol Hill, although perhaps with a long list of extraordinarily strict conditions that may cause the Mexican Government to bridle.
"It will be more contentious than we thought," said Representative Bill Richardson, Democrat of New Mexico, as he emerged from a meeting with Vice President Al Gore. "We could defeat this legislation."
One senior Administration official said he hoped to have the rescue package passed in the House and Senate by the end of this week, the kind of swift action that the Treasury Department contends is needed to keep the markets calm. But that time frame now seems unlikely, and today the Mexican stock market began to decline again as investors grew nervous that the United States help promised last week might not be forthcoming.
Mexico's hope is to use the loan guarantees for psychological advantage, assuring investors without actually using the American guarantees and paying the hefty fees Washington would charge to cover the risk taken by taxpayers. That fee, essentially an insurance premium, could total more than $3 billion.
Mr. Gore argued today that the United States could reap a significant profit on the deal with Mexico. Both he and Treasury Secretary Robert E. Rubin are trying to head off an effort by conservatives in Congress to append conditions to the loan guarantee, including requiring Mexico to try to stop illegal aliens from nearing the United States border and requiring Mexico to turn over part of its state-owned companies as collateral.
Mexico is so weakened economically by its current devaluation crisis that it can do little to oppose such demands. But Mexican officials say some political demands are not negotiable.
An official in the office of President Ernesto Zedillo Ponce de Leon who insisted on anonymity said: "Are you going to see Mexican soldiers policing the border? No. Will you see D.E.A. agents freely patrolling the streets? No."
At the heart of Mr. Clinton's national security argument is the fear that a devalued peso will make the United States more attractive than ever to illegal aliens from Mexico. The White House projected on Tuesday that if Mexico's financial problems worsened, 430,000 more illegal aliens would enter Texas and California this year, a 30 percent increase over the number who usually sneak across the border.
So far, the evidence is scarce. Officials of the Immigration and Naturalization Service along the border said today that there had not been any unusual increase in illegal crossings since the value of the peso began to fall just before Christmas.

HEADLINE: Stocks Are Mostly Flat on Fed Data

BYLINE: By ANTHONY RAMIREZ 

 BODY:
In unusually heavy trading, the stock market closed mixed but essentially unchanged yesterday as new data from the Federal Reserve indicated that inflation might still be lingering in the economy.
The prospect of favorable corporate earnings this month is helping to support what would otherwise be a market depressed by inflation fears, analysts said. 
 Reports of strong operating earnings from the Intel Corporation and other technology companies helped lift the Nasdaq index a bit yesterday, as other widely held technology companies like Apple Computer are set to report today. Computer industry stocks were the only group whose shares gained more than 20 percent last year.
The Dow Jones industrial average fell 1.68 points, to 3,928.98, while the broader Standard & Poor's 500-stock index slipped 0.34 point, to 469.71. The smaller-company Nasdaq composite index rose 0.24 point, to 772.38.
Volume on the New York Stock Exchange was higher than normal, with 345.2 million shares changing hands, about 8 percent above this year's daily average of 320 million shares and 19 percent above last year's daily average of 290 million shares.
Even with yesterday's slowdown, all three leading stock indexes are nearing their 1994 highs. The Dow is just 1 percent away from its peak of 3,978.36 on Jan. 31, 1994, while the S.& P. 500 is 2.5 percent shy of its high of 482 points on Feb. 2. The Nasdaq is the farthest away, about 4 percent less than its high of 803.93 on March 18.
Traders seemed to brace yesterday for the inflation-is-still-here data from the Federal Reserve's staff. Stock prices dropped sharply before noon, when the Fed briefing book, known as the beige book, was released.
Based on economic data collected earlier this month from the Fed's 12 district banks, the Fed's staff concluded that price increases "seemed somewhat more widespread than were reported in early December."
Using this and other data, Fed governors may well raise interest rates again. The stock market rallied on Friday and Monday, in part because traders were betting the Fed would moderate or even forgo a rate increase at its Jan. 31-Feb. 1 policy meeting.
Against this market-depressing tide, Intel reported on Tuesday that it had seen an increase of more than 40 percent in operating income before taking into account a large charge for replacement of its flawed Pentium computer chips.
"The market focused on the operating number," said Tim Grazioso, managing director in charge of Nasdaq trading at Cantor Fitzgerald & Company. "So Intel pretty much raised the entire Nasdaq group."
Erika Klauer, semiconductor analyst at Salomon Brothers, said Intel management was upbeat with analysts about 1995 trends, with expectations of perhaps 30 percent growth, to 64 million computer chips, and more than a third of that number the lucrative Pentium chip. Accordingly, Ms. Klauer, who has a buy recommendation on the stock, sees Intel's share price rising this year to between $85 and $90.
Yesterday, Intel rose 2 3/8, to 69 3/8, and was the second-most-active stock of the day, with nearly 12 million shares changing hands. The most active stock was RJR Nabisco, with nearly 12.1 million shares traded on the New York Stock Exchange. It slipped 1/8, to 5 5/8.
The earthquake in Japan depressed some American stocks. Procter & Gamble said that two of its six plants in Japan were damaged. P.& G. shares dropped 1 3/8, to 61 7/8.
The New York Stock Exchange composite index fell 0.28 point, to 255.97, with advancing stocks lagging behind declining issues by 1,061 to 1,171. The American Stock Exchange market value index rose 0.88 point, to 439.97.

HEADLINE: COMPANY REPORTS;
BANKAMERICA CORP. (BAC,N)

BYLINE: Reuters 

 BODY:
The BankAmerica Corporation said yesterday that its earnings rose in the fourth quarter and full year based on stronger interest income and reduced credit losses.
The nation's second-largest banking company said net income in the quarter ended Dec. 31 advanced 19.2 percent, to $591 million, or $1.41 a share, from $496 million, or $1.21 a share, in the comparable period a year earlier. 
 Net interest income increased by $147 million in the quarter, the bank, which is based in San Francisco, said.
Net credit losses in the quarter fell 83 percent, to $36 million, partly due to recoveries on foreign loans in Poland and Ecuador, it said.
Noninterest income fell in the quarter, in part because of lower trading income.
"Increasing earnings per share were our most important financial objective for the year," the company's chairman, Richard Rosenberg, said in a statement.
"We believe we are well positioned to benefit from an improving California economy and continuing growth in most of our other domestic and offshore markets," he added.
For the year, net earnings grew 11.4 percent, to $2.18 billion, or $5.36 a share, from $1.95 billion, or $4.79 a share.
BankAmerica shares fell 87.5 cents, to $41.625, in trading yesterday on the New York Stock Exchange.(Reuters)

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Treasury Prices Decline For 2d Consecutive Day

BYLINE: By ROBERT HURTADO 

 BODY:
Prices of Treasury securities declined yesterday for the second consecutive day as expectations increased that the Federal Reserve would soon raise short-term interest rates.
While many analysts and traders have for some time expected the Fed to raise rates for the seventh time since February, the size and the timing of the Fed's next move have been debated. Market participants' opinions change from day to day on each new economic report. 
 The price of the 30-year bond fell 3/32 , to 9628/32 , for a yield of 7.77 percent, unchanged from Tuesday. Rates on shorter maturities like bills were slightly mixed, with a three-month bill down 2 basis points, to 5.70 percent, and a six-month issue unchanged at 6.15 percent. A basis point is one-hundredth of 1 percent.
James Hale, a fixed-income analyst for MMS International in San Francisco, a market research and analysis firm, said most of the selling yesterday was in the shorter maturities.
The pressure on prices increased in the late afternoon when the Fed released its periodic survey of conditions in its 12 districts. The report, known as the beige book, said that the economy was vibrant and that price pressures had become more widespread since the last report.
"This almost guarantees that the Fed will tighten credit" after its policy-making committee meets, beginning Jan. 31, Mr. Hale said. Many traders and analysts expect the increase to be 50 basis points, while others predict an increase as large as 75 basis points. Some say the Fed will not act at all.
In early trading, prices of Treasury securities sagged on comments by the vice chairman of the Fed, Alan S. Blinder. Mr. Blinder said in an interview with Reuters that the danger of the economy bubbling over had risen since the last interest rate increase. He played down Mexico as a monetary-policy factor, saying that while Fed officials could not ignore the crisis, they must not sacrifice their chief goal of keeping inflation under control.
Data on November business inventories yesterday had little impact on the Treasury cash market. The Commerce Department reported that inventories rose seven-tenths of 1 percent in November.
The bond market has also largely ignored rising commodity prices. The Commodity Research Bureau index of 21 commodities rose 1.07 points yesterday, to 236.65, its highest point in three weeks. And crude oil prices have risen by more than $2 a barrel in the last month and a half, Mr. Hale of MMS International said. "While the Treasury market has not been closely following the C.R.B. index, traders should be aware of these rising inflation indicators," he said.
Traders will face a supply of new paper next week. The Treasury announced yesterday that it planned to sell $17.25 billion in new two-year notes on Tuesday and $11 billion in five-year notes on Wednesday.
In when-issued trading late yesterday the new two-year notes were being offered at a price to yield 7.52 percent, and the five-year notes at a price to yield 7.73 percent.
In other trading, the Federal National Mortgage Association, also known as Fannie Mae, priced its first global callable debenture issue.
Underwriters led by Lehman Brothers and Merrill Lynch, priced the $1 billion 10-year callable debenture at par to yield 8.50 percent, or about 80 basis points more than a Treasury note with a comparable maturity.
Rated triple-A by Moody's Investors Service and Standard & Poor's, about 65 percent of the issue was sold in the United States with the rest overseas.
In the municipal bond market, prices were up on expectations that fewer bonds would be issued this year. The average yield to maturity in the Bond Buyer index of actively traded 40 municipal issues fell 3 basis points, to 6.75 percent.
The Los Angeles Harbor Department sold $200 million of double-A rated revenue bonds through Bear, Stearns. The series A portion of the financing was priced to yield from a maximum 6.55 percent, with serial bonds yielding from 5 percent in 1996 to 6.35 percent in 2012. For series B, the maximum yield was 6.722 percent, with serials from 5.50 percent in 1999 to 6.60 percent in 2014 and 2015. Underwriters noted that for some investors, interest on the series B bonds might be subject to the Federal alternative minimum tax.
In the corporate market, the AT&T Corporation sold $300 million of 8.35 percent debentures due in 2025 at a price of 98.227 to yield 8.514 percent through Salomon Brothers. Priced to yield about 31 basis points more than the 30-year Treasury, the issue is rated Aa3 by Moody's, AA by S.& P. and AA+ by Duff & Phelps.

HEADLINE: BOOKS OF THE TIMES;
A Call to Deregulate Rules and Regulations

BYLINE: By CHRISTOPHER LEHMANN-HAUPT 

 BODY:
THE DEATH OF COMMON SENSE
How Law Is Suffocating America
By Philip K. Howard
202 pages. Random House. $18.
Americans may well take pride in living under what Aristotle called "government by laws, not men," but the situation has lately become ridiculous, writes Philip K. Howard in his exasperated book, "The Death of Common Sense: How Law Is Suffocating America." 
 Because of a campaign in the last three decades to substitute statutes for human judgment, Mr. Howard asserts, all sorts of unintended consequences have occurred. For instance, in 1991 New York City tested a system of coin-operated sidewalk toilets that seemed to work perfectly. But the city was unable to install the system, Mr. Howard writes, because "wheelchairs couldn't fit inside" the toilets, and "New York's anti-discrimination law provides that it is illegal to 'withhold or deny' from the disabled any access to 'public accommodation.' "
And, for instance, most of those charming old farmhouse bed and breakfasts in upstate New York are operated illegally because "most cannot comply with fire codes specifying enclosed fire stairs and other requirements for 'multi-story transient lodging' " that were written with motels in mind. By law, such bed and breakfasts will either have to be rebuilt at a prohibitive expense or face going out of business.
Stories like these abound in "The Death of Common Sense," stories of inflexible rules, of pointless but costly regulations, of bureaucratic paralysis and of conflicting demands for equality. In fact, the repetition of horror stories seems to be the organizing principle of Mr. Howard's tract.
Yet from his many stories he draws lessons of how such a presumed impasse was arrived at. America's desire for a perfect system of laws, he writes, "comes directly out of the Enlightenment," when "the philosophy of rationalism" held "that a natural order in government could be found similar to the order that Isaac Newton thought he had found in nature."
With the New Deal, he continues, "statutes began to dominate the legal landscape, providing job relief, welfare programs and Social Security; agencies like the Securities and Exchange Commission were created as part of a broad plan to regulate the economy." Individuals were still important "because they had authority," he adds. "Perhaps the greatest testimony to their accomplishments is that we still remember their names: Ickes, Tugwell, Hopkins, Landis, Corcoran, Cohen, Douglas, Berle, to name a few."
But in the 1950's, he continues, "the abuses of McCarthyism and civil rights violations in the South had led . . . to a heightened distrust of government officials" that developed "overpowering momentum during the counterculture revolution" in the 1960's. Mr. Howard singles out two people for promoting a greater reliance on law: to a minor extent Theodore J. Lowi, who in his book "The End of Liberalism: Policy and the Crisis of Public Authority" (1969), in Mr. Howard's words, "saw greater specificity as the antidote for special interest groups."
And to a major degree he blames Charles A. Reich, the Yale professor who wrote "The Greening of America," for two influential articles that appeared in the Yale Law Journal, "The New Property" (1964) and "Individual Rights and Social Welfare: The Emerging Legal Issues" (1965). These writings redefined individual rights as property requiring the respect of government. "Government should gain no power," Mr. Reich asserted, "by reason of its role as a dispenser of wealth." (124)
In Mr. Howard's view, this was a confusion of power with freedom, and altered what was once considered "rights against law," or in James Madison's words "rights against all government encroachments," to what Isaiah Berlin has defined as the right to anything. More succinctly put, rights were changed from a shield to a sword.
An effect of this change, in the author's view, has been the opposite of what was intended. With so many rights competing, no one has any rights. With too many laws on the books, there is no law. With so many weapons to fight hatred, everyone fights one another and hatred increases. "If there is no flexibility for the regulator, there is no flexibility for us," he points out. "Creating rules without flexibility is just a version of central planning." (180) Or metaphorically, "We fight off rules like branches hitting us in the face, losing any sense of where we are supposed to be going and bleeding from illogical dictates that serve no one's purpose."
How do we get out of these woods? Mr. Howard, a public-affairs advocate and founding partner of the New York law firm of Howard, Darby & Levin in Manhattan, offers no specific program. Only in his endless horror stories is he detailed.
But he makes clear that he believes in an escape from suffocating rules and a return to initiative. Civil servants should be given guidelines, but to get things done they must seize the day. As he perorates: "One basic change in approach will get us going: we should stop looking to law to provide the final answer. Law should articulate goals, award subsidies, allocate presumptions and provide mechanisms for resolving disagreements, but law should almost never provide the final answer. Life is too complex. Our public goals are too complex. . . . Law can't think, and so law must be entrusted to humans and they must take responsibility for their interpretation of it."
In short, what Mr. Howard is trying to do with this thoughtful little book is drive us all sane.

HEADLINE: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING -- ADDENDA;
Ogilvy to Begin New York (love) Affair

BYLINE: By James Bennet 

 BODY:
The New York State Department of Economic Development said yesterday that it had selected Ogilvy & Mather New York to handle its travel and tourism account, also known as the "I (love) New York" campaign. Billings, subject to legislative review, were estimated at $8 million to $10 million for the state's fiscal year, which runs from April 1 to March 31.
The assignment came after a mandated review in which McCann-Erickson New York, the agency on the account from August 1991 through July 1994, decided not to participate; McCann New York's decision came after the department asked another agency, Anderson & Lembke in New York, to produce two television commercials for the campaign. 
 The review was to have been decided last fall but was delayed for the gubernatorial election; the selection of Ogilvy New York and its subsidiary, O.& M. Dataconsult in Buffalo, was made by Charles A. Gargano, whom Gov. George E. Pataki named commissioner of the department. The other finalists were Bozell New York, Saatchi & Saatchi Advertising in New York and Wells Rich Greene BDDP in New York, which handled the account from 1977 to 1991.

HEADLINE: Mexico Needs Help, Not Extortion

 BODY:
The Clinton Administration faces surprising and shortsighted opposition in Congress to its bold plan to rescue the Mexican peso. Critics, both Democrat and Republican, say the plan will leave American taxpayers dangerously exposed if Mexico defaults on its bonds. They want Mexican concessions for American loan guarantees, including sale of the state-owned petroleum monopoly. They would also force adoption of labor reforms that Mexico steadfastly rejected during negotiations over Nafta, the free-trade accord with the U.S. and Canada.
The opponents are wrong. The Clinton plan is ingeniously designed to stabilize the Mexican economy without costing U.S. taxpayers any money. By stabilizing the peso, it would protect U.S. exports and prevent a temporary influx of imports and illegal immigrants. The plan would also stop financial turmoil from spreading elsewhere in Latin America. 
 The peso has plummeted over 30 percent in a month and could collapse if investors, fearing further depreciation or default, dump Mexican bonds and cash in their pesos for dollars. If that happens, import prices in Mexico would soar and possibly bury its fragile market reforms in a torrent of inflation.
The Administration's plan would guarantee up to $40 billion of loans to Mexico -- assuring investors that Mexico would redeem the bonds as promised. As a condition for the guarantees, Mexico would adopt strict monetary and fiscal controls -- to keep inflation and its trade deficit under control -- and pledge to pay back lenders, if needed, with future oil revenues. That safeguards U.S. taxpayers; Washington should actually make money because Mexico will pay fees for the loan guarantees.
The majority leader, Bob Dole, and Speaker Newt Gingrich back the Administration. Senator Daniel Patrick Moynihan of New York and other opponents of Nafta support guarantees because they recognize that preventing the collapse of a neighbor and major economic partner is important regardless of the merits of open trade or the current Mexican administration.
There is no good case for imposing extraneous conditions on Mexico. President Ernesto Zedillo is under fierce, often unfair attack for weak leadership. With or without loan guarantees, the Mexican economy will be hit hard by the fall of the peso and will need a full-strength President to keep a firm lid on wages and prices -- discipline that is needed to control the growing trade deficit and to stabilize the economy. Why force him to swallow painful political concessions dictated by Washington that would leave him weakened?
Mr. Zedillo might have been tempted to deal with internal opposition the way his party has traditionally maintained control: with political repression and extensive vote fraud. But this week he steered in the opposite direction -- entering an agreement with all major political parties to adopt rules for fair elections and cooperation. Now that Mr. Zedillo has promised to lock in market and democratic reforms, the U.S. has even more reason to help .
The Administration has negotiated reasonable conditions that provide maximum protection for U.S. taxpayers. This is no time for Congress to extort political concessions or raise false alarms about the cost of loan guarantees.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

TYPE: Editorial

HEADLINE: For '96, Clinton Looks to Ickes, Another Survivor

BYLINE: By TODD S. PURDUM, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Jan. 19

 BODY:
Harold M. Ickes has survived some of the bitterest Democratic Party wars of the last quarter-century, but he recently passed a new sort of milestone. With 54 weeks of service, he is now the longest serving deputy chief of staff in the Clinton White House, which has had five of them.
Not that he has had an easy time of it. The three main tasks of his tenure -- legislative stewardship of the President's health care plan, damage control on the Whitewater inquiry and strategy for the midterm elections -- all came unglued, if through no particular fault of his own. 
 But as President Clinton gears up for what is sure to be a difficult re-election campaign, no one is more central than Mr. Ickes (pronounced ICK-eez), the canny and controversial New York labor lawyer who helped him get elected in the first place. He led Mr. Clinton's New York primary campaign, was floor manager of the Democratic Convention and became deputy director of his transition team and now seems all but certain to play a crucial role in 1996, whoever winds up as formal chairman of the re-election campaign.
Mr. Ickes is literally a son of the New Deal -- his father, Harold L. Ickes, "the Old Curmudgeon," was Franklin Delano Roosevelt's Interior Secretary -- and his past mastery of party rules, platform procedure and ballot-access arcana is seen as strong insurance against any threat to Mr. Clinton's renomination.
But those same liberal credentials also make Mr. Ickes a lightning rod for Democratic critics who accuse him of leading Mr. Clinton astray just when the President must win back centrists. And Mr. Ickes' reputation for sharp dealing has led others, especially Republicans, to accuse him of eliding the niceties of etiquette. He dismisses both notions with characteristic plain-spokenness.
"There are people who have political axes to grind, with either me or the President, so they will find any twig they can to hang something on," he said the other day. "If you check around, I think you will find very few people in the White House who think I'm prosecuting a liberal agenda. My job is to give Bill Clinton my judgment of what is best for him and the country."
In a shifting cast of Clinton advisers, Mr. Ickes remains a constant, a longtime friend of both the President and his wife, Hillary, trusted to a rare degree equally by both. Two decades ago, before his marriage to Laura Handman, a fellow lawyer, he lived with Mrs. Clinton's old friend Susan Thomases, the Clinton campaign scheduler. Ms. Thomases says the first couple relies on him because "he has an incredible capacity for work and a wonderful capacity to segregate anything he might want to do from what the President wants and needs to do."
His influence has been clear in a range of recent Presidential actions, from the selection of Senator Christopher J. Dodd as general chairman of the Democratic Party and Don Fowler, a veteran South Carolina party leader as day-to-day chairman, to Mr. Clinton's proposal for a "Middle Class Bill of Rights" of tax breaks. An insomniac, Mr. Ickes is often up by 4:30 A.M., arriving in his cramped office in the West Wing before most anyone else and often leaving at 10 P.M.
Together with Erskine Bowles, the other deputy chief of staff, who handles operations, Mr. Ickes is at the center of the efforts of the President's chief of staff, Leon E. Panetta, to impose greater discipline -- and shorter and smaller meetings -- in the face of the inevitable chaos of White House life.
"He's a real lawyer," said George Stephanopoulos, the senior Presidential adviser. "He's meticulous in terms of following through, of pressing points until you've reached consensus or the point of disagreement."
In one sign of the passions Mr. Ickes can provoke, Representative Robert G. Torricelli of New Jersey, a contender for the Democratic committee chairmanship who lost out to Mr. Dodd, called a reporter to offer unsolicited criticism.
"Harold is a person of rather decided views, who feels passionately about things and pursues them aggressively," said Mr. Torricelli, who tangled bitterly with Mr. Ickes in 1980, when as head of the Democratic Convention's rules committee he supported Jimmy Carter and Mr. Ickes worked for Senator Edward M. Kennedy. "There are people who are best suited to give you private advice, and others best suited to represent you in public, and Harold is definitely the former.
"No matter what Harold's ideology might be, or whatever vendettas he feels from previous campaigns," Mr. Torricelli added, "his principal agenda should be to broaden the reach of the Clinton White House, and that remains to be done."
Mr. Ickes says that is what he is trying to do. He notes that despite his deep opposition to the death penalty, for example, he never tried to alter Mr. Clinton's support for the Federal crime bill that imposed it for about five dozen new offenses last year. "In a lifetime of politics, you build up a few enemies, if you've done anything of consequence," he said.
In fact, Mr. Ickes took his White House job a year later than originally planned because of a Federal inquiry into whether his law firm acted improperly in representing a mob-connected restaurant workers' union; the inquiry ended with no finding of wrongdoing.
Last year, Mr. Ickes raised eyebrows by joining other senior White House aides in talking to a top Treasury official about the status of a Federal investigation into the failed Arkansas savings and loan at the heart of the Whitewater inquiry. Republicans on the Senate Banking Committee have asked the Whitewater special prosecutor, Kenneth W. Starr, to review Mr. Ickes's testimony to Congress on the subject last summer for possible inconsistencies.
Before joining Mr. Clinton, a friend from their days protesting the Vietnam War, Mr. Ickes was a fox terrier in the service of losing liberal Presidential contenders, from Eugene J. McCarthy to the Rev. Jesse Jackson. It was almost solely on his say-so that some liberal New York politicians, who otherwise looked askance at a pro-death penalty governor from a small state like Arkansas, agreed to back Mr. Clinton in 1992.
But his friends say caricatures of him as a wild-eyed ideologue are vastly overdrawn.
"He's a very practical guy," said Representative Thomas J. Manton of Queens, a moderate Democrat who is also the party's county leader there. "In the primary, he was able to put together an interesting amalgam of left-of-center Democrats with those of us who consider ourselves more mainstream. I think that's his strength."
Mr. Clinton's challenge is to win back the swing voters who helped elect him, without so demoralizing what is left of the Democratic base vote of liberals, labor and minorities that they fail to turn out -- a task Mr. Ickes acknowledges is "very tough" for any Democrat these days, much less a wounded incumbent.
"I've always considered him neither right nor left, but a progressive who wants to do the right thing for the country," Mr. Ickes said of the President. "Now I think his focus on the economy is absolutely crucial, because without a strong economy, liberalism -- or progressivism, or however you define it -- is very hard to sustain."
Asked why he had stayed on in the face of so many vicissitudes, Mr. Ickes said: "Probably my insanity. And presumably, they have confidence in me. They know, and I have always told them, that the minute they cease to have confidence in me, they should tell me, and I'll go."

HEADLINE: G.O.P.'s North Korea Strategy: Attack Accord, but Don't Kill It

BYLINE: By STEVEN GREENHOUSE, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Jan. 19

 BODY:
Republicans in Congress showed their hand today on how they plan to deal with the Administration's agreement to defuse a nuclear crisis with North Korea: attack the agreement without seeking to overturn it.
In the first hearing on the agreement before this Congress, Republicans sought to put the Administration on the defensive by repeatedly attacking the accord for giving away too much to North Korea. 
 At the same time Republican lawmakers, at a hearing of the Senate Energy Committee, stopped short of seeking to scuttle the agreement for fear their party might get blamed if such a move fueled new tensions.
And next week the Senate Foreign Relations Committee will open an examination of the Administration's foreign policy with two days of hearings on the nuclear agreement.
But today, Senator John McCain of Arizona, whom the Republicans have designated as their spokesman on North Korea, was called as the first witness, and he bitterly denounced the agreement for giving the North several years before international inspectors can visit two waste sites believed to hold evidence that it has separated plutonium for use in nuclear weapons.
In the three-month-old agreement, North Korea promised to freeze its nuclear weapons program and dismantle its existing reactors and larger ones under construction. In exchange, the United States pledged to lead an international effort to provide the North with $4 billion worth of new light-water reactors. The waste fuel from the light-water reactors would be far harder to turn into weapons-grade plutonium than the fuel produced by the existing reactors.
Charles B. Curtis, Under Secretary of Energy, defended the agreement by noting that it got North Korea to promise to freeze and later dismantle its nuclear weapons programs as well as its reprocessing program.
Under the agreement, the North would not be given the nuclear components of the first light-water reactor until inspections were carried out. That is not expected to happen for five years.
Mr. Curtis urged the lawmakers to make available $10 million to help store 8,000 spent fuel rods in North Korea and stop their corrosion. The rods are corroding rapidly, he said, and this could make it harder to detect improper diversion of fuel.
Senator McCain faulted the agreement for promising the North $4 billion in new reactors as well as $500 million in fuel oil over the next 10 years. Such outside aid, he said, could prop up North Korea's Communist Government by aiding its economy.
But Mr. McCain, who is a leading Republican voice on national security, said it would be unwise for his party to seek to kill the accord.
"What the Administration has done is put us into a box that is very difficult for us to get out of," he said, "because if we refuse now to fund portions of this agreement, then of course we can be held responsible for the whole thing coming apart."
Senator Frank Murkowski, an Alaska Republican who is chairman of the Energy Committee, also attacked the agreement across the board. But he, too, warned against overturning it. "I do not believe that we should renege on this agreement," he said.

HEADLINE: New Democratic Chief Declares That Party Will Recoup

BYLINE: By RICHARD L. BERKE, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Jan. 19

 BODY:
Despite the "death sentence" handed to the Democrats in the Nov. 8 election, Senator Christopher J. Dodd, the incoming leader of the Democratic National Committee, vowed today that his party would rise again and take on the Republicans.
"The wake is over," he declared.
But Mr. Dodd, a Senator from Connecticut, lamented that Republicans were far more skilled at pressing their agenda and communicating with voters. 
 "We're literally operating in the dark ages, out of shoe boxes, when our counterparts, our political competition, has Apple computers," he said at a breakfast with reporters.
In his most detailed remarks since President Clinton named him general chairman of the party last week, Mr. Dodd said, "This is the most challenging moment for the Democratic Party in my lifetime."
Hours later, at the opening of the Republican National Committee's winter meeting here, it was clear how tough the challenge Mr. Dodd faces will be. His soon-to-be sparring partner, Haley Barbour, chairman of the Republican National Committee, sought to turn the tables on Democrats by accusing the new minority party in Congress of following "a strategy of delay and character assassination."
It is a point that Mr. Barbour no doubt planned to repeat on his party's satellite television program, "Rising Tide," the type of communications that Mr. Dodd suggested his party might want to emulate.
Mr. Dodd spoke almost admiringly of his Republican counterparts and even invoked the late Lee Atwater, the tough-minded Republican chairman who helped engineer President George Bush's victory in 1988. "You've got to tear a chapter out of Lee Atwater's book," Mr. Dodd said, explaining that it could take as long as eight years to rebuild the Democratic Party's field and fund-raising operations.
The incoming party leader offered no such praise for his Democratic predecessors, and instead issued a stern warning to the party.
"What happened on Nov. 8 was profound," he said. "It was not a speed bump. It wasn't some minor mid-course correction. People sent a very strong message that they were angry with how they saw Democrats leading. I think it's important to establish that. And my concern is that there are those who still don't want to come to terms with that fact."
Mr. Dodd asserted that the Democrats had "drifted away from central issues that people cared about," like economic and personal security.
But at another point Mr. Dodd suggested that the repudiation of Democrats was touched off not by a shift on issues but by a failure to communicate President Clinton's accomplishments.
"Part of that result was due to the fact that we did a miserable job as a party in letting people know exactly what had been done," Mr. Dodd said.
For his part, Mr. Barbour depicted Mr. Dodd, who was elected to a third Senate term in 1992, as a liberal who would try to pull the party to the left.
In the first step at regrouping, the Democrats will meet here on Saturday for the official vote on Mr. Dodd as general chairman. The party will also vote on the President's choice of Donald L. Fowler, a former state party chairman from South Carolina, as the chairman. He is expected to concentrate on daily operations while Mr. Dodd serves as the spokesman and chief fund raiser.
While several state Democratic chairmen said last week that they had qualms about the unusual arrangement, Mr. Dodd said the "team effort" would succeed.
"It's awkward, obviously," he said, "but nonetheless I think it's very manageable and doable."
While the Democrats talk about staging a comeback, the Republicans meeting across town will probably, in the words of Mr. Barbour, be "very jubilant."

HEADLINE: Deluge Leaves California's Wineries Wary but Hopeful

BYLINE: By BILL STAGGS, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: OAKVILLE, Calif., Jan. 16

 BODY:
Napa Valley's vineyards, producers of some of California's most prized and pricey wines, came through last week's flooding scarred but intact, with some experts even seeing a positive side to the state's latest natural disaster.
The sight of flooded vineyards had sent shivers through the $1.5 billion California wine industry, which has been staggered by years of recession, a decline in wine consumption and a plant louse called phylloxera that has threatened the health of the vines. 
 But after getting into the fields as the waters subsided, vineyard consultants and other agricultural experts found that while terraced vineyards suffered hundreds of thousands of dollars in damage, major anxiety about flood damage might have been unwarranted. And though they still fret over potential problems from waterborne diseases, these experts know that the vines are now dormant and essentially unaffected by a good soaking.
"So much water in late winter or spring would be a different story," said Paul Skinner, a vineyard consultant. He said "the not-so-obvious effects," like fungus and insects, concerned him, but he also noted that some of the best vintages had come after a winter of heavy rain.
Kim Marcus, news editor of The Wine Spectator magazine, which reports on the wine industry and rates wines, said the droughts that had hit the state were far more worrisome than an excess of water.
"The vines are dormant now anyway, and after several dry years the reservoirs are in sore need of replenishing," he said. "It might just be that there's as much good as bad in this."
While the physical threat from water seems under control, winery tasting rooms and restaurants are suffering.
"The effect of the publicity, not the floods, has been devastating," said Cindy Pawlcyn, executive chef of Mustards Grill in Oakville. "People have canceled their trips. We're doing a third of our normal business. And the people coming in are mostly locals."
Some of the most serious damage to the vineyards appears to be on hillside property along the Napa River on the eastern edge of the northern Napa Valley, home to labels like Groth, Stag's Leap and Caymus, which produce well-regarded cabernet sauvignons. At the same time, California's other premier wine-grape area, Sonoma County, seems to have escaped any serious effects.
Johnny White, manager of vineyards operations for Pina Vineyard Management east of Oakville, said the damage to properties he oversees in the Napa Valley came from the sheer volume of water.
"We had so much water running down the hills so fast that there was nothing we could do until the storm passed," Mr. White said, looking out over some of the 450 acres of mostly cabernet sauvignon vines in his care, many of them on the properties of absentee landlords.
On a bouncing uphill ride in his muddied, four-wheel-drive pickup truck shortly after the worst of the storms last week, Mr. White pointed to slope after slope with newly formed gullies cutting across neat terraces. From a perch more than 800 feet above the valley floor, he also called attention to newly planted vineyards crisscrossed with trenches cut by raging waters.
Mr. White said runoff on the slopes ripped out rock-lined ditches and clogged drains, forcing the torrents to find alternate routes down the hillsides.
What frustrated him most was that his terraced vineyards, like all those carved out here since the late 1980's, were carefully engineered, and their designs had to conform with conservation regulations of the Napa County planning department.
"This is going to be expensive to repair," he said.
A few miles north along the Silverado Trail, which snakes along the eastern edge of the valley, a slash of red-brown dirt against bright green grass showed the kind of havoc the rains brought.
Here crews from Beringer Vineyards, one of the valley's oldest and largest producers, had spent the last six months preparing a hillside site for replanting after it had sat idle for years. They had cut new terraces, lined a creek with fist-sized stones to keep soil from running off the property and planted cover crops.
Their efforts were not enough.
"Water moving downhill underneath just blew out the terraces," said Bob Steinhauer, vice president of vineyard operations for Beringer. "Everything we did there was totally engineered and approved by the erosion control people. What we didn't know was that there were major fissures in the rock and subsoil below."
Al Buckland, president of the Napa Valley Grape Growers Association, put the damage to vineyards at $500,000 to $1 million. He said most of the costs would be from repairing stream banks, clearing debris, rebuilding drainage systems and repairing trellises and drip irrigation systems.
While farmers and experts generally agreed on physical damage in the vineyards, they were less certain about pathogens that might have been transported in the tumult of soil and water.
Mr. Skinner said the damage to the infrastructure was obvious, but he expressed concern about "unseen" dangers.
He said the phylloxera thought to have spread in a 1986 flood was now so pandemic that further movement was not a worry. But he added that he was concerned about diseases like the fan leaf virus, which can debilitate vines over years, and the oak root fungus, which can kill vines outright.
Mr. Skinner advised against panic, though, saying that the spread of those vine diseases was speculative at this point.
"I can't say that there's a connection, but 1986 was a wonderful vintage following a similar flood in February of that year," he said. "I just don't think you can say that there is any direct effect of winter rains on the quality of a vintage."
The Wine Spectator's ratings of California wines score the 1986 Napa chardonnays at 91 on a scale of 100, and the cabernets at 95.

HEADLINE: A Korean Coming of Age;
Pan-Asian Superstore in Queens Defies Stereotypes

BYLINE: By LYNETTE HOLLOWAY 

 BODY:
When Syng Man Rhee opened a vast ethnic supermarket in Fairfax, Va., four years ago, 30 greengrocers from miles around closed their doors within 18 months, yielding to the giant whose prices and variety they could not beat.
Now, Mr. Rhee has opened a huge pan-Asian superstore in downtown Flushing, bulging with bok choy and cuttlefish, and hundreds of immigrant merchants here fear that his Korea Town Plaza will force them out of business, too. 
 The brouhaha over Korea Town Plaza, which occupies a 100,000-square-foot former post office in a neighborhood whose Asian population rivals that of Manhattan's Chinatown, marks a moment of reckoning for the Korean community as it comes of age as an immigrant group. Does the success of an individual, many wonder, conflict with the success of the community?
Korean merchants have become synonymous with small business in New York City. They have flourished, despite struggles, partly because they have often pooled their efforts and finances. Now, though, Mr. Rhee is daring to think big and American. And, while some of his compatriots applaud him, others act as if his grand enterprise is an affront to the communal ambitions of Korean immigrants.
"I'm not sure one can criticize this man, because it's the pure principle of capitalism that he applied," said Grace Lyu-Volckhausen, a board member of the Flushing Y.M.C.A. who is an active member of the Korean-American community. "But life is not just making money. The Korean community is very close knit, and you see people getting hurt. Maybe soon there will no longer be a neighborhood that's supportive."
When Korea Town opened its doors on Dec. 3, it was an event. About 3,000 cars crammed with eager shoppers clogged the narrow access roads leading to the store, following the signs that can be seen from a tangle of roadways running past the building. Then they flooded the warehouse, at 39th Avenue and College Point Boulevard.
Inside, the store, about the size of two football fields, is a dramatic departure from the small groceries to which most shoppers are accustomed. The products, including cooking utensils, flatware and gas stoves, are sold at 20 percent to 70 percent discounts. The store sells specialty items from Korea, Japan, China, the Philippines, Thailand and all of East Asia.
The gleaming white shelves brim with glistening plastic bulk packages of paprika, fennel, curry, Japanese buckwheat noodles, dried seaweed, dried straw mushrooms and jars of black bean sauce, soy sauce and sesame oil.
The fruit and vegetable stands hold stacks of choy sum, lotus, taro roots and daikon radishes. Bright pink salmon steaks lie alongside cuttlefish, shrimp and strips of flounder. Live crabs clamber in buckets lined up along the floor.
"Nobody has delivered this type of store to the Asian community," said Mr. Rhee, whose company is based in Maryland and has outlets in China, Korea, Japan and Los Angeles. "Most Asian-owned stores are small. Now, we have a bigger and better store. I don't think I will take business away from smaller stores. I do think everyone here is overreacting."
Shoppers say that Korea Town not only creates jobs but also represents the fulfillment of the community's potential, demonstrating both the business prowess of a single company and the purchasing power of Asian immigrants.
In fact, the small, vibrant commercial district in Little Taipei already attracts shoppers from throughout the metropolitan region, and its grocery stores generate $36 million a year in revenues, according to the Korean-American Small Business Service Center of New York.
Mr. Rhee said he is simply tapping into this consumer strength, pointing out that small-business owners already coexist with two other Asian supermarkets -- Han Yan on Northern Boulevard, and Han Arum on Union Street -- although, he admits, those markets do not begin to rival Korea Town in size.
"The community is very excited because you can buy large quantities and different varieties of food," said Jinn Zohar, who drove to the store from Albertson, L.I., to shop. "It's not a big problem to travel, because I come to Flushing to shop all the time. It's only a 20-minute drive." But for 18 months, the Korean-American Small Business Service Center has waged an incessant, vitriolic campaign against Korea Town on behalf of its 1,500 members. Its target: zoning violations.
The battle lines were first drawn in 1993, when Rhee Brothers announced plans to convert the former post office building at 131-09 39th Avenue into a retail food sales operation. The Buildings Department rejected the company's request for a permit last January because of the sheer size of the proposal. The area's zoning laws prohibit retail establishments of more than 10,000 square feet. Approval was granted in April after the construction plans were revised to meet the zoning requirements for a wholesale market.
But when Korea Town opened, it essentially operated as a giant supermarket, open to all shoppers. Many small business owners were angry.
"If he does not comply with the laws, I'm going to keep yelling," said Sung Soo Kim, president of the Small Business Service Center. "It's a real big shame."
Mr. Rhee created some of the same bitterness in Fairfax, Va., with the opening of Lotte Plaza, a 20,000-square-foot market in a mixed residential and commercial neighborhood.
"It's a very successful business and a big contributor to our sales tax base," said Earl A. Berner, economic development coordinator for Fairfax. "When they first came to the city for permits, some merchants were beside themselves. One woman came in here and cried on my desk, telling me we couldn't allow them to open because she would be forced to close. Today, her company is still open even though she had to make some adjustments."
Myung Kang, 40, said she and her husband were forced to change their stock when the store opened just doors away from their business in Fairfax. Once a greengrocery, the store now sells prepared foods and serves as a catering business, Dong-a-Asian. Thirty stores in surrounding areas simply went out of business, as Mr. Rhee's store began attracting shoppers from 50 miles away.
"I hope the people in New York have better luck," Mrs. Kang said. "He was too big for us to fight. And don't think we didn't try."
In Queens, the small merchants won a partial victory. Ten days ago, New York City's Department of Buildings issued the business a notice of violation and ordered the company to create separate wholesale and retail sections. This will effectively close off a large part of the store to consumers.
Tensions between superstores and small businesses are hardly unique to the Korean community as sprawling, suburban-style stores become increasingly common in New York City, encouraged by the Giuliani administration. The administration has recently proposed that areas long restricted to industrial enterprise be opened to more expansive uses, including enormous retail stores.
Richard Lipsky, the director of Neighborhood Small Business Association in Bellerose, who is fighting the proposal, is using the Korea Town Plaza conflict to that end.
"The catastrophe in Flushing sends a clear message that when you rezone the city to allow these stores to come in, you will get tenants who will alienate the community," Mr. Lipsky said.
In the last decade, Koreans have opened stores of every description in practically every neighborhood in New York City. They first specialized in wig importing, said Pyong Gap Min, an associate professor at Queens College who studies Korean businesses. When the wig business fell off in the 1970's, they moved into wholesale apparel, dry cleaning and the green groceries ubiquitous throughout the city.
Today, there are more than 10,000 Korean-owned stores in the city and the Korean population is 71,225, according to 1990 Census information. Many Koreans, even those with high levels of education or professional training, have started their lives here with small businesses that can flourish despite their owners' limited English. Their children, however, are becoming doctors, lawyers, investment bankers and other professionals, forcing their parents to close their businesses as they grow older.
Ki Young Lee, editor of The Korea Times, a New York City newspaper, said Mr. Rhee may represent the future Korean entrepreneur.
"The children who do not close their parents' business after they retire will make them bigger and bigger," Mr. Lee said. "It is only a natural progression."

HEADLINE: Stocks, Following the Dollar, Fall on U.S. Trade Outlook

BYLINE: By ANTHONY RAMIREZ 

 BODY:
The stock market followed the dollar, which tumbled against the German mark, as the Government reported that the United States economy was headed toward the biggest annual trade deficit in seven years.
A big trade deficit leads to a glut of unwanted dollars in the international currency markets, thus depressing prices for both stocks and bonds, which are priced in dollars. 
 "It was a day when people were getting out of the U.S. market as a whole," said David De Rosa, a director of foreign exchange trading at Swiss Bank, referring to dollars, bonds and stocks. The dollar in particular was vulnerable, falling to a 10-week low against the mark and slipping against other leading currencies. [D16.]
The Commerce Department reported yesterday that the trade deficit rose 4.3 percent, to $10.5 billion, in November. [D2.] The trade figures add to a growing list of economic data, including December's industrial production and factory use, that is expected to prompt the Federal Reserve to raise short-term interest rates a seventh time since February at its policy meeting on Jan. 31 to Feb. 1.
Only last Friday, the financial markets rallied, encouraged by the "economy is slowing" message of weak December retail sales and the possibility of no tightening by the Fed. "But the sentiment has changed," said Alex Scarsini, director of foreign exchange trading at Barclays Bank. "People are definitely looking for higher rates."
The Dow Jones industrial average fell 46.77 points yesterday, to 3,882.21, its steepest one-day decline since Dec. 8, when it fell 49.79 points. The broader Standard & Poor's 500-stock index fell 2.76 points, to 466.95. The smaller-company Nasdaq composite index fell 3.83 points, to 768.55.
The Dow fell steadily throughout the day, and plummeted more than 50 points by 3:33 P.M., setting off the New York Stock Exchange's "circuit breaker" rules, which are designed to slow high-speed, computer-guided trading.
The Dow has lost about half the 94 points it gained for the month, and the yield on the benchmark 30-year Treasury bond rose to 7.82 percent from 7.77 percent, taking back about a third of the fall in interest rates for the month.
In the Commerce Department report, the United States trade deficit appeared headed toward a full-year deficit of $152.5 billion, exceeding the record of $152.1 billion in 1987.
The trade figures, which were close to Wall Street's expectations, were simply the first in a series of assaults on the dollar, analysts say. The German mark had been strengthening for weeks against several leading currencies, including those of France and Italy, and only recently began strengthening against the dollar.
In addition, in afternoon trading the dollar fell below 1.52 marks to the dollar -- known as a technical support level -- prompting even more frenzied sales of the dollar, as traders who had made wrong bets scrambled to cut their losses.
The dollar later settled at 1.5160 German marks, down from 1.5344 on Wednesday. It slipped to 99.10yen from 99.57 yen.
The outlook for interest rates led traders to punish even Caterpillar Inc., which yesterday reported fourth-quarter net income of $1.38 a share, beating Wall Street's estimates by 19 cents. If rates rise and the economy slows, Caterpillar, a maker of heavy equipment, is sure to be hurt. Caterpillar fell 3 7/8, to 54 3/4.
By contrast, Intel improved as the computer industry continued to show strength, despite Intel's large quarterly charge for problems with its Pentium chip. Intel, the most active stock of the day, with 9.2 million shares traded, rose 15/16 , to 7011/16 .
Apple Computer, which reported that first-quarter net income had quadrupled, rose 1/4, to 45 7/8.
Compuware, a developer of specialized software, rose 3 1/2, to 42 3/4, after an analyst for the Founders Growth Fund recommended the stock in a stock-picking contest in The Wall Street Journal.
But Fair, Isaac & Company, another developer of specialized software, dropped 5 7/8, to 45 3/4, after it reported first-quarter earnings that were below Wall Street's expectations.
The volume on the New York Stock Exchange was slightly below normal, with about 314.1 million shares changing hands, below the daily average of 318 million shares this year.

HEADLINE: Suspect in Subway Bombing Is Indicted in Earlier Blast

BYLINE: By DAVID STOUT 

 BODY:
The man accused of the firebombing last month that injured more than 40 subway riders and terrified hundreds of others was indicted yesterday in that case and charged formally for the first time in an earlier blast that burned two teen-agers.
Edward Leary, a 49-year-old unemployed computer technician from Scotch Plains, N.J., was named in a 39-count indictment by a Manhattan grand jury announced by District Attorney Robert M. Morgenthau. The charges are attempted murder, assault, weapons possession and attempted grand larceny. 
 The indictment of Mr. Leary had been expected. Perhaps most significant was the prosecutors' assertion that Mr. Leary was responsible not only for the Dec. 21 firebombing that stunned the city but also for a Dec. 15 subway fire that injured the teen-agers.
Mr. Morgenthau said last night that similarities in the explosive devices -- each fire was linked to a glass jar filled with a flammable liquid, with two wires leading to a battery and a crude timer -- had convinced investigators that Mr. Leary was responsible for both fires.
The indictment announced yesterday supersedes an earlier, sketchy indictment that had been issued in late December to meet a technical requirement that an accused felon be indicted within 144 hours of arrest -- 6 days -- or be released on his own recognizance.
Mr. Leary, who is still hospitalized with the burns he suffered in the Dec. 21 blast, is to be arraigned in State Supreme Court on Feb. 23, Mr. Morgenthau said.
Attempted murder, the most serious charge in the indictment, carries a maximum penalty of 8 1/3 to 25 years in prison. First-degree assault is punishable by 15 years.
Mr. Leary was arrested on the afternoon of Dec. 21 in Brooklyn, where the authorities suspected he fled after his firebomb went off prematurely in his hands. It critically burned him and caused chaos on a crowded train that had just pulled into the Fulton Street station in the financial district.
Mr. Leary almost immediately became the suspect as well in the Dec. 15 incident, in which a teen-age girl's backpack suddenly caught fire on a subway train in Harlem, injuring her and badly burning a 13-year-old boy, whose clothes had caught fire.
Investigators believe that the Harlem fire, like the Dec. 21 blast, was set off when an incendiary device went off prematurely. The boy, Arnell Austin, was hospitalized with third-degree burns over 25 percent of his legs. Kamron Warren, 16, the girl whose backpack was set afire, apparently by a device under her seat, was less seriously injured.
The police concluded after questioning the two teen-agers that they had had nothing to do with the device in the Harlem case. The remains of that device were compared by police bomb experts and the Federal Bureau of Alcohol, Tobacco and Firearms with remnants of the firebomb used on Dec. 21.
Investigators have said that evidence found in Mr. Leary's home -- including notes, diagrams and materials they say could have been used to make firebombs -- suggested that he hoped to reap money through extortion after terrorizing the city.

HEADLINE: Reopening Old Battles

BYLINE: By DAVID E. SANGER, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Jan. 19

 BODY:
A month ago the White House was celebrating the first anniversary of what it called one of its greatest legislative and foreign policy successes: the hard-fought passage of the North American Free Trade Agreement, which President Clinton argued would create tens of thousands of high-paying jobs for American workers producing exports for a vibrant Mexican economy.
Now, battling the new Congress over a plan to rescue Mexico from an economic disaster of that country's own making, Mr. Clinton has been forced to confront the ugly truth that economic interdependence is a two-edged sword. If the Mexican financial system is allowed to collapse, he said earlier this week in a speech with carefully calibrated warnings, the American economy may be taken down with it. 
 And to the horror of many in the White House, what began as a straightforward financial bailout is reopening the trade-agreement battle, this time in a more hostile and more isolationist Congress. Many members in both parties see this as a chance to win concessions from Mexico they could not get in 1993, and a few view it as a prime opportunity to undo the entire accord.
One by one, the trade agreement's opponents have re-emerged in recent days. They argue that the United States would be compounding its first error -- free trade with a country that undercuts American businesses by keeping its wages artificially low and that floods Texas and California with illegal immigrants -- by using taxpayer dollars to rescue Mexico's economy from the ineptitude of its own leaders. The result, they say with an I-told-you-so glance, will be a bailout of rich Mexican and rich American investors who gambled on a miraculous ascent for Mexico and lost.
The truth is more complicated, of course: Mexico would probably be in this fix even if the trade accord was never invented, and while the rich who bought Mexican bonds would be bailed out, so would many decidedly middle-class Americans who have learned in the past year through a panoply of international mutual funds that an emerging market is frequently not a rising one.
But on Capitol Hill, where liberal Democrats who did not like what the trade agreement did to labor are again teaming up with conservative Republicans, the only relevant political fact is that the cornerstone of Mr. Clinton's international economic strategy has gone bad for the first time. That creates an opportunity to embarrass him badly.
Efforts by everyone from Vice President Al Gore to the Republican leaders to separate partisan emotion from economics have so far failed to generate the votes needed to pass the $40 billion in loan guarantees, which would cost American taxpayers only if Mexico defaulted.
"It's weird," one of Mr. Clinton's closest economic advisers said when asked to compare the debate over the trade accord in 1993 with the arguments over the loan guarantees today. "The issues are different, the arguments are different, but the reverberations are very similar."
The risk is that a battle in Congress, which now looks inevitable, may be all it takes to further rattle investors who have already pulled billions of dollars out of Mexico, leaving the Government there without the cash to pay off its short-term borrowings. That, in turn, could send the peso into a further downward spiral -- it has already declined 35 percent in a month -- and could raise the specter of a return to inflation and social unrest. Along the way, it could create enough chaos to wash out many of the benefits reaped from the reforms Mexico enacted in return for the free-trade agreement.
Mr. Clinton, trying to walk the fine line between raising the alarm and creating a panic, warned, "If we fail to act, the crisis of confidence in Mexico's economy could spread to other emerging countries in Latin America and in Asia, the kinds of markets that buy our goods and services today and that will buy far more of them in the future."
Mr. Clinton's problem is that while the trade agreement was sold with a positive message -- more trade equals more jobs -- the Mexican rescue is being sold with a negative and potentially dire one. Until this month, he could describe free trade in Latin America or Asia as a win-win deal, in which more open markets led to more sales of American exports. Now, he is like the banker who has discovered that a big client is on the verge of bankruptcy. He has no choice but to lend him a bit more because the danger of losing everything is too terrible to contemplate.
"In for a dime," said one senator who opposed the agreement but favors the bailout, "in for 40 billion."
While Mr. Clinton's argument about helping Americans by helping others is fundamentally sound, it also plays into the hands of opponents of the trade accord. They argued a year ago that while economic integration with rapidly developing nations may offer new opportunities for export, it also subjects the American economy to a raft of risks, many out of Washington's control.
In the North American Free Trade Agreement debate, Mr. Clinton overcame those objections, stitching together an unusual alliance of Republicans, historically the party of free trade, and Democrats whose arms he could twist. It is unclear whether he can do that again.
Some Democrats who reluctantly voted for the trade accord say they cannot put $40 billion of taxpayer money at risk to save it. And many freshmen Republicans are openly splitting with the party's traditional line. Eleven sent a letter yesterday to Speaker Newt Gingrich of Georgia, reminding him that bailing out foreign powers is not part of the House Republicans' "Contract With America."
"These freshmen are economic nationalists," said Patrick J. Buchanan, the conservative commentator and former Presidential candidate who seems positively gleeful that his predictions of disaster with Mexico are coming true (though in far different form than he predicted). "They don't burn incense at the alter of free trade."
Mr. Buchanan today called Mr. Gingrich and the Senate majority leader, Bob Dole of Kansas, "reflexive patriots" for backing the principle of a Mexican bailout at a meeting at the White House a week ago. Others, trying to win concessions from Mexico that they lost when the original accord was debated, are demanding that Mexico agree to everything from ending its trade relations with Cuba to increasing wages as productivity rises. That has a nice popular ring because it would help Mexican workers, who would create a big market for American goods if they rose into the middle class, but it would probably touch off inflation as well, the last thing Mexico can now risk.
So once again, Mr. Clinton will be forced to turn to his opponents for help. Today, he got some from his biggest one-time rival, former President George Bush. Mr. Bush, now a resident of Houston, where illegal immigration could skyrocket if the peso drops further, urged: "The measure proposed by the Administration should be considered in the Congress on its financial merits. The Congress should not attach extraneous political considerations to this legislation."
Mr. Bush concluded with a reference to Ross Perot: "There is no 'sucking sound' of jobs moving out of the United States."
Mr. Clinton's problem over the next week, of course, is to find a way to explain to Americans that their bigger fear should be a sucking sound of another kind, one of money pouring out of Mexico and leaving the United States' biggest neighbor down and out.

HEADLINE: Ford's Move Raises Fears Of Slowdown

BYLINE: By JAMES BENNET, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: DETROIT, Jan. 19

 BODY:
The Ford Motor Company said today that it would not make any of its Windstar mini-vans next week, citing a drop in dealers' orders.
The production cutback for the Windstar, which is less than a year old and has been one of Ford's most popular products, fanned fears among auto industry analysts that the market for new vehicles may be softening as interest rates climb. 
 Ford's move followed a cutback in the production of its small cars, and a decision by the Chrysler Corporation to postpone plans to increase the production of its small cars.
But Ford said it had seen no slowing of sales for the mini-van, or in the market generally. The auto maker attributed the drop in orders to the effect of rising interest rates on dealers, not buyers.
Higher interest rates raise the cost to dealers of carrying large inventories, because they pay interest on the vehicles, which they buy wholesale from the auto makers.
Wall Street analysts disputed Ford's view, noting that inventory figures suggested that dealers were already carrying more mini-vans and small cars than they could sell. That, the analysts said, explains the reason Ford has also offered incentives of $500 to customers who will lease Windstars.
"This has been such a strong market for so long, and suddenly we've hit a wall," said Jack Kirnan, auto analyst for Salomon Brothers in New York. "There's clearly been a slowing."
Mr. Kirnan cited as evidence the high inventories of small cars, mini-vans and luxury cars. According to Ward's Automotive Reports, Ford dealers had 98 days of inventory of Windstars at the end of December, compared with 89 days at the end of November.
Similarly, Dodge dealers had 98 days of Caravan mini-vans at the end of December, compared with 88 days the previous month. Chrysler has been offering rebates on its mini-vans for months as it prepares to introduce a redesigned mini-van later this year.
Mr. Kirnan said the inventories were excessive, even though stocks generally accumulated during the winter, when buyers tended to stay away from showrooms.
The news of Ford's cutback on the Windstar came after trading had closed on the New York Stock Exchange. Throughout the day, the stocks of the Big Three auto makers were heavily traded on fears that the Federal Reserve would be inclined to raise short-term interest rates this month.
On the New York Stock Exchange, shares of Ford fell 75 cents, to $27.50; shares of Chrysler fell 87.5 cents, to $49.25, and shares of the General Motors Corporation rose 25 cents, to $40.25.
Ford previously announced a one-week cut in production of the Ford Escort and Mercury Tracer models. This week Chrysler postponed plans to add a third shift of workers at its plant in Belvidere, Ill., where Neon subcompacts are made.
Ford said orders for mini-vans dropped in December, after the Fed's last increase in interest rates in November. Sales of the mini-vans in December were as strong as those in November, Ford said.
But the seasonally adjusted pace of industrywide sales for light trucks, which includes mini-van sales, slowed last month from November's level.
Dealers are now paying an interest rate of about 9.5 percent to finance their stocks. If they pay $15,000 wholesale for a car, that means they can expect interest charges of $240, assuming the car sits on the lot for two months, said Joel Pitcoff, market analysis manager for Ford. That is $85 more than they would have paid a year ago, he said.
Further, Mr. Pitcoff said, dealers, like others who watch the Fed, are anticipating more increases in rates.
The one-week cut in Windstar production will eliminate 6,000 Windstars. The 3,300 workers who make the mini-vans at the Ford plant in Oakville, Ontario, will stay home. Under the terms of their labor contract, the workers will draw 95 percent of their net pay.
The cutback in the production of small cars amounts to 9,400 cars: 5,900 Escorts that would have been made at an assembly plant in Wayne, Mich., and 3,500 Escorts and Tracers that would have been made at a plant in Hermosillo, Mexico.

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Fed Move To Increase Rates Seen

BYLINE: By ROBERT HURTADO 

 BODY:
Comments from three Federal Reserve governors yesterday convinced traders and analysts that the Fed would raise interest rates after its policy meeting at the end of the month.
While another increase in short-term interest rates has been anticipated, weaker-than-expected retail sales figures last Friday raised questions in the minds of many market participants about the size and the timing of the next Fed move. 
 But the vice chairman of the Fed, Alan S. Blinder, suggested yesterday that the Fed would increase interest rates in two weeks. In an interview with Bloomberg Business News, Mr. Blinder said, "The risks of overheating are greater than the risk of recession."
The comments echoed ones made by Mr. Blinder on Wednesday, which helped send Treasury prices lower.
Yesterday, the price of the 30-year bond declined 17/32 , to 9610/32 . Its yield, which moves in the opposite direction from its price, rose to 7.82 percent, from 7.77 percent on Wednesday. Shorter bills' rates were only slightly mixed.
Treasury prices were weighed down by a weak dollar and a report from the Federal Reserve Bank of Philadelphia showing inflation accelerating this month.
Theodore Ake, a senior vice president and government trading manager at Kemper Securities Inc. in Chicago, said, "The one factor having the most impact on the long end of the market was the dollar's weakeness, as it broke through a couple of key technical levels." The dollar tumbled to a three-month low against the German mark.
Traders said the market sank in afternoon trading as the higher-than-expected price components of the Philadelphia Fed index raised the prospect of further interest rate increases beyond the Fed's next monetary policy meeting on Jan. 31.
The Philadelphia Fed index, a survey of regional business activity, dropped to 10.4 in January from 26.5, but the prices index rebounded to 55 from 44.1 and prices received also rose to 24.4 from 19.0. Economists said this was in line with general market perceptions of a slight moderation in economic growth. But continued price pressures at the intermediate goods level are threatening to spill into final goods, they said.
Market analysts said the prices paid index rose to 55.0, its highest level in six years. The combination of a moderating pace of growth and pickup in price pressures, they added, reinforced market perceptions that the Fed will tighten on Feb. 1 and also that the economy will slow as the year progresses.
And to raise investor concern up a notch or two yesterday, were comments by few Fed officials that left the market bracing itself for another round of rate increases by the Fed. "The market is anticipating the central bank to raise interest rates a least once over the next few months," Mr. Ake said.
A Fed governor, John P. LaWare, said yesterday that while he did reassure bond investors that economic growth was slow, it was difficult to say whether the Fed was near the end of a cycle of raising rates.
One trader said that it was not encouraging when a Fed governor says he is surprised by the strength of the fourth-quarter gross domestic product. Mr. LaWare was in New York to deliver a speech on the banking industry to economists and financial journalists.
And in an interview with Dow Jones's Capital Markets Report yesterday, traders said another Fed governor, Susan M. Phillips, did not sound surpemely confident that the fight to keep inflation was finished. She said that it is "at least feasible" that inflation remained contained, but that it would be difficult to keep consumer prices below 3 percent.
In the municipal market, prices were stagnant for a second consecutive day after rising for weeks. Traders report that investors are running into sticker shock, with demand tempered by the higher prices.
Hawaii yesterday priced $268 million of its general obligation bonds through Merrill Lynch. The double-A rated issue was priced to yield from 5.25 percent for a bond due 1998 to 6.30 percent in 2015.
