HEADLINE: Trade Deficit Widened in November

BYLINE: By KENNETH N. GILPIN 

 BODY:
Despite continued vigorous export growth, the nation's trade deficit widened in November, the Government reported yesterday, and is well on the way to reaching record levels for all of 1994.
During the month, the deficit on goods and services rose by 4.3 percent from October, the Commerce Department said, to $10.53 billion from a revised $10.10 billion. 
Since consensus forecasts had been projecting a drop in the deficit, the report came as a surprise and probably contributed to a sharp decline in the dollar against the German mark. Before the release of the figures, economists had been forecasting that the November deficit would shrink to around $9.6 billion.
The dollar's decline last year against currencies like the mark and the Japanese yen may help ease the trade deficit in 1995, analysts said. But economic growth in the United States last year, and the resulting demand for imports, superseded any dampening effect that high-priced goods may have had on consumers.
"This is symptomatic of a country that is growing faster than its trading partners," said Paul Mastroddi, a managing director at J. P. Morgan & Company.
In a separate report that nevertheless suggests the economy remains strong, the Labor Department said yesterday that the number of Americans filing first-time claims for unemployment benefits dropped by a sharp 31,000 last week, to 323,000, the lowest figure in three weeks.
Analysts said the numbers might well reflect continued vigorous job growth. But they cautioned against reading too much into the number, since the period included the holiday marking the birthday of the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. Jobless claims are often extremely erratic during holiday periods.
In November, imports of goods and services rose by 2.5 percent, to a record $71.69 billion. The increase reflected a higher bill for foreign oil and more imports of autos. It is the seventh straight month that imports have hit a new high.
Exports registered strong growth as well, though not as much as imports. Helped by a big jump in the sale of commercial aircraft, exports rose 2.2 percent, to a record $61.16 billion.
The November numbers put the deficit on track to exceed the record $152.1 billion trade shortfall set in 1987.
Although persistent trade deficits require either inflows of foreign capital to finance them or a steadily depreciating currency to bring them back into balance, analysts said that in a $6 trillion economy the shortfall was not that worrisome.
"A $150 billion deficit is a drop in the bucket," said Edward Yardeni, chief economist at C. J. Lawrence. "If we don't want a trade deficit, then let's have a recession."
Still, the November figures show the continuation of some disturbing trends.
Despite continued dollar weakness against the Japanese yen, America's trade deficit with Japan was $6.19 billion in November. That number is nearly 7 percent lower than October's deficit, but is still the third- highest deficit on record for any country. Through November, the trade gap with Japan is running at an annual rate of $65.6 billion, far ahead of the 1993 record of $59.1 billion.
The effect of the drop in the dollar against the yen should begin to narrow that deficit somewhat this year analysts said, assuming growth in the United States slows and that Japan, whose economy has been stagnant for much of the last three years, can quickly overcome the effects of this week's devastating earthquake and begin growing again.
"I think Japanese growth will begin to kick in during the second half of the year," said C. Michael Aho, senior international economist at Prudential Securities.
In addition to the Japanese, the United States also ran substantial November deficits with China and Mexico.
The deficit with China was $2.89 billion in November, putting the deficit for the year at a record annual rate of $30 billion.
The size of the Mexican deficit -- $378 million -- was not as much of a worry as was the fact that it was four times higher than the October figure, and the strong likelihood that because of the 35 percent decline in the value of the peso it will widen much further in 1995.
"The Mexican situation will clearly hurt us in 1995 and perhaps in 1996," said C. Fred Bergsten, director of the Institute for International Economics, a Washington research organization. "But despite the earthquake, I think Japan will cut the other way. There, I think the rebuilding program will stimulate the economy by two to three percentage points higher than what it might have been."
Given the combined effects of an expected slowing in the American economy, the dollar's decline and continued good growth abroad, Mr. Bergsten said he expected the trade deficit to narrow by $20 billion to $25 billion this year.

HEADLINE: COMPANY REPORTS;
CATERPILLAR INC. (CAT,N)

BYLINE: Bloomberg Business News 

 BODY:
Caterpillar Inc. said yesterday that its fourth-quarter earnings more than doubled on strong domestic and foreign demand, exceeding analysts' expectations.
Investors, though, are apparently worried about the impact of rising inventories and higher interest rates on future profits. The company's shares fell $3.875, closing at $54.75, on the New York Stock Exchange. 
 Caterpillar, the heavy-equipment maker based in Peoria, Ill., reported net income of $279 million, or $1.38 a share, compared with $119 million, or 58 cents a share, in the corresponding period a year earlier.
The latest earnings exceeded a mean estimate of $1.19 a share by 19 analysts polled by Zacks Investment Research.
Sales jumped 24 percent, to $3.9 billion, driven by a 28 percent increase in exports to almost $2 billion.
Caterpillar said United States dealer inventories "rose significantly" and "were slightly above normal relative to current selling rates" at year-end. The company also warned that domestic demand could slow if the Federal Reserve increased interest rates again.
"Higher interest rates, lower housing starts and a lower pace of replacement demand are likely to result in a U.S. industry near 1994 levels," the company said.

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Falls Against Mark In Wake of Wider Trade Gap

BYLINE: By Bloomberg Business News 

 BODY:
The dollar fell sharply against the German mark yesterday after a report showed that the United States trade deficit was still widening
The trade gap in goods and services increased 4.3 percent, to $10.531 billion, in November, as merchandise imports set a record high for the seventh consecutive month. The deficit means foreign exporters have a wealth of dollars to sell for their own currencies when they bring revenue home. 
 Steady in Asian and European trading, the dollar lost 1.5 percent of its value against the mark in a little more than three hours as traders unloaded the currency.
"The trade numbers reminded people that we have to find $10 billion a month to come in here," said Richard Koss, manager of currency sales at Canadian Imperial Bank of Commerce in New York.
The dollar's fall against the mark was accelerated by technical factors, dealers said. The mark was also bolstered by an announcement by the Bundesbank that it was leaving short-term interest rates unchanged, as expected. The German central bank has kept interest rates steady since the summer.
The dollar fell to 1.5112 marks yesterday, its lowest level since Nov. 9, before recovering in New York trading to 1.5160 marks, down from 1.5344 marks on Wednesday. The dollar also fell to 1.2725 Swiss francs, from 1.2910 francs on Wednesday. The British pound rose to $1.5868 from $1.5700.
The dollar did not fall as far against the yen because many traders were still concerned that the devastating earthquake in Japan would disrupt commerce in the country.
"You couldn't convince me to buy the yen now, and the earthquake is a major factor," said Jack Griffin, currency sales manager at Fuji Bank in New York. He and other market participants said they were concerned that the earthquake would hurt Japan's economy, at least in coming weeks.
In New York trading, the dollar fell to 99.10 yen, from 99.57 yen on Wednesday.
Still, the dollar received some support from growing expectations that the Federal Reserve would raise short-term interest rates after its policy-making committee meets at the end of the month.
In other currency trading, the Canadian dollar continued to slide, falling to 70.14 United States cents, its lowest level in almost nine years. The Canadian dollar later recovered to 70.22 United States cents, down from 70.423 cents on Wednesday.
The Canadian dollar has fallen more than 2 percent against the United States dollar in the last month.

HEADLINE: The Ugly Side of a Tax Cut

 BODY:
Lieut. Gov. Betsy McCaughey of New York has tried to give a responsible answer to an irresponsible question. Gov. George Pataki asked her to propose ways to cut $1.2 billion from the state Medicaid -- the program that provides health coverage to the poor. The target was not, however, dictated by a desire to improve Medicaid, but rather by the need to pay for Mr. Pataki's tax cuts.
Ms. McCaughey answered the best way she could. But lopping off 20 percent of the programs would be ugly. Some New York City hospitals, already driven to the edge by state regulations, would close. The New York City region would be hit hard because it would give up the largest share of Medicaid reimbursements for the sake of honoring Mr. Pataki's tax cuts. And the proposals would reduce the quality of care for the poor. 
 The plan would cut more than $1 billion out of the $6.4 billion state share of Medicaid. Because the state pays about one-third of the costs, total Medicaid spending would fall by about $3.5 billion. The reductions would hit almost everyone -- including hospitals, physicians, nursing homes and home-bound care. To her credit, Ms. McCaughey carefully targeted the economies to spare pain. Children were exempted. And many of the specific cuts -- for example, in private-duty nursing and clinical psychology -- can be justified because they would cause relatively little grief and help New York State trim coverage that is now fabulously expensive.
But the entire package would do harm. Hospitals hit with budget cuts would have to take the only recourse possible -- eliminating services. The plan arbitrarily caps home-care services, but removes money to make room in nursing homes or hospitals to pick up the slack.
Several proposals could backfire. The plan would, for example, eliminate annual fee hikes for hospitals that offset inflation, and soften the blow by permitting the hospitals to charge private patients more than Medicaid patients. But a dual pricing structure would give hospitals strong incentive to cater to private patients and slight the poor. The poor could also be harmed by the proposal to steer Medicaid patients into health maintenance organizations. H.M.O.'s can provide quality care cheaply, but the plan in effect sets their premiums so low that such care might become impossible.
If Ms. McCaughey had simply tried to strip Medicaid of waste, she might have started by shedding non-emergency benefits and steering patients into managed care. But then the plan would need to let competition, not an arbitrarily imposed cost cap, wring out the excess while preserving quality; and she would not have met Mr. Pataki's need to pay for his tax cut. Ms. McCaughey's proposals are frightening. Under Mr. Pataki's political orders, they could not be otherwise.

HEADLINE: Cataclysm in Kobe

 BODY:
Could a Kobe-scale disaster happen here? By the latest count more than 4,000 people are dead, 21,000 injured and 275,000 homeless. More than 30,000 buildings have been damaged or destroyed and property losses are about $50 billion. Indeed it could. Earthquakes, which strike without warning, can inflict enormous destruction anywhere.
Each full point on the logarithmic Richter scale represents a tenfold increase in energy released. Last year's Los Angeles quake measured 6.8. The Kobe quake, at 7.2, was more than twice as powerful. Seismologists say that a 7.5-magnitude quake, many times more powerful than Japan's, is a realistic possibility for the Los Angeles area. 
 An earthquake's destructiveness depends not just on the energy it releases but on other factors like the type and depth of the earth's movement, the direction of the shock wave and the type of rock or soil it passes through. More controllable are reinforcement and flexibility standards for buildings, roads and bridges in earthquake zones.
Such structures can be made earthquake-resistant, but never fully earthquake-proof. Past a certain threshold highway overpasses will buckle, bridges will crack, buildings tumble, underground utility lines burst and explode.
Japan's current construction standards are comparable to those used in earthquake-prone areas of the U.S. But these apply only to buildings built after 1971. It is still too early to determine how well Kobe's newer buildings withstood Tuesday's shock. But any lessons learned there will need to be applied here as well.
Kobe is the main port of the Kansai, one of Japan's two main urban industrial regions. It is closely linked to the nearby metropolis of Osaka and the architectural treasures of Kyoto and Nara. All felt the quake, but the destruction was concentrated in Kobe, a city of 1.4 million.
What happens economically when one of the world's top industrial powers has its No. 2 port shattered? No one really knows. Forecasters say the destruction could be more than balanced by the stimulus of new construction. Japan is emerging from a long recession and could use a boost. The likely rise in domestic demand should reduce Japan's internationally unpopular trade surpluses.
Japan has most of the resources it needs to recover from this disaster. But the offers of help from around the globe, including the U.S., are important. They express the compassion that unites us all in our vulnerability to such cataclysms.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

HEADLINE: Why Russia Worries About NATO Expansion;
Its Time Has Passed

 BODY:
To the Editor:
Fred C. Ikle presents a strong case against expanding the North Atlantic Treaty Organization (Op-Ed, Jan. 11). But his arguments for maintaining the alliance warrant scrutiny. 
 The United States joined NATO in 1949 to strengthen Western Europe against internal disorder and to lessen its fear of an independent West Germany. However, NATO, like the Warsaw Pact, ended by increasing tension and fueling the arms race, as it developed into a mammoth military structure to deter Soviet attack.
That attack, we now realize, was never likely. The Soviets had neither the intention nor the capability of taking over the West by force. As it turns out, NATO and the Warsaw Pact were about image and bluff.
During the cold war the United States spent $5 trillion to defend Western Europe. Today we are still spending about $112 billion a year.
The European NATO members, with 400 million people and a combined gross national product greater than that of the United States, can afford to defend themselves, since there is no enemy in sight. If NATO is to be maintained, a budget-conscious American public must know why.
 
JUDITH PAPACHRISTOU
Professor of History
Sarah Lawrence College
Bronxville, N.Y., Jan. 12, 1995

HEADLINE: U.S. Dispute on Loan Guarantees Hurts Mexican Stocks

BYLINE: By ANTHONY DePALMA, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: MEXICO CITY, Jan. 19

 BODY:
Mexican financial markets deteriorated today for a third straight day as investors worried about a huge package of American loan guarantees that has been caught in a political crossfire in the United States.
The Mexican stock exchange lost 4.83 percent, closing at 2,051.9. In the last three days since the United States Congress started wrangling in earnest over the loan-guarantee package for Mexico, the stock market here has lost 191 points, about 8.5 percent of its value. Since the peso was devalued a month ago, the stock index has lost more than one-third of its value in dollar terms. 
 The peso weakened about 4 percent today, ending at 5.52 to the dollar here and 5.505 in late New York trading. In the last month, the peso has lost 37 percent of its value against the dollar.
Uncertainty in Mexico was further increased by revived reports that the American Federal Reserve would increase interest rates at the end of the month and thereby drain more investor money from Mexico.
Finance Minister Guillermo Ortiz has said that the rise in American interest rates in 1994 was one of the reasons that international investors began to sour on Mexico, pulling their money out and putting it into safer investments in the United States.
Investors today were also concerned about political demonstrations in a southern state, Tabasco, that were set in motion by a report that the governor would be replaced, and by changes in the management of this country's giant phone company, Telefonos de Mexico.
The loan guarantees from the United States are crucial to Mexico's plans to recover from its financial crisis. This country has more than $ 30 billion in short-term Government bonds coming due this year. The peso devaluation shattered many investors' confidence, and if the bondholders withdraw their money instead of rolling it over, Mexico would not have enough in reserves to pay what it owes.
President Clinton's offer of $ 40 billion in loan guarantees has helped reduce investors' fears about those obligations. But the United States Congress must vote on the package, and some members have said that they will not approve it unless Mexico pays high fees and accepts severe conditions.
"The Mexican market is so jittery that it is reacting to practically anything," said Joyce Chang, an emerging-markets analyst with Salomon Brothers in New York. "The principal fear of the market now is not that the package will be scuttled, but that killer amendments will be attached to the bill."
Ms. Chang estimated that if just some of the proposed fees were enforced, Mexico could have to pay as much as $ 5 billion to obtain the loan guarantees.
But Government officials here are confident that the package will be passed in Washington by the end of next week. "Mexico has the leverage right now," said an official who asked not to be identified. "Do you think that to save a couple of percentage points on the loan, the United States would be willing to risk damaging financial markets all over the world?"
Concern about Telefonos de Mexico was set off when Juan Antonio Perez Simon, the company's general director, was replaced on Wednesday night by Jaime Chico Pardo, an executive known as more decisive and freewheeling.
Telmex accounts for more than a quarter of Mexico's total stock market capitalization and its American depository receipts are heavily traded on the New York Stock Exchange. Telmex shares in New York dropped $ 1.75 today, closing at $ 34.50.
Mr. Chico Pardo, 45, was director general of Condumex, a company within Grupo Carso, a diverse conglomerate that exercises a controlling stake in Telmex. He is a close adviser to Carlos Slim Helu, head of Grupo Carso and one of Mexico's wealthiest men.
"The impression is that Perez Simon was not as quick or as flexible a manager as Telmex needs now," said Andrew J. Friedman, a telecommunications analyst at the Vector brokerage firm here. "They brought in somebody who could roll with the punches more."
Since the devaluation, Telmex stock has been downgraded by J. P. Morgan and other firms. The company faces huge peso losses and in the next two years will have previously unknown competition in local and long-distance telephone service.

CORRECTION-DATE: January 26, 1995, Thursday

 CORRECTION:
An article in Business Day on Friday about worries in the Mexican financial markets over a United States aid package misstated the percentage change of the peso against the dollar on Thursday. The peso fell 1.8 percent against the dollar, not 4 percent.

HEADLINE: 69 Democrats Ready to Back Budgeting Bill

BYLINE: By MICHAEL WINES, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Jan. 20

 BODY:
Democrats said today that 69 of them in the House would support a balanced-budget amendment when it came to a vote next week, all but assuring that the measure will pass a chamber of Congress for only the second time in seven tries.
Representative Charles W. Stenholm, Democrat of Texas, said the Democrats had lined up behind his version of the amendment, which requires a balanced budget no sooner than the year 2002 and prohibits tax increases without the approval of a majority of all the 435 members of the House and the 100 senators. 
 That announcement clouds the prospects of a rival proposal, backed by Speaker Newt Gingrich and others, that is a centerpiece of the House Republicans' "Contract With America." Their version would require three-fifths of the House and Senate members to approve future tax increases, a ratio that is intended to tilt any Federal deficit reduction strategies away from finding more revenue and toward cutting spending.
The balanced-budget battle dominated an otherwise sleepy day in which the full House and the Senate were absorbed in the minutiae of another "Contract With America" item, legislation that would free states and cities from the burden of paying to enforce Federal legal and regulatory orders.
Mr. Gingrich and other Republican leaders in Congress have mounted a vigorous campaign for their proposal this week. Their allies kept it up in a hearing of the Joint Economic Committee today, insisting that any balanced-budget measure that does not rein in the Government's appetite for money will effectively be toothless.
Virtually all Republicans support some form of a balanced-budget amendment, and the vast majority support Mr. Gingrich's version. But moderate Republicans and the Democrats led by Mr. Stenholm hold the balance of power, because two-thirds of the House -- 290 members, if everyone votes -- must approve a Constitutional amendment. And there are but 230 Republicans.
That means no amendment can pass without the support of at least 60 Democrats, and probably more, and Mr. Stenholm appears to be the only politician who can now deliver them. If the House does pass a balanced-budget amendment, it would be only the second time since 1982, when the Senate approved a similar measure. That measure died in the House.
In a letter to the Speaker that Mr. Stenholm and 65 other Democrats signed, the Texas Congressman said his version of the budget amendment had the "strong bipartisan support" essential if any proposal was to make it through Congress.
But Mr. Gingrich was not conceding that today. "We are going all out on our side of the aisle," he said at a news conference, adding that at least 220 of the 230 Republicans in the House would vote for what he called the "tax limitation" form of the amendment. But he added, "The weakness is on the Democratic side."
Experts in both parties say that only about 40 Democrats favor the three-fifths ratio in the Republican version , which is being sponsored in the House by Representative Joe L. Barton of Texas and in the Senate by Rod Grams of Minnesota, both Republicans.
But Republican support is not unanimous. In the House, Mr. Stenholm is joined Representative Dan Schaefer, Republican of Colorado Republican. And in the Senate, an identical version of the Stenholm amendment has Bob Dole of Kansas, the majority leader, as a sponsor; it was approved this week by the Senate Judiciary Committee.
Those two versions are the principal rivals in the amendment battle, but hardly the only contenders. Mr. Gingrich said today that lawmakers had come up so far with 37 alternatives to the amendment as specified in the "Contract With America." The House Rules Committee will meet on Monday to decide how and when to conduct the debate and vote on a balanced-budget amendment.
As Mr. Stenholm pressed his case in the House, advocates of the Contract version held a hearing of the Joint Economic Committee in a Senate office building to make theirs.
In a first for Congressional hearings, the economic panel watched and heard Milton Friedman, who won the Nobel Prize in economics in 1976, testify via television, from Stanford University in California, that a budget amendment that failed to discourage tax increases would not work.
Mr. Friedman's argument was similar to that of others at the hearing: the Government's income usually averages about 19 percent of the nation's gross domestic product, even if taxes are raised, because businesses and individuals change their behavior to keep their tax bills from rising. But, he said, the Government's penchant for spending has ballooned to about 24 percent of the gross domestic product in the last 15 years, and continues to rise.
If an amendment continues to make it easy for Congress to raise taxes, Mr. Friedman and others argued, Congress will do so. But that tactic will not ease the deficit, and will only feed a Federal bureaucracy that, the Nobel economist said, acts mostly as a wet blanket on economic growth.
There were dissenters. Lawrence Chimerine, managing director of the Economic Strategy Institute, said he agreed that deficit spending was "putting a huge burden on future generations that should have been stopped a long time ago, and better stop soon."
But Mr. Chimerine maintained that a budget amendment was no solution. Rather, he argued, an amendment will prove ineffective because huge swatches of the budget, including military spending and Social Security, have been deemed immune to budget cutting. And the remainder of the Federal budget, he said, cannot absorb the $1.2 trillion to $1.6 trillion in reductions needed to erase the deficit by the year 2002.
"You can't legislate or repeal the laws of arithmetic," he said.
Mr. Chimerine also warned that such steep spending cuts, spread over a relatively short time, could damage the economy and worsen a recession.
While the amendment continued, the Senate and the House were also debating a bill to make it harder for Congress to impose requirements on cities and states without providing money to pay for them. By wide margins, the House defeated two efforts by Democrats to weaken the bill.
While many Democrats say they support the general goal of removing burdensome "unfunded mandates" from cities and states, they contend that the current measure would go too far in reducing Federal environmental, safety and labor standards.
In both houses of Congress, Democrats have delayed a final vote by offering numerous amendments, but the bill is considered almost certain to pass eventually.
In the House, Democrats have drafted many amendments, each of them meant to exempt one kind of law or another from the restrictions in the new legislation, which would not flatly prohibit unfunded mandates but would erect procedural barriers to imposing new ones.
In consecutive votes today, the House first rejected the idea of exempting future laws governing water pollution from the effects of the bill, and then rejected a proposal to exempt any law intended to protect the public from unhealthy pollution coming across state lines.
There were no votes in the Senate during the debate today. Late Thursday night, after fending off a Republican effort to cut off debate, the Democrats finally agreed to limit to no more than 62 the number of amendments to be offered when the debate continues next week.

GRAPHIC: Photo: In a first for Congressional hearings, a witness testified yesterday via television. From California, the Nobel Prize-winning economist Milton Friedman addressed a hearing of the Joint Economic Committee. (Stephen Crowley/The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Striking Auto-Parts Workers Tentatively Settle With G.M.

BYLINE: By JAMES BENNET, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: DETROIT, Jan. 20

 BODY:
A three-day strike at a crucial General Motors Corporation parts complex was tentatively settled late this evening, but not before it had idled more than 32,000 workers in the company's assembly system and halted lines that make popular and profitable vehicles like the Chevrolet Suburban and the GMC Sierra pickup truck.
Officials of the United Automobile Workers union at the parts plant in Flint, Mich., said they would release no details of the agreement until a ratification vote of the local's 6,600 members scheduled for 1 P.M on Sunday. But they said that before the vote they would put 300 people back to work to begin shipping parts to prevent more assembly plants from closing. If the agreement is ratified, parts workers could be back at their posts as soon as Monday. 
 At least nine assembly plants and one assembly line in a 10th plant had shut down in the United States and Canada by this evening because of the strike. Those plants may not reopen, and others may still close, because it will take time for newly made parts to reach them.
The Flint factories, which normally operate round the clock, produce dozens of parts, including spark plugs and oil pumps. The union struck the complex on Wednesday, saying that G.M. had violated the terms of a three-year agreement signed last February. The company had promised to hire 500 workers over the life of the contract but had hired none, the union said. The union had also demanded that G.M. give the complex more parts to manufacture to keep new hires employed.
Under the union contract, G.M. does not pay workers whose plant is closed because of a strike, even if those workers are not striking. Such workers may be eligible for state unemployment payments. The union pays strike benefits of $150 a week only to workers out on strike.
G.M. has been trying to lower its costs by contracting with outside suppliers to produce parts. The company contends that those suppliers can make parts cheaper because U.A.W. wages and benefits of $42 per hour are more than twice what the suppliers pay their workers. At the same time, the company has resisted hiring more workers to keep pace with demand, instead scheduling record amounts of overtime.
For these reasons, the union has struck G.M. plants six times in the past year, selecting plants whose loss would damage the company the most.
G.M. has been slashing the inventories of parts it maintains at assembly plants, to adopt a Japanese manufacturing technique known as just-in-time delivery. That means a strike at a parts complex like the one in Flint snuffs production throughout the system within days.
A three-day strike at a parts plant in Anderson, Ind., last August ultimately shut down 13 assembly plants. G.M. settled that strike by promising to bring other parts-making work to the plant.
The plants that had closed because of the strike in Flint include the Buick City complex there, where workers struck in September in a successful effort to force G.M. to hire more people. Together, the strikes in Anderson and at Buick City cost the company 40,000 sales and $150 million in the third quarter of 1994, and an undisclosed amount in the fourth quarter.

HEADLINE: G.O.P. Affirms Plan to Stop Money for Unwed Mothers

BYLINE: By ROBERT PEAR, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Jan. 20

 BODY:
Congress heard widely differing opinions today about whether welfare payments encourage unmarried teen-agers to have babies, and whether Republican proposals to curtail such assistance would reverse the rise in births outside marriage.
Despite the conflicting testimony, Republican members of the House Ways and Means Committee affirmed their desire to pass legislation cutting off cash assistance to unmarried women under 18 whose children are born out of wedlock. 
 Representative Dave Camp, Republican of Michigan, declared that "illegitimacy is a social catastrophe." He said the Federal Government should no longer provide a comprehensive package of benefits to young men and women who "violate social convention by having children they cannot support."
William J. Bennett, the former Education Secretary, said: "Welfare may not cause illegitimacy, but it does make it economically viable. It sustains it and subsidizes it. And what you subsidize, you get more of."
More than two-thirds of black babies and more than one-fifth of white babies are born to unmarried women.
The depths of political disagreement on this issue were shown in the use of language. Democrats and child-welfare advocates generally avoided the term "illegitimacy."
"It places a stigma on the child," said Deborah V. Weinstein, a policy analyst at the Children's Defense Fund. "All children are legitimate in the eyes of God." Conservatives, on the other hand, used the term freely. They said they wanted to reimpose the social stigma associated with childbearing outside marriage.
Experts of all political persuasions expressed skepticism about the Government's ability to alter adolescent sexual behavior by manipulating financial incentives.
Rebecca M. Blank, a professor of economics at Northwestern University, said, "There is little relationship between welfare payment levels and rising problems of out-of-wedlock births."
"It is hard to understand how the recent rapid increase in unwed motherhood can be fueled by public assistance payments," Ms. Blank testified, because the purchasing power of such payments has declined in the last two decades.
James Q. Wilson, a professor of management and public policy at the University of California at Los Angeles, said out-of-wedlock births had been rising in many countries for three decades. "Throughout the world," he said, "we have seen a fundamental shift in attitude toward the importance of marital commitment. It is not a peculiar defect in the United States."
In response to questions, Mr. Wilson said, "I don't believe that taking welfare benefits away from children would cause the problem to go away." But he said common sense would suggest that "if people cannot get more money for having more children, they are less likely to have more kids."
A bill introduced by House Republicans, as part of their "Contract With America," stipulates that states may not increase cash assistance when mothers on welfare have additional children. States now generally make larger payments to larger families.
Mr. Wilson said the Federal Government should encourage "radical experimentation among the states," because it does not know enough to set "one national rule that fits all the states." He said states should experiment with programs that send public money to family shelters, maternity homes and private charities.
Mr. Bennett said that some states should try cutting off welfare payments for unmarried teen-age mothers. "You would actually see fewer children born out of wedlock," he said. "You would see less misery, and you could break the cycle" of poverty.
Representative E. Clay Shaw Jr., a Florida Republican who presided over the hearing as chairman of the Ways and Means Subcommittee on Human Resources, said Republicans intended to revise their original welfare bill to add provisions cracking down on fathers who failed to pay child support.
Representative Marge Roukema, Republican of New Jersey, said she and other women in the House wanted to establish criminal penalties for parents who willfully disobeyed court orders for the payment of child support. In addition, she said, states could withhold drivers' licenses or professional licenses from such parents.

HEADLINE: BASEBALL;
In Baseball, No Games, But the Game Is Expanding

BYLINE: By MURRAY CHASS, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: TAMPA, Fla., Jan. 20

 BODY:
Acting uncharacteristically but with necessity, baseball's expansion committee unanimously recommended today that the major leagues expand by four teams, two in "an expeditious manner" and two "in a reasonable amount of time thereafter."
The owners are expected to act so expeditiously that they will very likely approve the initial stage of the two-tiered expansion by mid-February. They may even award the first two franchises by then; if not, by the end of the month at the latest. 
 St. Petersburg-Tampa and Phoenix are virtually certain to be sites for the majors' 29th and 30th teams, beginning play either in 1997 or 1998.
In making its recommendation to the ruling executive council, the expansion committee departed from the position officials and owners had always held: that they would not act on expansion until they had a new labor agreement with the players.
But suddenly the committee has one or two compelling reasons to make the decision now. One is the April 1 deadline Phoenix faces for the implementation of a quarter-cent tax that would fund a new $275 million stadium. The tax won't go into effect unless the city is granted a franchise by then.
The other reason is the fight the owners face in Congress to hold onto their longtime exemption from the antitrust laws. Aside from the feeling that has grown generally in Congress to repeal at least part of the exemption, lawmakers from Florida and Arizona are poised to push a repeal bill because they are concerned with the economic disaster their states face without a legitimate spring training.
John Harrington of the Boston Red Sox, chairman of the expansion committee, met last week with Senator Connie Mack, Republican of Florida and a proponent of repeal, and Harrington just might have told Mack what was coming.
The executive council has to act on the committee's recommendation before passing it on to the full ownership, but Bud Selig, the council chairman, said in a statement, "Expansion continues to be on a fast track."
Harrington said the committee "believes that baseball will be well served by expansion."
The owners especially will be well served, because they are expected to extract an expansion fee in the $150 million neighborhood from each of the two new teams. The price will very probably be higher when the 31st and 32d teams are added. One of those could come from northern Virginia and another from Orlando, Fla., the other two sites under consideration. By the time the second tier of expansion is considered, though, other cities could step forward and join the competition.
Donald Fehr, the players' labor leader in the strike, welcomed the announcement.
"Obviously, we've been in favor of expansion a long time," he said by telephone from New York. "We've been trying to talk to them about expansion for about a year. We feel the more people playing baseball and the more people watching baseball, when there is baseball, the better off baseball will be."
People in the Tampa Bay area were cautiously ecstatic about the news. Seven previous times they anticipated getting a team, but their batting average remains .000. Before they had them in their clutches, they lost the Twins, the Athletics, the Rangers, the White Sox, the Mariners, the Giants and a National League expansion team.
Vincent Naimoli, a Tampa industrialist who heads the local group that would own a new franchise, said he was gratified at the prospect of bringing a team here, but he was a bit cautious himself.
"This is just one more step in the long process and hopefully we'll see the end of the road in a very short time," he said.
Jerry Colangelo, on the other hand, abandoned all caution. Colangelo, who operates the Phoenix Suns of the National Basketball Association, has worked for more than a year to put a major league baseball team in Arizona.
"Obviously, I'm very pleased," Colangelo said by telephone from Phoenix, "because in my opinion this was the major hurdle, and that was to respond to the question: Will baseball expand without a collective bargaining agreement? I think that question was answered today. The next step is to award the franchises to cities, and I feel very confident that Phoenix along with Tampa will be the two."
The new Phoenix stadium would not be ready until 1998, but Colangelo said if the new teams were to begin play in 1997, one of two spring training sites, either Phoenix Municipal Stadium or the new stadium in suburban Peoria, Ariz., could be expanded and used for one season.
 
Tryouts for the Mets
The Mets announced yesterday that they would conduct tryouts for replacement players in California, Florida and Texas, beginning next weekend.
The tryouts are open to those who have played professional baseball within the last five years. The sessions will be held next Saturday at Long Beach State and Brookhaven Community College in Dallas, and on Feb. 1 at the Mets' spring training complex in Port St. Lucie, Fla.
Players must bring their own spikes and gloves. Further information can be obtained by calling the Mets at (800) 685-8589.

HEADLINE: U.S. Eases Trade Limits on North Korea for First Time Since 1950

BYLINE: By STEVEN GREENHOUSE, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Jan. 20

 BODY:
For the first time since imposing an embargo against North Korea in 1950, the United States eased trade restrictions today, announcing that it would allow direct telephone calls between the two nations and permit travelers to use credit cards there.
The announcement came as the Administration, under heavy attack from Republicans for its nuclear agreement with North Korea, is moving carefully to improve relations with the North in the hope of building trust and insuring that North Korea continues to fulfill its promise to freeze its nuclear program. 
 An Administration official said, "We consider this to be a very important diplomatic tool for insuring North Korea's continuing cooperation and implementation" of the agreement signed in October, in which the North vowed to freeze and ultimately dismantle its nuclear program.
As part of its relaxation of the embargo, the Administration also announced that it would allow American news organizations to open offices in North Korea and permit North Korean journalists to open bureaus in the United States.
And in a small easing of its embargo on goods, the Administration said it would permit imports of one of the few North Korean products for which there is a large American demand: magnesite, a mineral that steelmakers use to line their blast furnaces.
North Korea announced two weeks ago that it would end its embargo on American goods and permit phone calls and financial transactions with the United States.
Administration officials also acknowledged that the relaxation of restrictions announced today was modest, but said that the prospect of further relaxation should serve as a powerful incentive for North Korea to abide by the nuclear agreement.
In that accord, the United States promised to head an international consortium that would provide North Korea with $4 billion worth of light-water atomic reactors and fuel oil. The spent fuel those reactors produce is far harder to transform into weapons-grade plutonium than the fuel produced by North Korea's existing reactors.
Under the October agreement, the United States and North Korea pledged to ease restrictions on telecommunications and financial transactions by Jan. 21.
The easing announced today was consistent with the approach the United States has used with other Communist countries over the past decade -- opening up trade and concentrating on increasing the flow of information and ideas. The thinking is that the inflow of Western ideas will increase support for democracy and free markets.
"The intention is to promote the exchange of information and openness," an Administration official said.
The State Department said further relaxation of economic sanctions "will depend on further verified progress on the nuclear issue as well as progress in other areas of concern."
Those areas, Administration officials said, include North Korean restraint in exporting missile technology.
The announcement came a day after Republican lawmakers hammered the Administration at a Senate hearing for, as they put it, helping to prop up North Korea's dictatorship by providing it with $4 billion in energy aid.
Reacting to the Administration move, Senator Frank Murkowski, an Alaska Republican who heads the Senate Subcommittee on East Asia, said in an interview, "I'm critical that they've been moving as rapidly as they are" in relaxing the restrictions.

HEADLINE: Mehdi Bazargan, Former Iran Premier, Dies

BYLINE: AP 

DATELINE: NICOSIA, Cyprus, Jan. 20

 BODY:
Mehdi Bazargan, Iran's first Prime Minister after the Islamic revolution of 1979, died today in Switzerland, said the official Iranian news agency, monitored here. He was in his late 80's.
He died of heart failure at a hospital in Zurich after collapsing at the city's airport, said Iran's Ambassador to Switzerland, Mohammed Riza Alborzi. He was headed with his wife and son-in-law from his home in Teheran to the United States for heart surgery, the envoy said. 
 Mr. Bazargan was a campaigner for democracy and human rights during the rule of the Shah Mohammed Riza Pahlevi, who was toppled in the Islamic revolution. In February 1979, Mr. Bazargan was appointed by Ayatollah Ruhollah Khomeini to head the provisional government that replaced the ousted monarchy.
As head of that lame-duck government, Mr. Bazargan appealed for calm and reason amid the revolutionary fervor that culminated in the takeover of the American Embassy in Teheran in November 1979.
He resigned when Ayatollah Khomeini endorsed the embassy siege, in which 52 Americans remained hostages until January 1981.
Mr. Bazargan went from being one of the staunchest supporters of Ayatollah Khomeini and of the revolution he led to one of his harshest critics. He served in Parliament until 1984 as a lawmaker of the Iran Freedom Movement, which he had founded in 1961. The group functioned as the only legal opposition group after the revolution, though its members were often harassed or beaten by Government supporters. The Iranian Government finally outlawed the movement in 1990.
It survived as a spinoff, the Society for the Defense of Freedom, until September 1991, when eight of the society's members or sympathizers, including some former Government ministers, were imprisoned after secret trials for treason.
At a time when the country's new ruling clerics were propounding a form of "revolutionary justice" in which thousands were summarily executed, Mr. Bazargan appealed for moderation.
In a speech at Teheran University before his resignation in November 1979, he said: "Don't expect me to act in the manner of Khomeini, who, head down, moves ahead like a bulldozer crushing rocks, roots and stones in his path. I am a delicate passenger car and must ride on a smooth, asphalted road."
The son of a merchant, Mr. Bazargan was born in 1907 in Azerbaijan, though the exact date and details are not known. He studied engineering for six years at the University of Paris in the 1930's and earned a degree in thermodynamics.
He returned home in 1942 to teach at Teheran University, where he became known as one of Iran's best mathematicians and was awarded the chair of thermodynamics at the university's Technical College.
All the while, he was becoming increasingly disenchanted by Government policies. By the 1950's he had achieved enough prominence in the opposition to be asked to serve in the Government of Dr. Mohammed Mossadegh, a nationalist foe of the young Shah.
When Prime Minister Mossadegh stripped the British-owned Anglo-Iranian Oil Company of its monopoly on oil production and nationalized the industry in 1951, he sent Mr. Bazargan to head the company's operations.
After Mr. Mossadegh was ousted in a Western-backed coup in 1953, Mr. Bazargan plunged into a campaign to overthrow the Shah, whom he accused of violating human rights. He was jailed several times, including a five-year term beginning in 1962, and gained a following among diverse groups who resented the Shah's rule.
This also aligned him with Iran's exiled religious leader, Ayatollah Khomeini, who assigned him to direct an oil industry strike in 1978 that weakened the main pillar of Iran's economy. With support for his Islamic campaign sweeping the country, the Ayatollah returned in triumph in early 1979 and appointed a 17-member Cabinet.
But as head of that short-lived provisional Government, Mr. Bazargan was constantly frustrated by "revolutionary committees" and by clerical pronouncements that clashed with his Cabinet's policies. "They have put a knife in my hand, but it is a knife with only a handle. Others are holding the blade," he said in describing his Government.

SECTION: Section 1; Page 22; Column 1; Editorial Desk 

LENGTH: 521 words

HEADLINE: To Help a City in Crisis

 BODY:
Warnings of deep trouble for the New York City budget took on a sharper edge this week when the Standard & Poor's rating agency put the city on a "credit watch." The trigger was Mayor Rudolph Giuliani's plan to pay $120 million of this year's debt service costs with newly borrowed money, in effect postponing the final payout to another day.
As a rule, borrowing just to get out of a tight budget squeeze is not a good idea; S.&P. is properly concerned that the city not slip into bad habits. However, borrowing seems justified this time. The Mayor says he is doing it to avoid disruptive midterm cuts for schools -- commendable restraint on his part. The school system has agreed to absorb deeper budget cuts next year. Moreover, city officials say this borrowing will cost less in the long run than the debt it replaces, because it has a shorter term at lower interest. 
 What the city really needs, though, is fewer narrow escapes and more real relief from its constant state of crisis. It needs a serious plan to end the chronic imbalance between revenues and expenses. Extended over several years, that plan could include borrowing, like the plan that lifted the city out of crisis in the 1970's.
Standard & Poor's is particularly nervous about New York because it rates the city higher than other agencies do. The Mayor in turn does not want the rating lowered because, embarrassment aside, a lower rating would mean higher interest rates on money the city borrows. But a downgrading seems unlikely as long as Mr. Giuliani works as hard and as effectively to tame the budget as he has so far. Except for his overprotection of the police and firefighting budgets, he is clearly trying.
There is still, however, a gap of at least $650 million to eliminate before the fiscal year ends on June 30. Why does that gap keep reopening every time City Hall claims to have closed it? Because each fix is precarious. The big problem this year has been the city's weak economy, especially Wall Street -- and, therefore, weak tax collections. But another problem is political weakness. Too often the Mayor and the Council swear they have put a tighter cap on spending than turns out to be the case, or that the city's income will rise faster than it actually does.
The budget would be in better shape if it had been cut more in June, but there was heavy constituent pressure on Council members to do less. Later, after a showdown with the Council, the Mayor had to cut $1 billion more, and now, with less than half the fiscal year left, an additional $650 million or more must go. The borrowing will fill part of the new hole; direct spending cuts will do the rest.
Budget uncertainties are further compounded by the new Republican majorities in Congress and the new Republican Governor of New York State. The threat of reduced Federal and state aid makes it all the more urgent that the Mayor, the Council, labor unions, business leaders and Albany pull together on a serious plan to end the city's constant and debilitating fiscal crisis. A special borrowing can help now, but it is not a permanent solution.

HEADLINE: Japanese-Owned Company Plays by U.S. Rules;
Selling Our Cars There

 BODY:
To the Editor:
Thomas L. Friedman in "Japan Fatigue" (column, Jan. 11) unfortunately echoes the Ford Motor Company's economically indefensible argument that its 1 percent share of Japan's car market proves that market is somehow "managed." By that token so too is the United States car market. 
 But there are at least 10 companies -- including BMW, Mercedes, Volkswagen and Subaru -- that have about 1 percent or less of this market. BMW, Mercedes and Volkswagen have the same percentage of Japan's market.
Imports have played a rapidly increasing role in the competitive Japanese market for the last decade. In 1987 they took less than 1 percent of the Japanese car market. In December 1994 they reached 12 percent.
Car imports now account for 19 percent of the United States market, down from 31 percent in 1987. Interestingly, imports in Japan take as much as 27 percent of the large-car segment, where the Big Three choose to sell their cars. Detroit has yet to offer products in the small-car segment, which represents the bulk of Japanese passenger-car sales.
To catch up with their international competitors, the Big Three are looking to Washington for numerical targets and other managed trade policies.
 
WILLIAM C. DUNCAN
General Director, Japan Automobile
Manufacturers Association
Washington, Jan. 16, 1995

HEADLINE: Japanese Gather for News of Quake;
At Bookstore in Rockefeller Center, Lists of Victims Are Posted

BYLINE: By NORIMITSU ONISHI 

 BODY:
Asami Sakamoto stood in the lobby of Kinokuniya Book Store in Manhattan, her nose inches away from sheets of white paper posted on a glass wall. Among the thousands of Japanese names, packed single-spaced onto eight pages, she searched for those of old friends in Kobe.
 Like Ms. Sakamoto, many of New York's Japanese residents have traveled every day since Tuesday to this Rockefeller Center bookstore. With telephone lines still down in Kobe, they have no option but to make personal visits to these ever-lengthening lists of those who died in Monday's earthquake. 
 Like the tens of thousands of survivors who lined up for emergency rations in Kobe, scores of Japanese students, artists and business executives stood patiently and quietly on line at Kinokuniya -- although employees said one young woman read down the lists and broke into tears.
 "Kinokuniya has played a peculiar role in the earthquake," said Setsuko Inaki, 33, a reporter for Nippon Television Network, which has its New York bureau in Rockefeller Center. "It has become a public gathering place."
 Indeed, Kinokuniya, more than any other spot, has drawn together the fragmented Japanese population in the New York area. For unlike other newcomers to New York, who have carved out city neighborhoods for themselves, the Japanese are scattered throughout the city and its suburbs, and have no natural center to their expatriate world. Kinokuniya at Rockefeller Center is the New York branch of a bookstore chain in Japan.
 In part, the Japanese have no natural gathering place, because, unlike many other foreign-born residents of New York, the Japanese here are not really immigrants. Most are not here to stay, but to study or work or escape what some see as the restrictions of Japanese society. And so they feel the sting of a disaster in their homeland particularly keenly because they have not severed their ties to it at all.
 For the first 24 hours following the earthquake, Kenzo Minami, 20, could neither sleep nor leave his apartment in Chelsea, he said. He could not reach his parents and younger brother who live in Nishinomiya, a city near Kobe that was one of the most devastated areas.
 To keep from panicking, Mr. Minami, a student at Parsons School of Design, began planning a new life for himself without his family. He imagined himself settling in Europe, where he has friends, because the pain of returning to Japan would be overwhelming.
 "Finally, my mother called to say everyone was fine," said Mr. Minami, who spent Wednesday at Kinokuniya's coffee bar, watching Japanese news broadcasts on their TV. "My younger brother woke up when a bookcase almost fell on his head, but a desk stopped its fall. It's strange. I felt I should have been with them. I felt I should have shared with them, as a family, the fear."
 There are about 54,000 Japanese nationals living in the New York area, according to the Japanese consulate. Most are business executives and their families, stationed here by such businesses as the Sakura Bank, the Mitsukoshi department store and Kobe Steel U.S.A. Many live in Scarsdale and Hartsdale in Westchester, in Greenwich, Conn., and in Fort Lee, N.J.
 Company assignments to New York vary in length, but most Japanese executives know their stay is temporary. So, many seek to re-create a Japanese life style in the suburbs of New York. Parents shop in Japanese grocery stores and get hair-cuts at Japanese hairdressers. Children take weekend classes at Japanese cram schools so as not to fall behind in their studies. Some teen-agers avoid American schools altogether and attend Keio High School, which opened in Purchase in 1990.
 Japanese students and artists, on the other hand, have chosen to immerse themselves in American ways. They have built something of a community on East Ninth Street on the Lower East Side. Many nominally came here to study English, but really came seeking a degree of social and economic freedom they could not find in Japan -- especially young women whose career prospects were made dimmer by the recession in their home country.
 Unlike these Japanese visitors, immigrants from Japan first arrived in the United States a century ago, searching for jobs and better lives. But restrictive immigration laws in the 1920's and later the outbreak of World War II, cut off new immigration. By the time the anti-immigration laws were repealed in the mid 1960's, Japan was becoming an economic superpower, and there were no economic forces pushing the Japanese to emigrate.
 The temporary Japanese community began growing here in the 1980's during Japan's economic boom, creating a Japanese presence that was new to the region Although economic difficulties often increase emigration from many nations, Japan's prolonged recession has actually decreased the the number of Japanese living in the New York area , as companies cut the number of executives stationed here.
 It is perhaps a measure of the earthquake's reach that it moved not only Japanese nationals, but many of this area's Japanese-Americans, who number about 10,000.
 All week, the Japanese American Association of New York in midtown Manhattan has bustled with twice as many regular visitors, both Japanese and Japanese-Americans who came to talk about the earthquake.
 Michiyo Noda, the office manager, said donations were made unsolicited, in person and over by telephone. Many were from nisei, or second-generation, Japanese-Americans -- often elderly women.
 Dr. Seiichi Shimomura, the association's vice president, said, "The nisei consider themselves pure Americans. Many of them don't even speak Japanese. Still, there are emotional ties to Japan."
 Dr. Shimomura, 73, a retired cardiologist, was born in Seattle but grew up in Japan. He spent his sixth-grade year in Kobe, where he had relatives with whom he has now lost touch. A few days ago, he recognized his elementary school, Sumayama, when a television report showed it in ruins.
 Like hundreds of others at the bookstore, as well as at the Japanese Consulate and at some Japanese restaurants where other lists of the dead were posted, Dr. Shimomura scanned for a familiar name.
 "I saw one Shimomura, age 5, in Kobe," he said. "So I wondered. But that's not an uncommon name."

HEADLINE: ABOUT NEW YORK;
An Old Boss Dies and Five Dreams Die With Him

BYLINE: By David Gonzalez 

 BODY:
WHEN Rafael Morales and his four brothers got beat out of a parking place, they got steamed.
 Then they got a lawyer. 
 Granted, this particular parking place is big. It holds several hundred cars and is better known as the Yorkshire Garage, where the Morales brothers worked for years and were treated like sons by the owner, Rudy Otero. Friends and customers on the Upper West Side said Mr. Otero so trusted the brothers that he promised to bequeath them the garage. After months of haggling over the estate of Mr. Otero, who died last year, the Morales brothers got something else altogether -- a new boss.
 In December, a man entered the garage and handed them a stack of fliers announcing a change of ownership. He asked them to tuck the fliers under the customers' windshield wipers.
 "I felt humiliated," Mr. Morales said. "I thought I had a business."
 As belittled as he felt by that experience, he was even more angered when he learned that part of the deal was put together by the law firm of Fischbein, Badillo. The firm helped the new owners negotiate a lease with the city, which owns the garage building at 151 West 108th Street.

HERMAN Badillo, the politician and the Mayor's adviser on school finances, was not involved in the lease negotiations, but the brothers said they felt betrayed nonetheless, given that they and Mr. Badillo hail from the town of Caguas, P.R.
 The mess -- the indignity, the legal wrangling -- could have been avoided if Mr. Otero had left a will.
 His relatives said he did not, but the brothers -- and their lawyer -- say that he must have. In fact, the brothers are willing to risk their jobs to prove it. They went to court yesterday to challenge Mr. Otero's relatives to produce the document or explain its absence and to try to block the transfer of the garage to new owners.

"EVEN if they fire us, they haven't buried the problem," said Carlos Morales. "We're going to dig out that problem and bring it to the courts and to the public."
 A dozen years ago, Rafael Morales was an unemployed factory worker looking for work. He took a break one day and dropped in on a friend who worked at the garage. He walked out with a job.
 The employees at the garage then were unreliable, he said. There were problems with drugs and other vices. His brothers replaced them.
 The five brothers grew close to Mr. Otero, spending their days working and talking with him. Carlos Morales said Mr. Otero once gave him $500 to help him buy text books for his courses at Mercy College.
 "What our own father never gave us as children," Carlos said, "this man gave us as adults."
 When Mr. Otero fell ill with the cancer that would kill him, Rafael took him to his doctor appointments. When weakness landed him in a hospital, the brothers would always visit.
 "They were the closest thing to a family that I knew he had," said Dr. Raul Lugo, Mr. Otero's friend and doctor. "Their relationship went far beyond what you'd expect from an employer and employee."
 Dr. Lugo, and several other customers and friends, insist that Mr. Otero wanted the Morales brothers to get the garage. Carmen Rohland said in an affidavit that when he told her he had "made arrangements" for the Morales brothers, she asked him if he had prepared his will.
 "Don't worry," she said he replied, "I already did that."
 The brothers have been worried ever since Mr. Otero's death in February. Rudy's brother Manuel and Mr. Otero's relatives went to the garage frantically searching for "the papers," the brothers said. The relatives declined to speak on the record, but they contend there was no will.
 The brothers negotiated with the estate through the summer, although for much of the time they did not know that another garage company was interested in their place. The brothers agreed to the city's request for a rent increase and sent off a draft agreement to the estate's lawyer.
 They heard nothing until the new boss arrived.

"IT sounds like pressure was being put on them to pay more than they were able to pay, to throw them out of the ball park because they didn't have the money to get in," said Jane Bevans, the brothers' new lawyer. "They did in fact have the money. And yet, even on top of that, they were forced out of the game."
 The estate's lawyer said Manuel Otero decided that letting HRF Operating Corporation run the garage was a wise business decision. City officials said they felt they got a fair market rent.
 Richard Fischbein, of the law firm that represented HRF, scoffed at the idea that the brothers were cheated. If the brothers have a dispute, it's with the estate and not his client. Besides, he said, the brothers got to keep their jobs.
 Yes, they're still working in the garage. Working by the hour for someone else.
 That's why they're in court working to keep their dignity.

HEADLINE: The Way It Was and Could Be

BYLINE: By JON NORDHEIMER, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: ATLANTIC CITY

 BODY:
In Louis Malle's 1980 film "Atlantic City," an aging numbers runner played by Burt Lancaster rues the passing of the heyday of this old resort city when hoodlum chic and a special pop spirit called "floy-floy" reigned.
 Even the natural wonder of the sea, he lamented, had eroded with time. "The Atlantic Ocean was something then," he said. 
 "You shoulda seen the Atlantic Ocean in those days," he said as he walked by new casinos rising from the rubble of hotels demolished by wrecking balls.
 Atlantic City 15 years later still seems to be a place filled with yesterdays and tomorrows. Rarely are thoughts as much about today as they are about how things once were or could be.
 When Florence Valore Miller looks south from the new city Arts Center on Garden Pier, she sees the ghosts of the splendid old boardwalk hotels torn down to make room for the new generation of glass and concrete casinos.
 Mrs. Miller, 77, who said her father opened Atlantic City's first Italian restaurant early in the century, leads a visitor to an oil painting by Attilio Sinagria hanging on a gallery wall. The top half is a lineup of doomed hotels, with their rococo blandishments and haughty names: Marlborough-Blenheim and Traymore, among others. The bottom half shows the present lineup of glossy barns and towers.
 "This is the beauty we had and this is the garbage we got," said Mrs. Miller, who ran an oasis of culture in a one-room arts center for 40 years until her badgering helped persuade city officials to build a new gallery and museum.
 Those more inclined to think about the future of Atlantic City are generally happier these days.
 Just a few months ago, there was gloomy talk about competition expected from neighboring states, especially Pennsylvania, where one-third of Atlantic City's gambling patrons come from. The theory was that once Gov. Robert P. Casey, an opponent of legalized gambling, left office this month, his successor would move quickly to clear the way for riverboat casinos in Philadelphia and other waterfront cities. Atlantic City casino operators were already hedging their bets by buying up land on the Delaware River to counter a blow to their huge investments here.
 But the new Governor, Thomas Ridge, has said he wants to put the gambling issue before voters in a statewide referendum -- a more drawn-out process than going straight to the legislature, and one with more uncertain chances of success.
 Another sigh of relief from the city's 12 casino hotels was almost audible on Election Day, when Florida voters crushed an initiative to allow casino gambling there, stealing the hearts and wallets of high rollers in winter and probably other seasons as well.
 Gov. George E. Pataki said he might consider putting a casino referendum before New York voters, but the vote might not come until 1997. By then, slot machines and gaming tables here could pile up an additional $10 billion in profits.
 An improving economy helped gaming profits here increase in 1994 by more than 4 percent after several slow years. That translates roughly into an additional $10 million per casino over the 1993 performance.
As icing on the cake, it seems likely that Gov. Christine Todd Whitman will sign legislation passed last month to ease regulation over nongambling aspects of the industry, a move expected to save casinos $10 million a year.
 A companion bill would clear the way for one owner to operate more than three casinos, now the legal limit. Although his name is nowhere on the legislation, the obvious beneficiary is Donald Trump, who could get his fourth gambling license for his Trump Regency hotel.
 Except for Bally's, which has two casinos, no other operator has more than one. At first most of the other owners opposed the bill that would aid Mr. Trump. At the showdown, however, most retreated, finding it inconsistent to limit state regulation in one bill and endorse it in another.
 One major player in Atlantic City who didn't back down was Mayor James Whelan. A 6-foot-, 7-inch schoolteacher elected last year to his second term, Mr. Whelan publicly took on Mr. Trump by saying a fourth casino would place too much power in the hands of one man.
 "Trump and I spoke and he's not happy with my position," the Mayor said in a recent interview. "But I like Trump. He's a promoter and that's what Atlantic City has been built on: People who promoted themselves, their property and the city."
 Mr. Whelan, 46, says he has become more aggressive in promoting the city. "I assume there will be legalized gambling within a two-hour drive of every major American city by the year 2000," he said. "The question is, how do we survive that?"
 "No other city can duplicate what's already here," the Mayor said, referring to the city's 12 gambling halls and more than 7,000 hotel rooms. "Donald Trump is not going to build another Taj Mahal," he added, referring to the $1 billion casino the developer opened in 1990.
 A new 500,000-square-foot convention hall should be in full operation by early 1997, he said, which should draw more people to a resort already pulling in 30 million visits a year, mostly repeat trips by a core of about seven million people from Virginia to New England.
 But what is needed most in a resort that doesn't have a golf course, a movie house or, until recently, a supermarket, is an expansion of attractions that will make Atlantic City a destination instead of a place to gamble for a night or two, he said. That, combined with continued efforts to upgrade neighborhoods that have crumbled after decades of neglect, would insulate the city from competition outside New Jersey, he said.
 However, Peter Boynton, the president and chief operating officer of Caesars Atlantic City Casino and Hotel, said he suspected that the recent good news from Pennsylvania and Florida might deflate what had been a promising start to diversify the resort.
 "From what I hear there is great relief about the lessening of competition from other areas," Mr. Boynton said. "It has put the timetable back at least one year on getting people moving on redevelopment, and what we need to do here to insure the future of Atlantic City."

HEADLINE: INVESTING;
Hedging Currencies: Has Its Time Come?

BYLINE: By Francis Flaherty 

 BODY:
MANY investors in foreign-stock funds know little about protecting their portfolios from currency swings, often called hedging. But as 1995 unfolds, they may be compelled to pay attention.
 "For 10 years nonhedgers gained as the dollar declined," said Malcolm Tulloch, an equity strategist at G. T. Global funds in San Francisco. The dollar bought 263 yen in early 1985 and now buys just under 100. For an unhedged American investor, this means $2.63 now for every $1 invested then in Japan, even if the stock price has not changed. 
 But many economists predict the dollar will rise against the yen, mark and other currencies in 1995. If they are right, a failure to hedge may trim returns, not augment them.
 "In 1992, the British market rose 25 percent, and the pound dropped 25 percent," Mr. Tulloch noted. Americans who invested there without hedging gained nothing. Those who used hedges, through forward contracts and other complex tools, preserved most of the stock gain.
 Of the foreign-stock funds surveyed by Morningstar, the mutual fund research company, 30 percent say they never hedge. About 13 percent say they actively hedge, and 57 percent do so occasionally.
 Among the funds that ever hedge, many are doing so now. Mr. Tulloch expects the mark to fall 15 percent in 1995 and has hedged his funds against the currency's decline. He is hedging the yen, too, as is Roy Gillson, manager of the $140 million IAI International Fund. "Twenty-eight percent of our fund is in Japan," Mr. Gillson said. "Half that is hedged."
 Other funds -- Dreyfus Global Growth, Japan Fund, SEI International Equity -- are also hedging the yen, and some funds have small hedges on the French franc and Swedish krona. Still others are considering the technique. "We think a stock's potential is more important than currency," said Gary Johnson, risk director at Scudder funds. "But we are looking at hedging more."
 The critics remain steadfast, however. "We get better returns without hedging," said Dorian Foyil, a research director at Templeton funds. "Hedges have costs." Mr. Gillson estimated his hedges reduced yearly returns by five-tenths of a percent. At other funds, it may be higher.
 Long-term investors benefit from a natural hedge, Mr. Foyil said. "When a foreign currency depreciates, it sparks the country's economy," he explained, creating equity gains that can undo the currency damage. In 1982, for instance, a peso devaluation of 83 percent sparked a 238 percent rise in Mexican stocks in dollar terms the following year.
 Also, hedges hurt the very diversification that makes foreign investing attractive. "U.S. investors have many dollar-based things -- houses, cars, bank accounts," said John Markese of the American Association of Individual Investors in Chicago. "Why turn foreign assets back into dollars?"
 Anyway, he said, "hedging assumes you can forecast currency moves, but they're unpredictable." Indeed, many funds hedged on the mistaken assumption that the dollar would rise in 1994.
 This year sees no unanimity, either. "We hedge if it makes sense," said George Murnaghan, a vice president of T. Rowe Price. "But we don't expect the dollar to rise much."
 Indeed, hedging is akin to pinning the tail on the donkey, with one right way and dozens of wrong ones. "Our funds average 25 different currencies," Mr. Foyil said. "Which should we hedge? And for how long?"
 Unpredictability cuts both ways. "I don't know if the yen will drop 15 percent, but if it does it will greatly affect my performance," said Kelly McDermott, who hedges for her Dreyfus Global Growth fund.
 Although focusing on stocks and letting currency swings cancel out in the long run seem plausible, the swings can go on and on, those who hedge say. "The pound has fallen since the late 19th century," Mr. Murnaghan noted.
 Moreover, "hedging mitigates volatility," said Philip Wagner, a manager of SEI International Equity. This gives all shareholders peace of mind, he said, and helps those who redeem shares in volatile times.
 Fund managers may have the most to gain. "The greatest crime for managers is to fall below the indexes," Mr. Markese said. "Hedges help them more than investors."
 What's an investor to do? "Find a good unhedged fund," he said, "and to reduce risk, diversify."
 Amy Arnott of Morningstar said, "For investing five years or less use a hedged fund; for longer use an unhedged one." And since hedging is hard, use a fund with a record.
 Or investors can take the Solomonic approach that Harold Evensky, a financial planner in Coral Gables, Fla., uses for foreign bond investments. "I use one fully hedged fund, an unhedged one and one that hedges intermittently. And, yes, it's an admission of confusion."
