HEADLINE: COMPANY NEWS;
Retailer From Chicago Places Big Manhattan Bet

BYLINE: By BARNABY J. FEDER, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: CHICAGO, Jan. 20

 BODY:
Fresh out of Northwestern University in 1960 with a degree in business administration, Gordon Segal took a job at the Four Seasons restaurant in Manhattan.
 "I ran out of money before I got promoted," said Mr. Segal, who gave up after six months. "I went home and said, 'I'm not ready for this.' " 
 Now he is going back for a second shot at making it in New York City. Mr. Segal, president of Crate and Barrel, the housewares and furniture chain based here, has a big store under construction at 59th Street and Madison Avenue in the heart of Manhattan's upscale retail district. It is being closely watched as part of the recent movement of several big retailers into New York City even as the Northeast's sluggish economic recovery remains on shaky ground.
 But this time, Mr. Segal -- with a chain of 55 stores stretching from Boston to California and a growing catalogue business -- seems about as ready as any newcomer possibly could be. He has spent four years mapping his March debut in the city he calls the "capital of the world." Much of the time was spent fretting over a midtown site. Mr. Segal also wanted to experiment at other Crate outlets to satisfy himself that his stores could sell furniture as successfully as they did housewares.
 To spread Crate and Barrel's name in the New York region and make distribution more efficient, he is going ahead with plans to open stores this summer in White Plains and in Short Hills, N.J.
 "Nothing really good happens too quickly," said Mr. Segal, who is 56. He has turned down repeated offers from investment bankers to take the chain public or sell it to investors with deep pockets so that it could expand more rapidly. He and a handful of senior executives own all the stock in Euromarket Designs Inc., Crate's corporate parent.
 The secret to Mr. Segal's strategy may be his melding of such cautious views about finance with an almost hedonistic affection for merchandise and merchandising. Mr. Segal and his wife, Carole, opened their first store in a former elevator factory here in 1962. They began by selling European-designed tableware they had fallen in love with on their travels but had been unable to buy locally. Starting out with too little money to afford store fixtures, they took their name from the packing crates and barrels on which they stacked display goods.
 The leased New York store, which will cost Crate about $10 million to develop, is less of a gamble than the company took in 1990 when it poured $24 million into building its flagship here on North Michigan Avenue. That modern, bright and glassy four-story structure was farther south than any major merchant had dared move on Chicago's "Magnificent Mile," but it quickly became a local landmark and a shopping destination for tourists. Some of the tourists include other retailers.
 "He's a consummate merchant," said Bernard Marcus, who built Home Depot into the premier mass marketer of do-it-yourself supplies. "I like to drop in to his stores whenever I travel to a place that has one because they are just plain fun."
 The Crate formula relies on distinctive products with modest markups, direct and long-term relationships with manufacturers, subtle but frequent design changes, brilliantly lighted arrangements of towers and rows of houseware items, and a strong emphasis on thoroughly trained, cheerful employees.
 It has been highly profitable, Mr. Segal said. Crate and Barrel will have revenues of about $274 million in the fiscal year that ends this month, up from $232 million the previous year, and is "at the upper end" of retail operating margins, he said. Mr. Segal declined to release more specific information or discuss how much of this year's gain came from opening new stores.
 As Crate and Barrel spreads beyond its Midwestern base, though, Mr. Segal's team confronts better-financed rivals like the Pottery Barn division of Williams-Sonoma Inc. In New York, it will also overlap part of the market of Bed, Bath and Beyond -- a housewares and linen "category killer" that blankets its category with a huge variety of offerings at discount prices. And he is invading the home turf of Bloomingdale's and Macy's,department stores that are both strong in housewares.
 The New York store, which will have 33,000 square feet of selling space, 50 percent more than the Michigan Avenue flagship, will not have exactly the same selection as other Crate stores.
 "We'll be a little less conservative in New York," said Barbara Turf, executive vice president for merchandising and marketing.
 To help keep its edge, Crate is paying more attention to financial and inventory management systems, subjects that Mr. Segal gamely but unsuccessfully tries to describe with the same verve he exudes when discussing merchandise.
 The company relies to an unusual degree on employees recruited from outside the retailing industry; many senior executives are former teachers who worked their way up the management ranks. (Carole Segal taught for a year before the first Crate and Barrel was opened, and Mr. Segal says teachers are skilled at teamwork and pay attention to customers.)
 "You'll find a lot of people here who thought they were on their way to another job and ended up staying," said Barbara Reiman, one of two regional vice presidents. As a fourth-grade teacher who loved shopping at Crate, she sought summer work 20 years ago and ended up taking a pay cut to join the company. Ms. Turf, who took a summer job at the original store 27 years ago, is another former teacher.
 Crate's offerings, outside of a few areas like cookware, where shoppers will find well-known brands like Calphalon, are designed and manufactured exclusively for it.
 "We never take a manufacturer's product straight off the floor," said Lon Hobkirk, the head of furniture operations. "No matter what the style, we'll have our version of it."
 That does not always come easily. One group of pieces that customers will see this spring is pine cabinetry that will age white rather than yellow, eventually matching a color Mr. Hobkirk had found on Scandinavian antiques. It took months of work with J & M Designs of Vernon, Calif., including a full week at the factory for Mr. Hobkirk, to get the right combination of bleaching. But Mary Beck, J & M's owner, is not complaining.
 "Crate is known throughout the industry as a treasured account," Mrs. Beck said. " They have an incredible eye."
 The batting average is not perfect, of course. Some products do better than they would in other stores, thanks to overall display wizardry. But Crate's corporate legends include several out-and-out pratfalls, like being several years too early into the slip-cover look only now becoming popular.
 Some of Crate's most loyal suppliers are based overseas. "Gordon was my first customer," said Jorgen Bodum, who since 1974 has run Bodum, his Danish family's glass and housewares business, which is now based in Switzerland. "He bought those French-press coffee makers we now sell to Starbucks and everyone else."
 It is finding new discoveries like Bodum that keeps Mr. Segal going.
 "My goal was not to build a chain of stores," Mr. Segal told a group of more than 20 New York employees earlier this week at their first orientation session. "My goal was to travel to Europe, eat well, find neat things and get people excited about what we found. My whole life has been spent trying to turn people on."

HEADLINE: Brisk Pace In Building Of Homes

BYLINE: By ROBERT D. HERSHEY Jr., Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Jan. 20

 BODY:
Despite a yearlong progression of higher interest rates, builders broke ground on new homes at a brisk clip last month to finish 1994 with a 13 percent annual gain and the highest output in six years, the Commerce Department reported today.
 Including an upward revision for November, recent construction activity has held up better than expected. Many analysts said this strength further solidified the case for the Federal Reserve to raise interest rates again later this month to try to restrain economic growth and keep inflation in check. 
 Separately, the University of Michigan's index of consumer confidence, which is released only to subscribers but is widely reported, was said to have shown a jump of 10 points in its preliminary January reading. That is considered another sign that economic vigor is greater than can be sustained without raising inflation.
 Concerns about inflation and higher interest rates sharply depressed bond prices today, pushing yields higher. [Page 48.]
 Analysts remained surprised by the modest toll that rising interest rates have taken on the housing market as the rate on conventional 30-year mortgages has climbed to 9 percent from 7 percent. Still, they detected evidence that the trend was starting to tip downward.
 In particular, they said that the unusually warm fall and early winter had artificially inflated construction activity by enouraging building that otherwise might not have occurred until spring.
 Housing starts over all actually edged down 1 percent last month, to an annual rate of 1,529,000, following what is now calculated as a 7.6 percent surge in November. Nonetheless, the December rate was the second highest of the year, behind November. And the decline in December was entirely attributable to a drop in building of multifamily housing; construction of single-family houses rose.
 "It's a false strength," said Robert R. Davis, chief economist for the Savings and Community Bankers of America, a trade group. He predicted that the economy would decelerate rapidly this year and that home construction would drop 10 to 15 percent.
Tommy Thompson, president of the National Association of Home Builders, said today that while he was pleased with the latest results he feared that further increases in interest rates were coming and he predicted a 5 percent decline in home building this year.
 "We're still concerned about the Fed and what they might do," said Mr. Thompson, a builder in Kentucky.
 A shift by consumers to adjustable-rate mortgages has helped cushion the impact of rising rates so far, but with adjustable-rate mortgages now accounting for 60 percent of new mortgages, up from 15 percent late last winter, they are unlikely to be such a mitigating force this year.
 December's modest decline in overall starts was a result of a drop in construction of buildings with two or more units, which slumped 13.9 percent from a very rapid November pace. Aided by restoration of a tax credit for low-income housing, multifamily construction had surged in the second half of the year.
 In single-family homes, December construction was at an annual pace of 1,226,000, a 2.8 percent rise that lifted the overall 1994 gain to 6 percent. At 1,195,600 homes, the yearly total was the highest since 1978.
 Still, said David C. Munro, an economist at High Frequency Economics, a New York consultant, the December results "are just kind of wobbly" in light of exceptionally favorable weather and other reports of weaker home sales and customer traffic.
 By region, starts in the Northeast and Midwest eased in December by 10.7 percent and 11.8 percent, respectively, while the South and West posted gains of 4 percent and 5.6 percent.
 Actual starts nationwide, without seasonal adjustment or annualization, were 95,100 last month, down from 112,900 in November and 98,700 in December 1993.
 Permits for future construction edged up six-tenths of 1 percent last month, the report also showed, with the West posting the only decline.
 Shipments of mobile homes, which are reported a month later than other housing data, rose 4.2 percent in November to an annual rate of 323,000.
 The University of Michigan's confidence survey surged in mid-January to 114.9 from 104.9, with the assessment of current conditions climbing 4 points, to 99.1, and the expectations component inching up two-tenths of a point, to 89.
 Such optimism, said Marilyn Schaja of Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette, makes the Commerce Department's recent report of weak retail sales late last year "even more suspect."

HEADLINE: Auto Shares Decline On New Ford Moves

BYLINE: By JAMES BENNET, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: DETROIT, Jan. 20

 BODY:
In a move likely to stoke fears that auto sales are flagging, the Ford Motor Company said today that it might close factories that make Windstar mini-vans and Escort small cars for longer than the one week it previously disclosed.
And after the New York Stock Exchange closed, the Chrysler Corporation announced that it was expanding rebates on the more expensive versions of its Neon subcompact cars, which have been selling poorly. 
 Although Ford executives said their production cutbacks did not reflect weakening sales, investors vehemently disagreed with them today.
 The earlier disclosures that Ford was planning one-week shutdowns at some of its factories sent auto stocks skidding. This morning, they fell further as one prominent Wall Street analyst slightly shaved his earnings estimates for Ford and Chrysler, citing weakening in mini-van sales and in the vehicle market more generally.
 In New York Stock Exchange trading today, Ford closed down $1.125 at $26.375. Shares of Chrysler ended at $47.125, down $2.125, and General Motors slipped 75 cents, to $39.50.
 Investors in G.M. may also have been reacting to a strike at a vital G.M. parts complex in Flint, Mich. The strike has halted assembly of more than two dozen models of cars and light trucks.
 The analyst, Jack Kirnan of Salomon Brothers, said the production cuts signaled broader weakening in the auto market. In particular, he said, the cutback in Windstar production, combined with a backup of other mini-vans on dealers' lots, indicated auto makers might have to cut prices to stimulate sales.
 "We would be amazed if Chrysler doesn't respond within a matter of days by adding a $500 rebate" or other incentive to its mini-vans, he wrote in an analysis released today. Chrysler has built up its inventories of mini-vans in anticipation of a production shutdown this spring to prepare to introduce a new model.
 The Neon rebates at Chrysler amount to $400 to $600 a vehicle, or lowered financing rates. The rebates had been available only to first-time car buyers.
 Meanwhile, Ford said the production cutbacks announced so far might not be enough to balance out supplies. "We may take another week of Windstar," said Ross Roberts, general manager of the Ford division. "We're taking a look at that."
 Similarly, Ford may shut its Hermosillo, Mexico, and Wayne, Mich., Escort plants for another week, he said. And Ford executives said they were not certain when they would restore overtime at their Kansas City, Mo., assembly plant, which makes Ford Contour and Mercury Mystique compact cars. Ford canceled overtime at that plant this week, after running two 10-hour shifts there since last summer.
 Ford contends that in each case, it is responding to a drop in dealers' order, not customer demand. As interest rates have risen, Ford said, the cost to dealers of carrying large inventories have also jumped.
 Higher interest rates have not discouraged customers, Mr. Roberts said, predicting that January's car and truck sales would come in ahead of last year's. "On the consumer, it's fine," he said of the effect of interest rates. "On the dealer, with his inventory costs, it's a problem."
 Over all, Mr. Roberts said, Ford dealers had 200,000 more cars and trucks in stock than they did a year ago. "That's probably more than we should have," he added.
 Ford dealers and their competitors said today that they had seen no slackening in demand, although several said that high interest rates were causing them to cut back on inventory.
 "Both the Windstars and Escorts have been selling like crazy," said Jim Catucci, a salesman at McCafferty Ford, in Langhorne, Pa.
 But several dealers said they were preparing to cut inventory because of rising rates. "Every 1 percent increase in the prime raises my cost of doing business by $5,000 a month," said David Wilson, owner of Toyota of Orange in Orange, Calif. "With current interest rates, we're at the level where we'll start to reduce inventory to decrease costs."
 Still, Mr. Wilson added, "rates haven't yet begun to affect consumer purchasing."

HEADLINE: Business Digest

 BODY:

Companies
 
The scramble for long-distance customers is growing wilder -- and more confusing for consumers. AT&T, MCI and Sprint have been promoting ever-more-generous discounts for people who make lots of calls. But people who make few calls or those who make lots of calls but have not signed up for a discount plan are seeing their prices go up rather than down. [Page 1.]
 
Microsoft's antitrust settlement was questioned by a Federal judge who displayed documents suggesting that Microsoft had intentionally deceived its rivals. [37.]
 
Crate and Barrel is making a move into Manhattan. Crate and Barrel, the Chicago-based housewares and furniture chain, plans to open its store in March. Its expansion is part of a recent movement of several big retailers into New York City even as the Northeast's economic recovery remains on shaky ground. [37.]
 
Ford may close plants that make Windstar mini-vans for longer than the one week it had previously announced. The planned production cutback drove down stocks of auto makers. [37.]
 
Viacom reached an agreement to sell its cable systems for $2.3 billion to a group that is led by a black entrepreneur and includes a company partly owned by Tele-Communications. [37.]
 
Trammell Crow is easing back into real estate development. The company, the nation's biggest developer until real estate values crashed in the 1980's, is cautiously looking for properties. [39.]
 
Shares of Cyrix jumped after the company said it had overcome manufacturing problems with its Intel-clone computer chips. [39.]
 
American Maize-Products received a sweetened bid of $38 a share, or $380 million, from a French suitor. [39.]
 
A strike at a G.M. parts plant was tentatively settled. [7.]
 
 
The Economy
 
The housing industry is showing strength in the face of higher interest rates. Housing starts slipped 1 percent in December, but still finishing 1994 with a 13 percent annual gain. [37.]
 
 
International
 
World trade has been disrupted by the closing of Kobe's port as a result of the earthquake this week. Kobe, Japan's largest container port, served as a hub for the movement of goods to other parts of East Asia, and its closing has had a domino effect. [1.]
 
Mexico's financial markets continue to be racked by concerns that the United States will not pass an aid package. [49.]
 
 
Markets
 
Stocks declined for the fourth consecutive session. The Standard & Poor's 500-stock index fell 2.17 points. [38.]
 
The dollar continued to slide against the German mark. The Canadian dollar touched another nine-year low. [47.]
 
Coffee prices tumbled on doubts that Brazil will join a quota plan. Sugar prices recovered, while crude oil slipped. [47.]
 
Treasury prices tumbled, dragged down by a weaker dollar and concerns over a new supply of securities. [48.]
 
 
Your Money
 
Insider trading among family members is increasingly a target of the S.E.C. Cases against people accused of using family ties to obtain secret corporate information and then profiting from that information in the stock market represented more than 10 percent of all the insider cases filed by the commission last year. [35.]
 
Are foreign stock funds that hedge against currency swings a better investment than funds that do not? While reducing the risk of volatility, hedges can be costly and they hurt the very diversification that makes foreign investing attractive. [35.]
 
Finding earthquake insurance is a struggle for many California homeowners. Some home insurers are quietly circumventing a law requiring them to offer earthquake coverage. [36.]

HEADLINE: Viacom to Sell Its Cable Systems for $2.3 Billion

BYLINE: By GERALDINE FABRIKANT 

 BODY:
Viacom Inc. reached a definitive agreement yesterday to sell its cable television systems for approximately $2.3 billion to an investment group that is led by a black entrepreneur and includes a company partly owned by Tele-Communications Inc.
 The two sides said Viacom would receive $1.6 billion to $1.7 billion in cash for the cable systems, which have 1.1 million subscribers. The longer the deal takes to close, the more cash Viacom receives. Viacom will also get a one-year secured note for $600 million, the companies said yesterday. 
 Moreover, the deal will provide Viacom with significant tax benefits, since the acquiring group, RCS Pacific L.P., is 21 percent owned by Frank Washington, a black entrepreneur.
 Analysts said the deal was quite favorable for Viacom because the short-term note was already valued close to its face value, regardless of the interest rate.
 "It is a fabulous deal for Viacom because they want to get out of the cable system business," said Paul Kagan of Paul Kagan Associates, a media consulting firm. "They want the cash and they can use it to pay off debt."
 He added, "They are basically swapping their cable assets for Paramount assets," referring to Viacom's $10 billion acquisition of Paramount Communications Inc. last year and the billions of dollar of debt that deal required.
 Mr. Washington is the general partner of RCS, a group that includes Intermedia Partners, a San Francisco-based cable system operator. Tele-Communications, the nation's largest cable operator, holds a 20 percent stake in Intermedia.
 Under Federal Communications Commission rules, the transaction qualifies for a minority tax certificate that allows Viacom to defer Federal taxes on profits from the sale for 20 years if it invests in other media properties. Viacom could defer more than $200 million in taxes.
 Next Friday, however, the House Ways and Means Committee has scheduled hearings on the minority tax certificate program in response to concerns about the tax deferrals expressed by its chairman, Bill Archer, Republican of Texas.
 The cable systems being acquired by RCS include ones in Northern California, Seattle and Tacoma, Wash., and Nashville, as well as other cities.
 Separately, Viacom and Tele-Communications said last night that the antitrust suit filed by Viacom against Tele-Communications during the fight last year for Paramount had yet to be settled, though a settlement was supposed to have been part of the cable systems deal.
 A person close to Viacom said last night that the lawsuit would be officially settled only when the cable sale closed. At that time, this person said, an agreement will take effect guaranteeing that Showtime, Viacom's pay television service, will be distributed over Tele-Communications' cable systems.
 The antitrust issues raised in litigation are effectively resolved in that contract, this person said.
 One analyst who spoke on condition of anonymity said he would only believe the lawsuit had been settled when he saw that the settlement had officially been signed.
 The sale of Viacom's cable systems was announced late yesterday, after the stock market had closed. Earlier, Viacom's actively traded class B stock ended at $44.50 a share, down 50 cents, on the American Stock Exchange. Tele-Communications' shares ended at $21.75, down 50 cents, in Nasdaq trading.

HEADLINE: Dow Off 12.78 on View That Rates Will Climb

BYLINE: By LEONARD SLOANE 

 BODY:
The stock market declined yesterday, with signs abounding that last week's upward momentum had been turned around. The Dow Jones industrial average lost 12.78 points to close at 3,869.43.
 The market was weighed down by inflation concerns prompted by a report showing a brisk pace in housing starts and by a surge in the University of Michigan Consumer Sentiment Index. The reports solidified the case for the Federal Reserve to raise interest rates, which could slow the economy as well as raise corporate borrowing costs. In addition, a weak dollar, sharply lower bond prices and a slew of bad corporate news helped to push stock prices downward. 
 Yesterday's session was also a "double witching," when options on individual stocks and options on stock indexes expire simultaneously. These expirations, which fostered a great deal of computer-guided program trading on Thursday as well, contributed to volatility.
 "The day's market activity was evidence of an economy that is not cooling as fast as had been thought as recently as last week," said Richard Cripps, chief market strategist for Legg Mason in Baltimore. "Obviously the outside influences were reasons for many investors to take profits."
 The consensus among market analysts is that the Federal Reserve will raise short-term interest rates by one-half of a percentage point when its policy-making group meets on Jan. 31 and Feb. 1. A week ago, faced with a report showing sagging retail sales, some analysts were doubting that there would be any increase at all.
 The Dow's decline yesterday followed a drop of 46.77 points on Thursday, the steepest one-day drop since Dec. 8, when the average fell 49.79 points.
 Among other market indicators, the Standard & Poor's 500 index closed at 464.78, down 2.17 points; the Nasdaq composite index closed at 762.05, down 6.50 points, and the American Stock Exchange composite index closed at 437.64, down 1.89 points.
 Declining stocks on the New York Stock Exchange exceeded advancing issues by 1,472 to 744. Volume on the Big Board totaled 378.2 million shares, far above Thursday's turnover of 314.1 million shares.
 The big losers included the major auto makers, which are particularly sensitive to increases in interest rates and swings in the economy. Ford Motor fell 1 1/8, to 26 3/8; Chrysler dropped 2 1/8, to 47 1/8, and General Motors declined 3/4, to 39 1/2.
 Many cyclical stocks -- which move up and down along with general economic conditions -- were also weak. International Paper was off 7/8, to 76 3/4; Aluminum Company of America was off 1 1/4, to 86 1/8, and Caterpillar was off 2 1/8, to 52 5/8.
 Computer issues plunged, despite a report from Apple that its fiscal first-quarter profits more than quadrupled. Among the Big Three, Apple closed at 42 5/8, off 3 1/4; Compaq closed at 41 3/4, off 1 1/8, and I.B.M. closed at 75 3/8, off 1 1/8.
 After yesterday's announcement by Morgan Stanley that its fourth-quarter earnings would be substantially lower than its third-quarter results, some financial stocks dropped. Morgan Stanley fell 3 7/8, to 59; Citicorp eased 1/2, to 38 7/8, and Bankers Trust declined 1/2, to 57 1/4.
 Also on the upside was Nabisco Holdings, a spinoff of RJR Nabisco, on its first day of trading. The most active stock on the New York exchange, Nabisco Holdings jumped 2 3/8, to 26 7/8.

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Mark, an Investors' Haven, Continues to Rise vs. Dollar

BYLINE: By Reuters 

 BODY:
The German mark yesterday continued to strengthen at the expense of the dollar, which fell against most leading currencies.
 The mark's strength, owing in part to the currency's growing attractiveness to investors as a safe-haven currency, has become a key factor behind the dollar's recent weakness against a broad range of currencies. 
 The dollar did manage to score modest gains yesterday against the Japanese yen, whose medium-term outlook is clouded by the need for reconstruction after the devastating earthquake in central Japan.
 In New York trading late yesterday, the dollar fell to 1.5115 marks from 1.5160 marks on Thursday. The dollar also fell to 1.2712 Swiss francs from 1.2725 francs. The British pound rose to $1.5890 from $1.5868. But the dollar edged up against the yen, to 99.40 yen from 99.10 yen.
 While the dollar has been bolstered since late last month by expectations that the Federal Reserve will again raise short-term interest rates after a policy meeting at the end of this month, many dealers are unsure of how much further the Fed will raise rates. Higher interest rates typically strengthen the dollar by making investments in dollar-denominated securities more attractive than those from abroad.
 "What's going on is the same pattern we've seen for the past year," said Ron Leven, global currency strategist at J. P. Morgan. "The market gets too enthusiastic about the dollar too soon and what you end up with is a lot of investors who are long dollars and don't know what to do."
 Also weighing on the dollar yesterday was a mounting Congressional debate over the Clinton Administration's $40 billion rescue package for Mexico. House Speaker Newt Gingrich said opposition to the package appeared to be growing, particularly among Democrats.
 Currency dealers said failure to get the plan through Congress would revive expectations of a weaker Mexican peso, which in turn would prompt the Federal Reserve to sell dollars on its behalf. That would tend to push the dollar down.
 In other currency trading, the Canadian dollar, which has been under intense selling pressure recently, touched a nine-year low of 70.07 United States cents before recovering to 70.25 cents, up slightly from 70.22 cents on Thursday. Traders said intervention by the Bank of Canada to support the currency helped to break its fall.

HEADLINE: FUTURES MARKETS;
Coffee Tumbles on Doubts Brazil Will Join Quota Plan

BYLINE: By Reuters 

 BODY:
Coffee prices fell sharply yesterday as traders doubted whether Brazil could afford to join a quota plan.
 On other commodity markets, sugar prices recovered, while crude oil prices slipped. The Commodity Research Bureau's index of 21 commodities edged down 0.06 point, to 237.17. 
 Coffee prices have staged a modest rally during the last month based on recent meetings among Central American coffee producers to reinstitute a retention scheme.
 Last year, Brazil, the world's largest coffee producer, and Colombia, the second largest, joined the plan that withheld up to 20 percent of coffee output to bolster prices. The market got an even larger lift in June and July, when twin freezes hit Brazil's coffee plantations.
 But traders questioned whether Brazil, burdened by high inflation and Government debt, could afford to withhold its crop this year.
 Coffee for delivery in March fell 2.5 cents, to 169.85 cents a pound, retreating from 10-week highs of 176.25 cents at the Coffee, Sugar and Cocoa Exchange in New York.
 Sugar prices rebounded from a two-week decline.
 Prices were helped yesterday, traders said, by speculation about problems with Cuba's crop. Expectations of sales to Egypt, India and China also helped prices.
 Sugar prices hit a six-year high of 15.74 cents a pound on Jan. 6. But prices had dropped 9 percent as the speculative bubble in sugar prices appeared to have burst.
 The market recovered yesterday, with the March sugar contract gaining 0.35 cent, to 15.13 cents.
 Cocoa prices rose to a four-month high, with March cocoa gaining $28, to $1,381 a metric ton.
 On the New York Mercantile Exchange, oil prices ended lower but ended with strong gains for the week, led by surging gasoline prices.
 Gasoline prices have risen on signs of increased consumption. But traders said yesterday that the data might reflect a switch to a new grade of cleaner-burning gasoline.
 The February crude oil contract lost 4 cents, to $18.65 a barrel, but advanced $1.13 for the week.
 February gasoline fell 0.72 cent, to 57.40 cents a gallon, and February heating oil edged down 0.14 cent, to 48.14 cents.

HEADLINE: Prices of Treasuries Fall On a Light-Volume Day

BYLINE: By ROBERT HURTADO 

 BODY:
Prices of Treasury securities dropped sharply yesterday as investors became increasingly concerned about the dollar and Congressional approval of the Mexican aid package.
 Traders are beginning to grow wary that if the dollar remains weak there is the possibility that investor demand for coming supplies of new Treasury securities will evaporate and cause prices to fall. 
 The price of the 30-year Treasury bond ended down 22/32 , to 9521/32 . Its yield, which moves in the opposite direction, rose to 7.88 percent, from 7.82 percent on Thursday and the highest in more than a week.
 The selling pressures in the market yesterday increased after the National Association of Purchasing Management released revisions to its December index, showing higher prices paid for intermediate goods. But yesterday's declines were exaggerated by a lack of trading volume, traders said.
 In early trading, the price of the 30-year Treasury bond slipped in tandem with the dollar, which was dragged down in part by fears that the Federal Reserve would be forced to sell dollars to support the peso if Congress failed to pass the Mexican aid package. A weaker dollar discourages foreign investors from buying American assets like Treasury securities.
 The market was also weighed down by two reports suggesting inflationary pressures. Although housing starts fell last month, they continued at a brisk clip. Separately, the University of Michigan's index of consumer confidence showed that current expectations were still high, analysts said, an indication that consumers were still buying. Analysts said the Michigan survey underscored the strength in job and income growth, which will likely keep inflation fears simmering.
 Traders and analysts are also concerned about a new supply of securities coming to market, said Michael P. Ryan, fixed-income strategist at Paine Webber Inc. "The market is looking at absorbing $28.25 billion of new two-year and five-year notes next week, then immediately afterward will be faced with the Government's quarterly refunding that will be announced on Feb. 1," Mr. Ryan said.
 In when-issued trading yesterday, the new two-year notes were being offered at a price to yield 7.55 percent, a couple of basis points higher than the previous day, while the new five-year notes were up 5 basis points to yield 7.81 percent, a sign that dealers will have to push hard to sell this maturity. A basis point is one-hundredth of 1 percent.
 Expectations of another increase in interest rates in two weeks is also keeping keeping buyers at bay, Mr. Ryan said. Most analysts and traders are expecting a rate increase of 50 basis points.

HEADLINE: Aid Doubts Strain Mexican Markets

BYLINE: By ANTHONY DePALMA, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: MEXICO CITY, Jan. 20

 BODY:
As the Clinton Administration and Congress bickered in Washington over an aid package to Mexico, the lack of an agreement and investor doubts continued to strain Mexico's volatile financial markets.
 Today marked one month to the day since the Mexican Government set off the current economic crisis by devaluing the peso. The Mexican stock exchange reversed its losses earlier this morning to close slightly higher, but the modest rally failed to compensate for three consecutive declines earlier this week, when the market index dropped more than 190 points. 
 The battered peso, which was worth 3.46 to the dollar before Dec. 20, closed slightly down at 5.585 to the dollar in New York trading today, compared with 5.505 in New York on Thursday.
 In Washington today, Administration officials professed confidence that they would get the aid package through next week, but laden with strict conditions for fiscal control in Mexico City. But on Capitol Hill, there was little evidence that the aid package was headed for quick passage.
 The Speaker of the House, Newt Gingrich, blamed Democrats for not having their own votes together to bring the aid package to the floor of the House this week.
 "Opposition to it seems to be growing, particularly among the Democrats, which will, frankly, make it much harder to get Republicans," he said. "And the longer you drag it out, the more people question the urgency, the harder it's going to be to pass it."
 Senator Jesse Helms, the chairman of the Foreign Relations Committee, vowed to hold "exhaustive and perhaps exhausting hearings on the pros and cons of the Administration's proposal," and said that the "vast majority" of senators he had spoken with were opposed to a Mexican bailout.
 The Administration's fear is that delay alone could send the markets awry, and today the new Treasury Secretary, Robert E. Rubin, provided new warnings of the global chaos that would occur if the problem spread to other markets in Latin America and Asia. The head of the Council of Economic Advisers, Laura D'Andrea Tyson, said that a global run could take a point off the growth in America's gross domestic product over the next two years.
 Financial analysts said the Mexican markets were likely to stay on a roller coaster until a final decision was made on the $40 billion loan guarantee package.
 "On days when it looks like the Mexican guarantees will be accepted by the U.S., all the markets, not just Mexico, will go up," said Neal M. Soss, an economist in New York who worked at the Federal Reserve Board during the Mexican debt crisis of 1982. "When it looks like the guarantees won't be accepted, they're all likely to tumble."
 The loan guarantee package is essential for investors because Mexico has practically lost its ability to get credit on the international market since the peso was devalued. The country has more than $25 billion in short-term bonds coming due during this year. Without the loan guarantees from the United States, Mexico will find it almost impossible to borrow money to cover its obligations.
 The Mexican market index ended today at 2,065.45, a gain of just 0.66 percent over Thursday's close.
 "There were some buyers at the end," said Pablo Riveroll, research director at Bursamex, a Mexico City brokerage firm. "But I'd say we had more sellers than buyers throughout the day. The mood of the whole week continued."
