SECTION: Section 3; Page 8; Column 1; Business/Financial Desk 

LENGTH: 1702 words

HEADLINE: A Prophet of Financial Doom Who Was Right

BYLINE: By SYLVIA NASAR 

 BODY:
MEXICO'S surprise devaluation of the peso last Dec. 20 was not altogether a surprise. Around Washington, economists who were watching Mexico had been warning that such a step was all but inevitable -- sometime. One prominent advocate of devaluation said, the day it was announced, that it was time for the "smart money" to move into Mexico.
But what the economists failed to anticipate was the financial explosion that followed: a free fall of the currency; a mass exodus by investors from markets as far-flung as Buenos Aires, Bangkok and New Delhi, and a very dark cloud over the previously bright prospects of a half-dozen Latin American countries. Referring last week to the biggest financial meltdown in recent memory, Stanley Fischer, the deputy managing director of the International Monetary Fund, admitted to a crowd of 150 economists who wanted to know what had gone wrong: "Everybody underestimated the reaction of the capital markets." 
 Not quite everybody. Guillermo Calvo, an economist at the University of Maryland and a former senior adviser to the I.M.F., was the most prominent of the pessimists. For most of last year he had, in fact, been issuing dire warnings. Mexico was sitting on a financial powder keg, he argued, and America's firefighting equipment -- a $6 billion insurance fund -- was woefully inadequate.
More a soft-spoken theoretical economist than a policy showboat, Professor Calvo has spent much of his career, as one admirer put it, "thinking beyond the conventional wisdom." At a seminar at the Brookings Institution last April, for example, Professor Calvo argued that a devaluation would shatter confidence. "Devaluation . . . may sow the seeds of destruction. Authorities would have revealed their taste for discretionary policy and people may come to believe that it could happen again." If a devaluation became unavoidable, he added, how it was handled would be paramount. Devaluation taken without prior consultation and support from Mexico's "Nafta partners, may . . . prove to be a poison pill."
The only way to prevent an all-out run against the peso, he said, was to obtain the full backing of the United States in advance. "It is imperative that Mexico obtain ample support from the U.S. Treasury (the numbers recently seen in the press look rather small), making it perfectly clear that the support would be automatic."
Like Federal deposit insurance in the United States, the professor reasoned, a big credit line backing the Mexican Government would reassure investors. If the line were big enough, a run would be averted and the line would never have to be tapped. Otherwise, he said, investors -- whose faith in the Mexican Government had already been shaken by the Chiapas rebellion -- would take a devaluation as a sign that the Government couldn't be trusted to defend the currency in the future. The fear of further declines in the peso would become a self-fulfilling prophecy.
"ONLY a few people like Professor Calvo anticipated the magnitude of the change in confidence and that's the magnitude of the risk," says Nancy Birdsall, executive vice president of the Inter-American Development Bank. "Everybody talks about volatile financial markets, but we were all surprised by the complete collapse of confidence." She adds: "People were listening to Calvo, but they weren't listening hard enough."
Before the devaluation announcement, there was apparently little advance consultation between Mexico City and Washington. The I.M.F. -- the world's watchdog for exchange rate crises -- was notified only hours before. The backup credit, $6 billion, turned out to be a fraction of the size the United States Treasury later decided it needed to be -- $60 billion. It took weeks to appreciate the sheer scale of the problem.
Professor Calvo's pessimistic view was based largely on two observations.
First, there were huge pools of highly liquid capital that could leave Mexico at a moment's notice. "The money supply had increased tremendously since the beginning of 1990, when the reforms began," says Professor Calvo in an interview. "I found that very suspicious and dangerous in principle. The peso did not have enough backing." He adds: "It's like taking the dollar off the gold standard."
Second, Mexico's Government did not have anywhere near the credibility with investors of, say, an Italy or a Britain. The relatively large difference between yields for dollar and peso assets reflects that lack of trust. Besides, the rationale for adopting a relatively fixed exchange rate, which Mexico did in 1990, was to show investors that the Government meant to keep its promises, particularly to hold down inflation.
"Imperfect credibility completely changes the set of effective policies," said Professor Calvo last spring, which is his way of saying that governments that enjoy lots of trust can get away with more than governments that don't. He likens a country like Mexico announcing it was changing its exchange rate to "somebody freezing and striking a match to get warmer. You wouldn't do that if you were sitting on a keg of gunpowder."
THE peso crisis wasn't the first danger that Professor Calvo spotted early on. In the early 1990's, when most academics were saying that capital needed to flow from North to South and Wall Street was turning euphoric about Latin America, he and fellow researchers cast a jaundiced eye on the torrent of capital pouring into poor countries. A good chunk, he admitted, was due to the free market reforms that were being adopted in most of Latin America. But at least half reflected the recession and low interest rates in the United States and other industrialized countries. With a recovery -- and a rise in interest rates -- in the United States, the region had better be ready, Professor Calvo warned. That was exactly what hit Mexico in late 1993 -- and one of the elements that set the stage for the current crisis.
To friends and colleagues, Professor Calvo's acuity is no accident. He is originally from Argentina, which has been battling high inflation and capital flight since the 1950's. There have been a number of major stabilizations: two in the 1940's, three in the 50's, two in each of the following decades. There have also been lots of ministabilizations as well as runs on the currency.
"I think about crisis all the time," says Professor Calvo, laughing. "It comes naturally to an Argentinian."
Professor Calvo's theoretical work revolves around the issue of credibility and how its partial or complete loss affects the outcome of different policies. He is an advocate of the rational expectations revolution, led by pioneers like the economist Robert Lucas at the University of Chicago. Professor Calvo "used their ideas to think about the real world, in particular the real world of high inflation countries," says Carlos Vegh, an economist at the I.M.F. who is occasionally a co-author with Professor Calvo.
How does Professor Calvo see Mexico's future? Everything, he says, depends on whether Washington and Mexico City will get things right in the next weeks. Getting things right, in his view, involves adopting loan guarantees quickly, setting the right conditions for the guarantees, and not being over-optimistic about how quickly the peso will recover.
"Mexico is on the verge of default," he says. "If they don't get support and they try not to default, they would have to print bonds. The 'pacto' -- Mexico's social contract among business, labor and government -- would be destroyed. Any attempt to freeze wages is hopeless. They would lose control of the monetary side; people would flee out of pesos into the dollar and you would have all the elements of hyperinflation."
If Mexico defaults, the fallout would be far more difficult to contain than that of the Latin American debt crisis in 1982, because instead of a handful of large banks the investors would be countless individual bondholders.
If, on other had, Washington and Mexico City get things right, Professor Calvo says, "I'd be optimistic. Possibly Mexico would be more competitive;, exports would be stronger and the trade deficit would shrink. Provided there is a peaceful atmosphere in the markets, in six months capital could come back."
 
 
 
AND ONE WHO SAW PROFIT
 Among the few Wall Street advisers cautioning investors in Mexico last year, Jim Grant, editor of Grant's Interest Rate Observer, was certainly the wittiest. He wrote this last March.
ELECTION year in Mexico is a time for democratic tradition, of which the greatest is that the governing party always wins. A second great electoral tradition in Mexico is the devaluation of the peso. It has been devalued against the dollar in each of the past three election seasons -- 1976, 1982 and 1988. As the 1994 election is only five months away, investors might profitably ask if Mexican history could repeat itself.
Checking up, we found no evidence that the holders of some $42 billion in foreign investments were conscientiously hedging themselves against the risk of expropriation. However, with a little application an investor can find a tailor-made put on the peso, now trading at a rate of 3.23 to the dollar. Because the peso has been stable for so long and because the options-pricing software of even the bulge-bracket firms is unacquainted with Mexican financial history, the theoretical price of an at-the-money six-month put, struck at four pesos to the dollar, is very close to zero.
Two derivatives desks to which we spoke quoted a price of 0.7 percent. Another -- none would be named -- quoted 0.18 percent. In other words, at the lower price, one could control $1 million in pesos for $1,800. If the peso weakened to four to the dollar, the implied profit per option at the end of six months would be $192,500. That would amount to a return of more than a hundredfold for betting on historical precedent.
(At the current rate, 5.7 pesos to the dollar, one of these puts purchased six months ago -- if they had been available then -- would have yielded more than twice as much profit, $433,000.)
(Reprinted with permission from The Interest Rate Publishing Corporation,  1994.)

The New York Times

PUB-DATE: January 22, 1995

SECTION: Section 3; Page 2; Column 3; Business/Financial Desk 

LENGTH: 1468 words

HEADLINE: Business Diary: January 15-20

BYLINE: By Hubert B. Herring 

 BODY:

THE ECONOMY
 
Once Again, the Fickle Market Loses Its Cool
Here we go again. Just one short week ago, the official word was: a slowing economy, no Federal Reserve rate rise in the offing, everything cool for the foreseeable future. The stock market loved all this, with the Dow industrials leaping nearly 50 points on Friday the 13th. Things stayed cool for a few days, but then came news that the nation is headed for its biggest annual trade deficit in seven years, sending the dollar to a 10-year low against the German mark. Also added to the mix were figures on things like industrial production, housing, consumer confidence and factory use that spelled strength -- and thus, with the usual perversity, danger to the markets. Not to be ignored, of course, were economic ripples from the Japanese earthquake. When the dust cleared, the Dow had given back 46 points on Thursday and 12 more on Friday. 

Painful Medicaid Math
Betsy McCaughey was given some nasty math homework, but she churned it out. Governor Pataki asked Ms. McCaughey, his Lieutenant Governor, to come up with $1.2 billion in Medicaid cuts, and she rose to the challenge, calling Medicaid "the intersection of economics, ethics, science, medicine, public policy and politics." Last week she itemized the pain: big cuts for hospitals and nursing homes, limits on home services for the elderly. Too painful? No, some say, New York's Medicaid program, the nation's most generous, is too fat. Yes, say others, New Yorkers don't need a tax cut that badly.
 
Don't Sleep and Drive
A trucking-industry spokesman says there's no reason to require truckers to have 12 hours off between shifts because, well, they might not sleep much anyway. Hey -- why pay them more than a few dollars? They might not spend it. True enough, beds have yet to be equipped with time clocks. Most people, though, have the option of getting a decent sleep; truckers must be given only eight hours between shifts. That, says the National Transportation Safety Board, is not enough. In a study out last week, the board said truck drivers who nod off at the wheel are a factor in up to 1,500 traffic deaths a year (the industry disputes this). In the 30's, when the eight-hour rule was born, truck refrigeration was rare, and pressure was on to keep food from spoiling. Times, the board noted, have changed.
 
Some Good Things Aren't Free
Most New Yorkers, if asked to pay a penny to enter Central Park, would resent it bitterly -- it would burst the image of glorious freedom attached to that priceless oasis. But it isn't free, of course -- it costs a lot to keep up, and budget cuts have greatly reduced the maintenance staff. So last week the Parks Commissioner, Henry Stern, had another idea: add a small tax -- $100 a year or so -- for people who live around Central Park, raising perhaps $5 million within a few years. Of course, as real estate listings would quickly show, New Yorkers already pay a big premium to be near the park. A thornier issue: will other parks, not surrounded by high-rent districts, be forgotten?
 
Banking, Redefined (Again)
Banks and their cousins are still feeling unsteady as the sand shifts rapidly under their feet. As mutual funds grabbed a lot of the money that used to land in passbook accounts, banks had to branch out, and one way was into annuities. These, they reasoned, were part of the "business of banking" as defined by the age-old laws. Insurance companies, with troubles of their own, tried mightily to protect this turf -- to no avail. Last week the Supreme Court said banks could keep selling annuities. Banks have already sold billions worth of annuities, but with this go-ahead that should grow fast -- as should the alliances between banks and insurers who want to stay in the game.
 
INTERNATIONAL
 
Earthquake Economics
Forget for a moment, if you can, the human disaster in Japan. Some catastrophes have a distinct economic impact, and that clearly applies here. For one thing, the huge spending needed to rebuild Kobe could help lift Japan out of a lingering recession (though of course that's an awful way to get this lift). But that, in turn, could push up interest rates worldwide, as deficit spending in Japan soaks up cash that might have been invested abroad. Also, great uncertainty now surrounds the business of supposedly earthquake-proof construction: many new bridges and buildings in Japan are billed as being able to withstand a quake that's 7.9 on the Richter scale (the severity of the devastating 1923 Tokyo quake), but a lot of them didn't last week, in just a 7.2 quake.
 
U.S. News Invades Mexico
American politics and policy invaded a fragile Mexico last week, doing what bulls tend to do in china shops. The week began with a vote of confidence as investors bought $400 million in Mexican Government bonds. But this calm was shattered quickly -- by Washington's squabbling about that crucial $40 billion in loan guarantees, with the possibility that "killer amendments" would be attached to them, and by threats of rising United States rates, which would lure capital away from Mexico. The result: the Mexican stock market and the peso were battered for several days until they stabilized on Friday.
 
COMPANIES
 
Low-Fat Goes Straight
You can almost hear Woody Allen, in "Sleeper II," marveling that in the 90's people really believed a high-fat diet was dangerous. Why, back in January of '95, even Frito-Lay, which owned the nibble market in those days, said it would invest $225 million in low-fat products, convinced that they would grow to a third of its multibillion-dollar business. In making this plunge last week, Frito-Lay said it saw a "huge mainstream audience" for such products. And Frito-Lay is nothing if not mainstream -- it has 43 percent of the "salty snack" market, leaving its nearest rival with a mere 6.5 percent crumb. But it's got a high-calorie battle on its hands: now, just 4 percent of snack foods are low-fat.
 
Big Blue and the Judge
By 1945, when Roosevelt died, pre-baby boomers had the feeling that he'd always been President. Just think what I.B.M.-ers must think of Judge David Edelstein. He's been hovering over the company as long as most of them can remember -- since, no doubt, before many of them were born. The issue dates to a 1952 antitrust complaint -- the days of punch cards (surely gathering dust in some computer museum). The Justice Department reached a settlement with I.B.M. in 1956, with Judge Edelstein overseeing it, and many times since, I.B.M. has sought to get him off the case, saying he treated the company unfairly. That antique settlement, I.B.M. insisted, was irrelevant to today's technology, but the judge always refused to lift the pact's restrictions. Last week, though, I.B.M. finally got its way: a Federal appeals court removed Judge Edelstein, who at 84 has served 44 years, the longest of any Federal judge.
 
An Anti-Newt Hot Line
At a time when most unrepentant liberals seem to have vanished from the face of the earth, a company would have to be crazy to try to attract customers by trumpeting its liberalism. But then there's Working Assets, the long-distance company that is unashamed of its activist stance and regularly offers free calls to Congress. Last week, Working Assets took on Newt Gingrich, calling the Gingrich manifesto a "Contract Against America" -- not only blowing its own liberal horn but inviting callers to do so too. It placed full-page ads offering "Free Calls to Stop Newt," even offering 10 minutes of free calls to non-customers (this offer expired on Thursday).
 
A Billion and You're Out
Anyone who can defraud General Motors out of $436 million is no ordinary criminal -- certainly smart enough to stay out of jail, even live well, after being caught. John McNamara has proved that. Mr. McNamara, the Long Island car dealer who came up with some highly creative bookkeeping to pick G.M.'s pocket, agreed to testify in a bribery trial that, considering the staggering sums he stole, can only be described as minuscule potatoes. The officials in that trial got off recently, while in return for his testimony, Mr. McNamara never went to jail, kept nearly $2 million in assets and started a new business. But with all the tough "three strikes" talk, he'd better watch out: If he steals $436 million from G.M. two more times, he's going to be in real trouble.
 
A Mini-Van Overdose?
Uh-oh. Do Americans, at long last, have enough of Detroit's mini-vans? Are rising rates taking a toll? Ford's Windstar has been a big hit for the past year, but dealers now have just too many of them, so on Thursday Ford said it would stop production for a week -- and on Friday said, No, maybe it'll be two weeks.

HEADLINE: MARKET WATCH;
In Trade Woes, An Echo of Reagan Era

BYLINE: By Floyd Norris 

 BODY:
ONE of the biggest economic surprises in 1994 was the trade deficit. It was supposed to narrow last year. Europe was recovering from its recession, and American industry was lean and mean after waves of cutbacks.
But it didn't happen. Trade deficits are back to the horrible levels of the 1980's, when an overvalued dollar devastated American industry. To be sure, exports did rise to record levels, but imports went up even more. The trade deficit for 1994, including services as well as goods, will be more than $100 billion, more than twice the 1992 level. 
 It seems likely that the import bulge is one of the indicators convincing the Federal Reserve that the economy is running too strong for its own good. Certainly, the Fed seems determined to raise interest rates again, as was seen by the drumfire of comments last week, and will probably do so next week. At some point -- and the retail sales figures make one think it may already be happening -- the Fed's efforts to raise interest rates will start to slow demand, for imported products as well as American-produced ones.
The trade problem is starkest in manufactured goods, that is to say trade leaving out services, energy and agricultural commodities. Because monthly figures can gyrate, and because there are seasonal factors, a good way to look at the figures is on a 12-month basis. It used to be that the worst performance ever was a deficit of $142.7 billion, set in the year ended October 1987. By February 1992 -- thanks in large part to recession here as well as a falling dollar -- the deficit had been cut in half, to $65 billion.
But since then, manufacturing exports have been growing much more slowly than imports, currently at about 10 percent a year for exports and 15 percent a year for imports. The result has been a soaring deficit. The manufacturing deficit broke the old record in October, and the November figures, released last week, put it at $152.4 billion.
In assessing the reasons for the disappointing performance, it is tempting to look at imports, and just say Americans are spending too much. Slowing the economy ought to do something about that, and that is probably how the problem will be addressed. But that might not be neccessary had different policies been pursued a decade ago. Then, the Reagan Administration -- with the consent of a Democratic House of Representatives -- followed a very loose fiscal policy at the same time the Fed kept money tight and produced sky-high interest rates.
One result of that was a soaring dollar. Many American exporters, particularly in the machine tools industry, simply went out of business. Now, the dollar is more competitive, and so is American industry. But companies that might have prospered are gone. Not only are they not exporting, but the goods they might have made must be imported. The developing countries have been taking in lots of capital goods imports in recent years -- that may slow now if Mexico's problems scare investors -- but the United States is getting a smaller share of that business than it would have a decade ago.
There's not much to be done about it now. But it can serve as a reminder that letting currencies get too wildly overvalued or undervalued levels can have economic effects that endure long after the currency levels have become more reasonable.

HEADLINE: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: MADISON SQUARE;
Prince George: Old Arena, New Battle

BYLINE: By MONTE WILLIAMS 

 BODY:
As the city's largest welfare hotel in the 1980's, the Prince George was a malignant presence on East 28th Street, its social ills spilling from the graffiti-scarred building onto the surrounding streets day and night.
Drug dealing, muggings, shoplifting and prostitution were commonplace. Co-op owners, who were unable to sell or rent their apartments, fled anyway. Merchants moved out as soon as their leases expired. On the east side of Fifth Avenue between 27th and 28th Streets, every ground-floor business -- except Chemical Bank -- closed in the first half of 1986. 
 In the late 80's, the city removed welfare families from the hotel, and the community exhaled. Merchants returned, restaurants opened and real estate picked up.
Now, Common Ground, a nonprofit corporation, plans to reopen the hotel as a "mixed-use" residence for the homeless and single working people who earn between $13,000 and $30,000 dollars annually.
And no one is surprised by the clamor of opposition the proposal has ignited. Least of all Rosanne Haggerty, Common Ground's executive director, who successfully overhauled another notorious hotel, the Times Square on West 43rd Street.
"The fear level is pretty high, but I understand it," Ms. Haggerty said. "The Prince George was a nightmare for the families that lived there, and it was catastrophic for the neighborhood."
Despite opposition from some businesses and local residents, Community Board 5 voted on Jan. 12 to support the proposal, basing its decision largely on Ms. Haggerty's success at the Times Square, the model for the Prince George.
"She has kept her promises," said the board's chairman, Nicholas Fish. "And she has been recognized by two successive administrations as developing exceptional affordable housing."
According to Deputy Mayor Fran Reiter, the Giuliani administration supports Common Ground's goal of "mainstreaming needy populations who have demonstrated a readiness" to return to society.
But, she added, "We have not yet signed off on this particular deal. The Department of Housing Preservation and Development is working with her now."
The proposed $28.5 million project, which would be financed by city, state and private funds, calls for the creation of 416 300-square-foot studio apartments with private kitchens and bathrooms. Half would be set aside for the formerly homeless -- "100 with some history of mental illness, 63 from the general shelter population, and 45 with AIDS," Ms. Haggerty said.
The plan also calls for a network of on-site social services, including a medical clinic, for tenants. People who work in the community would be given priority for the remaining 208 apartments.
Ms. Haggerty, who is moving to secure a mortgage from Resolution Trust Corporation, said she realizes she has a long way to go before winning over members of the business community who fear that the project would undermine the area's modest economic revival and threaten the nearby gift, tableware and toy industries.
"We believe there may be a use more compatible with the revitalization we're seeing," said Jane Crotty, executive director of the 23d Street Association, a conglomeration of businesses. "Buyers come here from all over to do business. The fact is, there may be a need for hotel accommodations in this area." M.W.

HEADLINE: At Work;
Promotions and Family Matters

BYLINE: By Barbara Presley Noble 

 BODY:
WHEN he went to work in 1987 for the Agricultural Marketing Service, an Agriculture Department agency, James Patterson may not have realized he would find his true calling, but find it he soon did. His job as an agricultural economist, international trade issues a specialty, frequently took him to Canada and Mexico. He discovered he enjoyed travel and working on the road. So he set off on the career track offered by the Government, transferring in 1990 to the Foreign Agricultural Service, another unit of the department, intending, after the requisite tests and waiting period, to be promoted to the officer category that would allow him to serve abroad.
Mr. Patterson sailed through the exams in early 1992, but instead of heading off on the briny for foreign lands, he's still at his old post in Washington, reduced to a superannuated clerical worker, he claims, while the Agriculture Department mulls over a disability discrimination complaint he filed against it in late 1992 with the agency's equal employment office. 
 At issue is whether his promotion can be denied because a member of his family has a chronic medical condition. Mr. Patterson argues it cannot. The Civil Rights Division of the Justice Department has written a letter to Agriculture citing the law in question, a letter that Mr. Patterson believes supports his interpretation. Neither that letter nor entreaties by several Senators appears to have had much influence in persuading the agency to pick up the pace of its decision-making. Mr. Patterson has understood for several months that a decision was imminent.
Tom Amontree, an Agriculture spokesman, said the department does not comment on personnel issues but added that the case is still under review. "This is a complex case," he said. "It involves a number of different regulations, and we must make sure everything is consistent before a final decision is made."
One of the many ironies of his case is that Mr. Patterson did due diligence on how his career might be affected by his daughter's health. The year before he took the exams for promotion, he sat down and had a conversation with an Agriculture Department official. Would his young daughter's congenital heart problem, corrected surgically but still requiring attention, have any effect on his desire to serve abroad? It would not cause a problem, he says he was told. The department had a history of flexibility in dealing with dependents' medical issues.
Mr. Patterson recounts this conversation ruefully now. He was not at all prepared for the reaction when, in fact, he did pass the yearly written and oral exams and became a candidate for promotion. Listed as eligible for assignment, he presented himself to the State Department, which must sign off on new Foreign Agricultural Service officers.
The State Department denied his daughter a medical clearance, bouncing his case back to the Agriculture Department, which later turned down a request for a medical waiver on the grounds that her care might end up being a financial burden to the Government.
As a Federal worker, Mr. Patterson is not covered by the Americans with Disabilities Act, which forbids "associational discrimination," or discrimination against an employee on the basis of a relationship with someone who has a disability. But he is covered by equivalent legislation, the Rehabilitation Act of 1973. In its letter to Agriculture, the Justice Department pointed out that Congress intended that the spirit of the disabilities act should apply to interpretations of the legislation that covers Federal workers. The Patterson case is unusual, employment lawyers said, because it involves a close family member. Associational discrimination cases have typically involved partners of people with AIDS.
Mr. Patterson says he tried to meet several conditions imposed by the Agriculture Department to get the medical waiver. His daughter's doctor certified her condition as stable, requiring medication and occasional monitoring that could be done by a general physician in most of the cities where foreign service officers are posted. He agreed he wouldn't try to take his child abroad or make any claims for disability benefits on her behalf.
Each time he responded to one of the department's conditions, he says, officials raised the stakes, until it became clear that he would be unable to satisfy them.
Mr. Patterson's frustration takes on a tinge of desperation when he talks about his family situation. Though he was married when he began his pursuit of a foreign service career, he is now divorced. His former wife has custody of their two children, including his daughter, and he has little contact with them. He believes that the response to his appeal has a tinge of moralism. "They take a paternalistic view about things," he said. "According to them, things have to be a certain way. Because the child is sick, I cannot leave her. They should not be second-guessing my life."
His lawyers' theory about the Agriculture Department's position is that they didn't realize what they were telling Mr. Patterson was illegal. He was told at one point, he says, that he didn't have a discrimination case because he didn't have the disability, a position clearly at odds with the law.
"The agency knows it took a stupid position originally," said Diane Vogel, one of two Washington civil rights lawyers working on Mr. Patterson's case. "They don't have the sense to back down, and now they're stuck."
Mr. Patterson says a friend who works on the Hill spoke with someone at Agriculture who assured him that a decision was on the desk of the equal opportunity officer, ready for release "any day now." Mr. Patterson hopes this time it's true.

HEADLINE: World Markets;
Once Again, Gold Lures Investors

BYLINE: By Paul Lewis 

 BODY:
THE economist John Maynard Keynes was fascinated by the legend of King Midas, whose greed was such that everything he touched turned into gold, leaving him rich but starving.
The tale, Keynes thought, was a profound warning that mankind's instinctive desire to hoard wealth leads to impoverishment, not riches. This insight contributed to his central belief that governments could and should spend their way out of recessions. 
 "Suppose we were to stop spending our incomes and save the lot," he once jokingly wrote. "Why, everyone would be out of work. And before long we should have no income to spend and starve to death."
Keynesian economics is out of fashion right now, with the governments of most industrial countries running deficits they cannot afford and want to abolish. But mankind's Midas instincts are enjoying a modest revival. The gold market finished 1984 with an annual average price of $384.21 an ounce, the third consecutive yearly rise and the second to beat inflation. (On the Commodity Exchange in New York, the price of gold for February delivery was $385.40 on Friday.)
Since central banks stopped pegging the price of gold in 1968, its value has been driven by the metal's dual nature as both a commodity and the ultimate store of value -- which, in Charles de Gaulle's phrase, "is eternally and universally accepted as the unalterable fiduciary value par excellence."
It was this mystical quality that helped propel gold to a record $850 an ounce in the inflationary, volatile climate of 1980. Relentless selling by the Soviet Union and the central banks of Belgium, Canada and the Netherlands pushed the price down again.
Now it is edging up once more, largely as a result of hoarding in the fast-growing economies of India, China and other Asian countries where incomes are rising and gold is traditionally valued both as jewelry and a store of wealth. These markets now absorb about 55 percent of production.
"The gold price is rising in an environment of low inflation because industrial demand exceeds mine production," noted Richard Scott-Ram of the World Gold Council, a body that promotes gold use on behalf of mining companies. He added, "so long as these emerging economies have strong growth and the middle class gets bigger, there will be demand for gold." According to Gold Field Mineral Services, a London-based analyst, total output from gold mines rose to 2,304 tons last year from 2,160 tons in 1991, while industrial demand for jewelry, electronics and coins climbed to 2,921 tons, from 2,816 tons.
The gap was bridged mainly by recycling discarded jewelry and by sales of gold bullion by central banks diversifying their reserves into interest-paying assets.
Such sales remain a sword of Damocles over the gold market. After peaking at 602 tons in 1992, central bank sales declined to 519 tons the next year and only 46 tons in 1994. Canada, with little gold left, is ending sales, while Belgium and the Netherlands also appear to have stopped.
But with a third of the 115,000 tons of gold in existence in their vaults, central banks retain the power to dent the market severely if they start selling again.
"Was it the massive sales of 1992 and 1993 or the return to a nearly neutral position in 1994 that will prove to be the exception?" Gold Fields Mineral Services asked in its latest review.
Meanwhile a British plan, implemented last year, for the International Monetary Fund to sell gold to help indebted poor countries, appears to be going nowhere, reducing another threat to the gold price.
Many ordinary investors value gold as portfolio ballast whose value ignores swings in stock or bond prices. Brokers naturally recommend mining companies over metal because they pay a dividend as well as moving with the gold price.
Auerbach Grayson, a New York broker specializing in South African mines, likes Val Reef, Western Deep Levels and East Transvaal Consolidated. Adam Horowitz of Rand International Securities adds Kinross and Beatrix. But an exotic possibility is Navan, an Irish minerals company traded in London, which owns a Bulgarian gold mine that is Europe's largest.
While the sky-high 1980's price stimulated new mining ventures, production growth is slowing to 1 percent this year and 2 percent in 1996 and 1997. "The huge growth in mine production that sent American output from a million ounces in 1980 to 10.6 million ounces last year is over," said John Lutley of the Washington-based Gold Institute, which represents American mines.
The key question now is whether the gold price can pierce the psychologically important $400 barrier that it has bumped against for most of the past year. A difficulty, traders say, is that mines are selling gold forward, creating a price barrier around this level.
Ian MacDonald of Credit Suisse said he believes the price will eventually "creep through," encouraged by "gold's role as a store of value in a world where so many currencies are depreciating."

HEADLINE: The Executive Computer;
Bringing Point-and-Click Ease to Corporate Computing

BYLINE: By Lawrence M. Fisher 

 BODY:
FOR all the buzz about client-server systems in the computer trade media, one would imagine there to be at least a handful, if not dozens, of companies battling for a share of this market. In fact there is only one independent, publicly held software company that derives its revenues solely from client-server applications: Peoplesoft Inc.
This is not to say that Peoplesoft has no competitors. It has many, and many of them much bigger than Peoplesoft, which expects to report sales of more than $100 million for 1994 when it releases its annual figures. 
 But all the rest are either mainframe software providers dragged kicking and screaming into the new world order; or vendors of relational data base software offering client-server applications to run atop their data management programs. The competition, of course, doesn't include the many client-server applications that are custom written for corporate use by in-house programmers or by consultants.
Peoplesoft, as the name may imply, was created to produce human resources management software -- for managing personnel records and the like. But the company has recently branched out to also offer general-ledger, accounts payable and other financial-management programs that were historically married to the mainframe.
Peoplesoft was founded in Walnut Creek, Calif., in 1987, the same year George Forrester Colony of Forrester Research is said to have coined the term "client server." Peoplesoft products were built from the start to take advantage of the growing power of desktop computers and networks that is the foundation of client-server.
The essence of the client-server approach is that computing tasks are split more or less evenly between desktop "client" computers and larger machines -- the "servers" -- that are connected across a network.
This allows the use of desktop graphic user interfaces, like Microsoft's Windows or Apple's Macintosh operating system software, which provide greater ease of use than mainframe terminals, and the ability to run many processes inter actively and in real time.
In contrast the host/terminal world of mainframe computing placed a "dumb" terminal on a user's desk that could only send or receive simple text-based commands. And this terminal had to take its place in the time-sharing queue for any real work to get done.
"We hit at an opportune time, when client-server wasn't invented yet, but all of the components were there," said David A. Duffield, Peoplesoft's chairman, president and chief executive, who co-founded the company with Kenneth R. Morris and took it public in 1993. "People fell in love with the personal computer, the graphic user interface and used our toolset to extend the ability of the software," he said.
"Even today, I don't think people care that much that it's client-server," Mr. Duffield said. "It's really the other components that make it attractive."
Of course, it is client-server that allowed Peoplesoft to take the pull-down menus and point-and-click way of doing things on a PC and apply it to corporate-wide computing. This was a significant change for human resources managers accustomed, say, to writing out organizational changes, submitting them to the data-processing staff and then waiting days or weeks for a printed report that might or might not be what they wanted. With Peoplesoft's tools, they could make the changes themselves, instantly, by simply dragging and dropping names and positions onto the virtual organization chart on their PC's.
Benefiting from both the proliferation of computer networks that made client-server possible and the broad adoption of business "re-engineering" that made more flexible programs a necessity, Peoplesoft's human resources management software has become the market leader.
These are large programs. Although they are considered "packaged software," in the sense that everything is included, they are not to be confused with shrink-wrapped packages like Lotus 1-2-3. The average cost of Peoplesoft's programs is about $300,000, and installation takes from three months to one year.
But compared with mainframe applications, those prices and installation times are very competitive with mainframe applications, and the payoff can be dramatic.
"We wanted to put tools in users' hands so they could get their data out of the data base without coming to us every time," said Diane Martin, director of product development for the National Association of Securities Dealers. The association, whose members operate the Nasdaq stock market, has replaced a number of custom programs for human resources and its own financial management with Peoplesoft applications.
The N.A.S.D.'s executives "have always had a lot of ad hoc requests for information," not contained in normal personnel reports, Ms. Martin said. With the old system, even an emergency request could take one to three days to be filled; in the new system, the same report can be generated in 30 minutes to an hour.
As Peoplesoft branches beyond personnel software into financial applications, it finds itself competing more directly with two much larger companies: SAP America, a unit of the largest German software company, SAP A.G., and the Oracle Corporation, the largest data base software vendor. Although both companies come from a mainframe and minicomputer background, both have mounted major efforts in client-server, and are currently ranked No. 1 and 2 in market share, ahead of Peoplesoft.
Peoplesoft's programs run in conjunction with all of the major relational data base management programs: I.B.M.'s DB2, Oracle, Sybase, Microsoft's SQL95 and Gupta's SQL Base. And Peoplesoft's software works with all of the major server operating systems: I.B.M.'s MVS and OS/2, Novell's Netware, Digital Equipment's VMS, Microsoft's Windows NT, and various flavors of Unix from Digital, Hewlett-Packard, Sequent, Sun and others.
On the client side, you can have any operating system you like as long as it is Microsoft Windows, although Peoplesoft executives say they would develop support for other clients -- Macintosh, maybe, or OS/2 -- if there was adequate demand.
All of Peoplesoft's programs share common commands and menus. They also share Peopletools, a suite of visual programming tools designed to speed the development of custom applications by eliminating the need for endless lines of code. These allow customers to modify programs using the same tools with which Peoplesoft's engineers wrote them.
"We encourage customers to implement as vanilla a version as possible and customize on the fly," said Ron Codd, Peoplesoft's chief financial officer. "Our product is strong enough to do that."
The relatively easy customization stands in contrast to mainframe environments, in which corporations can often spend a year or more customizing a mainframe application before putting it into regular use. Companies using Peoplesoft's tools say the gains in productivity and reduced costs are substantial. But they also say that adopting this new technology is not a trivial undertaking.
"We liked the fact that it was built from the ground up as client-server, not a 'legacy system' dressed up to look like client-server," said Kathy Lennon, director of corporate systems for Coastal Natural Gas in Houston, which uses Peoplesoft's human resources, general ledger and project-cost-assessment programs.
"But there's a steep learning curve for everyone," she said.

HEADLINE: Mutual Funds;
When the Title Doesn't Tell the Story

BYLINE: By Carole Gould 

 BODY:
WHAT'S in a mutual fund's name? Sometimes not enough, Alan Wildstein, a Connecticut investor, found.
Mr. Wildstein bought shares in the Warburg, Pincus Growth and Income Fund on March 29. "I was looking for a fund that balanced the risks of a growth fund with the comparative safety of an income fund." 
 When the price dived 9 percent less than a month later, he considered the loss so acute -- similar funds fell roughly 2 percent in the period -- that he sold on April 20.
So when he read a newspaper report last month that the fund's yield was negligible and that it had owned a big chunk of volatile technology stocks, he was annoyed -- especially because the fund's share price bounced quickly back after he had sold.
"I'm sure the manager didn't do anything he wasn't allowed to do," Mr. Wildstein said. "But the very name of the fund suggests a more conservative bent."
Also among the rudely surprised in 1994 were a whole slew of short-term bond investors who saw their funds' share prices tumble, even though their issues were expected to weather the rising interest rates better than longer-term ones. The Fidelity Short-Term Bond fund lost more than 4 percent of its value last year while its peers fell just 0.8 percent, according to Morningstar Inc. The fund was hard hit by its emerging-markets debt -- more than a third of its holdings in 1994.
While the prospectus lets the fund do so, "I don't think all the shareholders knew they were so heavily invested in foreign debt," said Jeffrey R. Kelley, associate editor of Morningstar Mutual Funds in Chicago. He added, "You'd think that a fund labeled 'short' would hold up in a rising interest rate environment."
Not Scudder Short-Term Bond, whose share price slipped to $10.94 from $12.01 last year, nearly 3 percent. Its problem involved big holdings in what Mr. Kelley termed "funky mortgages," like inverse floaters and private-label mortgages.
Similarly, derivatives caused large, well-publicized losses in several Piper Jaffray funds managed by Worth Bruntjen. His Managers Short and Intermediate Bond Fund also suffered, falling 8.4 percent last year.
Derivative securities made many funds' durations creep up as interest rates rose, essentially turning short-term bond funds into longer-term ones.
Then there is MIM Bond Income, which paid no yield at all in 1994. That's because it owned no bonds, just convertible securities and stocks.
The TCW/Dean Witter North American Government Income Fund suggests stability from government issues. But its United States holdings are almost entirely mortgage securities, some of them private-label mortgages, which are not backed by the Government. The fund fell 15.5 percent in 1994, partly because of investments in Mexican Government paper but mostly because of mortgage derivatives.
Meanwhile, Alliance North American Income did exactly what its prospectus allowed: put 24 percent of its assets in government securities of Argentina. So why don't they call it the Alliance North American and Argentina Income Fund?
As the Warburg example showed, equity funds are not exempt from confusion.
Fidelity Blue Chip Growth, for example, was indeed "blue chip" until Michael Gordon took over in 1993. He shrunk the fund's average market capitalization to roughly a fifth of its previous size. The fund gained 24.5 percent in 1993, but not because it owned blue-chip stocks.
Last year, the fund's average market capitalization rose to $4.4 billion, still just a third of the Standard & Poor's 500 stocks. And 30 percent was invested in technology stocks in 1994. That accounted for its great showing -- the fund gained 9.9 percent -- but it's still not a blue-chip fund.
What about IDS Managed Retirement? Most people like to think of their retirement funds stashed somewhere stable, especially older people who need to conserve capital. But with wide latitude on its investments, IDS had 25 percent of its holdings overseas in 1994, a third of that, unfortunately, in Latin America and another third in Southeast Asia. Thus the fund lost 4.6 percent, compared with 1.4 percent for its group.
Consider also Alger Income and Growth, which hasn't paid investors a penny in three years because of its high expenses and penchant for owning growth stocks.
The upshot: don't take names for granted.
By law, a fund's name is based on its investing 65 percent or more of its assets in a given category. But "there's a lot you can do with the remaining 35 percent that overrides the other two-thirds in the wrong environment," Mr. Kelley said.
Reading fund prospectuses helps, but not always because they are written so broadly. It is better to check a fund's annual or semiannual report to see what the manager is really doing.
And for bond fund investors, if your fund's yield is much higher than that of other funds, check it out. Something is probably going on that you may regret.

HEADLINE: Technology;
Want the 99th Floor? Getting There May Be Half the Fun

BYLINE: By JOHN HOLUSHA 

 BODY:
THERE seems to be a rule of life in the high-rise world: when you are really, really in a hurry, the elevator takes forever to arrive.
Elevator makers have been trying to make vertical travel quicker and more convenient. They have been replacing the slower motor and gear technology with gearless lift systems. Those elevators eliminate the gears and make the motor part of the pulley that controls the movement of the wire cables that suspend the elevator car and its counterweight. 
 Gearless elevators can move at speeds of up to 2,000 feet a minute, compared with systems using both motors and gears, which are limited to about 500 feet a minute, because of the mechanical drag of the gears.
Now a company that has quietly become the second-largest seller of elevators and escalators in this country, behind the Otis Elevator Company, is marketing a system that does away with "up" and "down" buttons and uses computer wiles to reduce trip times by as much as a third.
The Schindler Elevator Company, the American subsidiary of a Swiss company, substitutes a keypad similar to that on a telephone for the up and down buttons in hallways and eliminates floor buttons inside the elevator cars.
A person enters the number of the desired floor into the keypad, and the system, after assessing other requests, assigns an elevator.
A liquid crystal display above the keypad tells the person which elevator is assigned to the trip and whether it will be to the right, left or behind. Inside, a light panel shows the floors where the car is assigned to stop, but there are no buttons because the control system already knows where everybody is going.
"The system optimizes the handling of passengers, because it knows how many people are going where," said David J. Bauhs, chief executive of Schindler's American operation, the Schindler Elevator Corporation, based in Morristown, N.J.
For example, an elevator car with a predetermined number of passengers headed for the ground floor might be converted by the computer to an express, bypassing people wanting interfloor trips who would be served by other cars.
Mr. Bauhs said the system, called the Miconic 10, reduced both waiting and travel time and cut by as much as 30 percent the number of elevator cars needed in a building. Each car can cost $150,000 to $200,000.
One button on the Miconic 10 keypad displays a wheelchair icon for people with physical handicaps. Pressing that button before selecting a floor adds a synthesized voice prompt to the visual display: "Take elevator A."
Each elevator emits a different tone to enable visually impaired people to find the right car. The car announces the floor at which it has stopped and when the doors are open. The doors also stay open longer when the handicapped key is pressed and close more slowly than during regular operation.
That is the basic configuration. But Schindler officials say the system can be modified to improve security or provide information on the patterns of tenants' use for building managers.
For instance, the system could be configured so users would have to enter unique numerical codes before selecting floors. Based on that identification, visitors could be restricted to certain floors for security reasons. And, yes, the boss could have a code that would insure top priority for elevator service, meaning an express would always be available.
THE data on users could also be the raw material for "smart" buildings, which can tailor services to the actual patterns of use, rather than operating on an inflexible schedule.
"The system knows the person and the destination," Mr. Bauhs said. "So when the first guy comes in, it could be a signal to turn on the lights, air-conditioning and computer systems and then to turn them off when the last person leaves."
Though the keypad is more complex and costly than a system using up- and down-buttons, the savings generated by not having to put controls in each car make the systems about a wash economically, the company said.
SO far, the Schindler system has been installed only in the Ameritech building in Indianapolis, but will soon be put into Corning Inc.'s research and development building in Corning, N.Y., and the new headquarters of the American Association for the Advancement of Science in Washington.
Schindler -- no relation to the German industrialist immortalized in the recent film -- is a family-controlled Swiss company that does about $3 billion a year in business worldwide. It entered the North American market in 1979, when it acquired the Haughton Elevator Company in Toledo, Ohio.
In 1989 it acquired the Westinghouse elevator and escalator business and consolidated a number of regional maintenance companies into the Millar Elevator Service Company, which services elevators and escalators produced by a variety of manufacturers.
Schindler, which employs about 6,000 in North America, has a research and training center in Randolph, N.J., that includes five 210-foot elevator shafts.

GRAPHIC: Photos showing how the new elevator developed by Shindler Elevator operates. (Tom Strickland for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: The World: Japan's Nature;
A People Tremble in Harmony With the Land

BYLINE: By NICHOLAS D. KRISTOF 

DATELINE: KOBE, Japan

 BODY:
Earth shakes, ground trembles.
With great weight of snow,
The tight rope snaps back.
 -- Itto Nishimoto, haiku poet, 1907-1991
 WITH its neon lights and heated toilet seats and cellular faxes, the great trading city of Kobe a week ago seemed a citadel of modernity and affluence and internationalism, an antipodean New York with more sushi. Then the ground opened up Tuesday and unleashed an inferno that killed more than 4,000 people and returned part of western Japan to a primeval condition that would have been recognizable to the people who lived in Japan thousands of years ago.
 The earthquake was a horrific reminder that prosperity and technology cannot insulate a country from its natural environment. The familiar pattern of Japanese history -- development, disaster and reconstruction -- is now being repeated in Kobe and the surrounding cities as residents search the smoldering rubble for the bodies of their friends and try to rebuild homes and businesses that took a lifetime to create. 
It is of course risky to generalize too much about differences in foreign cultures. A century ago one of the first Japanese to travel to the United States wrote back, "In America, unmarried women are called Jones, and married women are called Johnson."
 Yet differences can be real, and sometimes the way people or nations react to disasters can open a window on their souls. The catastrophe in western Japan, and its orderly aftermath, with hardly a looter to be found, may offer some insights into life and society in Japan.
 Asian cultures have always felt themselves to be intertwined with nature in a way that is difficult for Americans to appreciate. Earthquakes, floods, typhoons, tidal waves, monsoons and volcanoes are an essential part of the natural order, nourishing life and extinguishing it, and the risks are always in the back of people's minds.
 The sense of vulnerability has bred a stoicism that can be seen in the streets of Kobe today. "Shikata Ga Nai," the Japanese say, "that's just the way it is; it can't be helped." Natural disasters may just be a matter of "unmei" -- fate -- a word that, when it is written, is composed of the characters for movement and for life.
 While Westerners have long seen humans in confrontation with nature, and usually overcoming it, the traditional Japanese conception was different. The Japanese saw themselves as a part of nature, so much so that even the word for nature, "shizen," is a modern one, only about 100 years old. Until then there was no need for a Western concept of nature, for people were not distinct from the environment but embedded in it. Japan is, after all, the only industrial country whose head of state (Emperor Akihito) is a descendant of the Sun Goddess.

 
 
Expecting Disaster
 Japan, in fact, has been subject to the cycle of natural disaster and renewal for thousands of years, and today the 30 million people in the Tokyo region sit atop an active fault that constantly threatens the kinds of upheaval that killed 142,000 people in the great Tokyo earthquake of 1923. The city fire authorities released a study a few days ago that another severe earthquake in Tokyo could kill or injure 68,000 people -- and that might be optimistic, since the Kobe quake produced more damage than anybody had anticipated.
 In one respect, it is much the same throughout Asia. In low-lying Bangladesh, flooding in 1988 left two-thirds of the country under water, and a typhoon in 1991 killed more than 100,000 people. Some were saved only when they were blown off their offshore islands and onto the mainland a dozen miles away. If global warming leads oceans to rise a few feet, much of Bangladesh may simply disappear.
 China is the great historical chronicler in the region, and its records go back for thousands of years in recording hundreds of thousands of people at a time killed by earthquakes or floods or changes in the courses of rivers.
 At the beginning of the 1960's a famine killed 30 million Chinese -- it was the worst famine in world history -- and as recently as 1976 an earthquake in the northern Chinese city of Tangshan killed 240,000 people by official count and perhaps several times that number.
 Yet Japan has traveled a long way from its Shinto roots as a nation of nature-worshiping rice farmers. Beginning with the Meiji Era a century ago, when Japan began its frantic and furious effort to modernize, every effort has gone into building skyscrapers and bridges and (supposedly) quake-proof freeways. Instead of keeping in harmony with the dragons of nature, engineers sought dominance.
 "We're exposed to a severe natural environment, and we're probably more aware of natural hazards than Americans are," said Yozo Fujino, an earthquake expert and engineering professor at Tokyo University. "So we've been paying extra to try to get more safety, but the quake shows that our procedures weren't adequate."
 Still, in some ways the engineers succeeded. There has been a good deal of second-guessing and recrimination about the collapse of buildings and bridges that were not supposed to collapse, but the fact remains that an exceptionally violent temblor took a region with millions of people, with enough strength to heave railroad cars on their sides, and 99.9 percent of the population survived.
 Japanese engineers have developed not only bullet trains that travel as fast as 170 miles an hour, but also a system whereby seismographs automatically dispatch computerized instructions to halt the bullet trains at the first sign of an earthquake. In Osaka, near the heart of the quake, the gas company has installed meters that instantly shut off the gas supply at the first seismic jolt. Japanese engineering was humiliated only because of its own exceptionally high standards.

 
 
Remembering Old Boasts
 Still, the humiliation is there. The Japanese newspapers are full of self-mocking recollections that after the Los Angeles earthquake a year ago Japanese said that freeways here could never collapse. The nation itself has been humbled, adding to the tangle of feelings the Japanese have about precisely who they have become and just where they fit in the modern world.
 Sometimes Japan seems torn between two perceptions of itself. One is of the irrepressible, unstoppable powerhouse, whose secret weapon is its own special national characteristics. That vision of Japan as No. 1 was strongest in the early part of World War II, when the Japanese Army and Navy overwhelmed allied forces in the Pacific and Southeast Asia, and again in the 1980's, when the Tokyo stock market seemed filled with helium and real estate tycoons ate food coated with gold -- the better for their health -- as land prices rose so high that the Imperial Palace grounds in Tokyo were supposedly worth more than all of California.
The other self-perception of Japan is of the poor island archipelago with few natural resources, one that is always living on the edge of one disaster or another. This more humble version returned a bit in the last few years following the collapse of the "bubble economy." The great earthquake seems to have again brought this image to the fore when Japan holds a mirror to itself.

 
 
A Lingering Uncertainty
 "It's been 50 years since the war ended and we're at a watershed," said Keigo Okonogi, a professor of psychiatry at Keio University in Tokyo. "We've had our economy hollowed out, corruption in politics, and very rapid changes. This earthquake will add to the sense of uncertainty among the Japanese people.
 "Japan had been proud of its highways, bridges, railroads, and they were destroyed in the quake, so there's a psychological blow to the Japanese people."
 Yet it is striking how, here in Kobe, people are looking only ahead. They are cleaning out their homes, or clearing the rubble, and seeing how they can rebuild their lives.
 One of the phrases the Japanese have used in describing themselves is "gaman," a term that has no equivalent in English but that roughly means a kind of stoical perseverence.
 Half a century ago, Kobe was nearly destroyed by bombing in World War II, and then the local people rebuilt it into one of the great trading centers of Asia, the port through which 12 percent of Japan's exports pass. Now, large sections of Kobe again are smoldering rubble, and the rebuilding has begun once more. The resilience is breathtaking.
 "In 1944 I was in Tokyo when it was heavily bombed, and in one night almost one-third of the city was bombed," Hiroyoshi Ishikawa, a professor of social psychology at Seijo University, remembers. "But the next day we began to adjust to the new environment and find a way to survive. It's the gaman mindset, and it's in the national character of the Japanese people."
 Perhaps it is a bit self-serving when Japanese see themselves as apostles of patience and perseverence, but it is true that such values are often drilled into young people from an early age. Whereas American parents are always telling Johnny to put on his jacket before going outside, some Japanese parents send Toshi-kun to kindergartens where the kids run around outside in winter in just their shorts. It builds character.
 Or maybe it just gives the kids colds. Even so, it at least helps create a sense of expectation that people will endure hardship together.
 There was little or no looting in Kobe, even though store windows were shattered and goods were sometimes available for the picking. Perhaps people didn't steal because they are good at heart, or perhaps because each neighborhood is like a little village, or perhaps because everybody is suffering together, or perhaps because residents are too worried about the shame of getting caught.

 
 
A Sense of Order
 It is common to describe Western society as guilt-based and Japanese as shame-based. Americans have hangups while the Japanese get embarrassed, or so the theory goes, and no doubt it can be taken too far.
 But this sense of personal honor and dignity, and fear of being shamed, may be one reason why the Japanese in Kobe are ideal disaster victims. Even when their lives have been torn apart by earthquake, they sometimes line up and politely offer: After you.
 Then, too, this part of Japan, which is known as the Kansai, is famous as an area where people are particularly pragmatic. In Osaka, the capital of the Kansai region, older folks sometimes still greet each other: "Mokari makka" -- "Have you made money today?" People of Kansai barely see pie in the sky before they're plotting to bring it down to earth.
 These days, this pragmatism is evident in the little ways that people are adapting. They press ahead to rebuild, accepting the week's tragedy with a measure of philosophical acceptance. As the great 17th century haiku poet Basho wrote, after finding a man's grave in a bamboo grove:
 The vicissitudes of life.
 Sad, to become finally
 a bamboo shoot.

GRAPHIC: Photos: The earthquake that devastated the city of Kobe last week and killed more than 4,000 people was the latest blow in Japan's long history of adversity at the hands of nature. It left the Motosumiyoshi Shinto Shrine in ruins. (Katsumi Kasahara/Associated Press)(pg.1); A woman and her grandchild were left homeless, 2 aong 140,000)(Reuters)(pg.6)

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

COUNTRY: JAPAN (99%); UNITED STATES (93%); 

STATE: KINKI, JAPAN (79%); 

CITY: KOBE, JAPAN (90%); 

COMPANY: TOKYO UNIVERSITY (69%);

HEADLINE: The Nation;
Timber! A New Idea Is Crashing.

BYLINE: By JOHN H. CUSHMAN Jr. 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
FOR a nation sharply divided about how to save rare species like the spotted owl, the California gnatcatcher and the Florida panther, the idea of ecosystem management seemed just the thing. Rather than letting the life or death of a single species determine the fate of proposed dams and timber projects, this new philosophy of land management was designed to protect broad natural habitats, including the species within them, while still leaving room for humans to exploit the land. Ecosystems, unlike species on the brink of extinction, are elastic enough to take some abuse by humans; they can be preserved without getting in the way of progress. So, in this era of public ambivalence about nature's neediest cases, the idea of ecosystem management seemed to have a bright political future. It offered something for everyone -- liberals and conservatives, conservationists and industrialists.
 Over the last two years, the Clinton Administration has embraced the concept of ecosystem management. In 1993 the Interior Department set up the National Biological Survey, a group of 1,700 scientists and natural resource specialists, charged with the task of making this concept work.
 The survey had scarcely begun when the Republicans came to town. The problem then became how to sell the Republicans on an environmental novelty that nobody could easily explain. Now that problem looks more intractable than ever.
 An ecosystem is an area -- usually a distinct landscape like Appalachia or a watershed like the Chesapeake Bay -- in which plant and animal communities live in complex relationships with one other and with the region's soil, water, air and climate. The trouble is, ecosystems, like cuisines, are inherently hard to define. "To some degree, an ecosystem is in the eye of the beholder," Interior Secretary Bruce Babbitt once testified in Congress.
 Ecosystem management is even harder to define. It's a slippery concept, calling for extraordinary cooperation among various uncoordinated bureaucracies and competing interest groups. A Congressional Research Service report on ecosystem management stated drily that "there is not enough agreement on the meaning of the concept to hinder its popularity."
 Apparently, though, there is enough agreement to kill the concept altogether. When the Republicans swept in, they quickly began devising a budgetary death for ecosystem management.
 This month, at the first budget hearing called by the new Republican majority on the House Appropriations Committee's subcommittee dealing with natural resource issues, star witnesses from conservative think tanks (including the conservative Heritage Foundation, the libertarian Cato Institute and the pro-business Citizens for a Sound Economy) advised the House to abolish the National Biological Survey, whose very existence was never explicitly authorized by Congress.
 Already the biological survey is under assault. The House Republicans' "contract" of high priority legislation envisions practically eliminating the scientific budget of the Interior Department -- a cutback that the new Republican chairman of the House Budget Committee, John R. Kasich of Ohio, wholeheartedly favors.
 But even while the National Biological Survey is threatened, the Clinton Administration's senior environmental officials are trying to save it. Their first small step in its defense was to rename the scientific agency the National Biological Service, which they hope will sound more appealing. Ultimately, they want to persuade lawmakers that ecosystem management is not a radical concept but an idea that all ideologies can embrace.
 "This approach, whether you call it ecosystem management or not, is the most significant contribution that this Administration has made to environmental policy," said George Frampton, the assistant secretary of Interior. "Trying to involve as many stakeholders as possible in our decisions, trying to meld good science with practical solutions, those are all things that the Republican center of power in Congress ought to support, even more than liberal Democrats."
 Three recent examples show what ecosystem management has accomplished under the Clinton Administration:
 *A Federal judge in Seattle has approved the Administration's plan for the old-growth forests of the Pacific Northwest. The plan allows for logging to resume at a low enough level that it does not disturb the endangered spotted owl's habitat or the streams that shelter salmon and hundreds of other species.
 *The State of California has reached an agreement with Federal water and wildlife agencies for managing the San Francisco Bay and its neighboring tributaries and deltas. According to that agreement, water would be allocated to agricultural and urban users in such a way that the spawning grounds of local fish would be protected.
 *In southern Florida, the Corps of Engineers has begun planning for the rehabilitation of the Everglades, an unfathomably complex ecosystem that in the past 50 years humans have altered almost beyond recognition.
 Still, the prospect for ecosystem management looks grim. Ecosystem management works best when artificial boundaries like state lines or property fences or bureaucratic turf do not matter. But in a world where boundaries do matter, the idea of ecosystem management, like the Endangered Species Act itself, collides again and again with the interests of private property owners -- and that is exactly what has bothered the conservatives about environmentalism all along.

HEADLINE: Ideas & Trends;
Has the U.S. Got a Horse for You: Mexico

BYLINE: By ALLEN R. MYERSON 

DATELINE: DALLAS

 BODY:
IT'S the sort of deal Michael Milken would understand. Take a wobbling borrower -- Mexico, in this case -- that needs to sell or shore up a tower of investments, maybe $40 billion worth, and agree to guarantee them. In return, pocket gazillions in fees. If everything goes right.
 That the United States is now looking like Mexico's junk-bond financier, under arrangements being hashed out last week, reflects the nation's huge stake south of the border. Banks, corporations and mutual funds, and their ma-and-pa investors, sent tens of billions to Mexico, and the United States has to bail them out. Mexican debt, which flirted with investment-grade ratings last year, now looks about as solid as the bonds pumped out by many a tottering savings and loan. 
 Last week, members of Congress derided the Clinton Administration's $40 billion rescue plan, on top of an $18 billion international package, as a welfare program for bumbling Mexican leaders and gullible American investors. President Clinton responded that the country has no choice. To hold back, he said, would ravage the American economy, devastate Latin American markets and send hundreds of thousands more illegal immigrants swarming northward.
 Mr. Milken, who in 1993 completed his jail term for securities fraud, had astounding success selling junk bonds and keeping issuers afloat. He convinced investors that high interest rates more than compensated for the risk that his clients would go bankrupt. At his peak, he persuaded investors to let his shakiest clients delay payments by promising even richer returns later.
 Investors might not think of their Mexican holdings -- called tesobonos and such -- as junk bonds. But they have the same sort of watery credit ratings as the Milken paper, plus so much currency risk that the Mexican Government has to offer 20 percent interest to sell more bonds. With Mexico Inc. as a client, Mr. Clinton and his Treasury Secretary, Robert E. Rubin, a former chief of the Goldman Sachs investment firm, have to save an issuer that went from sound to sickly in a matter of days. They must figure out how Mexico, as it careers towards insolvency, can keep paying its bills, especially invoices for American goods and interest for American investors.
 "In many ways what you have is a company that has had to go through a restructuring because it has run out of cash," said Jorge O. Mariscal, director of research in Latin American stocks at Goldman Sachs, which last November became the first American investment firm licensed to trade in the Mexican market. "A company like that has to have a new business plan."
The North American Free Trade Agreement that Mr. Clinton pushed through Congress in 1993 has, as promised, increased trade and employment on both sides of the border. But it has also lulled many investors into thinking that Mexico is just like Canada, only with palapas instead of permafrost. In December 1993, the month after Congress passed the agreement, United States investment in Mexico jumped to $3.9 billion, more than four times as much as the same month the year before. Many companies began treating North America like a single production zone, and auto makers turned a swath of Northern Mexico into Detroit South.
 Then came the peso's devaluation and the precipitous drop in Mexicans' buying power. Border shopping malls crowded with Mexican shoppers a few weeks ago are now nearly barren. The earnings of many of the United States' largest manufacturers, ranging from Mattel to Kimberly-Clark, the maker of Kleenex tissues and Huggies diapers, have already suffered. A currency trader at Chemical Banking who bet on the peso's strength lost his company $70 million.
 Although the peso's latest crash calls to mind the crisis of 1982, when banks were shaken by toppling Latin American loans, today's stakes are much higher.
 "With the banks, you could restructure the loans with a few bankers," said Robert Hormats, Vice Chairman of Goldman Sachs International. "Now you have to devise a mechanism that's persuasive to tens of thousands of stock- and bond-holders" who can dump their holdings if they don't like what they see.

 
 
Party Time
 Federal Reserve officials are even having to frame the nation's monetary policy with Mexico in mind. While the Fed remains likely to raise interest rates to fight inflation at home, its officials must weigh the risk that investors will then pull more money away from Mexico. Because Alan Greenspan, the Fed's chairman, hopes to avoid facing such a stark choice, several economists said, he has helped to package the $40 billion in loan guarantees.
 One past chairman once described the Fed's role as taking away the punch bowl just as the party gets going; some suspect that now that Mexico's invited to the party, maybe the punch bowl stays.
 As Mr. Milken remembers, the high-wire finance needed to balance a listing enterprise has its risks. At his firm, Drexel Burnham Lambert, junk bond finance yielded huge fees, unsteady debtors repaid or reorganized and everything worked just fine. Until it didn't. Then his company went bust.
 As Mexico's turmoil sloshed across the Rio Grande, some traders began betting against the currency and stocks of an even larger debtor, indeed the world's largest: the United States.

 
 
Vulnerable
 Not since the days when the boundary between the United States and Mexico was a matter of armed dispute have Americans felt so vulnerable. It was a Mexican President, Porfirio Diaz, who once said, "Poor Mexico. So far from God, and so close to the United States."
 In the 1990's, the response from many Americans might be, "The poor United States. So far from God, and so close to Mexico."
