HEADLINE: High Price of a 'Victory'

BYLINE: By STEVEN ERLANGER, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: MOSCOW, Jan. 21

 BODY:
The way the Government treated it, the raising of the Russian flag over the blackened hulk of the presidential palace in the rebel Chechen capital was akin to the Soviet flag going up over Hitler's Reichstag, an image graven in every Russian heart as the moment Nazism was finally beaten.
"At 15:35 on the 19th of January, the soldiers of the 276th Motorized Infantry Regiment, commanded by Col. Sergei Bunin, hoisted the flag of the Russian Federation over the presidential palace in Grozny," intoned Krasnya Zvezda, the army newspaper. 
 In Parliament on Friday, there was a proposal to make Colonel Bunin a Hero of Russia. Though voted down, it was an indication of the strained official effort to label the Chechnya mission a victory instead of the moral, political, institutional and financial disaster it has been.
While the war in Chechnya is hardly finished, it is not too soon to count the costs of Moscow's "victory" -- costs that extend far beyond the lives lost or ruined by one of the crudest bombardments of a virtually defenseless city in recent memory.
The war in Chechnya has exposed and widened the fault lines in the economic and political stability of a Russia only three years removed from totalitarian Communism.
Internationally, the war has damaged Moscow's already shaky relations with Europe, the Clinton Administration and the new Republican Congress; renewed fears of totalitarianism in Russia; accelerated the idea of NATO's expansion; hurt the prospects for Russian compliance with treaty limits on the use of conventional forces in Europe; delayed the ratification of two important arms-control treaties, and undercut investor confidence.
Domestically, it has isolated President Boris N. Yeltsin from democrats in Russian society; formalized a new, undemocratic decision-making body, the Security Council, which has become a semi-Politburo; and split and humiliated the army. It has weakened the Parliament, encouraged anti-Western paranoia, shattered financial and budgetary plans and threatened vital new loans from the International Monetary Fund, and driven the ruble to a record low against the dollar.
So if the raising of the Russian flag in Grozny allows Moscow to start trying to solve its problems there, it also means Mr. Yeltsin and his Government must make some fundamental decisions about what kind of country Russia is going to be.
Senior Western diplomats, like many Russian officials, speak with despair about the damage done. "Yeltsin seemed to fall into Chechnya almost thoughtlessly, with one stupid decision leading to another," said one diplomat. "Now he risks losing almost everything positive he's managed to build, and in an international atmosphere much less welcoming than it was."
Among the most important international consequences, he and others said, was the growing mistrust of Russian intentions. Mr. Yeltsin's pre-Chechnya threat of a new "cold peace" and his continuing reluctance to ally with NATO are only adding to the pressure now to expand NATO much more rapidly, precisely what Moscow does not want.
The operation in Chechnya has deepened suspicions about Moscow among American Republicans, now in control of both houses of Congress. Steady criticism of Moscow doubles back in the wary souls of Russian nationalists, who control the Parliament here. The new nativist politics in both capitals hinders the weakened Russian and American Presidents from enhancing relations.
Foreign Minister Andrei V. Kozyrev held thoughtful private discussions with Secretary of State Warren Christopher in Geneva last week, but it is obvious that Mr. Kozyrev does not represent the full force of his Government. The growing nationalism in Mr. Yeltsin's circle and in the Parliament, more strident with the loss of each Russian soldier in Chechnya, has led to a new distrust of the West.
There is more talk of protecting the economy from Western ownership and Western "designs." Last week the domestic spy agency asserted that the Peace Corps, the Carnegie Endowment, the Ford Foundation and the Soros Foundation were spying for Washington, not providing technical aid to Russia.
The mutual suspicion has jeopardized some of the greatest diplomatic achievements of the post-cold-war period. Russia has still not ratified a treaty banning chemical weapons or the key treaty sharply cutting strategic nuclear arsenals, Start-2.
The problem here is twofold. First, compliance will cost billions of dollars that Russia does not have; second, the Yeltsin Administration has failed to even begin lobbying for ratification in a Parliament more likely than ever to see the treaties as capitulation.
Chechnya has also been used by the Russians to argue for the renegotiation of the 1990 Conventional Forces in Europe treaty, which committed the old Soviet Union to confining tanks, armor and other military equipment by November to specific limits in areas west of the Urals.
Russia has complained regularly that its post-Soviet borders require a revised treaty, and it has now moved much more equipment into Chechnya than the treaty allows. Russia also failed to inform other European countries of its troop movements into Chechnya, in violation of a treaty designed to promote security.
Domestically, the political scene is now more unstable than at any time since October 1993, when Mr. Yeltsin ordered tanks to fire on the old Parliament building. The vulnerable Defense Minister, Gen. Pavel S. Grachev, has accused the head of Parliament's defense committee, Sergei N. Yushenkov, of "slandering the army" and blasted Mr. Yeltsin's human rights commissioner, Sergei A. Kovalyov, as "an enemy of Russia."
Equally important, the economy is badly overheating and the budget deficit widening. A bigger deficit means increased inflation, already in double digits for each month of the last quarter. More inflation promises a further weakening of the ruble and of investor confidence. On Friday the ruble fell to its historic low, 3,947 to the dollar.
"Except for God, no one knows how much has been spent in Chechnya," wrote the Vechernaya Moskva newspaper. Estimates range widely, from $2 billion to $4 billion.
None of those costs were figured into a tight draft budget for 1995 that is already not tight enough for the International Monetary Fund. The fund's experts are now in Moscow trying to decide how much to provide to Moscow in transitional loans.
Before the war in Chechnya, there was optimism that in return for a real economic stabilization plan and a lower deficit, the fund and World Bank would provide as much as $13 billion. There is less optimism now, especially since Chechnya is diverting political will from the painful task of stabilizing the economy. It will be harder now for Mr. Yeltsin to refuse new money to the military.
So with less than a year to go before parliamentary elections and 18 months before presidential ones, the Chechen fiasco puts Russia at another major crossroads.
Will Russia continue to seek partnership as well as aid from the West, or will it turn inward, nursing its wounded nationalism and paranoia?
Can Mr. Yeltsin find the political will to seek a rapprochement with his Chechnya critics, or will he retreat to a nondemocratic cronyism?
Can Russia move further toward a healthy private market and a democratic polity, or will it retrench toward more institutional corruption and bureaucratic dictatorship?
These questions matter more than ever now. "It may seem callous," a senior Western diplomat said, "but where Russia goes now matters a lot more than whether Chechnya becomes independent."

HEADLINE: WHITMAN OUTLINES A SKETCHY BUDGET

BYLINE: By IVER PETERSON, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: TRENTON, Jan. 21

 BODY:
Gov. Christine Todd Whitman today outlined a proposed state budget that promises a third income tax cut -- just how much the Governor will reveal Monday in her formal budget address -- and includes $ 160 million in new revenue from a flurry of taxes and fees that would reach all the way down to the pennies people save with supermarket coupons.
The proposed $ 15.9 billion budget to run New Jersey for 12 months starting in July contains some good news for urban schools and state colleges, which would get small increases in aid, but not enough to cover the rate of inflation. There is less good news for municipalities, which will get no increases in state help. And the news is clearly bad for the state's 65,000 employees; about 3,000 of them will be cut from the payroll over 18 months through layoffs, privatization and attrition. 
 Although today's news briefing was billed as an overview of the spending plan, figures provided by the State Treasurer, Brian Clymer, and the Governor's chief counsel, Peter Verniero, did not spell out how big an income tax cut the Governor would seek and did not provide figures that could be used to make a year-to-year comparison of spending on state agencies.
"In order to preserve the Governor's prerogative, these details will be available after the Governor's address," Mr. Clymer said.
There has been such widespread speculation that Mrs. Whitman will go ahead with a 5 percent cut in income taxes that anything less than that would be a letdown for many legislators.
In providing the budget overview this weekend, and making her formal speech Monday, Mrs. Whitman almost certainly guaranteed herself a stretch of articles based on information given out when and how her administration chooses. The last Republican Governor, Thomas H. Kean, followed this practice of releasing his budget plans; Jim Florio, a Democrat, presented the whole package on the day of his budget address to the Legislature.
State Democrats, who are in the minority in both houses of the Legislature, said the budget proposal is too reliant on the taxes and fees, and attacked it for forcing up local taxes by giving too little to schools and municipalities. Assemblyman Joseph Suliga of Union County, designated by the Democrats to respond to the details released today, called the budget outline "another Whitman sampler of property tax shifts, higher fees and increased borrowing."
The proposed budget relies on an improving economy to close a projected $ 1.8 billion budget gap in next year's spending plan, as well as savings from administrative changes within state operations, such as assigning lower paid nonuniformed workers to perform clerical work now done by police and corrections officers.
For all its lack of detail on overall spending plans, the budget proposal was rich in the political interpretation that Mrs. Whitman, who has made her reputation as a can-do tax and budget cutter, wants to deliver. Total state spending would have actually gone down, the budget outline notes, if nearly $ 600 million in unavoidable debt service, court-ordered school funding and local court costs had not been beyond her control.
In the absence of precise figures of where the Governor's cuts will fall, the briefing session devoted special attention to parsing the source and legal status of about $ 160 million in new revenues that Mr. Clymer proposed to win by what he called the closing of tax loopholes and what the Democrats are likely to call new taxes.
The administration thinks it can collect $ 50 million more by more careful audits of how alcoholic beverage taxes are collected. It also thinks it can raise $ 30 million by taxing alcohol when it leaves the warehouse rather than when the bar serves it, figuring that it is easier to keep track of liquor case by case rather than glass by glass.
Taxes will also be collected on commercial wrapping materials -- the envelopes Federal Express and United Parcel Service use for overnight mail, for example -- which are currently not taxed.
Mr. Clymer said limiting the use of dealership automobile license plates would produce $ 5 million more in auto registration fees, and taxing software distributed by computer consultants to their clients at the retail tax rate would be worth $ 1 million.
The state also thinks it can bring in $ 15 million by changing how shoppers are taxed on coupons issued by stores. For example, if a shopper uses a coupon that knocks 25 cents off the price of a taxable item selling for $ 1, he now pays sales tax on the 75 cents. Under the proposed change, the shopper would pay tax on the full dollar. This is already how the state taxes products bought with coupons issued by manufacturers; the change would affect items bought with coupons issued by the store.
Several of these items, including the extension of the sales tax to the savings on store coupons, will require new legislation, Mr. Clymer said, although he insisted it did not constitute a new levy.
Car dealers are currently using about 25,000 dealer license plates, a number Mr. Clymer would also like to reduce to force more dealers to pay for permanent registration. Mr. Clymer did not accuse the car dealers of illegality, only of being "liberal" with use of the plates.
"And you know how we feel about liberals," Mr. Verniero, the chief counsel, interjected.
Besides extending taxes to untaxed items -- Mr. Clymer insisted that this was a matter of fairness, and did not constitute an actual tax increase -- the proposed budget relies on $ 348 million in one-shot savings achieved primarily by raiding numerous small special accounts, tightening audits, and selling state property. The one-shot figure kept faith with Mrs. Whitman's promise to reduce reliance on one-time savings, which amounted to $ 800 million in the current budget.
The Governor proposed a small increase in basic school aid for the coming budget year, from $ 2.5 billion to $ 2.7 billion, which will be divided among the state's 611 school districts.
But for the first time, the Governor would penalize school districts whose spending on administrative overhead exceeds the state average by 30 percent, a threshold that is likely to be ratcheted down as Mrs. Whitman pursues her goal of forcing economies on the state's wildly expensive school system.
In addition, the proposed budget includes $ 8 million in incentives to reward small districts that merge with larger ones, reducing the large number of districts that are too small to support high schools.
In addition to the loophole-closing, the budget seeks to increase state charges, fees and assessments by $ 19 million. The fee for a teacher's annual certification and for a notary license would each be doubled from $ 25 to $ 50 per year, for example, raising $ 950,000 more annually from the teachers and an extra $ 1 million from notaries. The license to haul fertilizer would rise from 15 cents to 25 cents per ton, and income from carnival amusement ride permits would be doubled to $ 211,000 annually.
Even walk-in use of the state's 29 motor vehicle departments will incur a penalty of $ 5 for each transaction under the proposed state fee schedule, as a way of encouraging motorists to mail in their applications and renewals and so reduce the need for counter personnel.
The new budget seeks a $ 6 million reduction in student aid, but would add $ 21.2 million to the budgets of the nine state four-year colleges, $ 6.5 million to Rutgers and the two graduate schools, and $ 5.4 million to county-run community colleges.

HEADLINE: U.S. Exhorted To Maintain Role in Africa

BYLINE: By STEVEN GREENHOUSE, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Jan. 21

 BODY:
The President of Eritrea, one of Africa's newest nations, has come here to urge the Clinton Administration and Congress not to let the bitter experience of Somalia lead the United States to withdraw from the continent's affairs.
The Eritrean President, Isaias Afewerki, who is on a two-week trip to the United States, said in an interview that African nations need America's diplomatic clout and economic aid to help them achieve peace, democracy and better living standards. 
 Mr. Isaias, who heads one of the world's newest democracies, a country of 3.5 million people on the Horn of Africa that became independent in May 1993 after winning a 30-year war for independence against Ethiopia, said that when he meets President Clinton on Feb. 1 he will tell him, "It's an obligation for the United States to have a major role in Africa."
The Clinton Administration gives high marks to Mr. Isaias for joining other leaders in the region in supporting diplomatic efforts to end civil wars in Somalia and the Sudan.
Mr. Isaias, 47, said he feared that many Americans wanted the United States to play a minimal role in Africa after its mission in Somalia took a disastrous turn on Oct. 3, 1993, when 18 American soldiers died there in a firefight. The United States originally sent troops to enable relief groups to distribute food throughout the war-torn country, but they became embroiled in fighting when their mission changed to hunting down Somali militia commanders.
"The United States role in Somalia was welcomed by the region, but then something went wrong," Mr. Isaias said. "But it's wrong for people to say that because of that, the United States has no role to play in that part of Africa. One particular incident should not be decisive about what America's role should be."
Mr. Isaias voiced alarm at the push by many Republicans lawmakers to slash economic aid to Africa and to eliminate the $800 million Development Fund for Africa.
"When you consider that Israel receives $3 billion in aid and that Egypt receives $2 billion, $800 million in aid for the 600 million people of Africa is not a very large amount," he said. "Slashing aid to Africa will hurt many Africans but is it going to solve America's economic problems?"
Mr. Isaias insisted, however, that he had not come to the United States with his hand out.
"Our country was devastated by 30 years of war," he said of Eritrea, once the northernmost province of Ethiopia. "We recognize that the solution to our problems will not come from foreign aid. But we need foreign aid temporarily until we can stand on our own feet."
The United States is set to give about $22 million in aid to Eritrea this year, about half of which will be emergency food relief aimed at tiding the country over until it rebounds from a lengthy drought.
Mr. Isaias is also scheduled to meet with Secretary of State Warren Christopher and Anthony Lake, President Clinton's national security adviser.
Much of Mr. Isaias's trip has been devoted to wooing investors. With its long coastline along the Red Sea, Eritrea has attracted several oil companies interested in offshore exploration. Mr. Isaias is also hoping to attract investors' interest in tourism, agriculture and his country's gold and copper deposits.
"After 30 years of war, we have many infrastructure problems: roads, telecommunications, health and education," he said.
Eritrea, which had been a semi-autonomous part of Ethiopia, began its independence fight shortly after Ethiopia annexed it in 1962. Before being elected president, Mr. Isaias led the Eritrean People's Liberation Front in its struggle against Ethiopia's Army.

HEADLINE: Pataki Hiring Is Criticized As Cronyism

BYLINE: By KEVIN SACK, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: ALBANY, Jan. 21

 BODY:
At a news conference the morning after his election victory, George E. Pataki promised to purge state government of "Mario Cuomo's political cronies." But three weeks into his administration, the Republican Governor is facing increasing criticism that he is simply replacing Mr. Cuomo's "cronies" with those of his own.
While Mr. Pataki has won high marks for some appointments, particularly that of the budget director, Patricia A. Woodworth, he also has been assailed for hiring a number of people with questionable qualifications for their new jobs. 
 Many are longtime Pataki friends or political supporters, or their relatives. Some have close ties to Senator Alfonse M. D'Amato, Mr. Pataki's political patron. And many of the most political appointments have placed men with fierce partisan loyalties in position to reward campaign contributors and party workers with state jobs, contracts, business grants and low-interest loans.
Those include the selections of a master fund-raiser, Charles A. Gargano, to serve as Commissioner of Economic Development and chairman of the Urban Development Corporation; of George C. Sinnott, the former Nassau County personnel director, to head the Civil Service Commission, and of George J. Marlin, the Conservative Party leader, as executive director the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey.
Some of the appointees appear well qualified for their positions, but apparently won them with the help of political friends. For instance, Neil D. Levin, a vice president with Goldman, Sachs & Company, won his appointment as Banking Superintendent with the help of Mr. D'Amato, who he once served as a Senate aide. "Dear Alfonse: Enclosed, pursuant to our conversation, is a copy of my resume," Mr. Levin wrote 10 days after the election. "As always, I really appreciate your help."
Much of the sniping about Mr. Pataki's appointments has come from top Democrats, who find themselves out of power in Albany for the first time in two decades.
"This is a very political operation," said Assembly Speaker Sheldon Silver, a Manhattan Democrat. "And it would seem to me that with all the Republicans that come from the Reagan and Bush Administrations, who are out of work in Washington, that they could have found more qualified people."
The Senate minority leader, Martin Connor, a Brooklyn Democrat, said that the three appointees that have faced Senate confirmation thus far -- Mr. Sinnott, Labor Commissioner John E. Sweeney, and Secretary of State Alexander F. Treadwell -- "have less than impressive resumes." But Mr. Connor added that the Senate Democrats "respect the right of the Governor to pick his team."
Pataki aides dismiss the criticism as partisan carping and express confidence that Mr. Pataki's appointees will prove themselves capable.
"There are those who will criticize our appointments because these appointments represent George Pataki's ideology and not the failed liberal policies of the past," said Zenia Mucha, Mr. Pataki's director of communications. "We have reached out all over the nation to find the best and the brightest. These people have been put in positions where they will be able to fulfill their potential. They will prove the critics wrong."
Gerald Benjamin, director of the Center for State and Local Government Studies at the Nelson A. Rockefeller Institute of Government in Albany, said the presumption that party officials will not make effective bureaucrats is unfair. And, he added, "the recruiting base tends to be a little thin when a party's been out of power for so long."
The nomination that has received the most criticism is that of Mr. Marlin, a Pataki recommendation that is still being considered by Gov. Christine Todd Whitman of New Jersey. Former Port Authority officials have maintained that Mr. Marlin, an investment portfolio manager, is ill-equipped to run a far-reaching agency with 9,000 employees and a $2.6 billion budget.
Mr. Marlin is not the only appointment receiving scrutiny. The new Secretary of State, Mr. Treadwell, was an early Pataki supporter as chairman of the Essex County Republican Committee and vice chairman of the Republican State Committee. He, in turn, has hired William Powers Jr., the son of the state Republican chairman, as his $80,000-a-year first deputy.
The 30-year-old Mr. Powers is a graduate business student who has worked for his father as the director of operations for the Republican State Committee and as a manager and appraiser for the Federal Department of Housing and Urban Development. His father, a former aide to Mr. D'Amato, had deep influence at H.U.D. during the Reagan and Bush Administrations.
In defending the appointment of William Powers Jr., Mr. Pataki's press office released copies of his performance evaluations at H.U.D. showing that he received "outstanding" ratings and was considered "a self-starter type" by his supervisors.
The new Commissioner of Labor, Mr. Sweeney, is a lawyer who had served as executive director of the Republican State Committee. During Senate debate over Mr. Sweeney's confirmation on Tuesday, Senator Franz S. Leichter, a Manhattan Democrat, said, "I see no other qualification or reason for his appointment than his political service."
Similar criticism has been leveled at the Parks Commissioner, Bernadette Castro, an executive in her family's sofa company and the unsuccessful Republican candidate for United States Senate last year. Ms. Castro acknowledges that she has visited only a few state parks.
Democrats also have questioned the credentials of Richard E. Jackson, the Motor Vehicles Commissioner and a boyhood friend of Mr. Pataki and his successor as the part-time Mayor of Peekskill. Mr. Jackson has had no extensive exposure to the Department of Motor Vehicles (other than the 16-day suspension of his driver's license in 1991 for not responding to a 1989 summons for failing to wear a seat belt).
Several top Pataki appointees are relatives of the Governor's friends and supporters.
Constance Barrella, the woman hired by Mr. Pataki as deputy commissioner of environmental conservation, a $90,000-a-year job, is a former lobbyist for food retailers and the sister-in-law of Michael C. Finnegan, Mr. Pataki's counsel. Her resume does not include any direct experience in the environmental field. Mary Buchan, hired as a $32,500 administrative assistant for Lieut. Gov. Elizabeth P. McCaughey, is the wife of the Albany County Republican leader, Dennis Buchan.
Shoshana Hikind, who was hired as Mr. Pataki's $45,000 director of community affairs in New York City, is the wife of Assemblyman Dov Hikind, a Brooklyn Democrat who crossed party lines to endorse Mr. Pataki. Her resume lists her experience as constituent relations for her husband and her directorship of The Jerusalem Reclamation Project. In the resume, she touts her "diplomatic talent, sensitivity and exuberant personality."
Even some appointees who are considered highly qualified for their positions have family connections. Barbara Ann DeBuono, the Rhode Island health director nominated by Mr. Pataki to be New York's health commissioner, is the sister-in-law of Richard L. Farren, Mr. Pataki's personal attorney and a member of his transition team.

HEADLINE: The Return of the Subway Token Dance

BYLINE: By SAM ROBERTS 

 BODY:
A decade ago, George Fasel, a Bankers Trust vice president, discovered a quirky truism about New York City's subway fare: the cost of a ride roughly parallels the price of a slice of pizza. In the Brooklyn neighborhood that is home to Jay Walder, the Metropolitan Transportation Authority's executive director, pizza now sells for $1.50 a slice.
Whether that means the fare is about to rise is arguable, although virtually everyone involved agrees that the current $1.25 will not last much longer because of growing costs and shrinking city, state and Federal subsidies. 
 The question, then, is how much the fare will rise, and whether the increase will cover the cost of the proposed discount pricing system that would provide for free transfers between subways and buses.
One thing is certain: before any final decision is made on whether and how much to raise the fare, New Yorkers will be treated to the ritual finger-pointing and posturing over how much money the transit system should get from Albany and City Hall, with warnings of grave consequences for mass transit if the money is not forthcoming.
The M.T.A. had been projecting as far back as two years ago that the fare would rise to $1.50 this month, but with increasing ridership and the promise of subsidies from the state and city, the authority concluded that that increase could be put off for two years if the fare rose to $1.35 in July 1995.
But now, with budget cutting the dominant theme in Washington, Albany and City Hall, money that transit officials have long counted on may suddenly disappear, and the M.T.A. is warning that the fare will have to rise to $1.50 much sooner, if earlier promises of subsidies are not honored.
The M.T.A. says that in the most dire circumstances, the system could find itself in an $800 million hole.
Were riders to bear the full cost of operating the system and fill that $800 million gap, their tokens would cost roughly $2.50, a price that gourmet pizza lovers might stand for but that subway riders would not. As it is, riders now pay about 55 percent of the system's operating costs, a higher proportion than passengers pay on commuter railroads in the metropolitan area and on mass transit in other major American cities.
"There is no right or wrong answer to what level the fare should be," Mr. Walder said. "It's a public policy call."
The latest debate revolves around the Giuliani administration's refusal to reimburse the agency for rides by schoolchildren and its threat to withhold transit police money because the M.T.A. board has blocked a proposed merger with the New York City Police Department.
Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani, frustrated with an agency that, like the Board of Education, is subsidized but not controlled by City Hall, replied characteristically that the M.T.A. should follow the city's example and cut bureaucratic fat before increasing the subway and bus fare.
Peter J. Powers, the First Deputy Mayor, said, "The burden is on them."
Transit officials counter that since 1990, their operating budget has actually increased more slowly than inflation because the work force is more efficient and executives have generally been more cost conscious.
"We have cut costs while improving the quality of service," said Peter E. Stangl, the M.T.A. chairman.
The M.T.A. argues that though cuts were made, its back is now against the wall with the prospect of reduced subsidies. And even the Giuliani administration, which contends that there is fat in the Transit Authority's budget, acknowledges that the price of a token is unlikely to hold fast even if that fat is sliced away.
Asked whether fares would rise this year, the city's budget director, Marc V. Shaw, said, "Given state and Federal actions, yes."
Conflicts between City Hall and transit officials have been more predictable than train schedules, from as early as the inaugural run of the Interborough Rapid Transit system in 1904. The indulgence of railroad executives quickly gave way to alarm when Mayor George B. McClellan refused to relinquish the controls during what was supposed to be a ceremonial appearance in a subway cab.
"I'm running this train," he declared.
In the 1920's, Mayor John F. Hylan's animus toward what later became the Brooklyn Rapid Transit Company encouraged him to create the city-owned Independent system, which often competed with, rather than complemented, the private lines.
While inflation devalued the nickel and the Depression decimated ridership, the five-cent fare remained politically sacrosanct for 44 years. In 1948, Mayor William O'Dwyer, his left flank shielded by the Transport Workers Union's realization that a higher fare would mean more money for higher wages, doubled the fare to a dime. In the subsequent 44 years, the fare was raised 11 times.
In the 1920's, as Clifton Hood writes in "722 Miles: The Building of the Subways and How They Transformed New York" (Simon & Schuster, 1993), the state kept control over existing lines to protect Republican patronage jobs; the city was empowered to build a municipally owned system, but only if, after three years, the fare would fully cover operating costs and debt. That caveat was later amended.
Even with government subsidies, the transit system fell into decay by the 1970's. That decline was reversed in the mid-1980's only as a result of an innovative partnership with other levels of government, devised by the M.T.A. chairman Richard Ravitch and aggressively applied by his successor, Robert R. Kiley.
Under the latest incarnation of that partnership, approved in 1993, the city was supposed to maintain its contributions. The state, which had already dedicated all or part of nearly a dozen taxes to pay for mass transit, kicked in with more. The partners had other problems, though.
Beginning under the Dinkins administration, the city pared its contribution for construction. Last summer, the city stopped the school pass reimbursement, discovering what City Hall insisted was a $100 million transit surplus but what M.T.A. officials characterized as a dividend to be reinvested to defray costs this year.
Then, the Mayor threatened to withhold $320 million a year from the transit police unless the M.T.A. agreed to the police merger.
Suggesting that transit officials ask the state to reimburse student transporation costs and that they capitulate on the merger issue, Mr. Shaw, the city budget director, said, "Both of our actions can be rationally explained as not leading to a fare increase unless they take certain actions."
Mr. Walder, the M.T.A.'s executive director, said: "We're not arguing that we don't expect to be part of the solution. The Mayor and Governor are right: there are more efficient ways of achieving our objectives, and we should challenge ourselves on that. But we should not lose sight of that objective: ridership growth with better service and pricing incentives."
Given the financial pressures on Mr. Giuliani and on Gov. George E. Pataki, who must submit his first budget Feb. 1 and is mulling a successor to Mr. Stangl, would cooperation rather than confrontation really generate more money for transit?
"The answer is, I don't know," Mr. Stangl said. "But I am naive enough to think that's the best way to go. Because for each of them to suggest that cutting significant amounts of money doesn't have consequences for the public is a bit unfair. To minimize the antagonism that is not in the public interest, someone has to take a leadership role, and the only one who can do that is the Governor."


GRAPHIC: Subway fare increases have generally corresponded to the Consumer Price Index over time, but unscientific surveys have found a more startling correlation: between the price of a tken and the price of a pizza slice. While tha might portend an 10-cent increase in the price of a token, uncertainties like the political mood in Albany and mozzarella prices could undermine the correlation.

HEADLINE: Tough Act to Follow

BYLINE: By CLIFFORD J. LEVY, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: TRENTON, Jan. 21

 BODY:
The Republican rookies newly installed in Albany and Hartford will no doubt snap up copies of the budget outline released today by Gov. Christine Todd Whitman, hoping to draw strength from the 23-page report as if it were the latest dose of some potent political elixir.
After all, Mrs. Whitman's tax-cutting prowess in her first year in office in New Jersey was cited so often in the fall elections in nearby states that her name seemed to enter the lingua franca of the campaign trail. When George E. Pataki repeatedly told New Yorkers that he was a Whitman Republican, most knew what course he wanted to set for the state. 
 But now that Mr. Pataki is Governor of New York and another Republican, John G. Rowland, has taken office in Connecticut, wearing the Whitman mantle may turn burdensome for them. Today, Governor Whitman began venturing into more treacherous terrain in her quest to reduce state income taxes by a total of 30 percent by 1998. And whether or not she stumbles, she could eventually help trip up the newcomers.
The region is unified under a Republican banner that includes Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani of New York, and all four leaders have pledged to chisel away at long-sacred expenditures. Given Mrs. Whitman's popularity here and her growing national stature, the new governors can expect that in the coming months they will often be weighed against her.
Mrs. Whitman accomplished her first round of tax cuts largely by altering the formula for contributions to state workers' pension funds, a move that critics called a fiscally risky gimmick that would push costs to future governors -- and taxpayers. But aside from protests by unions, there was not much of an outcry around the state.
Today Mrs. Whitman announced that she would be laying off state workers, raising fees and paring down programs, all in an effort to reduce state income taxes further. Should she run into serious turbulence doing this, Democrats in New York and Connecticut might be able to use that to bolster opposition to Mr. Pataki and Mr. Rowland.
Voters got a glimpse of such tactics in the New York gubernatorial race, when the campaign of the incumbent, Mario M. Cuomo, rounded up a group of New Jersey mayors to criticize Mr. Pataki's proposal to cut state income taxes by 25 percent. The mayors said property taxes had risen and their municipalities had been hurt because of Mrs. Whitman, warning that New Yorkers would suffer similarly.
"What she has done so far is cut 15 percent by relying on the pension shuffle as a big part of her strategy," said Steven D. Gold, director of fiscal studies at the Nelson A. Rockefeller Institute of Government at the State University of New York. "It gets a lot harder from here on in for her. Pataki and Rowland for political reasons would like to say, 'Look what she's done,' but she hasn't done anywhere near as much as she has said in her professed goals."
Even if Mrs. Whitman sails through this year's budget battles, her success might still be nettlesome to Mr. Pataki and Mr. Rowland. Each told voters that he would bring Whitman-style changes, but each appears to be facing greater hurdles than she. When they encounter resistance, they may be questioned about why they have not performed as she has.
Mr. Pataki came into office with a projected $5 billion budget deficit, an economy that has stalled, one house of the Legislature controlled by Democrats and one part of the state -- New York City -- where he has weak support.
In Connecticut, Mr. Rowland has set forth a daunting goal, eliminating the state income tax, and must contend with a House of Representatives run by Democrats. He won quickly on his first strong budget measure, rolling back raises for state workers, only because he needed the approval of just one house of the Legislature, and he received it from the Republican-controlled Senate.
In New Jersey, Mrs. Whitman has had a stronger economy that has increased sales tax receipts, a Legislature dominated by Republicans and the advantage of being the first Governor in the region to call strongly for tax cuts. She was elected in 1993 and came into office with the budget balanced by her predecessor.
At a news conference today, Mrs. Whitman's chief counsel, Peter Verniero, said her budget proposal would require 20 separate pieces of legislation. She is expected to have little trouble getting those approved.
Stephen A. Salmore, a professor of political science at Rutgers University who also works as a consultant for Republicans, said, "In Connecticut and New York, they have different problems and they have bigger problems."
He added: "The Rowland pledge was to get rid of the income tax, and that's tough. Pataki has a larger structural deficit, a weaker economy and a lower bond rating, which is going to make it more difficult for him to do the kinds of refinancing and restructuring that Whitman did."
John Chapin, Mr. Rowland's director of communications, said the Governor would examine Mrs. Whitman's budget closely but does not intend to mimic her proposals. He said Mr. Rowland also believes that Connecticut residents understand that the fiscal and political situations in the two states are different.
"Governor Rowland is a big Christie Whitman fan, as many people are, but the influence of Governor Whitman is felt more on the stylistic plane than on the specific policy plane," Mr. Chapin said.
"She caused a number of governors to be emboldened to the thought that they really could shake up the status quo, that you didn't have to leave all campaign promises behind as rhetoric. The nature of where the budget dysfunction exists in New Jersey and Connecticut is different, but the idea of an aggressive change campaign is the same."

HEADLINE: Charities Squeezed as Demand Grows While Private and Government Aid Drops

BYLINE: By ABBY GOODNOUGH 

 BODY:
As government budget cuts threaten soup kitchens, homeless shelters and day-care centers, New York City's poor are depending more than ever on private charities. But after a spate of generosity during the holiday season, contributions to The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund have dwindled to a five-year low.
If donations stop, the seven charities aided by the campaign might have to reduce or even eliminate programs for the city's poorest residents. Facing severe cuts in government financing, these agencies will depend on private contributions to fulfill the most basic of needs. 
 By today, the Neediest Cases fund has raised $3,551,304.86 -- $98,022 less than last year on this date. To surpass last year's total of $4,590,568.69, the fund would have to raise more than $1 million in the next six weeks. To match the 1992 total -- the highest ever -- it would have to receive $1,532,246. This year's campaign, the 83d, ends on Feb. 28. It is not too late to give.
Since 1912, the fund has helped destitute New Yorkers find their way out of homelessness, unemployment, mental illness, drug addiction and numerous other problems. Every day of the year, money from the fund helps poor, sick and disabled people survive.
The Children's Aid Society depends on the fund to provide poor families with necessities like food, clothing and furniture. The Community Service Society of New York uses the money to help clients through crises, paying utility bills or a month's rent. And the Brooklyn Bureau of Community Service puts money from the fund toward rehabilitation programs for hundreds of disabled adults.
"With such extensive government cutbacks, we are struggling to maintain the most fundamental services," said Stephen D. Solender, executive vice president of UJA-Federation of New York.
Many people have doubled or tripled their gifts this year -- often in spite of their own financial struggles. Still, the number of donors has decreased. By Jan. 14, the fund had received 8,618 donations -- 1,082 fewer than last year on that date.
Because The Times pays the administrative costs of the campaign, all donations are sent directly to the seven social-service agencies. This year, the fund has helped an abused woman and her four small children furnish a new apartment. It has paid for a high school boy's graduation suit, and provided a homemaker to help a disabled woman care for her toddler.
Philip Coltoff, executive director of the Children's Aid Society, said he realized that many people felt overwhelmed by recent disasters like the earthquake in Japan and the floods in California.
But he added that New Yorkers should not forget about the more subtle problems in their own city.
"In the midst of so many world tragedies, we have stopped seeing the small tragedies that happen in our city every day," Mr. Coltoff said. "These are the problems we have to remember year in and year out. And without money from the Neediest Cases, these are the problems that could go unsolved."

HEADLINE: CLINTON WILL SEEK SPENDING TO CURB ALIENS, AIDES SAY

BYLINE: By ROBERT PEAR, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Jan. 21

 BODY:
Balancing new political realities with old political commitments, President Clinton will soon propose a major increase in the budget for enforcing immigration laws and labor standards, Administration officials said today. He is also believed to be leaning in favor of a proposal to increase the minimum wage.
Republicans in Congress are likely to propose even bigger increases in spending for immigration enforcement, especially for expansion of the Border Patrol. But the Republicans are divided over plans to increase inspections of factories and other work sites. 
 White House officials said the President would probably propose an increase in the minimum wage, as advocated by Labor Secretary Robert B. Reich. Mr. Clinton supported such an increase in the 1992 Presidential campaign, but aides said he had not decided whether to mention the idea in his State of the Union Message on Tuesday. Michael D. McCurry, the White House press secretary, said Mr. Clinton was still weighing the recommendations of his economic advisers.
The issues provide two examples of how Mr. Clinton hopes to respond to the political shift since Republicans won control of Congress.
Administration officials said that in promising to move against illegal immigration, the President hoped to beat Republicans to the punch on a topic of great concern to moderate voters who deserted the Democrats in November. By contrast, a proposal to increase the minimum wage would appeal to a traditional core Democratic group.
With Republicans controlling the House and the Senate, Congress appears unlikely to raise the minimum wage in the next two years. Many Republicans contend that any substantial increase would cause a loss of jobs.
Senator Edward M. Kennedy, Democrat of Massachusetts, recently introduced a bill to raise the minimum wage to $5.75 an hour from the current $4.25 in increments of 50 cents a year over three years. Labor unions support the Kennedy proposal and say they worry that Mr. Clinton will seek an increase of only 75 cents, to $5 an hour.
Mr. Reich contends that raising the minimum wage is one way to halt growing inequality in the distribution of income. "If we don't grow together," he said, "if we continue to grow apart, this country is going to pay a huge price in terms of its stability and its prosperity."
Mr. Clinton will use his speech on Tuesday to redefine his Presidency, to portray himself as a champion of the middle class and to articulate his vision for the next century, explaining how Government can help workers ride the roller coaster of economic change.
The bipartisan desire to increase the budget of the immigration service is an exception to the general push by President Clinton and Congress to cut employment and spending at Federal agencies. Those cuts will help pay for the new immigration initiatives, but Mr. Clinton will not disclose details of all the cuts until he sends his budget request to Congress next month.
Confidential budget documents show that the Administration is drafting ambitious proposals to combat illegal immigration, which supplies cheap labor for low-wage, low-skill jobs that might be held by American workers. A Justice Department official said the Administration was racing Congress to see who would "be first with the most on immigration issues."
The official said the Administration was acutely aware of Proposition 187 in California, which would make illegal aliens ineligible for most public social services, and the Republicans' "Contract With America," which would go further, denying welfare benefits to most legal aliens as well.
"Public attitudes will become more xenophobic unless we are given the muscle and resources to deal with the problem of illegal immigration," the official said.
Representative Lamar Smith, the Texas Republican who heads the Judiciary Subcommittee on Immigration, said in an interview that the Administration "seems to have had an election-night conversion on this issue."
But immigration officials said Congress was partly responsible for the problem because it had appropriated less money than they requested in recent years for certain enforcement activities.
Budget plans being drafted by the Administration would step up enforcement of the ban on hiring illegal aliens and increase investigations of those who smuggle aliens into the country or provide them with fraudulent identification documents. The draft budget calls for hiring 650 investigators, an increase of 41 percent over the 1,600 at the Immigration and Naturalization Service, which is part of the Justice Department.
Mr. Clinton will also seek $131 million to detain and deport aliens who have committed crimes or are here illegally, doubling the agency's capacity to expel criminal aliens. And he will also propose $15 million to build detention centers in Buffalo and San Francisco.
For the fiscal year that began last Oct. 1, Congress increased the budget of the immigration service by 25 percent to $2 billion. Lawmakers say they will closely supervise use of the money because the immigration service has a long history of poor management, documented in dozens of Federal audits.
The Administration began drafting its 1996 proposals before devaluation of the peso caused concern that hundreds of thousands of Mexicans might cross the border illegally to seek work in the United States. Members of Congress and immigration officials said the crisis in Mexico underlined the need for tougher immigration measures.
Administration officials advocate a balance between controlling the border and policing work sites to discourage the hiring of illegal aliens. Some Republicans favor a balanced approach, but others oppose the whole idea of employer sanctions as a burden on employers.
Enforcement of the employer sanctions law, through additional workplace inspections, would concentrate on New York, California, Florida, Texas, Illinois, Arizona and New Jersey, officials said. Investigators would focus on industries like construction, agriculture, hotels and restaurants, which have a history of employing illegal aliens. But inspections would be random in each industry.
The budget also calls for a substantial increase in the number of investigators at the wage and hour division of the Labor Department. The Labor Department would play a bigger role in enforcing immigration laws and could propose fines against employers who failed to verify the identity and citizenship status of job applicants.
A Labor Department official said his inspectors were willing to enforce employers' obligations under the immigration law but wanted to avoid conflicts with their primary mission. "We can't be in the business of identifying, apprehending and deporting workers," he said. "Our ability to do our job depends on the cooperation of workers who tell us about violations of wage and hour laws. The labor laws protect all workers, including undocumented workers."
In a monograph four years ago, Doris M. Meissner, now Commissioner of Immigration and Naturalization, said, "We know that employers who violate one labor law are likely to violate most labor laws." The 1986 ban on employment of illegal aliens is a labor standard, she said, and the Labor Department should be "a full partner" in enforcing it.
Administration officials said Mr. Clinton's proposal would reverse a decline in enforcement of wage and hour laws under prior administrations. The wage and hour division of the Labor Department had well over 1,000 investigators in the 1980's, but the number has decreased steadily, to 961 in 1990 and 791 at the end of 1994.
The Justice Department is also increasing the number of immigration judges, to speed up decisions on expelling aliens. It plans to add 63 judges to the 116 already on the bench, an increase of 54 percent.
A Federal advisory commission recently proposed that the Government establish a computerized register of the names and Social Security numbers of citizens and aliens authorized to work in the United States, so that employers could check the immigration status of job applicants. President Clinton will seek $8.3 million for a pilot program to evaluate the effectiveness of such a system.
The President will also propose increasing the size of the Border Patrol, but his increase is more modest than those favored by some in Congress.
The Border Patrol had 4,367 agents at the end of last month and plans to hire 600 to 700 this year under current law. The President's budget will seek 500 more agents for 1996.
By contrast, Representative Smith and Senator Phil Gramm, the Texas Republican who heads the Appropriations subcommittee responsible for the Justice Department, say they want to double the size of the Border Patrol. They propose adding 1,000 agents in each of the next five years, so the Border Patrol would have 10,000 agents in the year 2000.
In a recent memorandum, the immigration service cautioned the White House: "Whatever we propose, it should be within the realm of reality, of what we could possibly carry out. There's only so many Border Patrol agents we can bring on and train in a given year."

HEADLINE: Holy Bull, Front and Center;
Red Carpet Is Rolled Out for Gray Super Colt's '95 Debut

BYLINE: By JOSEPH DURSO, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: HALLANDALE, Fla., Jan. 21

 BODY:
Luciano Pavarotti will be singing on South Beach in Miami before a crowd of maybe 200,000 people late Sunday afternoon, and the San Francisco 49ers will be flying into town for the Super Bowl game, with the San Diego Chargers right behind. But up the road here at Gulfstream Park, another star will be taking another stage for another run at racing history, and the marquee outside the gate has had it right all week: Holy Bull's 1995 Debut.
He is big and brawny. He has gained 40 pounds and now weighs around 1,170. He stands well over 16 hands. He covers as much ground in two strides as most horses do in three. His girth measures 72 inches -- just a couple of inches less than the renowned Secretariat of 20 years ago. And the comparisons don't end there. 
 Holy Bull gets fan mail by the sack, carrots by the bushel and visitors by the flock. And he was voted the 3-year-old champion of 1994 last week, and will be voted the Horse of the Year next week.
He is the great gray supercolt Holy Bull, and he absolutely reigns over the sport from stall 43, barn 3, on the Gulfstream Park backstretch.
Holy Bull hasn't raced in four months, not since he won the Woodward at Belmont Park last September and went home for the winter, his two years at the races having earned 12 victories in 14 starts and $2.4 million for his owner and trainer, Jimmy Croll, the 74-year-old Pennsylvanian who inherited him from Rachel Carpenter.
"He's one of those freaks who comes along," Croll said the other morning outside his barn. "If you knew why, you'd do it again."
But this is a new year and a new show, and Holy Bull will go to the post under Mike Smith on Sunday afternoon for his 1995 debut in the seven-furlong Olympic Stakes. When his year is ended in October, he will retire to stud at the age of 4, and let racing historians make the ultimate comparisons.
"There will be nothing more to prove," Croll said. "It will be sad, but he has given us everything."
Before it is ended, the Bull will take a victory lap of America that may include the Donn Handicap at Gulfstream Park on Feb. 11, the Santa Anita Handicap in California on March 11, the Metropolitan Mile at Belmont Park in late May, the Iselin at Monmouth in New Jersey in late July, the Woodward again at Belmont in September and, for the final flourish, the Breeders' Cup Classic at Belmont late in October, a race that he skipped last year just as he had skipped the Preakness and Belmont Stakes.
Race tracks on both coasts are raising purses and otherwise rolling out the red carpet to attract Holy Bull, and the rivals to challenge him. Gulfstream doubled the purse for the Olympic to $100,000 and revised the distribution: The winner gets 50 percent of $100,000 instead of the customary 60 percent of $50,000, the second horse gets $18,000, the third gets $10,000, fourth is worth $7,000 and fifth, $5,000. And, according to the new economics of the age of Holy Bull, "all remaining starters will receive $4,000."
Since only five other horses were coaxed into the race, every horse going to the post will be taking an expenses-paid trip. In addition, one of those horses actually has a chance of winning since Croll has not cranked up Holy Bull too tightly for his first race of the year. He will be tested by Patton, who zipped six furlongs in 1:083/5 here two weeks ago, and Birdonthewire, who finished sixth, only four lengths behind the winner in the Breeders' Cup Sprint last Nov. 5.
The Gulfstream oddsmaker made Holy Bull the 3-5 favorite, Patton next at 5-2, Birdonthewire at 4-1 and then the others: Dusty Screen at 12-1, Hudson Bay at 20-1 and Lynn's Notebook at 30-1.
"He might lose," Croll warned. "People don't understand you can't wind up a horse too early in the year. One or two others in the race are ready. He's not quite there.
"We're trying to accomplish a lot in a short time. He stopped after the Woodward last September. He went back into training on Nov. 16, walked around the barn a couple of days. He went back to the track on Nov. 18. It's a tight schedule, and there's so much to do. You have to get that base under him."
Croll reflected on what he had wrought, and said, "He's maybe 90 percent of himself."
But to most people, 90 percent of Holy Bull would be plenty.
"It all started last spring at Keeneland, where the barn area is open to visitors," Croll said. "He hadn't done that much by then as a 3-year-old, but they came. I've had more than 100 letters. Artists come by wanting to paint him. Requests for pictures, and requests to take his picture. A guy in Holland keeps asking for a piece of his tail or his mane.
"I'm not sure where the mystique comes from. His color. How many great gray horses have there been? Then, his style: He goes out in front and dares them to catch him. Finally, there was a little story behind him, about Mrs. Carpenter leaving him to me."
Dr. Pete Hall, the veterinarian who now travels with Holy Bull, fed the horse a carrot and said:
"Maybe 1 percent of the horse population is gray, and very few great ones. You have Native Dancer, Spectacular Bid, Lady's Secret and not many more. And he's got personality. He has a bit of the devil in him. He loves people.
"They brought five handicapped kids to the barn one day to meet him, and the kids asked if they could feed him carrots. He loves carrots. Normally, he'll grab a carrot out of your hand. But he must have sensed something this time. Ever so gently, he practically licked the carrots off their hands."
Holy Bull's love for carrots created a crisis in his countdown to the Olympic. One week ago, he suddenly stopped eating.
"He started to slow down Friday, he ate next to nothing on Saturday, and nothing on Sunday," Croll said. "We checked him inside and out, took blood, couldn't find anything. So, I had to decide if he was going to blow the race. But he had no temperature, no sharp teeth, no blockage in his intestines, nothing. I figured maybe he was constipated from eating carrots. They gave us a bushel of them on opening day.
"So, we pumped a gallon of oil into him, and he snapped out of it. He turned right around, and started eating again. I worked him out Wednesday, and he went six furlongs in 1:12 out of the starting gate."
"I'm looking forward to 1995," Croll said. "It would be tough to top last year. But I hope he can match it."

HEADLINE: Investors Must Be Patient With Mexico

 BODY:
To the Editor:
"Peso's Woes: A Very Familiar Diminuendo" (Market Watch, Dec. 25) points out that the peso's devaluation should not have come as a shock to experienced international investors, and indeed, Mexico is an emerging market in which large corrections are more commonplace. For many thousands of less experienced investors, however, the impact was more unsettling. 
 The drop in the Mexico Fund and redemptions in open-end funds by such investors are disturbing from another perspective. Although Latin American stock and bond fund redemptions were modest, such redemptions continue to illustrate the lack of commitment many investors have toward a long-term investment strategy. When an investment adviser discusses long-term commitment with a client-investor, the understanding is that the client-investor will ride out volatile swings and that longer investment time frames would support that strategy. The one taboo is bailing out in crisis situations. Dollar averaging is promoted instead as an opportunity to increase shares in a fundamentally good investment.
The fundamentals are there in Mexico as well as in most other Latin American emerging markets. The patient investor, with long-term goals and a steady hand, should hold through situations like this and not be frightened into a rash decision.
 
JOHN F. O'SULLIVAN
South Plainfield, N.J., Dec. 26
 
The writer is a certified financial planner.

HEADLINE: A Debate Over Punitive Damages

 BODY:
To the Editor:
In "Stop the Misuse of Punitive Awards" (Viewpoints, Dec. 25), Richard A. Booth decries the $5 billion punitive award that an Alaska jury assessed against Exxon for its 1989 oil spill in Prince William Sound. Exxon clearly deserves this verdict for its arrogant and irresponsible corporate behavior. 
 For years after the decline in oil prices, Exxon managers reduced the number of people responsible for environmental compliance. They delayed repairs for refinery, pipeline and other equipment to save money.
At Exxon's recent trial, the jury decided to impose punitive damages of $5 billion (just three weeks of gross revenue for Exxon) not only to punish the company for its recklessness but also to deter it from committing similar acts. While jail terms for some Exxon executives might have been more appropriate, the jury figured that the only way to force mega-corporations like Exxon to shoulder responsibility is to hit them in their bank accounts. And Exxon's bank account is one of corporate America's biggest. With 1993 revenues of $111 billion, a rare triple-A credit rating and profits of more than $5 billion a year, a one-time $5 billion fine will barely make a dent.
The spill from the Exxon Valdez, while not intentional, was also not an accident. It was the result of recklessness. Exxon's executives have acted for decades as if the law did not apply to them or their company. In recent years, Exxon illegally fouled waterways in New York and New Jersey, and it was ranked by the Council on Economic Priorities as one of America's worst corporate polluters. On top of all this, Exxon has led fights against better health, safety and environmental regulations -- including a requirement for double-hulling of tankers.
While Exxon is spending several million dollars trying to convince opinion leaders that a $5 billion punitive award is extreme, we should consider what would happen if Exxon is not held accountable. If corporate executives are not forced to think about the consequences of their actions, then we will tell Exxon and other polluters that it is O.K. to pollute the water and the air and harm the health and safety of America's citizens.
 
EDWIN S. ROTHSCHILD
Washington, Dec. 29
 
The writer, energy policy director of Citizen Action, a national consumer group, led a consumer boycott of Exxon after the Exxon Valdez oil spill.

HEADLINE: A Debate Over Punitive Damages

 BODY:
To the Editor:
Why should a plaintiff, presumably a victim, be allowed to "punish" an offender? This practice smacks of economic vigilantism. By all means, let a deserving plaintiff be made whole, but penalizing a defendant for reckless behavior is normally the province of the state. Punitive awards should be treated like a fine. If not directed to the public coffers, then the levy should be earmarked for the area involved, e.g. a highway safety fund if the defendant happens to be an auto manufacturer.
 
ROBERT J. VOLTILE
Wilton, Conn., Dec. 25

HEADLINE: Let Mexico Disclose Its Foreign Reserves

 BODY:
To the Editor:
 Mexico's devaluation of the peso by close to 35 percent and the policy leading up to the devaluation is a disaster. It was caused by Mexico's failure to curb the large trade deficits that resulted from an orgy of consumer buying coupled with Mexico's hiding its dollar reserves from public scrutiny. 
 Millions of United States investors, individuals and institutions that relied on the Mexican Government's integrity have lost billions of dollars.
 We are not going to have real free trade or world trade until and unless everyone plays by the same rules.
 The Mexican Government does not regularly disclose its foreign reserves, and if a company regulated and registered in the United States must file regularly with the Securities and Exchange Commission, and must file major changes of circumstances regularly, why shouldn't a foreign government, selling its bonds and some securities in privatized companies in United States markets be required to do the same?
 It has been the failure of Mexico to live up to the same standards as a United States company that helped make this disaster possible.
 The Securities and Exchange Commission should require Mexico and other countries selling their securities in this country to make at least weekly or monthly disclosures of foreign reserves so that the public can determine for itself the status of the economy.
 Foreign reserves are as important to determine the credibility of a currency of a foreign country as the balance sheet is to determine the credibility of a private corporation, and devaluations take place when these foreign reserves fall. If regular disclosure were required, not only would the public be aware of these reserves, but also the disclosure process might assist in forcing governments to act responsibly.
 I was also amazed to read that the Mexican finance minister had with him this month at a lunch at a New York hotel a man who, according to a reputable financial magazine, controls companies that account for 25 percent of the entire Mexican stock market, including the telephone company of Mexico. Where is that disclosed in any prospectus issued on Mexico?
 
LAURENCE W. LEVINE
New York, Jan. 16, 1995
The writer, a lawyer, was a director of the Argentine American Chamber of Commerce, 1962-94.
