LENGTH: 2394 words

HEADLINE: Some Co-ops Still Struggle With Default

BYLINE: By NICK RAVO

 BODY:
LIKE thousands of New Yorkers eager to join the real estate gold rush in the mid-1980's, Eric Marcus bought an apartment in a newly converted co-op building. And like many New Yorkers in the mid-1990's, Mr. Marcus has seen his investment collapse.
His co-op, the Lincoln Spencer on the Upper West Side of Manhattan, is in foreclosure; his equity, about $ 25,000, is in danger; his 350-square-foot studio, bought for $ 65,000, is unsalable. 
Even if he rented the apartment out, he says, the money would not cover the $ 486 monthly payments on his loan and the unit's $ 613-a-month maintenance.
 "Buying in this building was like buying swampland in Florida, except that people didn't live in the swampland," said Mr. Marcus, a writer and vice president of his co-op's board of directors. "We were young and stupid."
 It has been six years since large numbers of co-ops in New York and its suburbs started falling into default and, less often, foreclosure on their underlying mortgages. At the peak of the crisis, hundreds of buildings were afflicted by financial ailments of varying degrees of severity sparked by a variety of causes.
 Gary R. Connor, the deputy New York State attorney general who heads the state's Real Estate Finance Bureau, estimated that 10 percent of the 4,000 buildings converted to co-ops in the city since 1980 have, at one point, fallen into default, a category that can range from one missed payment to several missed payments to foreclosure and, the ultimate -- and extremely rare -- nightmare for those involved, deconversion.
 Some co-ops are still struggling. Mr. Connor estimated that about 60 buildings in the city -- 15 percent of the 10 percent that went into default -- are currently behind in their underlying mortgage payments.
 "It was a rolling process," Mr. Connor said. "We started to see a large number of defaults in late 1989 and early 1990. Some were resolved fairly quickly. Some took two or three years to get worked out."
 "Most co-ops in the city are healthy now, though," he said.
To decipher the arcane financial troubles that have hurt many co-op buyers in New York, it is first important to understand the difference between a share loan and the underlying mortgage.
 The underlying mortgage is the loan used to buy, renovate or maintain the building. It can be taken out by existing shareholders or, in the case of conversions from rental to co-op, by a developer, or sponsor.
 During a conversion, the obligation to repay the underlying mortgage is transferred from the sponsor to the co-op corporation, which now holds the shares in the building -- although the sponsor may, and usually does, continue to own many or even all shares in the co-op corporation.
 The sponsor then starts to sell its shares to individuals. The buyers, using cash or share loans to buy their shares, become part-owners of the co-op; they are also given leases for apartments that relate to the number of shares they purchased. To pay off the co-op's underlying mortgage, the shareholders make maintenance payments, which are also used for taxes, repairs, cash reserves and operating expenses.
Most of the problems, according to Stuart M. Saft, a Manhattan real estate lawyer and chairman of the Council of New York Cooperatives, occurred when co-op sponsors saddled co-op corporations with high underlying mortgages by overstating the value of the apartments to lenders. (Unlike a residential mortgage, which runs for 15 or 30 years, an underlying mortgage on a co-op is usually due in five or 10 years and generally has to be refinanced.)
 Then the sponsor -- who often used the unsold shares as collateral to borrow more money to convert another building into co-ops -- would be unable to sell any more than 25 to 70 percent of the shares. Then, the sponsor would default on its maintenance payments on the unsold units. This led to the co-op corporation defaulting on its payments on the underlying mortgage.
 Defaulting on underlying mortgage payments then made it all but impossible for any shareholder to sell an apartment because lenders were extremely reluctant to refinance an underlying mortgage or provide financing for a share loan to prospective buyers. The specter of foreclosure and a subsequent loss of equity scared away potential all-cash buyers, too.
 The problem was exacerbated by a long recession (unemployment rose to 10 percent in the city), demographic changes (the end of the wave of affluent, real-estate-obsessed Baby Boomers moving to the city) and a sharp drop in the value of much residential property in many parts of the city (as much as 30 percent in some neighborhoods and for some types of apartments, like studios) between 1988 and 1993, though prices appear to have firmed in the past year).
 "The problems exist either because no one wants to buy apartments, and there are many sponsor-owned unsold apartments, or it is because the mortgage is too high because of greedy sponsors," Mr. Saft said.
 Many of the problems, he added, involved conversions that occured between 1985 and 1989, in buildings in poor physical shape and housing families with moderate incomes.
 Many of the lerger defaults also occurred in Brooklyn, Queens and the Bronx. "Developers saw that people were making a tremendous amount of money doing conversions in Manhattan, but they couldn't afford to convert in Manhattan," said Edward T. Braverman, a Manhattan lawyer specializing in co-op law. "So, they went to Brooklyn and Queens and bought properties at inflated prices."
 During the early 90's, many co-ops have reached work-out agreements that reduced their debt. For example, the mortgage on the four five-story former tenement buildings at 328-334 West 17th Street in the Chelsea section of Manhattan was recently restructured by the Cheshire Group, a private real estate investment company in Manhattan, which bought the loan at a discount.
 "I was approached by the co-op, and it was a 100 percent amicable deal," said Susan Hewitt, the group's president.
 The co-op's problems began in 1990 when shareholders discovered that they were in default on a three-year-old $ 1.4 million underlying mortgage, and the sponsor, who still owned 75 percent of the shares, was nowhere to be found.
 Making matters more complicated, the bank, Central Federal Savings Bank, which had started a foreclosure proceeding on the co-op, went under. So the Resolution Trust Corporation, a Federal entity created to sell off assets and collect loans of failed savings institutions took over the loan and placed the co-op in receivership.
 "The building has been in the twilight zone," Ms. Hewitt said.
 Then, last fall, Ms. Hewitt's group bought the mortgage from the R.T.C. for $ 300,000 and agreed to pay about $ 500,000 in back taxes. She also wrote down the mortgage the shareholders owed to $ 750,000 over 5 years at 9 percent annual interest. The interest will provide the a small profit for the investors.
 They will realize more profit in an arrangement whereby the shareholders will divide the proceeds of the sale of unsold shares. This will also help bridge the gap between the original $ 1.4 million loan and the new $ 750,000 loan. The sale of unsold shares may never be enough to erase the $ 650,000 gap. An attempt must be made to make up the difference, however, or the co-op could be held liable for taxes on a forgiven debt.
 There are 64 apartments in the co-op, but only 32 are rent-regulated; 16 of the others are shareholder-owned; 5 are vacant and 11 are occupied at market rents.
 "One of the things that made the building appealing was that 50 percent of its apartments were owner-occupied or market-rentals," Ms. Hewitt said.
 That percentage means that it is likely that the building will eventually become 50 percent owner-occupied, as rent-regulated tenants have less incentive to buy their units or leave. (Co-op apartments in buildings with less than 50 percent of the units owned by occupants are extremely difficult to sell because lenders are reluctant to make share loans, the co-op equivalent of a mortgage on an individual apartment, on them.)
 Some co-ops have had more trouble arranging workouts. The 305-unit Cruger-Holland co-ops in the Pelham section of the Bronx, for example, are on the verge of completing a complex agreement that will help it out of bankruptcy.
 "We are lucky that we got a deal to begin with," said Mary White, an assistant operations manager for Paine Webber in Manhattan and president of the Cruger-Holland Association.
 The buildings were converted from rental units in 1989 and 1990. The sponsor, who held 80 percent of the shares in the co-op, literally abandoned the project, however, in 1991; the R.T.C. eventually became the owner of the shares. Meanwhile, the bank that issued a $ 9.5 million underlying mortgage on the building sold the loan to a private investor, Pelham Realty Associates, in March 1993, at a discount; it will not divulge how much.
 Just before Pelham Realty Associates was to foreclose on the co-op, though, the co-op filed for bankruptcy protection. An arrangement worked out this month with the investors requires the co-op to pay a $ 9 million mortgage at 7 percent annual interest over 5 years and continue paying the loan at 7 to 9 percent for another five years. The original loan was at 9.5 percent and 10.5 percent.
 The investors also retain control of the board for eight years and will provide financing for new apartment buyers. Prospective buyers can get financing elsewhere, but it is doubtful that lenders would be willing, at least in the beginning, because of the high percentage of unsold shares.
 "We went through a living nightmare, practically running the building ourselves, hiring contractors, dealing with shareholders and tenants, financial reports, everything," Ms. White said. "Nobody would buy into a bankrupt building."
 "We are hoping that Pelham Realty Associates will start selling apartments again, and we will become a normal co-op again."
 The situation could be worse. At the 227-unit Lincoln Spencer co-op, at Broadway and 69th Street, the shareholders and the lender are at loggerheads over a $ 9 million underlying mortgage that started in 1987. Simply put, the shareholders' maintenance payments do not cover the mortgage, taxes, operating expenses and repairs, even after the co-op raised the maintenance several times. Mr. Marcus's maintenance increased by about 23 percent, to $ 613 from about $ 500.
 "Raising it any more would have made apartments unsalable and bankrupted individual shareholders," Mr. Marcus said.
 So, with the loan due in 1997 and the prospects for refinancing looking dim, the co-op contacted the lender, the Dime Savings Bank, and sought a loan reduction, asserting that the building's value had dropped to $ 5 million.
 Thus far, though, the two parties have not been able to reach an agreement. The bank filed for foreclosure last year after the co-op fell behind in its underlying mortgage payments. A receiver was appointed earlier this month.
"We're not saying we won't pay," Mr. Marcus said. "We are saying, 'Let's find a way to make us whole.'"
 Such brinkmanship is common in workout negotiations, which can last years even after a foreclosure is filed. Oftentimes, a co-op also files for bankruptcy to buy time during the foreclosure or in an effort to get a lender to accept a reorganization in which they will receive less than they are owed.
 Mr. Saft of the Council of New York Cooperatives, however, cautioned that lenders often become very adversarial when a co-op files for bankruptcy. "We don't think it is the right strategic move," he said. "We would rather fight in the foreclosure arena. In the bankruptcy arena, you can quickly lose control of the process."
 Co-ops, generally, have an unusual amount of leverage, though, largely because of the state's rent-regulation laws, a system that consists of both rent-control and rent-stabilization. (Rent-controlled apartments are those built before 1947 that have been continuously occupied by a tenant, or a legal successor, since 1971. When rent-controlled apartments are vacated their rents rise to market level and they become rent stabilized. Apartments built between 1947 and 1974 are also rent-stabilized. Last year, the state also deregulated apartments occupied by households earning $ 250,000 or more for two consecutive years in units with an authorized rent of at least $ 2,000 a month as of Oct. 1, 1993.)
 Widespread co-op conversions started in the early 1980's because landlords, who were financially constrained by rent-regulation, found that they could realize a larger return on their property by selling their buildings to their tenants.
 "You can blame the whole co-op phenomenon on rent-stabilization," said Doug Heller, a real estate lawyer, who represents Lincoln Spencer co-op.
 Another effect of the rent-regulation system is to make lenders reluctant to take back a co-op building in a foreclosure because apartment owners caught in a deconversion often become rent-regulated tenants. And their rents, generally, would not be high enough to offset the building's expenses.
 "Only in New York does a foreclosure reduce the value of real estate," Mr. Saft wrote in an article published in the quarterly Real Estate Finance Journal this winter.
 Of course, deconversion from a co-op to a rental building also results in shareholders losing their equity. Such scenarios, however, have been rare.
 "We have only seen three foreclosures on an underlying mortgage in New York that went all the way, and the buildings deconverted," Mr. Connor said.
 Regardless, the threat of staying in the building as tenants paying below-market rents after a deconversion gives shareholders an unusual amount of clout. Imagine, for example, the owner of a typical single-family house in the suburbs losing the home in a foreclosure but being allowed to remain in the home indefinitely at a substantially reduced rent.
 "The bank may think that we are frightened, but we have a lot of tough people here," said Mr. Marcus, who could become a rental tenant paying a mere $ 200 a month to keep his Lincoln Spencer studio.
 "No one wants the building to go bankrupt, but ..."

CORRECTION-DATE: February, 19, 1995, Sunday

 CORRECTION:
An article on Jan. 22 about financiallytroubled co-op buildings in New York mis stated the level of rents imposed when a property reverts to rental status as a result of a foreclosure action. Detailed guidelines for such cases, which are rare, have not yet been set by the courts or the state agencies involved. The rents paid by the former co-op owners who become tenants are not, as the article stated, generally rolled back to pre conversion levels.

SECTION: Section 13CN; Page 19; Column 1; Connecticut Weekly Desk

HEADLINE: THEATER;
At Age 80, the Shubert Reassesses Its Role

BYLINE: By ALVIN KLEIN 

 BODY:
Mama, it is a play that tells the truth about people, Negroes and life and I think it will help a lot of people to understand how we are just as complicated as they are -- and just as mixed up -- but above all, that we have among our miserable and downtrodden ranks people who are the very essence of human dignity. That is what, after all the laughter and tears, the play is supposed to say. I hope it will make you very proud. See you soon. Love to all,
Lorraine 
 LORRAINE HANSBERRY wrote those words to her mother on Jan. 19, 1959. "I am sitting in a nice hotel room in New Haven, Conn." is how the letter began. Downstairs, next door in the Shubert Theater, she went on, finishing touches were being put on the set for that week's opening of "A Raisin in the Sun."
Such are the memorabilia that haunt memory, the golden past that permeates the walls of the Shubert, where a wall of fame in the inner lobby lists the world premieres and the pre-Broadway tryouts of landmark losers and legendary hits, from "Flahooley" to "My Fair Lady."
Those were the glory years when New Haven defined "out of town" and the Shubert, which opened its doors in 1914, was the big-time tryout stop just before Broadway. Then came the dark times, marked by a seven-year closing from 1976 through 1983.
The Shubert's 80th birthday last month gave cause for reflection and, yet again, redefinition. For the theater, which now runs as a performing arts center for 130 performances a year, many of them two-week engagements of post-Broadway national tours of the pre-Broadway tryouts of old, and subsists as a rental for community events the rest of the time, can no longer be the last fixing place for the Broadway-bound.
By the prevailing law of economic fatalism and stunning illogic, all the world is a tryout stage for Broadway but Broadway is in retreat from the world. The obstacles of outrageous finance, from production costs to ticket prices, have put Broadway, with its ever-decreasing product, into the realm of myth, as opposed to Mecca, for aspiring shows.
Apart from the obvious supposition that more plays and musicals would be realistically Broadway-bound if Broadway let them in, the days of the out-of-town tryout are, practically speaking, over. The number of new Broadway shows available for touring are negligible and the size of those shows cannot be accommodated by theaters built for actors and singers making human sounds, in contrast to soaring helicopters and crashing chandeliers.
To Caroline Werth, who began her fourth year as the Shubert Performing Arts Center's president on Jan. 4, a "two-pronged problem" faces the theater as the millennium approaches. "The shows we're looking at for next season will be costing an average of $50,000 a week more than this season's," Ms. Werth said, "and that translates to a $600,000 problem." In turn, that means a major push for more money because "the amount we're now raising, $500,000 a year, must be more than doubled."
Prong two: The physical limitations of a theater that had no problem with "Will Rogers Follies" but cannot accommodate mega-musicals like "Miss Saigon," "Phantom of the Opera," "Sunset Boulevard" or "Beauty and the Beast."
"Raising ticket prices is not an option we want to contemplate," Ms. Werth said. The top ticket is $50 on weekends, "And we won't cut back on the quality loyal audiences expect. We're selling more tickets than ever. Interesting bind, isn't it?" Miss Werth asked, looking up from the numbers.
"When you see those long lines at the box office -- this season, 'Grease' set a new house record -- and the place is packed, a lot of people are convinced everything is rosy," said Ron Shaw, the president and chief executive of Pilot Pen Corporation of America and the Shubert's new chairman of the board. "But it doesn't mean we're making money." The Shubert has a $500,000 accumulated deficit and an anticipated $100,000 loss this year.
A sellout at the 1,600-seat theater usually means it is filled to 76 percent of capacity, the 400-seat second balcony representing the exile to vertigo-land from which few theatergoers think they'll return. "We have to find a way to build a second theater so we can one again become a tryout house," Mr. Shaw said.
A new theater? Now we're talking another $20 million, maybe $30 million. "And when they tell me the odds are against me and that I'll fail, that's when my adrenalin goes" is Mr. Shaw's response to that. "And we'll keep the Shubert alive as well."
Clearly the problem has more prongs than is worth counting and it isn't only money driven, though Ms. Werth's otherwise "mean and lean" operation, as she calls it, suggests that cost consciousness must be a way of life. Or put another way, "Where does the money come from and how do we find new sources of revenue?" are the questions that don't go away.
Where does popular taste and responsibility come in? One is dealing with the non-esthetic of an audience that wants to see Robert Goulet in an artistically bereft "Camelot" (that cost the Shubert $265,000 a week, not counting $150,000 in operating expenses.) Last season, the show grossed $460,000 a week. That audience preferred the Goulet personal appearance to "Guys and Dolls" in its spiffy new production with no box office names. And survival demands that a theater like the Shubert attend to the business of indulging audiences rather than the process of enlightenment.
That's the contageous mentality that rules Broadway and filters through the touring management organizations. "She Loves Me," as magical a musical as anyone could crave, that had its world premiere at the Shubert in 1963, had a proposed tour of the latest Broadway production dropped. "Carousel," a 1945 musical that was meant for the Shubert (where "Oklahoma!" came to life) is, in its 1994 incarnation, simply too vast to play here, unless the production is drastically down-scaled, which may yet happen.
Can audience tastes be transformed to embrace quality or will theatergoers go on insisting on excess? Can the Shubert be a pre-Broadway house once more?
Ms. Werth is gamely presenting "Angels in America," in March, perhaps the most debated and honored Broadway plan in decades, a real status "hit" that closed in New York with a loss of more than $500,000. Mr. Shaw's company, Pilot, is the production's sponsor. Will Shubert audiences buy it? "I'm not a theater expert," Mr. Shaw said. "I sell pens."
The remaining Shubert Theater series:
Feb. 14 to 26: "Laughter on the 23d Floor" by Neil Simon.
May 2 to May 14 "Jelly's Last Jam" starring Maurice Hines and Savion Glover.
March 17 to 26 "Angels in America" (nine performances of "Millennium Approaches," four of "Perestroika").

GRAPHIC: Photos: Ron Shaw, Shubert chairman and president of Pilot Pen of America.; Caroline Werth, president of the Shubert Performing Arts Center in New Haven.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

TYPE: Review

COUNTRY: UNITED STATES (90%); 

STATE: CONNECTICUT, USA (90%);

HEADLINE: Profile;
For U.S., He's Behind All the America's Cup Hopes

BYLINE: By GLENN RIFKIN 

DATELINE: BRISTOL, R.I.

 BODY:
ANY way you look at it, Eric Goetz can't lose. There are three syndicates vying for the right to represent the United States in defense of the America's Cup, sailing's most prestigious prize, and Mr. Goetz (pronounced gertz) built the multimillion-dollar boats for all of them.
Mr. Goetz's sweep of boat-building honors for this classy but cutthroat competition is akin to having the same trainer handle three horses in the Kentucky Derby. This is, after all, a sport in which technology has become a critical factor, with each syndicate spending as much as $35 million for a chance to defend the cup. And the three defense syndicates -- the America<3> Foundation, Team Dennis Conner and PACT 95 -- as well as most of the seven international challengers, go to extraordinary lengths to keep the design secrets of these Formula One race cars of the seas under wraps. 
 As important as the crew and organization are, boat speed wins the cup, and competitors spend millions in research to find a design edge. To gain that edge, competitors in past years have resorted to skulduggery. Bill Koch, whose America<3> is the defending champion, spent more than $2 million on "intelligence" during the 1992 campaign. He hired helicopters to fly over competing boats to get photos of masts and keels, and even set up a decoy spy boat.
New rules this year are intended to limit the spying, but the need for both secrecy and edge remains. Not only is security at Eric Goetz Custom Boats tight and the 30 workers not afflicted with loose lips, but Mr. Goetz provides the most technologically advanced boat money can buy. By perfecting the use of composites like carbon fiber in racing yachts -- thereby making them stronger, lighter and much faster -- and in being able to deliver on time and within budget, he has, in fact, cornered the market.
"At this point, there isn't any choice," says Vincent Moeyersoms, general manager and president of the America<3> syndicate. "Any sensible America's Cup syndicate has to go to him. Going to anybody else would be a pretty big risk."
Says John Marshall, president of PACT 95: "It's not a real good statement about the U.S. boat building industry that there's only one builder. The U.S. boat building industry has shrunk and demand has been reduced for top quality product."
MR. GOETZ, 45, has spent 20 years building custom boats for wealthy sailors like Ted Turner and has earned a reputation for being absolutely scrupulous. The boat builder is a trim 5 foot 10 and has a puckish sense of humor. An unassuming, casual man who is serious about his work, he sets the tone for his staff at his boatyard in this historic maritime community on Narragansett Bay.
"He shuts down his whole operation at 5 P.M. on Friday," says Bill Trenkle, vice president of operations for Team Dennis Conner. "He doesn't believe in overtime and he wants his people to spend their weekends with their families."
Mr. Goetz has built championship boats for virtually every major sailing competition in the world, including Mr. Koch's 1992 America's Cup winner. His unflappability is legendary, as is his ability to sublimate his ego, a rare trait among boat builders. He will build to the blueprint specifications of a syndicate's designers and engineers. "Most boat builders want to force their ideas and techniques on the customer," says Mr. Trenkle. "Eric is much more open-minded."
Mr. Goetz's revenues range anywhere from $2.5 million to more than $3.5 million in an America's Cup year. Although a cup racer costs upward of $3 million, he does not take in that amount. In the 15 to 22 weeks it takes to build an America's Cup boat, he constructs the hull and puts together all the other components. Expensive items like masts, winches, electronics, riggings and materials like carbon fiber are all priced separately, however. Mr. Goetz has a computerized inventory system that tracks parts and he will often act as a contractor for a client but all of the costs don't go directly to him. (He declines to say what he charges each client.)
The four or five boats Mr. Goetz builds a year are treated as new family members, and he keeps watch from a distance as they compete in the world's top sailing challenges. If problems arise, he is quick to respond. Two weeks ago in San Diego, the PACT 95 yacht, Young America, was severely damaged by a freak tornado that tore through the syndicate's compound. Straightaway Mr. Goetz and four of his crew flew to California and by the next day repairs began. They worked night and day to refurbish the $2 million boat so that it missed only a day of scheduled competition.
The son of a German father and Japanese mother, Eric Goetz grew up in Port Washington, N.Y. His father, a shipping broker in New York, is an accomplished amateur sailor and woodworker, and Mr. Goetz combined those passions early in his own life. His junior high school yearbook had him saying he wanted to be a naval architect.
Although he majored in anthropology at Brown, he devoted much of his time to sailing. He was captainof the school's sailing team and spent his summers crewing on sailboats for the likes of Thomas Watson Jr., the former I.B.M. chairman and a Brown alumnus. Boat building was, for Mr. Goetz, the natural calling, a way to combine his love of sailing with a stable life in one port. He taught himself to build boats. If he had been born in Germany, he explains, he would have started out as an apprentice, but here he simply learned by doing.
"I have a sailing background from childhood," he says, "and I was always fiddling with my hands, making something out of wood or tinkering with lawn mower engines. Like everyone else, I learned to build boats by doing it." He got his first break from Art Paine, who commissioned him to build one of his boat designs. "The hardest thing is selling that first boat," Mr. Goetz says.
When he is asked why he chose such a remote location for his boatyard, Mr. Goetz responds: "Bristol has built more defenders for the America's Cup than any town on earth." He points out that boat building for the event began here in 1870. "We have a wonderful nurturing environment here to build boats," he continues, pointing to a custom-mast shop across the street and a custom boatyard next door.
BEFORE 1992, racing yachts were constructed of aluminum. But that year a new class of boats was introduced that used preimpregnated carbon fiber, an extremely strong and rigid material that is a component of the Stealth bomber. This material reduced hull weight by 50 percent. There were other changes. The older boats, which were 64 feet long and 12 feet wide, were replaced by dynamic new vessels, up to 77 feet long and 18 feet wide, allowing the America's Cup to be sailed in boats that were lighter, stronger and much faster.
Mr. Goetz began using composites in 1976 to reinforce the wooden boats he was building. In 1988, he penned a memo to himself: "If we want to be among the elite, we have to build for the America's Cup." His becoming an expert in composites would pave the way. By the early 1980's, he recalls, "We couldn't sell wooden boats. In 1983, we put a beautiful wooden boat on the water and nobody wanted to talk to us about anything but composites."
As is his custom, he became an expert in composites by using them. During the 1992 America's Cup, while building the racers for Mr. Koch, Mr. Goetz worked closely with two professors from the aeronautics and astrophysics department at Stanford University who were experts in composites.
Expertise in composites isn't enough, he says. It is one thing to be innovative and another to deliver on time. "We have a reputation for delivering boats when we say at the price we say." With sponsors like Chevrolet, Ocean Spray, Hewlett-Packard and Citizen pouring millions into the syndicates, he adds, "you can't tell the sponsors the boat is late. When the media event is supposed to happen, it better happen."
Despite occasional lean years like 1993 -- an "onerous luxury tax," says Mr. Goetz, on top of a recession -- his boatyard has thrived. He has built more than 70 custom boats, including yachts, cruising boats, powerboats and ocean-racing maxi-boats. Sailors from Spain, France and Japan come to his boatyard, which doesn't even bear a sign for the company. "People know how to find Eric," says Mr. Trenkle.
Mr. Koch, whose syndicate poured $63 million into winning the 1992 America's Cup, used Mr. Goetz for that competition after having commissioned other boats from him. And Mr. Koch, as did Mr. Conner, tried to persuade Mr. Goetz not to build a boat for his competitor, but to no avail.
"In 1992, we had come into the America's Cup late and Dennis had already booked a slot with Eric," recalls Mr. Koch. "We agonized over whether to let him do it. We concluded he was the best boat builder in the United States."
Mr. Goetz set up separate operations, a half-mile apart. Nonetheless, the super-cautious Mr. Koch hired his own security people and had his own construction manager and crew on site at all times. "We did checks," he says. "My guys would have beers with his workers and see if they could persuade them to talk about Dennis's boat or our boat. They passed with flying colors."
For the 1992 competition, Mr. Goetz built three boats for Mr. Koch (for $5 million each, according to Mr. Koch). He is currently finishing this year's America<3> yacht, to be sailed by the first all-female crew in the 144 years of competitions. This crew has thus far been sailing in the 1992 Cup winner. In all, Mr. Goetz has built 10 multimillion-dollar boats for Mr. Koch.
Reaching the pinnacle of his profession hasn't changed Mr. Goetz's outlook. "We run a fun shop," he says. "Everyone has a key and on any given night, guys are working on their own boats or cars till all hours. That's the greatest security you could have."
 
Eric Goetz
 
 Born: June 30, 1949; New York City.
 
 Education: B.A., anthropology, Brown University.
 
 Car: 1995 Saab 9000.
 
 Family: He and his wife, Marcia, president of an import company in Bristol, R.I., have a 9-year-old daughter, Katie.
 
 Favorite activities: Skiing in Davos, Switzerland, and sailing on the Narragansett Bay.
 
 Last book read: "Sheba" by Jack Higgins.

HEADLINE: In the Region/Connecticut;
New London Building on Its Maritime Reputation

BYLINE: By ROBERT A. HAMILTON 

DATELINE: NEW LONDON

 BODY:
ALMOST $150 million worth of construction is planned in southern New London County in an effort that those involved say could establish the region as the national center for marine science and maritime history.
A cornerstone will be the $18.5 million OceanQuest science center on a 24-acre waterfront parcel in New London. Students at the center, which will be modeled after Space Camp in Huntsville, Ala., will enroll in week-long courses that will include time in submarine simulators and remote-operated submersible vehicles. 
 Also planned are a $45 million renovation and expansion of the Mystic Marinelife Aquarium, $30 million in improvements to nearby Mystic Seaport, the Thames River Maritime Heritage Park in New London and Groton and a proposed $60 million expansion of the marine sciences center at the University of Connecticut's Avery Point campus.
The major component in UConn's request to the Legislature is for a $34 million, 116,000-square-foot Marine Sciences Research and Education Building. All of the projects are at least partially state-funded.
The projects would complement existing attractions such as the Nautilus Submarine Museum in Groton and the Coast Guard Academy and the academy's tall ship Eagle in New London.
"It's going to set us apart as the premier maritime center in the country," said Vivian C. Stanley, executive director of the state-financed Southeastern Connecticut Tourism District. "When you start listing them all, it's absolutely wonderful, what's happening in the region. Now it's going to be a matter of knitting them all together, and going out to sell them."
The region already has the top three tourist attractions in the state -- the aquarium, the seaport, and the Nautilus museum, in that order.
A. Kathryn Shelton, marketing director for the nonprofit, New London-based Corporation for Regional Economic Development, said a 1989 state study had found that tourism contributed $434 million to the New London County economy in 1989, the latest available figures. Tourism is one of the three most promising "clusters" identified in her organization's draft regional economic development plan; the others are manufacturing and biotechnology.
Richard Erickson, executive director of the Southeastern Connecticut Council of Governments, agreed. "What's being proposed is undoubtedly going to make the region more of a destination," he said. "And it's going to give the whole region a maritime identity, not just Mystic."
GROUND has been broken off Shaw Street in New London for the OceanQuest marine science camp, with $2.4 million in state grants and the rest in private financing, said Michael O'Donnell, co-executive director of the project with Philip J. Slack. They were managers at a local defense contractor, Analysis & Technology, before resigning to develop OceanQuest.
"New London has a fantastic waterfront that is completely underutilized," Mr. O'Donnell said. "Hopefully, this will be the start of a revitalization of the whole area."
The first phase of the development will be a 150-room hotel, and an 85,000-square-foot learning center, including a 300-seat conference room and 200-seat theater. Phase two will consist of a 360-degree movie theater of about 16,000 square feet, an estimated 54,000-square-foot expansion of the learning center.
Mr. O'Donnell expects 20,000 students a year, aged 12 to 18, to enroll in the week-long programs at OceanQuest. The cost will be $600 to $1,000, depending on the course track.
Project consultants include Jean Michael Cousteau, son of the famed marine scientist Jacques Cousteau, and Edward Buckbee, the retired developer of Space Camp. "They're giving us international exposure, right from the start," Mr. O'Donnell said.
OceanQuest has agreements with the Naval Undersea Warfare Center in New London, Project Oceanology in Groton and other local centers of marine science to cooperate on educational programs.
The Thames River Maritime Heritage Park, a state-financed development, will be modeled after Freedom Trail in Boston. Its 15,000-square-foot visitors' center (including a small museum) off State Street, on which construction will start this summer, will provide directions to historic sites such as the Custom House and Coast Guard Academy here, the Ledge Lighthouse in the Thames River and Fort Griswold in neighboring Groton.
Bruce G. Hyde, the New London City Planner, who is a a member of the park advisory council, said tourists could visit several of the sites in a walking tour, then catch a boat from downtown New London that would take them across the river to the Groton sites.
"With the exception of Ocean Beach Park, New London really hasn't had an anchor attraction like the aquarium or the seaport," Mr. Hyde said. "OceanQuest and the Heritage Park will give us that. And having both of them in New London will make the impact even greater."
Hugh P. Connell, president of the Mystic Marinelife Aquarium, said the expansion and renovation project is designed to make the 21-year-old aquarium look as modern as newer operations in Baltimore, New Orleans and Monterey, Calif.
"We realized if we didn't start updating now, by the turn of the century our aquarium would be a quaint, old-fashioned institution," Mr. Connell said.
The project, expected to raise attendance from 750,000 to 1.1 million people a year, will include a new lobby and entrance area, breeding pools, an area for treating stranded marine mammals, a new auditorium, and a new wing for research and exhibits.
Robert Ballard, the undersea explorer who discovered the Titanic and other famous shipwrecks, has announced a plan to move his Institute for Undersea Exploration to the aquarium from Woods Hole, Mass. His new institute will feature a ride that will simulate a trip to the ocean floor in a research submarine, and exhibits on some of his discoveries.
THE aquarium expansion got a boost last year when the state announced it would underwrite two-thirds of the cost. "If you've got the first $30 million locked up, it's a lot easier to raise the last $15 million," Mr. Connell said. "It's not going to be easy, but that state grant makes it possible."
At Mystic Seaport, there are three projects under way, including a $20 million, 150,000-square-foot Maritime Research Center that will include 60,000 square feet of exhibit space.
"This will make our broad-based collections accessible not only to visitors but to students and scholars," said J. Revell Carr, the Seaport's president and chief executive.
Mr. Carr said that in addition to more than a million historic photographs, 100,000 ship blueprints, and innumerable examples of figureheads, scrimshaw, paintings and prints, Mystic Seaport had 480 old boats.
"There's no museum in the world that has a collection of watercraft of that magnitude," Mr. Carr said. "It's an enormous resource, and one that has been largely inaccessible until now."
The Seaport is also undertaking a $10 million expansion and renovation of its 19th-century whaling village.
Mystic Seaport offers its own educational programs, including one in which students spend a week living as people did aboard 19th-century whaling boats.
Mr. Carr said since all the maritime projects would be drawing people with similar interests, he foresaw the opportunity to forge strong relationships among them.
"It would seem logical that someone traveling a great distance to take a course at OceanQuest might stay over another week for a course here," Mr. Carr said. "I can see the basis for strong cooperation among all the programs."

GRAPHIC: Photo: The Charles W. Morgan whaling ship, above, at Mystic Seaport; Hugh P. Connell, right, the president of the Mystic Marinelife Aquarium. (Thomas McDonald for The New York Times)

The Economy
 Unknown intruders have developed a new way to break into computer systems. For computer users, the problem is akin to homeowners' learning that burglars have master keys to all the front doors in the neighborhood. The new form of attack leaves many of the 20 million government, business, university and home computers on the global Internet vulnerable to eavesdropping and theft. A Federal computer-security agency plans to advise users today on a complicated set of measures to prevent it. [Page A1.] 
 Prices for new cars and trucks have risen faster than most Americans' income in the last 20 years, and the auto companies are embroiled in a debate over whether they are leaving too many customers behind. In recent months, the average spending on a new car surpassed $20,000. [D1.]

HEADLINE: New York Bonds Face Rate Rise

BYLINE: By MICHAEL QUINT 

 BODY:
The bond market is hardly spooked, but the problems in balancing New York City's $31.8 billion budget have made investors nervous enough that they are likely to exact slightly higher interest rates this week, when the city sells $645 million of new bonds.
That will eventually translate into millions of dollars more that the city must pay at regular intervals to service its debts. New York is the most active issuer of bonds in the country, after the Treasury, and every hundredth of a percentage point -- or basis point -- in interest is significant. 
 For $110 million of 30-year bonds, such as the city plans to offer this week, each basis point is equal to $11,000 of interest a year. So, a change of 45 basis points -- the increase now being anticipated, compared with a similar issue in November -- would amount to $495,000 a year for as long as the 30-year bonds are outstanding.
The city will benefit somewhat from a general decline in long-term bond yields over the last couple of months, and its interest rate for the new bonds is expected to be lower than that in its previous sale in November.
But interest rate levels discussed among investors and securities dealers late last week suggested that the decline in yields for long-term city bonds would not be as great as for other borrowers in the municipal bond market. That means that New York is likely to pay a higher interest rate, relative to other borrowers, than a few months ago.
Officials from the city government and Prudential Securities, which is handling the sale, declined to comment on interest rates for the bonds, but said the sale would be "successful."
Arthur Spector, manager of the public finance department at Prudential, said, "Investors and Wall Street recognize that as the Mayor and the city move inexorably toward structural balance in the budget, it is good for the city."
But until the city makes changes in its outlays and revenue so that future budgets are balanced more easily, investors are buying on faith that the budget will somehow be balanced and that investors will be paid the money they are owed -- a reality of New York municipal finance for many years.
The challenges to that faith are numerous right now, as the city faces a weak local economy with lower tax revenue than expected, heated political battles about midyear spending cuts and uncertainty about the ways the state, which faces its own multibillion-dollar budget gap, can ease the city's problems.
John B. Pinkham, manager of the $4.5 billion Franklin New York Fund, said that since late last year, the yields on city bonds had increased about 15 to 20 basis points, relative to the yields on the bonds of state authorities with comparable ratings.
Mr. Pinkham attributed the deterioration of the bonds to the city's long-term budget problems, not to the warning issued last week by the Standard & Poor's Corporation, the credit-rating agency, that it might lower its A- rating if the city did not continue to cut spending. "City bonds never traded as if they were A-, anyway," he said.
Mr. Pinkham, whose fund sells largely to individuals and is the biggest in the country specializing in New York bonds, said the city still had the support of individual investors attracted by the bonds' exemption from Federal, state and city income tax. The current problems are not as severe as those before the 1975 default on city notes, he said, "and there is a fairly blase attitude among many individuals."
In weighing the risks against the interest rates that the city is expected to pay, Mr. Pinkham said the city's long-term bonds were "relatively attractive," and he was likely to be a buyer.
Duncan Smith, head trader at Lebenthal & Company, a New York firm specializing in municipal bonds, said the city's bonds did not participate fully in the rally of the last few weeks that raised prices and reduced yields on many other municipal issues.
"Sure, the market sees the budget turmoil and bad headlines, and it has some effect," Mr. Smith said. "But there has been a lot of that the past five years, and I see this sale as a good buying opportunity."
He said the tax-exempt status of the bonds meant that a yield of 7.25 percent was the equivalent for most individual investors of 12 percent on bonds with taxable interest.
The interest rates on the bonds will be set this week through negotiations between the city and securities dealers. But last week, securities dealers began circulating in their own ranks and among large customers the suggested interest rates, which could be adjusted up or down as needed.
For the bonds of the shortest maturity, due on Aug. 15, 1996, the interest rate could be as low as 5.20 percent, rising to 6.10 percent for those due in about five years and 7.05 percent for bonds due in 15 years. For the longest-term bonds, due in 2024, the suggested yield was 7.20 percent or 7.25 percent.
For the shortest maturities those due in five years or less, the proposed yields are only slightly higher than those in November, as securities dealers try to persuade investors to accept smaller increases than have occurred in other kinds of bonds. But for the longest-term bonds, the yield is up substantially, compared with those of other issues.
The suggested yield of 7.25 percent on 30-year New York bonds would be 35 basis points more than the Jan. 19 index of like-rated 30-year bonds of other municipalities, as compiled by the Delphis Hanover Corporation, a bond research company in Southbury, Conn. In November, the city was able to sell bonds due in 2020 with a yield of 7.55 percent, 10 basis points lower than the Delphis Hanover index.

HEADLINE: THE MEDIA BUSINESS;
An Enduring Voice for Black Women

BYLINE: By DEIRDRE CARMODY 

 BODY:
In 1970 four black men with no magazine experience published 50,000 copies of the first general magazine aimed at African-American women. They hoped it would provide some jobs, make some money and help bring self-esteem to women who had been virtually ignored by mainstream publishers.
Twenty-five years later, Essence magazine has become the pre-eminent voice for black women. Its circulation passed one million last year. And, after years of wooing luxury markets, the magazine now includes among its advertisers Chanel, Giorgio, Cadillac and Estee Lauder. 
 In 1992, Essence Communications, the magazine's parent, acquired Income Opportunities, a magazine with a circulation of 400,000 aimed at people who have been let go from their jobs and want to start their own businesses. The acquisition was a rare example of a minority company buying a white-owned business.
As part of the acquisition, Essence relocated the mostly white staff of Income Opportunities to the Essence offices at 44th Street and Broadway in Manhattan.
Although magazines are its core business, Essence Communications, which had revenue of $77 million last year, also licenses eyeglasses, hosiery and fabric patterns under the Essence name. It publishes a mail-order catalogue aimed at black consumers and is considering starting other publications, including a magazine for Hispanic women.
Essence has built a kind of cult following, not only among blacks but among people who deal with the extraordinary problems faced by many black women.
Sarah Buel is a white assistant district attorney in Norfolk County, Mass., and an adjunct professor at Boston College Law School, where she teaches a course titled "Domestic Violence and the Law." Though she says she has no connection to Essence and knows no one there, she tells lecture audiences around the country, black or white, what she tells her students -- that they should subscribe to Essence.
"I find whites are very hungry for information about what is really going on in communities of color," said Ms. Buel, who lectured in 46 states last year. "There are tremendous stereotypes that even my colleagues make about African-American women. Essense talks about issues in a way that would help white judges, police officers and prosecutors."
The magazine's articles have included "Facing AIDS," a first-person account of living with AIDS; "Love With a White Woman," about interracial marriage; "Sickle-Cell and Your Child," about the inherited blood disorder that primarily affects blacks, and a column on the subject of blacks and I.Q. tests.
There are also regular features on health, beauty, fashion, culture and contemporary living. The November issue is always devoted to black men, who make up 28 percent of the readers. Non-blacks constitute 8 percent.
A large part of the success can be attributed to Susan L. Taylor, editor in chief since 1981, who has infused the magazine with an inspirational tone. Ms. Taylor writes a monthly column, "In the Spirit," urging black women to celebrate their accomplishments and never to lose heart. A collection of her essays under the same title has been published in hard cover by Amistad Press and in paperback by Harper Perennial.
"The mission of Essence," she said, "is to inspire, inform and uplift black women, to help our sisters move their lives forward so that they can carry the word and thereby hopefully uplift our race."
Essence readers have a median household income of $28,000 and a median age of 35. But Ms. Taylor said she did not edit the magazine with its demographics in mind.
"No matter what social, economic or political differences we might have, all black women are cut from the same cultural cloth," she declared. "Whether we learn it in the church or the mosque or in our mother's kitchen, we are reared to believe that we should take responsibility for our lives. You will be hard pressed to find any black woman who was not raised to believe in herself and to believe in God."
Two of the founders still help run the magazine: Edward Lewis, the publisher and chief executive, and Clarence O. Smith, its president. They express pride that their magazine is still really the only general magazine for black women, though others, like Heart and Soul, a guide to healthy living published by Rodale Press, feature some of the life-style issues found in Essence.
"It is very important that Essence is a voice for African-American women because we know that they are going to read a Vogue, a Vanity Fair, but they are not going to see themselves month in, month out as a black woman," Mr. Lewis said. Black women, he said, do not often see their concerns directly addressed in the mainstream press.
Yet, mainstream magazines have increasingly been running ads aimed at black women. But Mr. Lewis and Mr. Smith said Essence was holding its own. Ad pages in 1994 were virtually even with those in 1993.
Muriel Gonzalez, senior vice president for marketing at Estee Lauder U.S.A., which began advertising in Essence in 1993, said that when one of her company's products is advertised in the magazine, "we can really see the results because we see consumers with a page of the magazine coming in to ask for it." Some Estee Lauder ads, like ones for Fruition, a facial-treatment product, were "tailored for the magazine and cite the benefits of the product for women of color," she noted.
Essence has been profitable since its sixth year, Mr. Lewis said. The parent company, which is run by an eight-person board, is privately held and has been profitable for 15 of its 25 years.
Mr. Smith said he and Mr. Lewis wanted to position Essence Communications as a broad communications company, rather than one that publishes only for the African-American market. He said the company would bid in the Federal auction of airwaves for wireless phone services. Licenses for these personal-communications services will allow companies to offer voice, video and data communications through hand-held devices.
The auction for the part of the airwaves for which Essence would be eligible will take place in mid-April, at the earliest. "It will change the way people communicate," Mr. Smith said. "Essence will be trying to win some of that spectrum so that it can enlarge its services as an information provider."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Two of Essence's founders, Clarence O. Smith, left, its president, and Edward Lewis, the publisher and chief executive. They express pride in serving the wide reading interests of black women over a 25-year period. (Chester Higgins Jr./The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Far-Reaching Effects Seen If Mexico Rescue Is Halted

BYLINE: By KENNETH N. GILPIN 

 BODY:
A failure by Congress to approve the $40 billion rescue package for Mexico would have far-reaching effects that would go far beyond America's relationship with its third-largest trading partner, economists and political analysts say.
The vote may take place as early as this week. Should the measure fail, reaction in financial markets both here and abroad will almost certainly be negative. Equally profound, analysts say, would be the signal sent to the rest of the world about the manner in which the United States intends to conduct international economic policy. 
 "The effect would be staggering," said C. Fred Bergsten, director of the Institute for International Economics, a Washington research organization. "To have the first action by the new United States Congress be to turn this down would be read not only in Buenos Aires and Mexico City but in Bonn, Tokyo and Paris that the United States has turned away from the world."
The package, advanced by President Clinton, has also been endorsed by Alan Greenspan, chairman of the Federal Reserve Board.
Yet the package has met opposition in both houses of Congress, primarily from those members who had fought the North American Free Trade Agreement that helped to accelerate business ties between the United States and Mexico. Many fear the package is rescuing an economy from the ineptitude of its own leaders, and some see it as a chance to win concessions on the pact that could not be won initially.
On Thursday, Newt Gingrich, the Speaker of the House, said he was finding more opposition to the package among Democrats than Republicans.
Analysts said that aside from doing psychological damage, defeat of the package would have several financial effects.
For one, the dollar, often seen as a safe-haven in times of crisis, would probably come under attack. It began falling last week against the German mark when the rescue package first got into trouble. By Friday, the dollar was down 1.4 percent against the mark for the week.
"The impact on the dollar against the Japanese yen and European currencies will be very sharp," said Robert D. Hormats, vice chairman of Goldman Sachs International.
"The feeling will be that Mexico will be less and less able to buy American goods," he said, meaning that the United States trade deficit could widen.
David Hale, chief economist at Kemper Securities in Chicago, estimated that failure to pass the legislation would increase the trade deficit by "at least" $10 billion to $15 billion. For 1994, the trade deficit is expected to hit $152.5 billion, its highest in seven years.
In addition, a wide-ranging economic and political crisis would be precipitated in Mexico, with attendant costs to the United States. The Mexican stock market dropped nearly 8 percent last week and the peso began to slide against the dollar again, falling 6 percent.
"If it doesn't go through, the Mexican banking system, already very weak, will probably collapse completely," Mr. Hale said. "Domestic demand in Mexico will fall by 5 percent to 10 percent. Illegal immigration will rise. For the United States, this is a multidimensional crisis."
There could also be a further meltdown in other emerging markets in Latin America, markets that were unnecessarily weakened by the onset of the peso crisis in December. In turn, that would probably have an adverse impact on the region's economic prospects.
"The prospects for exports to emerging markets generally could be dampened," said John Lipsky, chief economist at Salomon Brothers.
Financial markets have been nervously watching the debate in Washington for days, operating under the assumption that the package would be approved.
At the end of last week, though, Wall Street began to reconsider that thesis, as bickering in Congress escalated over the the package and its importance relative to advancing the Republican Party's domestic agenda. The longer the political in-fighting between House and Senate Democrats and Republicans continues, the dimmer the prospects for approval become, the analysts said.
It is a view that is shared by at least some Congressional leaders pushing for the bill's passage.
"It is my strong view that the risks of defeat go up in direct relation to the delay in consideration of the measure," Representative James A. Leach, the Iowa Republican who has led negotiations on the package for his party, said in a letter last Friday to Representative Charles E. Schumer, the New York Democrat.
Despite the wrangling, observers have hopes that a deal will ultimately be forged. That view was echoed by Mr. Leach and Representative Barney Frank, the Massachusetts Democrat who has been negotiating for the minority.
"It is important to do this as quickly as possible, because the markets interpret delays in a negative way," Mr. Frank said in a telephone interview.
In a telephone interview on Friday, Mr. Leach said he hoped the measure could be brought up late this week, after the House considers the balanced-budget amendment to the Constitution.
But the makeup of the new Congress is not inspiring a great deal of confidence about approval.
"I have been fairly confident because the Congress fears being accused of triggering a financial crisis," Mr. Bergsten said.
"But with this enormous turnover, two-thirds of the members of the House are in either their first or second term," he said. "They don't realize they could cause what could be like an accidental nuclear war."

HEADLINE: Auto Makers Begin to Rethink Prices

BYLINE: By JAMES BENNET, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: DETROIT, Jan. 22

 BODY:
Prices for new cars and trucks have risen faster than most Americans' income in the last 20 years, and the auto companies are now embroiled in a debate over whether they are leaving too many customers behind.
In recent months, average spending on a new car has exceeded $20,000 for the first time. That has produced healthy profits for the industry but also caused at least a few auto makers to begin looking for ways to make their vehicles less expensive. 
 By contrast, two decades ago, the typical new car cost $4,400 -- the equivalent of $12,800 after adjusting for inflation. In 1974, the average family spent one-third of a year's income to buy an average-priced car; last year, it needed to spend more than half.
"We know we're pricing some people out of the market," said Robert J. Eaton, chairman and chief executive of the Chrysler Corporation. He blamed government regulations for most of the increases.
Others, however, attribute the problem chiefly to what they say are the auto makers' tendency to build cars primarily for affluent customers. "The Big Three are adding too many features and pushing stickers up too much," said Susan Jacobs, president of Jacobs & Associates, an automotive consulting firm.
A few auto companies are planning to offer cheaper versions of their more expensive cars beginning this fall. For instance, Chrysler will produce a less luxurious Plymouth model of its new compact sedans for less than $15,000; Dodge and Chrysler dealers now offer them for up to $20,000. But with the industry enjoying a solid recovery, most executives are courting the more affluent customers.
More auto makers are aiming their marketing at well-paid college graduates in their 30's and older, and at two-income families. Even more than the Big Three, the Japanese have catered to these affluent buyers. Not only have Japanese companies brought out luxury vehicles, they have also upgraded family cars like the Toyota Camry and the Honda Accord.
In addition, the auto makers have seized on leasing -- once confined to luxury makes and company cars -- to help keep monthly payments within reach.
The current success of the auto companies' pricing approach may help explain one big paradox of the present economic expansion: the combination of strong growth with relatively stagnant average earnings. There are more than enough affluent people willing and able to pay higher car prices, consigning most Americans -- whose incomes have barely kept up with inflation -- to the used-car lot.
Indeed, while Japanese makers are being squeezed by the high yen, the overall strategy is generating robust profits for Detroit, as demonstrated by the announcement by Chrysler last week that it made more money during 1994 than it ever had before.
Many in Detroit say that affordability is not a serious problem. "I think it's rubbish," said Alexander J. Trotman, chairman and chief executive of the Ford Motor Company. He said customers bought more cars and trucks in 1994 than they had in any of the last five years.
"We're not forcing them to buy Explorers," Mr. Trotman said, referring to a hot-selling sport-utility vehicle. The base price for the four-door Explorer, with two-wheel drive, is $20,870, and most versions cost much more.
But some analysts say the auto makers cannot hope for long-term growth in the United States without broadening their notion of who their customers should be.
"More and more people are getting locked out of the new-car market," said Christopher W. Cedergren, senior vice president of the Autopacific Group, a marketing and consulting firm in Santa Ana, Calif. Even the typical buyer of small cars like the Ford Escort has an income of $45,000, he said, well above the median income for all American households., which was less than $37,000 in 1993, according to the most recent Government figures.
Indeed, there are already some signs of price resistance in the market. Higher interest rates appear to be scaring the most price-sensitive buyers away from showrooms. Ford plans to suspend production at two small-car plants and its Windstar mini-van factory this week because there are too many vehicles on dealer lots. Ford will also offer rebates on Windstar leases. The $20,000-plus price on the mini-van strains the budget for many families.
Similarly, Chrysler on Friday expanded rebates on the more luxurious models of its Neon subcompact, which were not selling well. It recently decided against adding workers at a Neon assembly plant, and it is rushing out cheaper, stripped-down versions.
But those are stopgap measures. To attract more bargain-oriented buyers, auto makers from Chrysler to BMW are also planning significantly less expensive versions of their higher-priced cars, beginning later this year. BMW, for instance, will offer a model for slightly less than $20,000, far less than its typical offering. Led by Toyota, several Japanese auto makers, whose prices have risen much faster than Detroit's, are hoping to recapture a position at the lower end of the market. They hope to develop small cars to sell in the $10,000 to $12,000 range.
At Chrysler, Plymouth will offer the Breeze, a version of the Chrysler Cirrus and Dodge Stratus compact sedans, for less than $15,000. Buyers will get some features, like air-conditioning and even compact-disk players, but not others, like V6 engines.
Yet even here, Chrysler is aiming Plymouth at people up to age 40, with incomes as high as $60,000.
General Motors, perhaps as much from desperation as conviction, has been the most aggressive in trying to win back less-affluent customers. In the family sedan market, G.M. priced its redesigned Lumina, together with its two-door version called the Monte Carlo, well under the competition, at $16,295 and $17,295, respectively, compared with $18,120 for the base Ford Taurus and $18,509 for the Dodge Intrepid.
Auto reviewers derided the G.M. car for bland styling, but customers liked it. In just five months, G.M. has sold 100,000 Luminas and Monte Carlos and taken orders for 120,000 more, a pace that would make the car one of the top 10 sellers of the year.
Some of G.M.'s rivals are noticing. "I take them very seriously," said Robert A. Lutz, Chrysler's president. "Value is what it's all about."
In general, however, the auto companies are taking advantage of the strong market today to raise prices further. That will leave the auto industry with an even narrower slice of the American population as customers.
Though the precise number has ebbed and flowed with the economy, the proportion of American families buying new vehicles has steadily slipped since the 1960's. "The trend is very clear and very direct," said Paul D. Ballew, an economist with the Detroit branch of the Federal Reserve Bank of Chicago.
Despite today's sales success, the industry's focus on the top tier could come back to haunt auto makers. It may even be restraining economic growth in general. If there were lower vehicle prices and greater income gains at the bottom of the ladder, Mr. Ballew said, the number of vehicles sold could well surge beyond the 15 million plus projected for this year. "The new-vehicle market is growing," he said, "but at an anemic pace."
Analysts' fears of a brewing "affordability crisis" are finally beginning to capture the attention of some auto makers, for two reasons.
First, many people are buying beyond their means. Subsidized lease deals and strong consumer confidence may be temporarily masking an underlying affordability woe.
That problem, which the auto makers worry will only worsen as they add equipment to vehicles to meet tightening emissions standards, could deepen the next sales downturn and make a rebound harder to achieve. For now, however, leasing -- once exclusively a means of making luxury cars more affordable -- has become much more important in selling cars and trucks of all types.
Second, some auto makers say they may be overlooking a lot of potential buyers. "There's a market opportunity there, clearly," said John F. Smith Jr., president and chief executive of the General Motors Corporation. "Affordability is an issue."
The North American International Auto Show here this month highlighted the challenge. A record turnout of car buffs and potential buyers marveled at coming products, ranging from Ford's new Taurus sedan to Toyota's RAV-4 baby sport utility. The prices, however, did not draw rave reviews.
"It's a rip-off," said Dan Burgess, a 21-year-old college student, who said he was interested in the Dodge Neon, which has a base price of $10,000 with destination charges but usually costs at least $2,000 more in dealer showrooms. "You've got to pay tons to get something to drive."
Like many other shoppers, Mr. Burgess said he would probably look at used cars, which now outsell new cars each year two to one and account for one of three dollars spent on vehicles, up from one in six in 1980.
The cheapest car sold in the United States is the Geo Metro subcompact, powered by a tiny three-cylinder engine and priced in its base version for $8,395. But its popularity is limited. Indeed, several executives and independent analysts said they thought it impossible, given regulations and material costs today, to build a profitable car with any customer appeal for less than $8,000.
While the auto makers have achieved enormous productivity gains and other cost decreases in recent years, they contend that those savings have allowed them only to restrain price increases, not offer lower-priced cars.

HEADLINE: Asian Stocks Plunge on Rate Fears

BYLINE: By Bloomberg Business News 

DATELINE: TOKYO, Monday, Jan. 23

 BODY:
Stock prices across Asia plunged today to their lowest levels in a year or more, as concern that the United States would raise interest rates pushed investors away from stocks.
In Japan, the Nikkei index of 225 issues fell 1,054.73 points, or 5.6 percent, to 17,785.49, below its level a year ago. In addition to fear about the anticipated action by the Federal Reserve, Japanese stocks were undermined by concern that the country's economic recovery would be hurt by the Kobe earthquake. 
 Analysts said foreign investors lowered their offers to get rid of electronics, steel and chemical stocks they bought last year as bets on the recovery.
In Hong Kong, the Hang Seng index was down 3.6 percent, its lowest level in 20 months. The stock market there is affected by United States rates, because the territory shadows American monetary policy.
In Singapore, the Straits Times Industrials index was lower by more than 3 percent, to an 18-month low. Analysts there cited the Fed's policy making meeting on Jan. 31 to Feb. 1, when a decision will be made on whether to raise interest rates again to stall inflation.
Singapore's interest rates are closely tied to those in the United States because of trade and currency links, and higher interest rates make stocks less attractive than bonds and other fixed-income investments.
A report released on Friday showing that United States housing construction had reached a six-year high in 1994 heightened concern that accelerating inflation would prompt the Fed to raise rates.
Elsewhere, the stock markets in Australia, Taiwan, Thailand and Kuala Lumpur also fell sharply.

HEADLINE: Orange County Aides Talk of 2 Mystery Funds

BYLINE: AP 

DATELINE: SANTA ANA, Calif., Jan. 22

 BODY:
As much as $85 million in interest due to participants in the Orange County investment pool was placed in mystery accounts maintained by the county treasurer's office, the new chairman of the county Board of Supervisors said over the weekend.
The information will be turned over to the Securities and Exchange Commission and the district attorney's office, which are investigating possible wrongdoing in the investment loss now standing at $1.69 billion, Supervisor Gaddi Vasquez said at a news conference on Saturday. 
 Mr. Vasquez said auditors examining the county's books on Friday found that $82 million to $85 million had been diverted to a "mystery fund" consisting of two accounts called the 9 JJ Account and the Economic Uncertainty Fund.
"It doesn't please us at all to find another dimension to this crisis," said Bruce Bennett, the county attorney. "As of now, the records seem to show that the money was misallocated."
The county counsel, James Mercer, said the Supervisors did not know who created the 9 JJ Fund, or for what purpose. Orange County's administrative officer, Ernie Schneider, said he had asked the Board of Supervisors to set up the Economic Uncertainty Fund two years ago, but added that "Citron was responsible for keeping the accounts straight."
Robert L. Citron resigned as treasurer after Orange County filed for bankruptcy protection last month. The assistant treasurer and tax collector, Matthew Raabe, was placed on administrative leave after refusing to answer questions about the mystery accounts, Mr. Vasquez said.
The discrepancies, which involved interest revenue for fiscal 1994 and 1995, were found by auditors from an outside accounting firm, the county said. But it concluded that none of the diverted interest was spent and that the records appeared accurate enough for pool participants to be credited with the correct interest.
