HEADLINE: Budget Amendment May Be Short Of Enough States for Ratification

BYLINE: By DAVID E. ROSENBAUM, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Jan. 22

 BODY:
If Congress approves a constitutional amendment requiring a balanced Federal budget, many state legislatures will probably ratify the measure quickly, but maybe too few to make it part of the Constitution.
A state-by-state survey by correspondents of The New York Times found that some legislatures, afraid of the fiscal consequences, would most likely refuse to ratify the amendment and that the outlook was cloudy enough in others to raise considerable doubt that it will ever be adopted. 
 To become part of the Constitution, an amendment must be approved by two-thirds majorities in both the House of Representatives and the Senate and then be ratified by the legislatures of three-quarters, or 38, of the states.
A balanced-budget amendment is a top priority of the Republicans now in control of Congress. The House plans to vote on the matter by the end of the month, and two-thirds approval of the amendment in one form or another is expected there, although not absolutely certain.
The Senate will not vote until next month at the earliest, and the prospect there is uncertain. It would take 34 votes in the Senate to block the amendment, and 33 of the 37 senators who voted against such a measure last year are still in office.
The situation in the states is even murkier. Many of the more than 7,400 state legislators are, of course, influenced by public opinion polls showing that 80 percent of Americans favor a balanced-budget amendment. But many state officials, especially governors, are concerned that balancing the Federal budget would force deep cuts in Federal aid to the states and place a heavy burden on the states to raise their own taxes or sharply reduce services.
Expressing the view of other students of state governments, Steven D. Gold, director of the Center for the Study of the States at the State University of New York in Albany, said he believed that support of a balanced-budget amendment would wane when state officials calculated what it might mean for their own budgets.
"Thus far," he said in an interview, "most state legislators haven't thought about what the effect would be. But the arithmetic is devastating."
According to the National Association of State Budget Officers, the states receive more than $600 billion a year in direct Federal aid.
Some states are more dependent than others. For instance, in 1992, Federal money made up more than 57 percent of Alabama's budget but only about 15 percent of the budgets of Hawaii and Delaware. On average, the association reports, about a quarter of the states' budgets consist of money from Washington.
More than 40 percent of that money is allocated to health care, mostly Medicaid. The rest goes largely for welfare payments, food and housing assistance, education, training, social services and transportation.
Balancing the Federal budget by 2002, as most versions of the constitutional amendment under consideration would require, would mean a combination of Federal tax increases and spending reductions of more than $1 trillion over the next seven years. If, as Republican leaders in Congress are insisting, taxes were not raised, and if Social Security, the military and essential costs like maintaining prisons were exempt from cutbacks, other Federal spending, including grants to states, would have to be reduced by about 30 percent.
Nonetheless, the governors and legislative leaders in many states said in interviews over the last two weeks that ratification of the amendment by their legislatures was a foregone conclusion.
In Utah, for example, the majority leader of the Senate and the Speaker of the House, both Republicans, did not need even a moment of reflection before answering a reporter's question about whether the Legislature would approve the amendment.
"Definitely," said Senator Lane Beattie.
"Without question," said Representative Melvin R. Brown.
In South Carolina, Gov. David Beasley, a Republican, said he hoped his state would be the first to ratify the amendment. The South Carolina Senate is controlled by Democrats, but Republicans have a majority in the House of Representatives this year for the first time in 118 years.
Other states where ratification looks certain include Alaska, Florida, Idaho, Indiana, Michigan, Montana, New Hampshire, North Dakota, Virginia and Wyoming.
Many politicians in those states argue that they are required by law or by their own constitutions to balance the budgets in their states and that the Federal Government should be bound by the same discipline.
"We just have a mind-set that if we can live within our budget, the Federal Government can live within its budget," said John Dorso, the Republican majority leader of the North Dakota House.
In fact, every state but Vermont has a legal requirement that its budget be balanced. But many states avoid this proscription in a variety of ways. They all issue bonds to finance roads, bridges, sewers and other capital projects, and many resort to outright gimmicks to make it appear as if the budget has no deficit.
Donna J. Boley, a retired bookkeeper who is the Republican minority leader of the West Virginia Senate, explained how it works in her state: "You appoint authorities -- parkway, regional jail, school building, solid waste -- which incur long-term debt without a vote of the people."
In several small states, the legislature meets only for a brief period every other year. In some, this year's session will be over before Congressional action is complete, so they will probably not be able to consider a balanced-budget amendment until 1997. But in Montana, the amendment is so popular that Gov. Marc Racicot, a Republican, may call a special session to vote on ratification.
For one reason or another, Hawaii, Vermont and West Virginia are among a handful of states where the amendment does not seem to stand a chance. In West Virginia, for instance, the strong opposition of United States Senator Robert C. Byrd means that the matter will probably never come to a vote. In Vermont, Gov. Howard Dean, a Democrat, has taken the lead in warning officeholders in other states that a balanced-budget amendment might mean that the Federal Government would simply foist obligations onto the states.
In New York, the Legislature's lower house, the Assembly, will probably reject the amendment if it ever reaches a vote there. Sheldon Silver, the Democratic Speaker, said he was "concerned that in times of recession, when deficit spending is used to stimulate the economy, that particular method would be lost to us."
In most of the other large states, including California, Pennsylvania and Illinois, which, like New York, have full-time legislatures with highly trained professional staffs, the leading politicians are withholding judgment on the amendment until they figure out the degree to which it would require them to raise their own states' taxes or lower their own spending.
In interviews, many officials agreed with Robert C. Jubelirer, the President pro tem of the Pennsylvania Senate. "These guys aren't going to ratify a balanced-budget amendment," Mr. Jubelirer, a Republican, said of his colleagues, "and then be told you have to raise taxes in Pennsylvania. If we're told that is not the case, I think ratification is do-able."
Officials in Connecticut took a similar stance. In New Jersey, Gov. Christine Todd Whitman, a Republican, strongly supports the amendment in principle, her spokeswoman said, and would like to lead the charge for it.
The issue of a constitutional amendment requiring a balanced Federal budget has been before the states in one form or another for years. Twenty-nine legislatures have voted for a measure calling for a constitutional convention to deal with the matter. But most of those states acted before 1980, and the legislatures of three states -- Alabama, Florida and Louisiana -- subsequently voted to rescind their votes on the convention.
Many state officials say they want any constitutional amendment to include a provision prohibiting the Federal Government from passing on new obligations to the states without money to cover them. A measure limiting, although not outlawing, what are called unfunded mandates is now pending in Congress and will almost certainly become law. But chances are remote that such a provision would be written into a constitutional amendment.
Once Congress approves a constitutional amendment, there is no limit on how long the states have to ratify it. But the prevailing view among proponents and opponents of the balanced-budget measure is that if 38 legislatures do not adopt it in the first year or two, it will never be added to the Constitution.
"The political momentum slides across the country when time drags," said George D. Caruolo, leader of the Democratic majority in the Rhode Island Senate. "People become more interested in parochial concerns, and the whole thing becomes more complicated."
Parochial concerns are, indeed, the chief enemy of the balanced-budget amendment. "When it comes to that vote," said David Harris, the Republican Secretary of Finance and Administration in New Mexico, the first question legislators will ask will be, "What does it do to us?"

HEADLINE: U.S. Embassy Officials in Bosnia at Odds Over Talks With Serbs

BYLINE: By ROGER COHEN, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: SARAJEVO, Bosnia and Herzegovina, Jan. 22

 BODY:
Sharp dissent emerged at the United States Embassy in Sarajevo today over the Clinton Administration's decision to change its policy and engage in direct negotiations with the Bosnian Serbs despite their rejection of an international peace plan.
The dissent centered on what one official described as attempts by the State Department to oust the American Ambassador to Bosnia, Victor Jackovich, who has always rejected direct talks with the Serbs until they accept the peace plan. He was recalled to Washington on Wednesday for what were officially described as "consultations." 
 "These are not consultations," said the official, who spoke on condition of anonymity. "They have offered Mr. Jackovich another ambassadorship and they are trying to ease him out because he opposes bringing the Serbs to the negotiating table in this way."
Charity Dennis, a State Department spokeswoman, said she had no information on why Mr. Jackovich was in Washington at such a sensitive time in Bosnia. Mr. Jackovich did not respond to two calls to his Virginia home.
Charles H. Thomas, the United States envoy to Bosnian peace negotiations, carried out the new American policy today by going to the Bosnian Serbs' stronghold of Pale and meeting with their leader, Radovan Karadzic. The change in policy was announced on Thursday in a letter from Secretary of State Warren Christopher to Bosnia's President, Alija Izetbegovic.
In contrast to his previous visits to Bosnia, Mr. Thomas was not accompanied by the officials from Russia, Britain, France and Germany, the countries that with the United States make up what diplomats call the contact group.
Until last month, when cracks began to appear in the Clinton Administration's policy of isolating the Bosnian Serbs until they accepted the contact group plan, such visits to Pale were barred.
Mr. Jackovich stood strongly behind this former policy of using diplomatic isolation, military threats and economic pressure to compel the Serbs to bend.
But on Thursday, the day after Mr. Jackovich was recalled to Washington, his deputy at the embassy, John Menzies, went to Pale for unpublicized talks with the Bosnian Serbs. "Yes, I went to Pale," Mr. Menzies said, but declined to give further details.
It was on Thursday that Mr. Christopher's letter to President Izetbegovic arrived, explaining that the United States had decided "to resume a dialogue with Pale" because of the new opportunities afforded by a four-month cease-fire that went into effect on Jan. 1.
Thus even before Mr. Izetbegovic, who was then in Cairo, had time to respond to Mr. Christopher's letter, the ranking American diplomat in Sarajevo had gone to Pale. The town near Sarajevo is the capital of what the rebel Serbs in Bosnia call their republic. The Serbs who hold 70 percent of Bosnian territory after 33 months of war.
A United Nations Security Council resolution approved last September calls for an end to any political dialogue with the Serbs until they accept the contact group plan in full. This plan would oblige the Serbs to give up a third of the land they hold and accept 49 percent of Bosnia, with the balance going to a Muslim-Croat federation.
Mr. Christopher's letter said the American decision to engage the Bosnian Serbs in a dialogue was conditional on the roads into Sarajevo being opened. The roads into this encircled city were still closed today when Mr. Thomas went to Pale.
Mr. Thomas plans to go to there again on Monday before the expected arrival in Sarajevo of his contact group colleagues. Thus the United States, in a sharp reversal of policy, has now taken the lead in talks with the Serbs.
Mr. Jackovich's absence from Sarajevo at a time when Mr. Thomas and Mr. Menzies are visiting Pale fits a pattern established during the last two months.
The Ambassador was also called away shortly before Charles E. Redman, who used to have Mr. Thomas's job and is now Ambassador to Germany, went to Pale on an exploratory visit in December. The man who accompanied Mr. Redman at that time was Mr. Menzies, who took up his post in November and also accompanied Mr. Thomas today.
It was Mr. Redman's visit that initiated the Clinton Administration's softening toward the Serbs. This continued later in December when former President Jimmy Carter -- clearly acting for the Administration -- engaged in the shuttle diplomacy between Pale and Sarajevo that led to the current cease-fire. Once again, while Mr. Carter was here, Mr. Jackovich was out of town.
Dissent has long racked the shifting American diplomatic approach to Bosnia. In 1992, at the beginning of the war, several diplomats quit the State Department because of what they regarded as the Bush Administration's inadequate response to the Serbs' policy of killing or evicting Muslims in the territory they held.
The Serbian policy has been toned down since then and the killing has stopped, but forced evictions and mistreatment of Muslims continue.
Officials said Assistant Secretary of State Richard C. Holbrooke had spoken to Mr. Menzies about Mr. Jackovich's present recall even before the Ambassador knew that he was going back to Washington. Mr. Holbrooke was described as the architect of the new American policy.
Shortly before he left for Washington, Mr. Jackovich confided to people who know him that he found the Serbs' ability to set the agenda in Bosnia excruciating and the Clinton Administration's reluctance to use even mild force to back up diplomacy dismaying.
The aim of Mr. Thomas during his current visit is to persuade Mr. Karadzic and the Muslim-led Bosnian Government to agree to resume political negotiations on a peace settlement. The Bosnian Government insists that the Serbs first accept the contact group peace map, which was initially portrayed as a take-it-or-leave-it plan.
But the Serbs do not want to accept a plan that would divide their territory into what they say are indefensible and economically weak fragments. The most they have offered is to resume talks "on the basis of the contact group plan."
American officials said that the fact Mr. Thomas went alone to Pale was insignificant. They said other contact group officials were due to arrive on Monday and Mr. Thomas simply took advantage of a couple of spare days in Europe to pursue talks with the Serbs. Up to now, the contact group officials have always acted together.

HEADLINE: Despite the Risks, the U.N. Plans a World Conference on Poverty

BYLINE: By BARBARA CROSSETTE, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: UNITED NATIONS, Jan. 20

 BODY:
Threatened by a general decline in foreign aid worldwide, a Republican-led Congress bent on cutting American contributions, and a White House that is cool toward internationalism except where trade is involved, the United Nations is nonetheless preparing for its first conference on poverty and other social problems.
Secretary General Boutros Boutros-Ghali and diplomats who have been promoting what they call the World Summit for Social Development see it as a chance to demonstrate that the United Nations, far from being only a peacekeeping agent, has a major role in alleviating social ills in an age of petty wars and widening income gaps. 
 The conference, now being planned in two weeks of meetings in New York, is one of the most ambitious -- and risky -- events the organization has planned for its 50th anniversary year.
So far nearly 100 world leaders are expected to attend the meeting, which is scheduled in Copenhagen from March 6 to 12. President Clinton is not expected to go, diplomats said. But the State Department says a delegation leader will be chosen after the Administration has time to study the agenda, which should be completed next week.
"The summit in a sense is the true end of the cold war," Juan Somavia, Chile's representative to the United Nations and the originator of the conference, said in an interview. "What we intend to say is 'look, this is the first time in history -- not only in the history of the U.N. but in the history of the world -- that we are getting together to discuss the problems of ordinary people of the world.' That's quite a major thing."
The problems of ordinary people include more than a billion lives condemned to poverty. According to the United Nations, 13 to 18 million people die annually of causes related to poverty.
One of every 10 people cannot find work at a living wage; in rural areas worldwide, 40 percent of women work for no wages at all. Civil wars, overpopulation and other forces are driving millions to migrate within and between countries. Illegal trafficking in people is big business.
The planning meetings have already reignited a smoldering debate between rich and poor nations over the roots of poverty and underdevelopment. At the simplest level, it is a battle for dwindling resources between the world's industrial North and underdeveloped South, with each side accusing the other of not doing enough to make life better for the world's poorest people.
On the table are arguments about whether free-market economic reforms are the right prescription for developing nations, and whether aid and trade partners have the right to ask questions about unfair labor practices, the employment of children and human rights in general.
"The whole summit comes about because of the insecurity of people after the cold war," said Mr. Somavia, the originator of the conference. "We have less insecurity in the military sphere and more insecurity in the personal and community spheres. We've replaced the threat of the nuclear bomb with the threat of a social bomb. There is no society that is saying, we don't have the problem of poverty, unemployment or social integration."
To compound these challenges, the conference organizers say that public corruption is growing -- in some cases draining up to 10 percent of a country's gross domestic product. Poor countries now owe $1.4 trillion in debts to outside lenders, nearly twice as much as a decade ago.
In response, there are more calls from poor countries, especially those in Africa, for foreign debts to be forgiven and for international lending organizations to stop making support contingent on changes in economic policy.
But at the World Bank, Armeane M. Choksi, vice president for human resources development and a citizen of India, says that a confrontational attitude toward donor nations and banks by governments and private groups would be self-defeating given the present climate surrounding foreign aid.
"If the developing countries take the position that there has to be a massive transfer of resources from the rich to the poor, they've lost the battle even before they begin," Mr. Choksi said in an interview. "We in the developing countries -- and I'm from one -- have to accept the notion that we have been independent for 40, 50 years. The primary responsibility for improving the welfare of our people is ours."
At the scheduled conference delegates will consider proposals to share the burden of development equitably. The agenda, now being adjusted to meet the concerns of dozens of delegations, is expected to ask governments to collect taxes and mobilize savings more efficiently, while working to cushion the effects of the economic adjustments recommended by international agencies.
Developing countries would be asked to cut defense spending and arms production in favor of programs like education and health.
Richer nations and world organizations would be asked to share more money and expertise and to help ease or cancel the debts of developing countries.
The goal is to lay the groundwork for international policy to deal with these social issues.
Mr. Somavia is confident that some consensus will emerge in Copenhagen, and that the conference will build on past summits -- on the environment in Rio in 1992, Human Rights in Geneva in 1993 and population in Cairo in 1994 -- toward what he calls "a major effort at defining the agenda of the 21st century." A summit on women's issues will take place in Beijing in September and another on human habitation is to be held in Istanbul next year.
"Without anybody having planned it, or having a grand design," he said, "the fact is that these are all conferences that have to do with the life of people."

HEADLINE: Clinton Plans A New Vision Once Again

BYLINE: By TODD S. PURDUM, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Jan. 22

 BODY:
Bill Clinton has revived, reinvigorated or reinvented himself half a dozen times since he set out to win the White House, and in his State of the Union Message on Tuesday night, his advisers say, he aims to do so once again by sketching a vision of how he will cooperate -- and compete -- with the new Republican ascendancy.
In the 11 weeks since the midterm elections ended Democratic control of Congress -- and many of his own hopes for sweeping legislation -- the President has consulted with people as diverse as historians and "personal growth" gurus in contemplating what to make of the rest of his term, and how to win another. He now plans a speech that will be less a list of new proposals than a litany of the themes that helped elect him: economic security for working Americans, reform of Washington's wayward ways, and shared responsibility between a caring Government and committed citizenry. 
 Mr. Clinton may offer some specific examples of how to meet those goals, like raising the minimum wage, consolidating various government departments or tightening campaign finance and lobbying laws, aides said. But they said the 30- to 40-minute speech would be mostly what one called "a dialogue with the American people about where the country should be going," a phrase Mr. Clinton himself used Saturday in a speech to the Democratic National Committee's winter meeting here.
In recent weeks, advisers say, the President has repeatedly expressed deep frustration that he and the Democrats have failed to communicate a rationale as succinct or compelling as the Republicans' bold vows of change in a time of social and economic upheaval and voter discontent. At the same time, though he has been reticent about direct attacks, his aides say Mr. Clinton believes that many of the prevailing prescriptions for slashing government programs or curtailing welfare benefits are punitive, simplistic or would benefit the wealthy at the expense of working Americans.
Accordingly, Mr. Clinton hopes to use the singular spotlight of the speech to a joint session of Congress -- with Speaker Newt Gingrich looking over his shoulder in the House chamber -- not only to pledge cooperation on tasks like shrinking government and cutting taxes, but to argue that his Administration was doing this well before the Republicans took charge. He is also expected to vow to oppose any effort to roll back some of his proudest achievements, like the ban on assault weapons or the national service program in which college-age students work in exchange for scholarships.
"Resilience is his middle name," one White House aide said today. "And I think you'll see a man who relishes the fight."
Finally, aides said, Mr. Clinton plans an appeal for renewed civic participation.
"We've got an excuse -- I do -- for being a couch potato at the Super Bowl," Mr. Clinton told the Democratic Party leaders this weekend. "I'm not good enough to play -- or young enough, or strong enough. But we're all good enough to play in citizenship." He said that his 1992 campaign had succeeded partly by inspiring participation. "We did all those town meetings, we got on those buses and rode across the country, we stopped in little crossroads where nobody had ever been before. And we treated people like they had good sense and could be involved in a dialogue about our country's future."
For much of the last two years, Presidential advisers acknowledge, Mr. Clinton has forsaken the bully pulpit for such deep immersion in the details of policy and legislative battles that he has not managed to win credit for his victories on free trade and economic recovery, on cutting the deficit or shrinking Government by 100,000 employees.
"He's got a whole new chance, not just Tuesday night, but starting Tuesday night," one senior Administration official said.
Mr. Clinton's longtime friends have seen him come back from the brink time and again in his long career, though no one thinks it will be easy this time.
"He's always believed government has an obligation to help people, but that people who get government help have an obligation to give something back to the commonwealth," said Al From, president of the centrist Democratic Leadership Council, the "New Democratic" organization Mr. Clinton helped found. "I think he came here and got caught up in all the old battles of Washington. Sometimes you need a two-by-four between the eyes."
Last weekend, the President and Hillary Rodham Clinton summoned Mr. From, Vice President Al Gore and his wife, Tipper, historians, senior White House aides and experts on "reinventing government" including the author David Osborne to Camp David for a three-and-a-half-hour discussion of what Mr. Clinton sees as a crossroads in American political history, and how he might respond.
"Part of the discussion was of how to find a coherent way of articulating what Democrats believe in," said Alan Brinkley, a historian at Columbia University who specializes in modern American politics. "Everyone was not in complete accord, but I think there was general agreement that Democrats needed to find a way to defend the idea of government without necessarily defending everything the current government does."
In recent weeks, Mr. Clinton has strived to find such a balance, pledging a new round of reorganization and cuts in government spending to finance tax breaks for education and families with children that he calls a "Middle Class Bill of Rights."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Facing a challenge from the new Republican majority, President Clinton is trying to reshape his image. He and his wife, Hillary, attended a Democratic National Committee meeting on Saturday, where he said he would engage in a "dialogue with the American people." (Stephen Crowley/The New York Times)

HEADLINE: The Contract's False Tax Promise

 BODY:
The Republicans loaded their "Contract With America" with tax cuts they say are honorably designed to stimulate economic growth. Democrats sneered at key proposals -- tax cuts for business investment and capital gains -- because they would overwhelmingly benefit well-to-do families.
These two proposals are definitely flawed. But the problem is not simply one of equity. If lowering the tax on capital gains -- the profit from selling stocks, bonds and other assets -- and the taxes on business investment would boost the economy, then Congress could consider embracing the contract, and find other ways to collect additional money from high-income investors. 
 The real problem is that these two ideas would harm the economy by steering some individuals toward worthless investments. That the G.O.P. has proposed ideas at odds with its lofty rhetoric fuels suspicion that its real motives lie elsewhere -- perhaps lining the pockets of favored benefactors.
On capital gains, the contract would tax only half, instead of all, of the profits from selling assets. That would reduce the top rate for many investors from 28 percent to below 20 percent. The G.O.P. would also exclude from taxes the portion of profit -- the rise in the price of an asset since the date of purchase -- that is due to inflation.
The proposal is misguided. For starters, it is cleverly structured to cost the Treasury only small amounts during the first few years but open up gaping holes in the budget thereafter. The proposal would apply tax cuts to capital gains from past investments, a wasteful giveaway that cannot possibly achieve the stated purpose of stimulating future investment.
There is another, more complicated, flaw. Consider investors who borrow money to purchase stock. A portion of interest payments compensates lenders for inflation during the life of the loan. Under the contract, investors would continue to deduct all of their interest payments, including the part due to inflation. But they would be allowed to exempt from taxes the part of their profit caused by inflation. This lopsided accounting for inflation creates a tax break so large that it can steer investment into unproductive assets. The investment loses money, but the investor gets rich by way of a large tax deduction.
An honest capital gain cut would apply only to new investment. It would cover those new assets that contribute to workplace productivity. That could include corporate stock. But it would exclude collectibles and, perhaps, real estate. Even if Congress took this honest route, the economy might not know the difference: many studies indicate that cutting capital gains taxes packs little wallop. Savings and investment would hardly budge.
On business investment, the contract is equally gimmicky. The cost to the Treasury would remain small in the first few years but then explode. Current law allows businesses (and reasonably so) to deduct the cost of expensive equipment over its lifetime. The contract would change the accounting rules for inflation to allow businesses to deduct far more than the initial purchase price. This devious provision would, once again, encourage wasteful investments because investors become eligible for huge tax breaks.
A sensible tax code would encourage investors to put their money where it would produce valuable goods and services. The contract, by contrast, would tell them to put their money where it would produce the biggest tax break. That is a ticket to economic stagnation.
The right reason to reject these two parts of the contract is that they would harm the economy. The fact that the contract would shower 30 percent of the tax savings on the 2 percent of families earning more than $200,000 per year adds a galling insult to fairness.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

HEADLINE: Vietnam Won the Right to Choose Its Destiny;
Real Foundation Stones

 BODY:
To the Editor:
Thomas L. Friedman in "Ha Noi or Ha Loi" (column, Jan. 15) describes an incident in Hanoi where every morning a Vietnamese woman crouched on the sidewalk with her bathroom scale, and he gave her a dollar and weighed himself. 
 In the mid-1970's near the corner of Eighth Avenue and 38th Street, a severely crippled man accompanied by his dog sat on a dolly with an open handbag filled with ballpoint pens. People would drop spare change into his handbag.
This man and the Vietnamese woman are not even micro-entrepreneurs; they are beggars. To our shame and their credit they had found a way to overcome the reluctance of people to give them money and thus preserved their dignity.
The real "foundation stones" of the Asian economic miracle are the hundreds of thousands of Asians who work in industry under substandard conditions for subsistence wages. We in the "developed" countries have yet to learn what the Vietnamese development expert knew, that unsustainable development is killing us all.
 
JAMES T. DETTE
Weehawken, N.J., Jan. 15, 1995

HEADLINE: Vietnam Won the Right to Choose Its Destiny

 BODY:
To the Editor:
Thomas L. Friedman makes a convincing case in "Good Morning, Vietnam" (column, Jan. 18) for ending our grudges against Vietnam. "It's time that we declare victory," he announces. 
 The Vietnamese fought a bloody, prolonged war for the right to choose. Twenty-nine years later they have chosen the free-market system. If there is victory to be declared here, it is the Vietnamese people's.
Two years ago I was a delegate at the Naval Academy Foreign Affairs Conference at Annapolis, Md. One featured speaker declared his joy at seeing Coca-Cola and Levi jeans attain "most wanted" status in Vietnam. We didn't need to fight the war, he said, we have won it anyway.
The point I made to the speaker also applies to Mr. Friedman's column: The Vietnamese people have embraced the free market, their model of socialism having failed to bring equity and progress.
Today the United States is the dominant global economy. American commodities fetch a high premium in any crude bartering transaction or sophisticated trade system. Vietnamese teen-agers are not embracing jeans and soft drinks in some misty-eyed ideological realignment.
Mr. Friedman also recalls a taxi driver who listened to BBC tapes. If he is trying to learn English, does it matter what the source is?
If Mr. Friedman is mourning that European businessmen are taking advantage of the investment vacuum, he has a point. But his desire to see the Dallas Cowboys replace Manchester United in the minds of the average Vietnamese smacks of something other than business interest. It seems a call for cultural aggression.
 
NAEEM MOHAIEMEN
New York, Jan. 18, 1995

SECTION: Section A; Page 14; Column 54; Editorial Desk

HEADLINE: Vietnam Won the Right to Choose Its Destiny;
What's in the Archives?

 BODY:
To the Editor:
It may be wise for the United States to establish full diplomatic relations with Vietnam, as Thomas L. Friedman advises (column, Jan. 18). But some of his arguments are based on misconceptions. 
 The Vietnamese army that repulsed the 1979 Chinese invasion hardly fits Mr. Friedman's adjective "tiny." The People's Army of Vietnam was then one of the world's largest: 500,000 men organized in 14 infantry divisions and 33 regiments.
Furthermore, to argue based on that victory that "there is no more powerful counterweight to Beijing than Hanoi" ignores the huge increase in Chinese power over the last 15 years. The Chinese economy has quintupled since 1978, thanks to liberalized economic policies.
Until recently, the Vietnamese economy was shrinking under the old Communist system. As a result, the ratio of power between Vietnam and China has shifted markedly in China's favor. If the United States seeks allies to contain China in Southeast Asia, it might look to Thailand, Malaysia and Indonesia. Vietnam will likely need decades to match their economic performance.
Mr. Friedman ignores the real missing in action issue. I agree there are no Vietnam-era prisoners of war left alive. But Oleg Kalugin, the former K.G.B. agent, and the Harvard researcher Stephen J. Morris have raised questions about hundreds of Americans who possibly remained in enemy hands after the supposed full exchange of prisoners in 1973.
Such stories may be false. But there is reason to believe Hanoi has not shown all its archives contain about possible atrocities. Until this is settled, the United States should refrain from sending an ambassador to Hanoi.
 
BRIAN R. SULLIVAN
Senior Research Professor
Institute for National Strategic
Studies, National Defense University
Washington, Jan. 18, 1995

HEADLINE: METRO DIGEST

 BODY:

NEW YORK CITY
 
A SCHOOL WHERE IT'S O.K. TO EXCEL
Any school with a selected population is destined to shine, especially if it has high standards, advanced courses, strong leadership and involved parents. Midwood High School in Flatbush, Brooklyn, with 55 percent of its students selected for excellence from all over the city, has all of those, and extras, like access to Brooklyn College across the street. But there is something else about Midwood. By all evidence, it succeeds unusually well for the students who come from the neighborhood, too. Midwood manages to overcome what educators say is one of the gravest problems in schools today -- peer pressure against achievement. Metro Matters, B3. 

TEEN-AGER STABS MOTHER WITH SCISSORS
A Brooklyn teen-ager was charged with second-degree murder yesterday after the police said she stabbed her mother to death with scissors in the family's Starrett City apartment on Saturday. The girl, Elizabeth DeCicco, 15, an honors student at James Madison High School, was angry when her mother, Sharon, demanded the scissors during an argument shortly after noon, a police spokesman said. When the mother demanded the scissors again and was about to strike the girl, the spokesman said, "The scissors were then thrust in the direction of the mother and went into her chest." B3.
 
5 WOUNDED IN SHOOTING AT APARTMENT
Five people were shot and wounded, two critically, when three gunmen forced their way into an apartment in Brownsville, Brooklyn, looking for crack cocaine and money late Saturday night, the police said. After the male victims were told to strip, the gunmen opened fire for unknown reasons, one officer said. B3.
 
PATIENT'S CASE THROWS LIGHT ON ESCAPES
Nestor Villamil slipped away from Creedmoor Psychiatric Center in Queens Village six times in the span of a year. But that was in 1991 and 1992. Now, Mr. Villamil does not run away anymore. His case provides important clues about how to prevent the mentally ill from fleeing state hospitals by the thousands. The answers suggested by his experience are not just stronger locks, higher fences or more vigilant guards, but better job programs, improved drug therapy and some measure of freedom and dignity. B4.
 
HIGHER RATES LIKELY FOR CITY'S BONDS
The problems in balancing New York City's $31.8 billion budget have made investors nervous enough that they are likely to exact slightly higher interest rates this week, when the city sells $645 million of new bonds. That will eventually translate into millions of dollars more that the city must pay out. Business Day, D1.
 
REGION
 
L.I.R.R. SUSPECT PLANS STRATEGY
Colin Ferguson spent the weekend at the Nassau County jail preparing the opening statement he plans to deliver in court this week against charges that he murdered six people on a Long Island Rail Road train more than a year ago. Alton G. Rose, one of Mr. Ferguson's legal advisers, said that despite his objections, Mr. Ferguson, who is acting as his own lawyer, planned to make his own opening statement. Mr. Rose joined Mr. Ferguson at the jail yesterday to help plan a defense strategy and to go over the statement, which the judge in the case has tentatively scheduled for Thursday. Reporter's Notebook, B5.
 
GUARD HURT IN MOVIE THEATER SHOOTING
Moviegoers waiting in line to buy candy and popcorn dropped to the floor when gun shots were fired into the crowded lobby of the Commack Multiplex Cinemas theater complex in Commack, L.I., wounding a security guard. The shooting was the latest of a series of violent incidents in theaters in the New York area and on Long Island over the last several years, and the third at the Commack Multiplex in the last three and a half years. B5.
 
3 KILLED IN HOUSE FIRE IN NEW JERSEY
A woman and two young sisters were killed and three sisters and their grandfather were critically burned in a fire in a two-family house in Irvington, N.J., officials said. Eighteen people lived in the building, including 11 from one family, the police said. An off-duty Newark police officer reported the fire and helped rescue some people from the burning building, the police said. B5.

HEADLINE: With Few Clues, Hearing Will Open on USAir Crash Near Pittsburgh That Killed 132

BYLINE: By MATTHEW L. WALD 

 BODY:
Four months after USAir Flight 427 rolled abruptly to the left and plunged to the ground at 300 miles an hour, killing all 132 people on board, the National Transportation Safety Board will open hearings in Pittsburgh today with a disturbing lack of clues and no working hypothesis about what caused the crash.
By the time the safety board gets to the hearing stage, said a spokesman, Mike Benson, "you usually have some better indications than what you have here." 
 In this case, Mr. Benson said, "We're going to have to piece this together, and it will take much more extensive work on our part."
About 30 witnesses are expected to testify over four or five days on a variety of subjects, including the possibility that a rudder control unit could have malfunctioned and caused the accident. The device helps keep the nose of the plane pointed forward.
Witnesses will also give information about pilot training, maintenance and other factors that could have contributed to the crash of the USAir jetliner, a 7-year-old Boeing 737, last Sept. 8 on an early evening flight from Chicago.
"We are confident we're going to be able to find a probable cause," Mr. Benson said. It is possible, he said, that the record will point to some conclusion that is not now evident.
A spokesman for the Air Line Pilots Association, Bob Flocke, said: "We're going into this without even a single viable theory. For every theory they've got, they've got physical evidence or aerodynamic theory that it didn't happen that way."
The N.T.S.B. has failed to establish a probable cause in only four major crashes in its 28-year history. The most recent was the crash of another Boeing 737, belonging to United Airlines, in Colorado Springs on March 3, 1991.
"There are a lot of comparisons being made between the two accidents, mainly because there's not a lot to explain either one of them," said a USAir spokesman, Paul Turk.
Some people are offering theories, though. A retired Trans World Airline pilot, H. G. Gibson, said the failure that made the USAir flight go out of control may have been related to the one that struck his jet, a Boeing 727 that suddenly rolled right and fell 35,000 feet in less than a minute, in April 1979 near Saginaw, Mich. He is petitioning the safety board for a hearing in that case.
The USAir plane crashed in Aliquippa, Pa., as it was approaching Greater Pittsburgh International Airport in clear weather at about 7 P.M. It took only about 25 seconds to roll to the left and crash.
One person who listened to the cockpit voice recorder said that in that brief period, someone says, "Wow," and then the captain can be heard three or four times telling the first officer, "Hang on there, hang on."
The hearings are of special interest because the crash was USAir's fifth in five years. They are also of intense interest in Pittsburgh, where the airline is a mainstay of the local economy and where there had been no major crashes since 1958.
Boeing, which built the plane, will send witnesses and a videotape explaining the control system. Other witnesses will come from the Federal Aviation Administration, USAir, the pilots' union, and component manufacturers.
The USAir spokesman, Mr. Turk, said the purpose of much of the testimony will be to rule out certain causes. For example, a witness from the F.B.I. will testify that there was no evidence of a bomb.
But much attention will also focus on the system for controlling the rudder, which on the 737 is a single vertical surface above the tail. Last year the F.A.A. issued a directive saying that the power control units for the rudders of all 737's should be replaced by 1999, but Mr. Turk said the unit on the plane that crashed had not been replaced. Even now, he said, only about one-third of the units on USAir's planes have been switched.
"A major issue is the availability of parts," Mr. Turk said.
The F.A.A. ordered the power control units replaced because hydraulic fluid leaks could make the rudder hard to operate or even make it move in the opposite direction from the one the pilot wanted. But the F.A.A. said in its order that the flaw was not known to have caused any in-flight problems in 737's.
In early 1992, the F.A.A. considered ordering the inspection of another part of the power control unit, but decided about a year later that the inspection was unnecessary.
Still, there is anecdotal evidence among pilots that the rudders can act erratically. The Seattle Times reported this month that it had analyzed reports submitted to the F.A.A., which it said the agency had not analyzed, and found 21 power control unit failures reported by United States airlines from 1974 to 1994.
It also found 22 failures of the rudder control unit, a yaw damper. A yaw is a move of the nose to the left or right that differs from the direction of the plane's course; the damper, using gyroscopes to sense sudden changes of direction, sends commands to the rudder faster than a human pilot could, to keep the plane pointed straight.
In the case of the T.W.A. incident in 1979, Mr. Gibson and his co-pilot recovered in part by lowering the landing gear to change the aerodynamics. The plane was moving so fast that all of the landing gear doors were later found to have been damaged by over-stress in the maneuver.
The safety board attributed the incident to pilot error, but Mr. Gibson said the loss of control was consistent with failure of the rudder. He said the 727 and the 737 use some of the same components in the rudder.

HEADLINE: CITY;
Who Should Pay for Parks? Voices From Those in the Field

BYLINE: By DOUGLAS MARTIN

 BODY:
Last Thursday, Parks Commissioner Henry J. Stern called together 200 of his employees and others interested in parks to celebrate the 61st anniversary of Robert Moses' taking over as the first Parks Commissioner for the entire city.
 Mr. Moses, the present Commissioner recounted, arrived at the Arsenal, the department's fortress-like headquarters in Central Park, in a fleet of chauffeured black Packards, and pushed ahead full speed. With the help of an army of relief workers from Federal programs and architects and planners working in tents around the clock, Mr. Moses built an empire; he added 658 playgrounds, 15 pools, 15 miles of public beaches and 20,000 acres of park land, bring the total of New York City acreage under parks Department control to 15 percent. 
 But since Mr. Moses' departure in 1960, the agency has struggled to maintain its holdings. Gone are the Federal workers, gone is the guaranteed revenue stream from the Triborough Bridge and Tunnel Authority, which Mr. Moses also headed.
 Mr. Stern has suggested that to maintain its parks, New York needs to look to other solutions, and last week pushed a proposal by the Central Park Conservancy to set up a special district -- like a Business Improvement District -- in the blocks surrounding that park. But Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani immediately shot down the idea, since it essentially would have involved taxing people who live near the park to pay for its upkeep. Others have criticized the proposal, saying that such a system, if applied citywide, would tend to favor parks in wealthier, more dense areas like Manhattan, while doing little for parks in the other boroughs.
 Mr. Stern's proposal, though, highlighted a larger issue: How is the city to maintain its grand parks system when it lacks the money -- and, some say, the will -- to do so by traditional means?
 Some suggest a special citywide tax that would go solely to the parks system, while others say a park's neighbors should bear the bruden, since they get the greatest benefit. DOUGLAS MARTIN

GRAPHIC: Photos: Henry Christensen 3D, chairman, Prospect Park Alliance -- "All of us who try to raise money for the parks are dismayed by the steadily diminishing financial support given to parks by city administrations over the past six years. So I am sympathetic to the motivations of the Central Park Conservancy.
 "The neighbors of a landmark park like Central or Propsect Parks should make substantial contributions. The parks increase the value of those residents' property. But I do view these as voluntary contributions.
 "Also, I think you already have problems raising money for small parks and this could only exacerbate that. We should seriously examine a citywide dedicated levy, whether you call it a tax or user fee, to support all the parks. It would be similar to Federal highway taxes and could not be diverted to other things."; Linda Dividoff, executive director of the Parks Council -- "Some new form of taxation might be necessary to meet the true needs of parks, which our studies indicate are around $300 million. This would require a change to the City Charter as well as approval by the State Legislature if the tax were on anything but real estate. New Yorkers would vote for it. A poll by the Commonwealth Fund last year showed 65 percent of New Yorkers would support doubling park spending."; Daniel A Biederman, executive director of the Bryant Park Improvement District -- "With Bryant Park we had a vision. But all the opposition helped us. We had plenty of time to study what we were going to do.
 "You can take Bryant Park and re-create it in a low-income neighborhood. There are ways to help parks that have no commercial support behind them.
 "If the Central Park idea goes through, and if four or five other major parks follow suite, there will be less pressure on the Parks Commissioner. It might loosen up some funds."; Gordon Davis, lawyer and former Parks Commissioner -- "How do you avoid the problem of the rich taking care of themselves, while the economically disadvantaged areas lack the wherewithal? It's an important discussion. There is no doubt something is required to protect the parks from the cycle of feast and famine. And, in any event, parks never really feast.
 "How do we reproduce the democratic success of Bryant Park? Can you reproduce it in Coney Island? Maybe you can pair a park in a rich district with one in a poor district. New York has to find new ways to finance public spaces. It's important to people all across the city."; Ronnie M. Eldridge, City Council member -- "I have serious reservations about special assessments because I believe it's another form of taxation. It's not just parks: I'm not sure I favor the concept of dedicated revenues in general. I want to protect the libraries and schools and repair the streets too. And what about health care? We're going to be torn in a million places.
"The property tax system needs to be overhauled to raise more revenue. And that has to apply to everybody."; David Fisher, Superintendent of the Minneapolis Park and Recreation Board -- "There's no magic in any of the park financing ideas. You always have to walk a very careful line between prudent financial management and disenfranchisement of people who can't afford to pay.
 "We tried and gave up the idea of special districts 25 years ago. The system became so imbalanced between rich and poor that there were uprisings by communities demanding their rights. We went back to a single citywide park district with a guaranteed revenue stream supporting all our parks.
 "The heaviest users of the parks are people who vote less often. And in parks, squeaky wheels get the grease.
 "I don't know how much money the New York City park system has left. But it's incumbent upon them to distribute it equitably. We must avoid the privatization of public space."; Elizabeth Barlow Rogers, Administrator of Central Park -- "We used to have the greatest park system in the country. It was the one that was emulated in other cities. But here have been these intermittent periods of terrible decline. We can't let that vicious cycle of deterioration start up again.
 "I'm not going to be here forever, and the fund-raising effort is not going to sustain itself forever. We've restored so much of the park now it's difficult to see how we can maintain it at the same level.
 "But this proposal is really for the other parks. The other parks are really continuing to slide."; Peter Rothschild, landscape architect and park designer -- "My fear about the Central Park proposal is that there will be reduced support from the pbulic sector for other parks around the city. A new tax does not guarantee the equitable distribution of the revenues.
 "A special tax may also result in lessened support from the general fund. Parks get a smaller piece of the budget despite the fact the people feel parks are terribly important.
 "I also feel a fundamental problem parks have is that revenue they create and produce do not go to the parks, but just into the funeral fund." (Nancy Siesel/The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Germans, 5 Years Later: Bitter and Still Divided

BYLINE: By CRAIG R. WHITNEY, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: BONN

 BODY:
Judging by what has happened since reunification in 1990, Germany is likely to be more preoccupied with itself over the next five years than intent on exercising the new economic and political might that made its European neighbors so uneasy five years ago.
Chancellor Helmut Kohl rammed unification through the NATO alliance and the European Community in 1989 and 1990, brushing aside fears that Europe would be dominated by a German colossus of 80 million people. 
 For the time being, Mr. Kohl's reassurances about German power have proved depressingly true for his Government. Germany's main problem -- in the fifth year of reunification -- is essentially what it was at the start: How to make one country out of what remain two separate states, one eastern and one western.
Officials close to Mr. Kohl say that the Chancellor was chastened by the apprehension about reunification that was shown by some European leaders, especially President Francois Mitterrand of France, whom Mr. Kohl considers a close friend.
But the unexpected difficulties of reunification have also chastened Mr. Kohl. His Government had to re-introduce a 7.5 percent income tax surcharge this year to help pay for reunification -- a tax already so unpopular that the Government coalition now has a majority of only 10 seats in the 600-member lower house of Parliament.
In effect, Mr. Kohl can govern only with the consent of the Social Democratic opposition, which holds a majority of the seats in the upper house, and the Social Democrats are skeptical about throwing Germany's weight around in the NATO alliance or the United Nations.
Despite a ruling by the German constitutional court last summer allowing German military participation in NATO and United Nations peacekeeping missions, a high-ranking American official said recently, "Germany is not able, at the moment, to play a leading role in reconfiguring the alliance to enable it to respond to the new challenges of the post-cold war era."
The central problem of reunification is clearly demonstrated in the latest official unemployment figures. In what used to be West Germany, the Federal Labor Office reported, the unemployment rate climbed to 8.2 percent last month, and in what used to be East Germany, it rose to 13.5 percent.
What is the national unemployment rate? The Federal Labor Office in Nuremberg does not calculate one. But the Organization for Economic Cooperation and Development in Paris says that unemployment in all of Germany last year was an average of 9.6 percent, a 45-year high.
"The reason we keep two sets of books is that the two economies are not comparable," said Eberhard Mann, a spokesman for the labor office. "We have a developed industrial economy in the west, and a collapsed Communist economy in the throes of transition in the east."
Despite great strides in eastern Germany, most of the 64 million people in western Germany seem to believe that unification did not really mean much change at all for them.
The Germans who were rejoicing in the streets in 1990 have since become sullen and resentful. Many western Germans -- "Wessis" -- resent having to pay to bring their eastern cousins into the late 20th century. A lot people in eastern Germany -- "Ossis" -- feel patronized.
Life for eastern Germany's 16 million people today bears no resemblance to what it was before 1989, in part because of a net annual transfer of $100 billion from their richer western neighbors, who are paying to help retrain workers, restructure state enterprises and get eastern German wages and benefits up to western levels by next year.
But high wage levels and social costs are the main reason why nearly 3.6 million Germans are now unemployed. About that many are likely to remain so as long as employers' mandatory contributions to health insurance, social security and fringe benefits stay so high that they discourage hiring, German economists and politicians say.
"Everything has changed for the people here in the east, from the social security system to the tax system, the rent system, the school system, everything you can imagine," said Birgit Breuel, who was the head of the Government agency in charge of privatizing the economy in eastern Germany. The agency wrapped up its operations last month with a total debt of $173 billion.
"You probably can't imagine how difficult it is to have everything you were familiar with change overnight," said Jutta Richter, a Leipzig resident. Her daughter, a musician, fled to the west just before the Berlin wall fell five years ago.
Mrs. Richter used to go to East German supermarkets and pick up whatever brand of soap or supermarket special happened to be in stock. Now, she says, she has to figure out which of 10 brands of detergent is the best buy -- things her western cousins had a lifetime to learn.
Her husband, Adi, is a semipro tennis player who is well known throughout eastern Germany. "Since reunification, not once has any western German magazine spelled my name right or correctly identified my team," he said. "I'm convinced it's deliberate -- they just don't want to recognize that we can play tennis over here, too."
He travels occasionally through the posh neighborhoods of western Berlin, but says he feels out of place there.
"The eastern part of the city is gray, run-down, and smells of coal smoke, but it's more like home to me," he said.
The diplomats and scholars who know them best have no doubt that the Germans, both eastern and western, will make unification work. But it will probably take a generation until Germans feel they are truly one people.
In the meantime, in Leipzig, where the people marched peacefully through the streets five years ago chanting, "We are one people," they now tell wry jokes about what Germans say to each other when they meet.
"We are one people," says the easterner. "So are we," says the westerner.
